gold_sents: The plaintiffs filed a lawsuit on March 8, 2014, alleging that the City of Montgomery, Alabama, improperly imprisoned them for failing to pay traffic fines.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that they did not have an ability to pay the fines due to their financial circumstances and that the city did not consider their ability to pay.[SENTMARKER]On May 1, 2014, the District Court granted the plaintiffs motion for a preliminary injunction, preventing the city from collecting more money from traffic tickets of plaintiffs'.[SENTMARKER]On October 31, 2014 the parties filed to dismiss the case pursuant to a settlement agreement, which included numerous changes to Municipal Court proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: This case was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Alabama against the City of Montgomery and Judicial Correction Services, Inc. (JCS), a private for-profit corporation, on behalf of people who were jailed by the City because they could not afford to pay their traffic ticket fees, costs, and surcharges.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the City's policy of charging appeal bonds to those who cannot afford them violated their Fourteenth Amendment due process and equal protection rights by imprisoning them without conducting a meaningful inquiry into their ability to pay and by threatening to imprison them for failing to pay the balance on outstanding fines, fees, and costs associated with traffic tickets they incurred.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on November 17, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The City agreed to refund the full amount owed to the City for the inability to pay a $50 fine, and to provide the plaintiffs with a copy of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice, and the parties agreed that no one will be jailed again in the future for the failure to pay.

gold_sents: In 2013, indigent detainee filed a complaint against the City of Montgomery and a Municipal Court Judge for unconstitutionally ordering the petitioner to serve time for her inability to pay court-order fines and fees for their traffic violations.[SENTMARKER]The complaint was originally filed in the Circuit Court of Montgomery County, Alabama and then transferred to the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Alabama, where it was consolidated with a similar case.[SENTMARKER]In the amended complaint, petitioners alleged that the imprisonment orders violated their Sixth and Fourteenth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]Petitioners sought remedy through injunctive and declaratory relief.[SENTMARKER]In 2014, the parties reached a settlement that provided new judicial procedures for the Municipal Court to follow regarding indigent defendants and nonpayment.[SENTMARKER]It also included three declarations, most importantly, it declared that the constitutional principles set out in Bearden v. Georgia, 461 U.S. 660 (1983), and Turner v. Rogers, 131 S. Ct. 2507 (2011) applied to municipal court proceedings, and awarded plaintiff's attorney fees.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in November 2014.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 28, 2013, a woman filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Alabama against the City of Montgomery, the Montgomery Municipal Court, and Judicial Correction Services, a private probation company.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants violated her constitutional rights to due process, equal protection, and to counsel by ordering her to be incarcerated in the municipal jail for 54 days because she was unable to pay her traffic ticket fines and court costs.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that they were illegally jailed for their inability to pay outstanding fines, fees, and costs, in violation of the Fourteenth and Sixth Amendments to the United States Constitution and the Alabama Constitution, and Rule 26.11 of the Alabama Rules of Criminal Procedure.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a settlement agreement in November 2014 that required the defendants to pay the plaintiff's attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed that the municipal court should not have a policy requiring incarceration when individuals cannot pay their fines.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: A prisoner facing the death penalty in Arkansas sued over the form of lethal injection used by the state.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed because of a lack of evidence that Arkansas's use of lethal injections subjected prisoners to a significant risk of pain.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed, and one of the three plaintiffs was executed in 2017.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 1, 2006, four Arkansas death row inmates brought this action under 42 U.S.C.  1983 challenging the constitutionality of the state's lethal injection protocol for execution by lethal injection.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the Arkansas Department of Correction's protocol presents an unnecessary risk of conscious suffering and extreme pain, amounting to cruel and unusual punishment prohibited under the Eighth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On June 12, 2006, the Supreme Court issued a unanimous decision in Hill v. McDonough, ruling that a Florida death row inmate, Clarence I-Iill, may challenge Florida's three-drug injection protocol, which is similar to the Arkansas protocol, as well as its use of this protocol demonstrates deliberate indignities to the plaintiffs' serious medical needs.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a stay of execution in order to permit the plaintiffs to litigate their challenge to the lethal injection protocols.[SENTMARKER]On August 9, 2007, the district court ordered the case consolidated with a similar lawsuit filed by Don William Davis.[SENTMARKER]The parties referred to the set of execution instructions he has developed.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on June 19, 2006, and the parties filed a motion for summary judgment on May 1, 2006.[SENTMARKER]On May 22, 2008, the parties moved to reopen their case and the court granted the A DC's motion to dismiss the case without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]On July 11, 2008, the court dismissed the case with prejudice and terminated the case.[SENTMARKER]On November 9, 2008, the case was closed.

gold_sents: On August 23, 2018, three Maricopa County, Arizona residents who have been referred to Maricopa County's Marijuana Diversion program filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona, Phoenix Division.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive and monetary relief, claiming that the Maricopa County Attorney's Office and Treatment Assessment Screening Center jointly operated a marijuana possession diversion program that discriminated against the poor in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment, and led to unreasonable search and seizure in violation of the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs amended their complaint twice to include new named plaintiffs for the class.[SENTMARKER]The District Court denied the defendant's motions to dismiss the complaint, and discovery is ongoing both for class certification and the underlying claims.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 23, 2018, a group of Arizona residents filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona against the Maricopa County Attorney's Office (MCAO) and the Treatment 23 Assessment Screening Center (TASC) alleging violations of the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants jointly operate a possession of marijuana diversion program that penalizes the poor because of their poverty.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that they were forced to submit to drug and alcohol testing after 90 days in the program if the sole reason they remain on the program is that they cannot afford to pay the fees necessary to complete it.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and ordered the defendants to pay monetary damages and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On March 8, 2006, the Pacific News Service filed a lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the California Department of Corrections in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief, alleging that the defendants had violated the constitutional rights of the press and the public to attend, meaningfully observe, and gather and report on important information at executions being carried out by the defendants at the California State Prison at San Quentin.[SENTMARKER]On May 30, 2013, the issue in this case became moot due to a state court decision.[SENTMARKER]In Sims v. California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR), the California Court of Appeals held that CDCR’s lethal injection regulations were invalid for failure to comply with the APA.[SENTMARKER]The court permanently enjoined CDCR from carrying out the execution of any condemned inmate by lethal injection until their new regulations complied with the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]This case closed after a voluntary dismissal filed by the plaintiff organization.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 13, 2006, Pacific News Service (PNS) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR) challenging the inclusion of pancuronium bromide in San Quentin's lethal injection protocol.[SENTMARKER]PNS alleged that the use of the 23 second drug in the lethal injection cocktail, paralyzes all movement of the inmate's 24 muscle fibers.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed, however, that one intended purpose and effect of the drug is to induce paralysis.[SENTMARKER]The case is not a challenge to the death penalty or to all lethal injection executions in California, but rather a First and Fourteenth Amendment right to attend and witness important public proceedings in the context of an execution.[SENTMARKER]On February 10, 2006, the 2 Court consolidated the two cases, and the parties agreed that the case should be dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]On August 13, 2010, the court ordered the CDCR to turn over its supply of sodium thiopental to the FDA.[SENTMARKER]The CDCR has since complied with the court's order and the case is closed.

gold_sents: This civil rights class action was filed in 2012 in the Eastern District of California; it alleged due process violations when the state arbitrarily denied parole to nearly all lifers who had served their minimum sentence.[SENTMARKER]On October 2, 2015, the parties entered into an agreement by which the defendants agreed to make changes to the psychological risk assessment processes used by the parole board.[SENTMARKER]The Court approved the settlement in May 2016, and retained jurisdiction over the case until January 1, 2017, with the plaintiffs' able to get an extension of the Court's jurisdiction if the defendants fail to abide by the agreed upon terms.[SENTMARKER]In February of 2019, the court issued an order stating that the defendants had complied with the order.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In October 2018, a plaintiff sued Denver over its bond fee requirement.[SENTMARKER]Within a few months, the defendants changed their policy and submitted an Offer of Judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: In June of this year, a Denver resident was arrested for alleged violations of municipal ordinances and was detained in jail for five days solely because he could not pay a $50 bond fee.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado against the City and County of Denver, Colorado, and the Denver Sheriff's Office.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Denver's policy of detaining a person solely because of his inability to pay a bond fee violated the Fourteenth Amendment's due process and equal protection provisions.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiff's motion for summary judgment, finding that Denver had not violated the defendant's constitutional rights by detaining Mr. Howard because he was unable to pay the bond fee, and that the defendant was not required to release him on the conditions set by the court.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on September 20, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff was released on August 10, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 22, 2012, several national and local news agencies filed a § 1983 lawsuit against the state of Idaho, alleging that the policy of the Idaho Department of Correction to prohibit public viewing of the preparatory phase of the execution process, during which the inmate is restrained and the IV is inserted, violates the First Amendment right to free speech and the Fourteenth Amendment right to due process.[SENTMARKER]The District Court denied plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction on June 5, 2012, but the Ninth Circuit reversed the denial, on June 8, in time for the injunction to apply to the scheduled execution of Richard Leavitt.[SENTMARKER]On July 10, the District Court entered a permanent injunction ordering the Idaho Department of Corrections to modify their execution procedures to allow witnesses to the execution throughout the entire execution process.

gold_sents: In 2016, prisoners that had completed their sentences but remained incarcerated by the Illinois Department of Corrections filed this class action against the state in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Illinois statutory scheme governing mandatory supervised release (MSR) for sex offenders and the requirement for offenders to have an approved “host site” in order to be released from custody violated their Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The court awarded the plaintiffs summary judgment on the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment claims.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a permanent injunction on January 15, 2020,  requiring IDOC to present a plan for releasing class members from custody, and quarterly reports outlining steps that were being taken to ensure that all class members would be properly released by January 2, 2021.[SENTMARKER]As of July 2020, the court's supervision of IDOC's progress is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 18, 2017, a group of homeless sex offenders filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against the Illinois Attorney General, the Illinois Department of Corrections, and the Illinois Prison Review Board.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments by imposing unmeetable restrictions on where they can live that must be satisfied in order for such individuals to be released on mandatory supervised release (MSR).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as monetary relief.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved for summary judgment on four grounds, arguing that the plaintiffs' claims fall within the scope of habeas corpus rather than 42 U.C.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit denied the defendants' motion to dismiss on three grounds.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On October 21, 2015, a private plaintiff sued the City of Dodge City, Kansas and Ford County in a civil rights action arising under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the Dodge City's wealth-based post-arrest detention scheme violated the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought injunctive relief, compensatory damages, and a declaration that the City's wealth-based detention practices were unlawful.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle that the City would be enjoined from holding an arrestee in custody after a non-warrant arrest on the basis of inability to post bond.[SENTMARKER]The court retains jurisdiction to enforce the injunction but the case otherwise appears closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 22, 2010, a man arrested for disorderly conduct in Dodge City, Kansas filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Kansas against the City of Dodge City and the Ford County Sheriff's Office.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that the Defendants' policy of refusing to release arrestees from jail unless they pay a generic and arbitrary "bond" amount violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the Plaintiff's motion for entry of a final judgment in favor of the Plaintiff and the Defendant.[SENTMARKER]The Court entered an injunction requiring the Defendants to release all individuals arrested (for non-warrant arrests) in the City for violation of municipal ordinances of the City on Own Recognizance Bonds ("OR Bonds") without further conditions of release as soon as practical after booking and will not require individuals to post any type of monetary bond pursuant to an established schedule for the alleged offense.[SENTMARKER]The Defendants also agreed to pay the plaintiff's costs and attorney's fees incurred by the Defendant to enforce the injunction as set forth above.

gold_sents: In 2015, prisoners in the Kentucky Clark County Jail filed this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky, alleging that the state did not afford adequate procedural right prior to unlawfully charging inmates a fee for their incarceration without an order from the sentencing court.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a declaratory judgment, permanent injunction of the practice, and monetary damages.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss and dismissed all claims alleged in the complaint with prejudice, and all pending motions were denied moot.[SENTMARKER]In 2016, the plaintiffs appealed but the appeals court affirmed the judgment of the district court.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 26, 2013, a former inmate of the Clark County Detention Center filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky against Clark County, Kentucky and Clark County Jailer, Frank Doyle.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants' practice of charging prisoners for their incarceration without an order of a sentencing court violated the Fourteenth Amendment and the Due Process Clause of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the federal claim with prejudice, and dismissed the state claims without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]On March 11, 2016, the Sixth Circuit affirmed the district court's dismissal of the federal claims.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This 2017 class lawsuit was brought by two residents of East Baton Rouge Parish in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that, in charging fees in addition to bail to be released from prison before trial, the defendant RHI had violated federal and state anti-racketeering law, their Due Process and Equal Protection rights, and the right to be free from unreasonable searches and seizures.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a private settlement, and the case was dismissed on February 20, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 4, 2019, a group of individuals arrested for criminal offenses in East Baton Rouge Parish, Louisiana filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana against Rehabilitation Home Incarceration (RHI) and the local sheriff's office.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' pretrial supervision practices violated the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs sought monetary relief from defendants' extortionate and unconstitutional pretrial supervised practices, which violated the state and federally-protected rights of the class members.[SENTMARKER]The court granted RHI's motion for partial dismissal of the case on June 4, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2015, indigent former criminal defendants filed this putative class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that that the defendants had a practice of imprisoning individuals who had failed to pay court debts without meaningfully determining whether the individuals had the ability to pay the debt.[SENTMARKER]In August 2018, granted plaintiffs’ motion for class certification, and held that the Judges’ policy/practice of not inquiring into the ability of the persons falling within the certified class to pay before they are imprisoned for non-payment of court debts was unconstitutional, and that the Judges’ failure to provide a neutral forum for determination of such persons’ ability to pay was unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed to the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit affirmed the lower court on August 23, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The defendants petitioned the Fifth Circuit to rehear the case en banc on September 6, 2019, but the court denied to rehear on September 30.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a petition for writ of certiorari in the U.S. Supreme Court on December 20, 2019.[SENTMARKER]Cert was denied on March 3, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 13, 2016, two New Orleans residents filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana against the City of New Orleans, the Orleans Parish Criminal District Court, and the Sheriff's Office.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment rights by placing and keeping them in jail prior to any debt-collection proceedings when they cannot afford to pay the preset amount of money required for release after a Collections Department nonpayment arrest if the person seeks to contest the issue of nonpayment or the validity of the debt.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the case for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, finding that the plaintiffs had no standing to pursue their claims for equitable relief.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On June 18, 2020, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana against the Orleans Parish Criminal District Court and Orleans Parish Sheriff Marlin Gusman.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by the Roderick and Solange MacArthur Justice Center and Civil Rights Corps, alleged that the defendants' post-arrest detention and release procedures that require presumptively innocent arrestees to pay a bond to a commercial surety to secure their release violated the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The parties sought injunctive relief, declaratory and monetary relief, and class certification.[SENTMARKER]On November 1, 2019, the plaintiffs filed an emergency petition for writ of habeas corpus, claiming that they were impermissibly jailed despite voicing to the court their inability to pay the bond amounts imposed.[SENTMARKER]On June 9, 2020, Governor Jon Bel Edwards signed Act 110 of the 2020 Session of the Louisiana Legislature, which was signed into law on June 18, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The parties discussed the effect of the new law on the status of the case and the parties agreed that they would dismiss the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]On August 18, 2020, the case was dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In December 2020, four individuals at East Baton Rouge Parish Prison (EBRPP) filed this class action lawsuit alleging violations of their Fourteenth and Sixth Amendment rights by judicial and prison officials.[SENTMARKER]On December 15, the plaintiffs filed a motion for temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The request for a temporary restraining order was later withdrawn in January 2021.[SENTMARKER]A settlement conference is scheduled for March 11 and the deadline for the parties to file a joint status report is March 21.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' responsive pleading to the complaint is due on March 22, 2021.[SENTMARKER]This case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 6, 2020, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana against the East Baton Rouge Parish Sheriff's Office and the Criminal Division of the 19th Judicial District Court.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Sheriff and Warden of the EBRPP violated the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution when they set secured financial conditions of release without an inquiry into ability to pay or consideration of non-financial alternatives, which results in jailing poor members of the community for no reason other than their poverty while allowing release from jail for their similarly situated counterparts who have greater financial means.[SENTMARKER]The class seeks declaratory and injunctive relief on behalf of all individuals who are in the custody of the Sheriff’s office after their arrest and who have been or will be subjected to the bail practices of the Judges and Commissioners of the District Court and who receive determinations on their eligibility for bail from the Judge's office and when detaining individuals.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs also allege that they have been physically and sexually assaulted repeatedly by the detainees in the jail.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

of Corrections in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff objected to the three-drug cocktail (sodium pentothal, pancuronium bromide, and potassium chloride) pegasus_output_sents: On January 19, 2006, an inmate sentenced to death by lethal injection filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.[SENTMARKER]The inmate claimed that the state's lethal injection protocol unnecessarily added potassium chloride, a saturated solution of the compound that is toxic to the heart, to the three-drug cocktail of sodium pentothal, pancuronium bromide, and potassium chloride.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the inmate's request for a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction, and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]On February 1, 2006, the Supreme Court granted certiorari and a stay of execution to a Florida inmate who had challenged Florida's execution protocol.[SENTMARKER]The case is scheduled to be heard in September 2006.

gold_sents: In response to the economic crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic of 2020, Congress passed the CARES Act, which created, among other things, the “Paycheck Protection Program.”[SENTMARKER]Under this program, small business owners could apply for a loan from the Small Business Administration; if they later certified that all of the loan funds had been used for qualifying expenses, the loan would be forgiven.[SENTMARKER]The SBA’s rules disqualified many small business owners with criminal records.[SENTMARKER]Several small business owners brought this lawsuit against the SBA in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland, challenging this criminal record exclusion.[SENTMARKER]On June 29, the court granted a preliminary injunction requiring the SBA to extend the application deadline for the named plaintiffs from June 30 to July 21, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The following week, Congress passed follow-up legislation extending the deadline for all applicants to August 8, 2020.[SENTMARKER]As of July 29, 2020, further developments in the litigation are pending.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 27, 2020, a New York-based graphic designer filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the Small Business Administration (SBA) and the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) under the CARES Act.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the SBA's Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) excluded small business owners with criminal records from the federal government's critical federal aid program.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the plaintiffs allege that the criminal history exclusion is arbitrary and capricious, and that the defendants failed to carry out a ministerial duty.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction, which was denied by the District Court.[SENTMARKER]On June 10, 2020, the Seventh Circuit affirmed the district court's granting of a temporary injunction enjoining enforcement of an immigration rule in Illinois.[SENTMARKER]On July 21, 2020, the parties filed a joint motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be dismissed, and the case is closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On February 8, 2015, a group of individuals brought a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri against the City of Ferguson, Missouri, alleging that the City's policies and practices of jailing people for failure to pay fines owed from traffic tickets and other minor offenses violated their rights under the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory, injunctive, and compensatory relief.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the plaintiffs' motion to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction, and the case was dismissed on February 13, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed the district court's decision to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 27, 2015, a person jailed by the City of St. Ann, Missouri (the City), for failing to pay the fee required under the City's secured bail system, sued the City in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri, arguing that the City had violated the Fourteenth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution, and asking for declaratory relief, injunctive relief, damages, attorneys' fees, and costs.[SENTMARKER]On September 3, 2015, the Judge assigned to the case, Judge Rodney W. Sippel, granted a stay in the proceedings to allow the parties to test the effects of a provisional settlement agreement, under which plaintiff agreed to drop his non-equitable claims, and under which the City agreed to end its secured bail policy and pay the plaintiff a $10,000 fee for acting as a class representative.[SENTMARKER]On May 4, 2018, a Consent Agreement was signed by Judge Sippel, whereby most of the original relief sought was agreed to by the Defendant.[SENTMARKER]The Court retains jurisdiction for two years, which may be extended for one more year upon agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 4, 2015, a homeless man filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri against the City of St. Ann, alleging that the City's policy and practice of refusing to release ordinance violation arrestees from jail unless they pay a generically set "bond" amount violated the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff sought declaratory, injunctive, and compensatory relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the City agreed to end its use of a fixed cash bail system for new arrestees and to notify all arrestees in writing upon release of the time, date, and place at which they are required to appear in court, if any.[SENTMARKER]The City also agreed to pay the Plaintiff $10,000 as a "class representative fee."[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to seek, when and as needed, the continued stay of the lawsuit for up to a period of one year as provided herein.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On August 9, 2016, a group of individuals who were placed in jail because of an inability to pay fines, penalties, and other charges filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued thirteen St. Louis County municipalities under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and § 2201.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by ArchCity Defenders and private counsel, asked the court for declaratory, injunctive, and compensatory relief, claiming violations of the Fourth, Sixth, and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]In their complaint, the plaintiffs claimed that the defendant municipalities engaged in a deliberate and coordinated conspiracy to fill their coffers by extorting money from thousands of poor, disproportionately African-American people in the St. Louis region.[SENTMARKER]On April 24, 2017, the case was dismissed as to all defendant municipalities except the City of St. Ann.[SENTMARKER]The case (including mediation efforts) is ongoing against the City.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 24, 2014, the ACLU of Missouri filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri against the City of St. Ann, the St. Louis County Sheriff's Office, and the city of Beverly Hills, Missouri.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants held hundreds of people in their jails for non-payment in each of the past five years.[SENTMARKER]The defendants failed to provide inmates access to a shower, limited inmates' use of phones, and failed to give inmates medication for their chronic medical conditions.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled on April 24, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs a total of $325,000.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also required the defendants to provide the plaintiffs with a copy of their policies and procedures.

gold_sents: In June 2017, a man awaiting criminal trial and Lexington National Insurance Corporation filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that that the Criminal Justice Reform Act violated the bail provision of the Eighth Amendment, due process under the Fourteenth Amendment, and freedom from unreasonable search and seizure under the Fourth Amendment because the act favored non-monetary pre-trial release conditions over bail.[SENTMARKER]After and appeal to the Third Circuit regarding denial of preliminary injunction and a subsequent denial of certiorari in the Supreme Court, the plaintiff voluntarily dismissed the case.[SENTMARKER]This case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 14, 2017, a New Jersey criminal defendant filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey against the Attorney General of the state and the Camden County Prosecutor alleging that New Jersey's Criminal Justice Reform Act (CJRA) violated his Fourth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, damages, and other relief.[SENTMARKER]The District Court denied the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, and the Third Circuit affirmed the District Court's denial of the motion.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of the United States (S.C.) issued an opinion in support of the State's position that the CJRA was constitutional.[SENTMARKER]The Third Circuit held that the district court did not have jurisdiction to issue an injunction because the parties had not yet reached a settlement agreement.

gold_sents: Persons in the custody of the New York State Department of Correctional Services (DOCS) brought this class action against DOCS and the New York State Division of Parole (DOP) for the extra-judicial imposition of sentences requiring post-release supervision.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' motion to dismiss was denied by the District Court, and the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit affirmed.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' motion for summary judgment was granted with respect to several defendants, but denied on the issue of qualified immunity; and plaintiffs' cross motion for partial summary judgment on the issue of liability for three officers was granted.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the qualified immunity decision, but the Second Circuit affirmed.[SENTMARKER]On remand, the defendants moved for summary judgment again, but that motion was denied.[SENTMARKER]The case is currently scheduled for trial in Summer 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: The Legal Aid Society represented hundreds of individuals arrested by the New York State Department of Correctional Services (DOCS) for violating the terms of post-release supervision (PRS) administratively imposed by the DOCS.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the case on the grounds that because plaintiffs’ constitutional rights were not clearly established at the time that those rights were allegedly violated, state officials were entitled to qualified immunity for their actions.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Second Circuit vacated the district court’s judgment and remanded the case for a determination of whether plaintiffs had timely filed their petition for a writ of habeas corpus.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction because they had not shown a likelihood of success on the merits.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit granted plaintiffs' motion for class certification, but the motion was denied as moot and the court never addressed the merits of class certification.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Civil Rights Corps sued Tulsa County and various judicial officers, alleging that the court system operated a wealth-based detention system by detaining arrestees without inquiring into their ability to pay bail.[SENTMARKER]While the plaintiffs motion for preliminary injunction was denied, the plaintiffs motion for class certification is still pending.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 6, 2018, the Tulsa County Sheriff's Office was sued in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma on behalf of hundreds of people detained in Tulsa County Jail solely because they could not afford to pay money bail.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' wealth-based detention scheme violated their equal protection and due process rights.[SENTMARKER]They sought declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification on the same day, and the case is now closed.[SENTMARKER]The district court remanded for consideration of the public's interest in light of the jail's COVID-19 Plan, which allegedly has negative effects on the detainees' mental and physical well being.

gold_sents: On March 25, 2015, the plaintiffs filed a consumer class action on behalf of consumers nationwide who had been the subject of misleading and inaccurate background reports sold by the defendant, RealPage, Inc. to landlords.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania under the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA), alleging that the defendant, RealPage, Inc., adopted and maintained a policy and practice of failing to timely update the criminal record information it maintained so as to eliminate records of cases that have been expunged, thus not accurately reflecting the final disposition of these cases.[SENTMARKER]Moreover, the plaintiffs alleged that the defendant systematically violated FCRA by failing to provide complete and accurate disclosures of all information the defendant maintains about consumers to these consumers upon request.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled, and the defendant agreed to provide consumers additional information about federal agencies responsible for enforcing FCRA, refrain from including expunged criminal records in tenant screening reports, and disclose the names of vendors who retrieved criminal record information to consumers, plus damages.[SENTMARKER]The settlement term ended in 2020, and the case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 5, 2014, Plaintiff James Jenkins brought a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia against RealPage, Inc. ("RealPage") alleging violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ("FCRA"), 15 U.S.C.  1681-1681x (FCRA).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that RealPage violated the FCRA by failing to timely update the criminal record information that it maintains to eliminate records of cases that have been expunged and (ii) failing to provide complete and accurate disclosures of all information it maintains about consumers to those consumers who made a request for their "file" copy.[SENTMARKER]On July 13, 2015, the parties entered into a settlement agreement, which established a $936,200 settlement fund for payments to class members and for attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to dismiss the case on the merits, with prejudice, with no costs.

gold_sents: In 2020, the Nashville Community Bail Fund filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that a local rule which required it to agree to garnishment of judgment fees from bail bonds before it could post bail for indigent arrestees violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the Constitution and threatened its ability to operate as a non-profit.[SENTMARKER]The District Judge granted a preliminary injunction in March 2020 enjoining the County Criminal Court Clerk from garnishing fees from bonds posted by the Bail Fund.[SENTMARKER]In December 2020, the District Judge approved a consent decree where the Bail Fund and the County Government agreed to make the injunction permanent.[SENTMARKER]The matter is ongoing as the parties are litigating over who should pay attorneys fees and how much.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 5, 2020, the Nashville Community Bail Fund (NCBF) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee against the Nashville Office of the Clerk of the Criminal Court of the Twentieth Judicial District.[SENTMARKER]The NCBF challenged the constitutionality of Davidson County's local rule governing bail bonds 10(B) in the United States District Court.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the complaint alleged that the local rule violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments and the right to due process.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the motion for preliminary injunctive and Declaratory Relief on March 17, 2020.[SENTMARKER]On May 22, 2020, the court granted a preliminary injunction, enjoining the criminal court clerk from enforcing the rule.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a consent decree, which was entered on June 22, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree requires the court clerk to post a bond for each person arrested and detained in Davidson County who is unable to pay a bail bond.[SENTMARKER]The decree is to be binding upon the parties and their respective heirs, successors, or assigns.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the consent decree are subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In May of 2016 two indigent people brought a suit against the City of El Paso in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas for jailing them for failure to pay fines, despite their inability to do so.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs brought this action under 42 U.S.C. 1983, and allege that the Defendants violated their Due Process and Equal Protection rights under the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs request declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]They want to enjoin the Defendants from enforcing their current debt collection program, which jails people who can't pay a certain portion of their fines for traffic and misdemeanor offenses.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs allege that Defendants adopted their debt collection program to generate revenue for they city, and the individual plaintiffs were not informed that they could assert their indigence.[SENTMARKER]Rather, the Plaintiffs were simply told they had to pay or go to jail.[SENTMARKER]On January 12th, 2017 Judge David Guaderrama granted the Defendant's motion to dismiss in part.[SENTMARKER]Judge Guaderrama dismissed the Due Process claims, but did not reach the Equal Protection claims.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs filed an amended complaint in January 2017, and after the Court denied two motions to dismiss filed by defendants over the course of 2017, the parties stipulated to dismissal of the action pursuant to a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]In the settlement agreement, defendants agreed to maintain certain administrative practices for three years.[SENTMARKER]Among other things, these practices related to notice to defendants, policies and procedures for: payment plans; notice to defendants of court hearings and schedules; and indigency hearings and warrants issued for non-payment.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 20, 2016, the Electronic Privacy Information Center (EPIC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against the City of El Paso, the Presidential Advisory Commission on Election Integrity, and other entities and officials alleging violations of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the E-Government Act (E.G.A.).[SENTMARKER]Specifically, EPIC alleged that the defendants violated the rights of low-income debtors by intentionally refusing to inform them of their rights, and refusing to properly inquire into debtors' financial inability to pay their fines and/or the debtors' reasons for failing to pay.[SENTMARKER]The court granted EPIC's request for a preliminary injunction in part and denied its motion to dismiss in part.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed not to collect voter data unless and until they completed a privacy impact assessment as required by E-G.[SENTMARKER]A copy of the settlement agreement is available on the court's website.

gold_sents: In January 2016, two indigent women that served imprisonment terms at the Randall County Jail filed this complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the City of Amarillo's municipal code created a modern-day debtors' prison and violated their Fourteenth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]In August 2016, the Court granted the defendant's motion to dismiss and ordered the plaintiffs to pay $3,660.00 in litigation costs.
pegasus_output_sents: The City of Amarillo, Texas was sued in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas for violating the Fourteenth Amendment and the Due Process Clause of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the City's fine collection system is unconstitutional as applied to indigent individuals.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, they alleged that municipal officers violated the Equal Protection Clause by converting a fine only offense to jail time solely because an individual was unable to pay a fine.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that they were incarcerated for failure to pay fines assessed for non-jailable offenses without informing them of their constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss, arguing that the plaintiffs failed to state a plausible claim for municipal liability.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the case is closed.

gold_sents: Foster children in Georgia's Fulton and DeKalb Counties brought suit against the state and counties Division of Family and Children Services.[SENTMARKER]The class of children alleged that they did not receive necessary treatment and services while spending months in emergency shelters, experienced abuse and neglect as a result of an insufficient number of caseworkers, and received inadequate health care and emotional services while in foster care.[SENTMARKER]In 2005 and 2006, the plaintiffs reached settlement agreements with the state, Fulton County, and DeKalb County.[SENTMARKER]As of November 2018, the State is still under the supervision of the independent monitor in order to meet the court-ordered benchmarks, having not yet completed sufficient improvements.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 6, 2002, nine foster children in the custody of the Georgia Department of Human Resources filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia on behalf of a class of Fulton and DeKalb County foster children and a subclass of African-American foster children.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to correct alleged deficiencies in the foster care system.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motions to dismiss and for summary judgment, but the Tenth Circuit vacated and remanded with directions to consider separately each provision of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]On October 28, 2005, the district court entered a consent decree between the plaintiffs and the Fulton County Department of Family and Children Services (Fulton DFCS), which was modified by agreed orders on December 15, 2008 and November 2, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties were unable to reach an agreement as to the appropriate amount of fees and expenses to be awarded.[SENTMARKER]Finally, the District Court ordered the defendants to pay the entire cost of mediation.[SENTMARKER]The parties appealed, and the case was remanded for further proceedings consistent with the Supreme Court's decision in the NAACP case.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court remanded the case to the Eleventh Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs, who are children in the custody of the New Jersey Division of Youth and Family Services (DYFS), brought suit against the state alleging abuse, neglect, and lack of services.[SENTMARKER]After the New York Times published several articles about the deaths of children in the care of DYFS due to lack of care, in 2003 the state entered into a settlement agreement providing for a systematic overhaul of the state child welfare system.[SENTMARKER]The latest modification of the agreement was made in 2015 and remains in force.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 27, 2003, the parents of two children in the custody of the New Jersey Division of Youth and Family Services (DYFS) filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey alleging violations of the United States Constitution and federal statutes.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the children's civil rights by failing to provide them with adequate infordated data in the form of a pre-placement preventive services program designed to help children remain with their families or be returned to their families when appropriate.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on July 27, 2003.[SENTMARKER]The agreement required the defendants to provide the plaintiffs with training on how to use the program, and to ensure that the children were not placed in shelters as an option for youth who need to be placed out of their homes.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss in part and denied in part, finding that most federal statutes issue did not unambiguously confer rights under  1983; .<n>The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs, children in the custody of the New York City Child Welfare Administration ("CWA"), and children who, while not in the custody of CWA, are or will be at risk of abuse or neglect and whose status is known or should be known to CWA, sought declaratory and injunctive relief against both the city and state for systematic deficiencies that jeopardized their well-being.[SENTMARKER]The case was filed on December 13, 1995, and the parties reached to two separate settlement agreements, one with the city and one with the state, on December 2, 1988.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs returned to court in January 2001, seeking an order directing the state to comply with specific terms of the state settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The court found that the state had acted with insufficient diligence in implementing the information management system, and therefore extended the terms of the agreement in this area and directed that the plaintiffs receive semi-annual reports.[SENTMARKER]The defendants provided a January 2017 report to show that they were continuing to develop, implement, and update their information systems for child welfare needs.[SENTMARKER]A year later, the court ended its supervision of the portions of the settlement that it had retained jurisdiction to enforce.
pegasus_output_sents: In December 1995, a group of children who were the legal responsibility of the New York City child welfare system filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the City's Department of Social Services (SCR) failed to provide the children with counseling or support services when they were in the custody of the City.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case, but the parties moved jointly for class certification and approval of a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]On March 31, 1999, the district court approved the settlement agreements.[SENTMARKER]On June 18, 1996, the parties filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]On July 27, 1998, the parties informed the court that they were engaged in settlement negotiations.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed the City Settlement Agreement and the State Settlement Agreement with the court on December 2, 1998.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit affirmed the District Court's dismissal of the case on September 26, 1997.[SENTMARKER]The parties appealed the decision to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court remanded the case for further consideration.

gold_sents: This was a class action challenge to New York's unnecessary institutionalization of children in foster care in psychiatric facilities.[SENTMARKER]The initial settlement agreement, entered on February 28, 2011, provided for increased community-based placement opportunities for children in foster care with mental illness as well as individualized planning, staff training, and monitoring.[SENTMARKER]In addition to the initial settlement agreement, on July 7, 2011, the plaintiffs agreed to release defendants from all liability in exchange for payment from defendants.[SENTMARKER]On January 22, 2016, the parties agreed to extend the Court's jurisdiction until June 30, 2016, at which time its jurisdiction presumably expired.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 12, 2010, three children in the custody of the New York City Administration for Children's Services (ACS) filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that ACS violated Title 11 of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by improperly placing and detaining children who are in foster care in acute-care psychiatric hospitals longer than necessary and failing to move these children to the least restrictive placements appropriate to their needs.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement on October 12, 2010.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to implement a new policy and procedure for the provision of emergency and inpatient mental health services for children in ACS's foster care and child protective system.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is final and binding on all parties, as weB as their successors and assigns.

gold_sents: On May 30, 2013, an eleven-year-old child in the custody of the South Carolina Department of Social Services (SCDSS), filed a lawsuit in the Court of Common Pleas, Abbeville County, South Carolina, against SCDSS and the Boys Home of the South (BHOTS), alleging that, as a result of Defendants' failures, Plaintiff was sexually assaulted on multiple occasions, causing him severe and permanent mental injury.[SENTMARKER]Following removal to Federal Court, in early 2014, Plaintiff settled with both SCDSS and BHOTS for an undisclosed sum of money.[SENTMARKER]BHOTS also permanently closed as a result of the lawsuit.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 1, 2013, a South Carolina foster child filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina against the South Carolina Department of Social Services (SCDSS) and Boys Home of the South, Inc. (BHOTS) alleging that he was sexually abused while in foster care by another foster child, A.R.[SENTMARKER]Dkt.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the sexual abuse was preventable because the SCDSS and BHOTS allegedly had notice and knowledge that the foster child had engaged in sexually inappropriate behavior with other foster children.[SENTMARKER]They alleged inadequate supervision at BHOTS.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that they failed to provide Plaintiff with urgently needed medical and mental health treatment after the alleged abuse.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion for summary judgment on January 21, 2014, and the parties agreed to a settlement on March 24, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the funds for John Doe will be placed in a discretionary trust and an educational trust for his benefit.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to approval by the court.

gold_sents: On January 12, 2015, a class action lawsuit was filed against the South Carolina Department of Social Services (SCDSS) in the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina, alleging numerous deficiencies in the operation of the state's child welfare system.[SENTMARKER]On September 28, 2015, the parties reached an interim settlement agreement, providing for an end to certain SCDSS practices, as well as for studies of additional SCDSS practices.[SENTMARKER]Monitoring revealed incremental improvements in conditions, and the settlement remains in effect.
pegasus_output_sents: This case was brought in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina on behalf of children in the custody of the South Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS) in violation of the Constitution and laws of the United States.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs alleged that the defendants failed to provide basic health care services to children in foster care and that the children were placed in restrictive, institutional settings.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a Final Settlement Agreement (FSA) on October 4, 2016, which required the defendants to provide medical and dental assessments, periodic medical/physical and dental health screenings, and follow-up treatment to children as required under the "Early Periodic Screening, Diagnosis and Treatment" (EPSDT) provisions of the Medicaid Act.[SENTMARKER]The FSA also required the defendant to develop a Health Care Improvement Plan (the "Plan"), which was to address long-standing problems experienced by children and their siblings and parents in the operation of the state's child welfare system.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed in January 2019.

gold_sents: A paraplegic individual who uses a wheelchair sued Chipotle for violations of the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) and California state law in two of its California restaurants.[SENTMARKER]The defendant implemented a new "Customers with Disabilities" which the district court found to be in compliance with the ADA, but the Ninth Circuit found otherwise, that viewing the ingredients behind the counter was part of the "Chipotle Experience."[SENTMARKER]Ultimately, the defendant lowered the heights of the walls in front of the food-preparation areas in all of its California locations so that customers in wheelchairs could see the ingredients, and the plaintiff was awarded $898,549 in attorneys' fees and costs and $5,000 in statutory damages.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2005, Maurizio Antoninetti, a paraplegic, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California against Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., alleging violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the California Disabled Persons Act (CDPA).[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case with prejudice upon the defendants' motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Ninth Circuit vacated the district court's judgment and remanded the case for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: The California Department of Fair Employment and Housing filed this ongoing lawsuit on behalf of several LSAT test takers against the Law School Admissions Council (LSAC).[SENTMARKER]The State claims that LSAC routinely denies reasonable accommodations to test takers with disabilities in violation of the California Unruh Civil Rights Act and the Americans with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]In 2014, the parties have agreed to a consent decree that the court approved.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 12, 2012, the California Department of Fair Employment and Housing (DFEH) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Law School Admission Council, Inc. (LSAC) seeking damages and injunctive relief over alleged violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the California Unruh Civil Rights Act (UCR) in violation of the California Fair Housing and 15 Employment Act (FEHA) (Cal Gov. Code  12900, et seq.) against LSAC.[SENTMARKER]Code  12900, et seq.) against LSAC.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in May 2014 and the parties entered a consent decree in May 2014.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree requires LSAC to comply with the ADA and UCR by providing accommodations to test-takers of the Law 19 Admission Test (LSAT) in a manner accessible to individuals who claim to have a disability.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed that LSAC would cease the practice of annotating test scores that were earned under non-standard time conditions.[SENTMARKER]The decree is effective for four years from the date it was entered and will remain in effect for the next four years.[SENTMARKER]On May 29, 2014, Judge Edward M. Chen granted the parties' motion to dismiss the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed by the Court of Appeals for the 9th Circuit.

gold_sents: Disabled plaintiffs sued a public transit agency for violation of the Americans With Disabilities Act and the Rehabilitation Act, alleging their bus system presented numerous barriers to access, subjecting the plaintiffs to delay, embarrassment, and ridicule by passengers and drivers.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent decree, in which the defendant agreed to remedy the problems with its bus system and pay $250,000 in damages, fees, and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 1, 1999, two individuals with disabilities filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado alleging that the City of Steamboat Springs, Colorado violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (Rehabilitation Act) by failing to make its public transportation system readily accessible to and usable by persons who use wheelchairs.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged violations of Title II of the ADA and of Section 504 of Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the City agreed to modify, as needed to comply with the ADA, a men's and a women's restroom on the east side of the rodeo grounds, and to provide comprehensive training for all bus and van operators, dispatchers, and mechanics.[SENTMARKER]The decree was final and binding on the parties, including all principals, agents, employees of the City.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on December 12, 2000 without prejudice.

gold_sents: Disabled patrons of a concert venue filed a class action against the owners and operators of the venue for failure to remove barriers to access.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled, with Defendants agreeing not to obstruct wheelchair areas and to pay damages and attorneys' fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 26, 1992, the Colorado Cross-Disability Coalition (CCDC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado against the owners, operators, lessors and/or lessees of Fiddler's Green, a concert hall in Denver, Colorado.[SENTMARKER]The CCDC alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to provide adequate seating for persons with mobility limitations and their nondisabled companions in violation of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs alleged that they were denied full and equal enjoyment of the services, facilities, privileges, advantages and accommodations of Fiddler’s Green on the basis of disability.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that defendants negligently and falsely represented to the plaintiffs that reserved wheelchair seating was available at the concert with the intent that the plaintiffs would purchase tickets for wheelchair seating.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and ordered the defendants to pay the plaintiffs injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On December 2, 2020, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a complaint against the National Railroad Passenger Corporation (“Amtrak”) for allegedly violating the Americans with Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. §§ 12131-12165, by failing to make its intercity rail stations accessible to individuals with disabilities by July 26, 2020, as required by the Act.[SENTMARKER]The case was never properly docketed or assigned to a judge, however, because the government announced its settlement with Amtrak on the same day.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required Amtrak to design at least 135 accessible stations, complete construction at 90 stations, and be in the process of constructing at least 45 stations within 10 years of the settlement date.[SENTMARKER]The agreement also required Amtrak to train staff on ADA compliance, establish a monitor-approved process for managing ADA complaints, and create a settlement fund to compensate individuals who were harmed by Amtrak’s most inaccessible stations.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was monitored by the Federal Railroad Administration and the Department of Justice.
pegasus_output_sents: The Department of Justice filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the National Railroad Passenger Corporation (Amtrak) under Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA) and its implementing regulation, 49 C.F.R. Part 37.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Amtrak had violated the ADA by failing to make its stations readily accessible to and usable by individuals with disabilities, including individuals who use wheelchairs, and of necessary remedies to bring its services, programs, and activities into compliance with the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which Amtrak agreed to pay the United States a total of $1 million to resolve the complaint.[SENTMARKER]In exchange for the settlement agreement, the parties agreed not to sue each other in the future for violations of Title II.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: On July 22, 2013, attorneys from United States Department of Justice Civil Rights Division filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida against the State of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ alleged that nearly two hundred children with disabilities were unnecessarily segregated from their communities and the general population by the State, which had placed them in nursing homes.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ sought an injunction requiring the State to comply with Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), 42 U.S.C. § 12131-12134, which, as interpreted by the Supreme Court in Olmstead v. L.C., 527 U.S. 581 (1999), forbids the unnecessary institutionalization of disabled individuals, and mandates that their rehabilitative and medical needs be provided in a manner that enables disabled individuals to be independent and integrated members of the community.[SENTMARKER]L.C., 527 U.S. 581 (1999), forbids the unnecessary institutionalization of disabled individuals, and mandates that their rehabilitative and medical needs be provided in a manner that enables disabled individuals to be independent and integrated members of the community.[SENTMARKER]In June 2014, the case was consolidated with another pending case, which is in the Clearinghouse as PB-FL-0007.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 20, 2011, the Department of Justice's Civil Rights Division filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida against the Florida Agency for Persons with Disabilities (APD).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the APD violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by placing hundreds of children with disabilities unnecessarily in nursing facilities and failing to provide sufficient reimbursement rates for in-home nursing services.[SENTMARKER]The APD also violated Title II of the ADA by limiting the availability of many community-based services for children with significant medical needs.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in April 2014 that required the A PD to implement a number of corrective measures.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the State to ensure that the children were placed in the most integrated setting appropriate to their needs and to provide educational opportunities for the children and young adults who are placed in these facilities.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: In 2005, two organizations that advocates for people with disabilities filed this lawsuit n the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued the City of Detroit, claiming that the city had failed to meet federal and Michigan accessibility standards in altering intersections and sidewalks.[SENTMARKER]In 2006, the parties negotiated a plant to correct the affected intersections and sidewalks.[SENTMARKER]As of 2018, a special master continues to monitor implementation of the agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: The Center for Community Access, Inc., a nonprofit Michigan corporation, filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan in June 2006 against the City of Detroit, Michigan, under Title II of the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and Michigan law.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the City had violated the ADA by failing to install curb cuts that meet the required accessibility standards and codes.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a settlement agreement in August 2006 that required the City to pay the plaintiffs' attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the City was required to make certain improvements to the city's streets and sidewalks.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the city to pay plaintiffs' attorneys' fees, costs, and damages.[SENTMARKER]In August 2008, the parties filed a motion for contempt for the City's failure to comply with the court's August 2006 Court Order.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the motion, and the parties agreed to settle the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: This was a case brought to make a 300 unit apartment complex in Canton Township, MI accessible to persons with mobility impairments.[SENTMARKER]It was filed in 2006 in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan by two individuals and the Fair Housing Center of Southeastern Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The suit eventually resulted in about three quarters of a million dollars in retrofits, damages to the plaintiffs and attorney fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 21, 2006, the Fair Housing Center of Southeastern Michigan (FHC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against Beztak Properties, Inc., Uptown Investors LLC, Biltmore Properties Companies, Incorporated, and Monogram Homes Inc.[SENTMARKER]The FHC alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), Fair Housing Amendments Act (FHRA), and Michigan With Disabilities Civil Rights Act (PWDCRA) by failing to design, construct, and/or operate the Uptown Apartment complex in Canton, Michigan in such a manner that the facilities are readily accessible to and useable by individuals with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also allegedly retaliated against the plaintiffs because they asserted their rights under the ADA and PWDCRA.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a partial settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs a total of $325,000.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: A class action lawsuit was filed on July 10, 2012, against the Mississippi Department of Education, under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Improvement Act of 2004 (IDEA), alleging that the defendant had failed to execute its responsibilities under IDEA, by not ensuring that the Jackson Public School District provide disabled students with a free and appropriate public education in the least restrictive environment, even after conducting an investigation into the School District and identifying its systemic failure to meet its IDEA obligations.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement on September 29, 2014 stipulating the implementation of a Program Sustainability Plan for the 2014-2015 school year.[SENTMARKER]On September 11, 2015 District Court Judge Daniel P. Jordan III granted a motion to dismiss with prejudice.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2010, a group of students with disabilities in the Jackson Public School District filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi against the Mississippi Department of Education under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Improvement Act of 2004 (IDEA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief under the federal law, alleging that the defendant had failed to provide the students with the free appropriate public education they are entitled to receive under the IDEA.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also sought to hold the defendant accountable for failing to comply with its statutory duty to ensure that the students received the appropriate educational and supportive services they need to achieve academically.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction, finding that the defendants had violated the law by failing to provide their students with appropriate academic programming and related services.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement agreement in which the defendant agreed to provide students with special education services via video streaming from other classrooms and to create a separate alternative school program to serve only children with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On August 3, 2006, plaintiffs, a group of disabled persons receiving public benefits filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the South District of New York against the New York Human Resources Administration alleging that it discriminated against disabled persons by involuntarily segregating them by transferring their public benefits cases from local benefit centers to three hub centers that only serviced people with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The Court approved a proposed settlement agreement in June of 2015.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 19, 2006, the New York City Human Resources Administration (HRA) was sued in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York by individuals with disabilities who alleged discrimination on the basis of handicap in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and New York State Human Rights Law.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought class certification and a preliminary injunction enjoining HRA from reassigning class members’ cases to the hub centers involuntarily.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to this court in November 2011 and the parties attempted to negotiate a settlement of monetary claims.[SENTMARKER]On November 7, 2014, the parties presented the court with a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the defendants would provide plaintiffs with draft training materials for their review and comment, provide the plaintiffs with reasonable counsel fees and costs as though they were prevailing parties, and that the plaintiffs would be entitled to reasonable compensation for their counsel.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for class certification in part and granted the plaintiffs’ motion for preliminary injunction in part.[SENTMARKER]On May 18, 2006, the court certified a class and appointed The Legal Aid Society and Milbank Tweed Hadley McCloy, LLP as counsel for Class Counsel.[SENTMARKER]In December 2013, the parties asked the Court to adjourn the scheduled trial to permit the parties to proceed with the injunctive relief portion of the settlement process; the parties expressed that they hoped to present the Court with the settlement agreement on November 7, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties have continued to negotiate the in the settlement portion of this litigation.[SENTMARKER]On March 31, 2015, the parties filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the motion for summary judgment on the grounds that the parties had not met their burden of showing that the case was not a class action.[SENTMARKER]On April 11, 2015, the court dismissed the case with prejudice.

gold_sents: Students sued the New York City Department of Education, the City of New York, and the chancellor of the New York City Department of Education to seek injunctive relief under the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Individuals with Disabilities in Education Act, Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and New York state law.[SENTMARKER]The student plaintiffs are either student in Staten Island District 75 schools or vulnerable to being sent to those schools, which are separated from New York City community schools.[SENTMARKER]District 75 students receive their education in a restrictive setting where they are largely isolated from interactions with students who do not have disabilities.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs seek injunctive relief in the form of a permanent injunction against future violations and an order for a remedial plan to reimagine policies, practices, and norms that will permit each student to learn in the most integrated setting possible.[SENTMARKER]The case remains open.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 12, 2014, Disability Rights New York filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York against the New York City Department of Education (DOE), the NYC Department of Human Rights Law (NYHRL), and the DOE's Chancellor, Richard A. Carranza.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the DOE placed students with disabilities in segregated and unequal public schools and classrooms in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (Section 504), the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), and NYCHRL regulations.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs' counsel is experienced in federal class action litigation, including in education, special education, and the civil rights of persons with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
