gold_sents: Four blind or visually impaired library patrons sued the Free Library of Philadelphia in in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, seeking relief under Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and Title II of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that the Library's new program to lend e-reading devices was discriminatory, because the Nook Simple Touch devices the library had procured were inaccessible to visually impaired users, and because accessible alternative devices were available.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a settlement and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The library agreed to transition to the exclusive use of accessible devices within four years, and to add ten accessible e-readers within 60 days of the settlement date.
pegasus_output_sents: In November 2010, a group of blind library patrons sued the Free Library of Philadelphia in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, alleging that the Library's e-reader lending program violated Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 and Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs alleged that the library's use of NOOK e-book reading devices was in violation of Section 504 because the devices were inaccessible to the blind.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Final Settlement Agreement, which required the Library to comply with Section 504 by refraining from lending any inaccessible e-reading devices to its blind patrons.[SENTMARKER]The agreement also required the library to purchase e-readers that are fully accessible to both patrons who are blind and patrons who do not have such disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the parties settled the case in December 2010.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the following terms: (1) the Library will no longer lend e-books to patrons with disabilities; .[SENTMARKER](2) the library will not purchase or use any of the devices; .[SENTMARKER](3) the plaintiffs will be awarded reasonable attorneys' fees and costs; and (4) the library is required to provide its patrons with a copy of the ADA's accessibility guidelines.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs filed a suit in federal court on January 20, 2011, against Millcreek Township, PA and the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation (PennDOT).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the sidewalks and intersections in Millcreek were not in compliance with the disability accessibility mandates of the Americans with Disabilities Act and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and sought injunctive and declaratory relief, and attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]On November 23, 2016, the parties partially settled, with the Township and PennDOT committing to adhere to ADA requirements in the future and to retrofit sidewalks and intersections where necessary.[SENTMARKER]A series of consent decrees, over which the court retains jurisdiction, have been entered and the case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 28, 2011, three individuals with disabilities filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania against Millcreek Township, Pennsylvania and the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation (PennDOT) alleging violations of Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (Section 504) with regard to street level pedestrian walkways, intersections, and other facilities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, but not damages, on behalf of themselves and the class.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Consent Decree and Partial Settlement with respect to some of the claims set forth in the complaint, but the parties have continued discussions and negotiations regarding several unresolved additional issues.[SENTMARKER]Under the consent decree, Millcreek agreed to install at least 110 curb ramps each year until the remaining curb ramps are installed.[SENTMARKER]Millcreek also agreed to establish and maintain a written nondiscrimination and sexual harassment policy and shall inform its employees of the policy.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed to allow at least fifteen days to agree upon any modifications to the Consent Decree.[SENTMARKER]The Court will retain jurisdiction to enforce all terms of this consent decree.

gold_sents: In 1996, parents of a student with autism filed this lawsuit on his behalf against the Arkansas Department of Education and the Williford School District under the IDEA, the ADA, Section 504, and 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]The parents claimed that their son was unfairly discriminated against due to his disability and was deprived of an appropriate education.[SENTMARKER]In 2004, the Eastern District of Arkansas Court held that neither defendant had violated the federal statutes and found for state and the school district.
pegasus_output_sents: In 1996, Thomas and Dianna Bradley filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas against the Arkansas Department of Education (ADE), the Williford School District, and several school district officials.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged violations of the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA),  504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by the ADE and the local school district.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed all of the plaintiffs' claims with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]In 2000, the plaintiffs filed an additional suit naming the same defendants as weI![SENTMARKER]In 2002, the district court granted the defendants' motion for partial summary judgment, finding that none of the defendants violated federal law.[SENTMARKER]The parties then appealed the decision to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This federal lawsuit was filed in 2000 in the Eastern District of California; in it, a former high school student and the Gay-Straight Alliance Network sued his school district for failure to take effective measures to remedy continuing harassment that he faced based on his sexual orientation.[SENTMARKER]The case settled for a consent decree entered August 15, 2002, which required the defendants to implement a mandatory staff training program, revise its policies, select compliance coordinators, develop systems for reporting harassment and discrimination, allow students to form a gay-straight alliance, and create a community advisory group.[SENTMARKER]The decree implementation period was 6 months.
pegasus_output_sents: In November 2000, the Visalia Gay Straight Alliance Network (GSA Network) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California against the Visalia Unified School District (VUSD) alleging that the VUSD violated the Civil Rights Act of 1964, Section 5(a) of the Education Act of 1965, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs alleged that the defendants discriminated against gay and lesbian students based on their actual or perceived sexual orientation.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that they were subjected to harassment and discrimination in the form of verbal and physical harassment, as well as discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim, and the parties entered into a consent order on June 30, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The consent order required the defendants to implement a mandatory staff training program for all certificated employees, administrators, and non-certificated staff who are responsible for monitoring student behavior.[SENTMARKER]The program will be mandatory for all students in one grade level in all VUSD high schools and 20 continuation schools on the subject of preventing harassment, discrimination, and school safety, and will not cover topics listed in Education Code Sections 51201.5, 51550, 16554 or 51820 requiring parental notification.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendants were required to develop policies to address the hostile and intolerant environment on the basis of actual or perception of sexual orientation or gender in all schools within the district.[SENTMARKER]The order was effective immediately upon the entry of the consent order and will remain in effect until June 30, 2005, or 60 days after the last report under 6 Section X is received, whichever date is later.

gold_sents: The plaintiff, Students for Fair Admissions (SFFA) sued the U.S. Department of Education to compel compliance with its FOIA request related to its investigation of Princeton University.[SENTMARKER]The defendant notified Princeton of the request and the lawsuit, and Princeton then filed a lawsuit against SFFA to enjoin the disclosure of the materials requested under FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The present case was consolidated into that suit, and the parties jointly stipulated to this case's dismissal.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 11, 2016, Students for Fair Admissions, Inc. (SFFA) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Education, New York Office for Civil Rights, alleging that the Department violated the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) by failing to respond to SFFA's FOIA request for documents concerning the investigation of Princeton University.[SENTMARKER]On July 17, 2016, Judge Tanya S. Chutkan granted the Department's motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]On December 2, 2016, the Court entered an order enjoining the Department from continuing to withhold any and all non-exempt records under the claim of exemption, and ordering the Department to produce, by a date certain, any responsive records to the FOIA request and a index of any responsive documents under the FOIA claim.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed on December 3, 2017.

gold_sents: Princeton sued U.S. Department of Education and OCR in a "reverse FOIA" to stop them from releasing documents related to an OCR compliance review to Students for Fair Admissions, Inc., which had submitted a FOIA request and filed a lawsuit against the DOE to compel disclosure.[SENTMARKER]Parties voluntarily dismissed case.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 13, 2016, the Office for Civil Rights (OCR) of the U.S. Department of Education (D.C.) received a complaint alleging that Princeton University had discriminated against African-American applicants to its undergraduate admissions program.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the University had used race and national origin as a factor in the admissions process.[SENTMARKER]OCR responded to the complaint with a FOIA request under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) for all documents concerning the investigation of the University's admissions program, including, but not limited to, information about the applicant's academic and non-academic performance in high school and personal essays.[SENTMARKER]On October 27, 2016, the complainant filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia seeking to compel disclosure of the materials identified in its FOIA request.[SENTMARKER]On May 26, 2017, the court granted the defendant's motion for summary judgment and remanded the case to the OCR for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case was docketed as Students for Fair Admissions, Inc v. United States Department of education, No. 1:16-cv-02154-TSC.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be closed.

gold_sents: On October 26, 2010, a group of students with disabilities filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana against the Louisiana Department of Education for failing to provide accessible free public education to students with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]After negotiations, the court approved a Consent Decree in March 2015.[SENTMARKER]An Independent Monitor continues to file periodical assessments as the State works toward full compliance under court supervision.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 31, 2015, ten students with disabilities filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana against the Orleans Parish School Board, alleging discrimination under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Improvement Act of 2004 ("IDEA"), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 ("Section 504"), and Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act ("ADA").[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs represented a class of approximately 4,500 New Orleans students who were denied access to public school because of their disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their rights by denying access to students who the school knew or should have known were disabled.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendants agreed to comply with the terms of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree requires the defendants to provide annual technical assistance to each school under its jurisdiction regarding the prohibited practice of undocumented suspensions, develop and disseminate information to parents of students at each school, and develop a written complaint investigation protocol describing the school’s process for investigating allegations of discrimination on the basis of disability.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to provide the plaintiffs with a copy of the school's policy on the use of paraprofessionals.[SENTMARKER]The decree is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: Several student members of a high school religious club brought suit against the city of said high school alleging violation of their freedom of speech, assembly, and free exercise of religion under the First Amendment's Establishment Clause and Free Exercise Clause.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged unlawful discrimination based on the religious content of their speech in violation of the Equal Access Act and the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause, in addition to violation of their freedom of expression under Massachusetts state law.[SENTMARKER]On June 16, 2003, the Court entered a consent decree between the school and the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]As per the decree, the defendants agreed to rescind punishment of the plaintiffs for the distribution of the religious materials, remove prior restraints and content-based restrictions of distribution of materials during non-instructional time without complying with substantive and procedural safeguards, so long as distribution doesn't substantially and materially disrupt the operation of the school or the new policies.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were awarded $28,500 in attorneys' fees and costs and the case was closed.
pegasus_output_sents: In December 2002, a group of students at Westfield High School filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the City of Westfield, the Westfield Public Schools, and the Westfield High Bible Club.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the First and Fourteenth Amendment rights of the students by prohibiting them from distributing candy canes with an attachment that contained the story of the candy cane and some Bible verses to fellow students.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, finding that the school's policies were unconstitutional prior restraints on free speech.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs $28,500 in attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 31, 2018, The National Federation of the Blind filed this lawsuit in the U.C.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Maryland (Northern Division).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the U.S. Department of Education and the Secretary of Education along with the Acting Assistant Secretary, claiming that the changes to the 2018 OCR Manual violated the Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. §§ 551 et seq., and was contrary to the mission of the OCR.[SENTMARKER]These changes in § 108(t) of the 2018 OCR Manual require mandatory dismissal of complaints if the claim is either part of "a pattern" of complaints against multiple recipients, or places an unreasonable burden on OCR's resources.[SENTMARKER]These changes also eliminate the appeal rights of complainants.[SENTMARKER]The parties came to a settlement agreement reopening complaints dismissed under the contested rules of the manual and allowing parties that had their cases dismissed under the rule to petition the Department to reopen their cases.[SENTMARKER]The case is not officially closed until February 2021, when the parties can no longer file for further enforcement.
pegasus_output_sents: The National Federation of the Blind (NFB), The Council of Parent Attorneys and Advocates, Inc. (COPAA), and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights (OCR) on May 31, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the OCR's March 5, 2018 issuance of a new OCR case processing manual, which allegedly eliminated certain substantive rights of complainants that the Office for Civil Rights is designed to protect, violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]On November 29, 2018, the parties filed an amended complaint and a motion for a preliminary injunction, which was granted by the Court.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the case without prejudice by paying $50,000 in attorney's fees and costs in full and final settlement of any and all claims for attorneys' fees and cost in connection with the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed without prejudice, and the parties are required to file a joint status report on or before November 19, 2019.

gold_sents: On May 14, 2020 the plaintiffs filed a lawsuit against the Department of Education (ED) in the United States District Court in the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that regulations issued by ED "sharply limit educational institutions' obligations to respond to reports of sexual harassment and assault" and therefore contravened Title IX of the Education Amendmentsof 1972.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing with responses to the complaint due on July 31, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 12, 2017, the Council of Parent Attorneys and Advocates, Inc. (COPAA) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the Department of Education (D.E.)[SENTMARKER]alleging violations of Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the D.C. violated Title IX when it failed to conclude the investigation of a complaint that a student had been raped by a male student while walking home from school.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, COPAA's mission is to prevent sexual harassment and assault in K–12 schools by educating students, families, and schools about students' right to an education free from sex discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that COPAA failed to provide appropriate support services to the student as she struggled to continue her education.[SENTMARKER]On May 6, 2020, the Court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, finding that the complaint was filed in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and Title IX.[SENTMARKER]The Court also granted the plaintiffs' request for declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to dismiss the case.

gold_sents: On November 7, 2006, the people of Michigan approved by majority vote a statewide ballot initiative-Proposal 2-which amended the Michigan Constitution to prohibit discrimination or preferential treatment based on race or gender in the operation of public employment, public education or public contracting in the State.[SENTMARKER]Both Proposal 2 and the University of Michigan's announcement that it would comply triggered litigation.[SENTMARKER]On November 15, 2012, the en banc Sixth Circuit held that Proposal 2 created a comparative structural burden that undermined the Equal Protection Clause (which the court called the "political process" argument).[SENTMARKER]Accordingly, the court found Proposal 2 unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On March 24, 2013, the Supreme Court granted review of the case.[SENTMARKER]Argument will be after the Court's summer break.[SENTMARKER]On October 15, 2013 the Supreme Court heard oral argument in the case.[SENTMARKER]In an opinion written by Justice Kennedy and joined by Justice Roberts and Justice Alito, the court reversed the Sixth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]There were two concurring opinions and a single dissent.[SENTMARKER]In his opinion Kennedy asserts that this is not a case about resolving the debate about racial preferences, but rather about whether it is constitutional for Michigan to allow its voters to decide the issue.[SENTMARKER]The court holds that there is no authority in the Federal Constitution or in this Court’s precedents for the Judiciary to set aside Michigan laws that commit to the voters the determination whether racial preferences may be considered in governmental decisions, in particular with respect to school admissions.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 8, 2006, two black high school seniors filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against the University of Michigan and the Michigan Attorney General challenging the implementation of a state constitutional amendment that was to go into effect on December 23, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the amendment violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the State of Michigan's motion to intervene, and the district court granted summary judgment in favor of the Attorney General.[SENTMARKER]On March 18, 2008, the District Court issued a final order granting summary judgment to the State and dismissed all claims.[SENTMARKER]On January 5, 2007, the plaintiffs appealed to the Sixth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit reversed the District's grant of summary judgment, concluding that the portions of Proposal 2 that affect Michigan’s public institutions of higher education impermissibly alter the political process in violation of the equal protection clause.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In late 2003, several students with disabilities filed a lawsuit against the New York City Department of Education and the New York City School Board for failing to follow the orders of impartial hearings requiring them to compensate or fund tuition and services for the special education needs of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]In 2008 a settlement agreement was approved which included injunctive and compensatory relief.
pegasus_output_sents: In September 2003, a group of parents of children with disabilities brought this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the New York City Department of Education.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had violated the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) by failing to comply with decisions, determinations, orders, and statements of agreement and orders of Impartial Hearing Officers (IHOs) entered pursuant to the IDEA.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' request for class certification on December 11, 2007 and the parties agreed to a settlement on April 10, 2008 that provided and injunctive relief for the two subclasses.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed that the plaintiffs were entitled to reasonable attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2012, a parent, individually and on behalf of their student-child with an educational disability in the Buffalo City School District, filed this class action complaint in the the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Buffalo City School District Board of Education and its superintendent denied free appropriate public education to children with educational disabilities, failed to promptly provide children with disabilities related services, and failed to provide parents with meaningful participation in their children's educational decision-making process.[SENTMARKER]In 2015, the parties reached a settlement that required more timely speech and language therapy for members of the class and awarded attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in March 2015.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 13, 2012, a class action lawsuit was brought in the United States District Court for the Western District of New York against the Buffalo City School District.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Individuals with Disabilities Education Improvement Act (IDEA), 20 U.S.C.  1400 et seq., by failing to provide a free appropriate public education (FAPE), including special education and related services, to educationally disabled children and their parents.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification on July 3, 2013, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement on June 17, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the defendants to comply with all federal and state laws and regulations relating to the education of children with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the district would provide the individual plaintiff with a free, appropriate public school education and that the defendant would provide services to such disabled students where services for non-disabled students were no so delayed.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the district's motion for certification on October 13, 2013, but the parties appealed the decision to the Second Circuit, which affirmed the district court's decision on June 3, 2013.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit remanded the case to the District Court to consider the parties' appeal.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On February 15, 1996, students filed a class action lawsuit against Owasso Independent School District ("OPS"), claiming that it had violated  Title IX of the Education Amendment of 1972, the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution and 42 U.S.C. § 1983 by intentionally denying  female students an equal opportunity to participate in interscholastic and other school-sponsored athletics.[SENTMARKER]On October 2, 1996, the Court entered a consent decree, which settled each of the claims stated in the Complaint and resolved all claims asserted against individuals who were named in their official and individual capacities, dismissing claims for damages.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 2, 2016, a group of female students at Owasso Public Schools in Oklahoma filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the school district violated Title IX by failing to provide equal opportunities for female students to participate in interscholastic and other school-sponsored athletics.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief requiring the district to fund and sponsor girls' sports so that the interests and abilities of all female students are accommodated in a non-discriminatory manner.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent decree in which the district agreed to pay $75,000 to the plaintiffs, construct a softball field on the district's high school campus, and provide equal access to weight training and conditioning facilities and equipment to female athletes and male athletes.[SENTMARKER]The district also agreed to provide the plaintiffs with a grievance grievance procedure, as amended, to be available to students and employees who believe that Title IX's requirements related to public school athletic programs have not been adhered to.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment and dismissed the case with prejudice.

gold_sents: Parents, on behalf of female students of Chouteau Public Schools, brought suit against the school district alleging that the school had violated female students' rights under the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment and Title IX of the Education Amendment through disparate treatment with respect to interscholastic athletics and programs.[SENTMARKER]In a settlement agreement, the school district agreed to take steps to remedy the discriminatory actions by, among many things, providing coaching, facilities and equipment to both male and female athletic teams on a gender-neutral basis.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 28, 2000, a group of female students at Chouteau Public Schools in Chouteau, Oklahoma filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the school district violated Title IX by denying female students meaningful participation opportunities in interscholastic and other school-sponsored sports.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, including the provision of locker rooms and facilities for both practice and competition; and (7) publicity.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the following terms: The school district must fund and sponsor a sufficient number of additional athletic teams for female students; the district must provide female students with off season training opportunities to female athletes that are equivalent to those available to male athletes; and the District must engage in the active promotion of sports participation opportunities available to female students.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is subject to final approval by the court.

gold_sents: A lawsuit was filed on behalf of all school-age students with disabilities in Pennsylvania seeking to increase the number of children with disabilities educated with their non-disabled peers, and to make sure schools provided real supports to make sure inclusion would work as required by the IDEA.[SENTMARKER]After eleven years, the parties reached a settlement; however, the final report demonstrates many of the terms of the agreement was not met.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 30, 1994, a group of parents of children with disabilities filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Pennsylvania Department of Education (PDE) violated the Individuals with Disabilities in Education Act (IDEA) by failing to identify disabled students, develop individual educational programs or plans, and provide a free appropriate public education in the least restrictive environment to the maximum extent reasonably possible.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in which PDE agreed to provide comprehensive development and training to regular and special education personnel concerning provisions for supplementary aids and services to students with disabilities in regular classrooms.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also required PDE to create materials representing that all children, including those children who are disabled, are welcome in school and to disseminate information to parents about training opportunities and materials.

gold_sents: In 2015, a transgender boy filed a lawsuit against his school district because they would not allow him to use the boys' bathroom.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the school district's motion to dismiss, but the appeals court reversed and remanded, and the district court has since granted a preliminary injunction allowing plaintiff access to the boy's bathroom.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court agreed to hear the school district's appeal in 2016, but later remanded the case after the Department of Education and Department of Justice withdrew their prior guidance on the issue.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the district court to determine whether the plaintiff's graduation from high school rendered the case moot.[SENTMARKER]On May 22, 2018, the district court denied the defendant’s motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff filed a second amended complaint on February 15, 2019, and a motion for summary judgment on March 26, 2019.[SENTMARKER]On August 9, 2019, the court granted the summary judgment; the defendant appealed the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 9, 2014, a student at Gloucester High School in the Gloucester County School Board (GCSB) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia against the GCSB.[SENTMARKER]The student alleged that the School Board's transgender restroom policy violated Title IX and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the student's Title IX claim and denied his request for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The Fourth Circuit vacated the district court's preliminary injunction, and the Supreme Court granted a writ of certiorari.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2005, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed a lawsuit in the Northern District of Alabama against Tyson Foods, Inc. Fourteen current and former African American employees at Tyson's Ashland, Alabama plant filed a lawsuit over the same issues, and the cases were consolidated.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed that Tyson had maintained racially segregated facilities and had subjected African American employees to a racially hostile work environment and retaliation and threats.[SENTMARKER]On November 7, 2006, the parties settled and Plaintiffs received $871,000, while Tyson was required to institute anti-discrimination policies and programs at its Ashland plant.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 11, 2005, the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Alabama, alleging that Tyson Foods, Inc. violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by creating and maintaining a racially segregated bathroom facility at its Ashland, Alabama, facility.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the EEOC alleged that Tyson retaliated against certain employees after they complained about the existence of this racially segregated facility.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which Tyson agreed to pay a total of $871,000 to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In 2006, the EEOC filed this case against Eagle Produce in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged sex and wage discrimination.[SENTMARKER]In 2008 the parties reached a settlement agreement which included monetary compensation, as well as requirements for training and reporting.

gold_sents: In September 2005, the EEOC filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California under Title I and Title VII against Taylor Made Digital Systems.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought injunctive relief and damages, alleging that the defendant discriminated against one of its employees on the basis of her sex (female/pregnant) and race (African American).[SENTMARKER]In October 2006, the court  (Judge Maxine M. pegasus_output_sents: On September 29, 2005, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against Taylor Made Digital Systems, Inc., a subsidiary of Ricoh Company, Ltd., under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Taylor Made subjected a pregnant female employee to unlawful race and sex discrimination when it refused to allow her to return to her position and demoted her.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the defendant violated Title VII by retaliating against any current or former employee who opposed any practice of race discrimination or sex discrimination because of his or her pregnancy.[SENTMARKER]On December 21, 2005, the parties entered into a consent decree, which was approved by Judge Maxine M. Chesney on December 23, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree provided for the defendant to pay a total of $30,600.00 to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also agreed to post on its website its anti-discrimination policy which includes but is not limited to race and pregnancy discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed not to engage in any retaliation against any employee because he or she opposed the practice of sex discrimination or pregnancy discrimination or participated in any manner in any investigation conducted by the defendant.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendant agreed to pay the plaintiff's attorney's fees and costs.

gold_sents: In 2008, six Best Buy employees filed a class action lawsuit against Best Buy alleging discrimination on the bases of race and sex.[SENTMARKER]In 2011, the parties settled.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement provided for the implementation of policies to protect employees against discrimination and monetary relief.[SENTMARKER]On December 8, 2015, the monitor reported that Best Buy had complied with the terms of the consent decree and it thus expired.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 22, 2003, the San Francisco District Office of the EEOC brought this suit against Best Buy Co., Inc. in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Best Buy discriminated against African-American and female employees on the basis of race, color, national origin, and/or gender.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in which Best Buy agreed to pay the plaintiffs in the amount of $75,000.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was subject to approval by the court.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties entered into a non-discrimination and anti-harassment agreement, which requires Best Buy to post its anti-retaliation policies on its intranet website, provide training to its general managers regarding the terms of the agreement, and post an annual message from its CEO on its website.[SENTMARKER]Best Buy also agreed not to discriminate against its female employees with respect to job assignments, promotions/ 11 transfers, and exempt compensation.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed in September 2003.

gold_sents: This case was brought by employees of El Paso Corporation against their employer alleging violations of ERISA and the ADEA as a result of the conversion of their pension plans to a cash balance formula.[SENTMARKER]However, the Tenth Circuit ruled that the defendant’s conversion to a cash balance plan was legal, as were the means the company utilized to transition to the new pension plan.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 28, 2004, three former employees of El Paso Corporation filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that El Paso's conversion of its defined benefit pension plan to a cash balance plan violated the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA) and the Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief, monetary relief, and injunctive and declaratory relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted summary judgment to El Paso and El Paso Pension Plan, and denied the plaintiffs' Motion to Certify Class.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On September 29, 2011, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC") brought this lawsuit against Beverage Distributors Company, LLC ("BDC") on behalf of a visually impaired company employee in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado under the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 ("ADA").[SENTMARKER]The EEOC claimed that BDC discriminated against the employee in violation of the ADA when it conditioned his employment on the results of a medical exam and subsequently refused to hire him as a night warehouse loader upon learning that he had a disability.[SENTMARKER]The jury initially awarded the employee $132,347 in back pay, but it found that his damages should be reduced by $102,803 because he could have mitigated those damages by finding a comparable position.[SENTMARKER]On December 9, 2013, the District Court vacated these findings and awarded injunctive relief, only to be reversed by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit because of erroneous jury instructions.[SENTMARKER]The 10th Circuit denied the EEOC's petition for rehearing in May 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in December 2015, and the matter appears to be closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 9, 2012, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado against Beverage Distributors Company, LLC (BDC), a wholesale liquor distribution company.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that BDC violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) when it withdrew its conditional offer of employment as a Night Warehouse Loader upon being informed that Mr. Mike Sungaila was legally blind and terminated his employment.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the EEOC's motion for summary judgment, and the parties entered into a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The decree required BDC to hire an outside consultant to provide employee training and assistance in revisions to BDC's policies, job postings, notice posting, and reporting and compliance review.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also required the defendant to report its compliance with the decree to the Court within six months of the decree's entry.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, Beverage Distributors asked the court to postpone the decree until the Tenth Circuit rules on the issue of whether BDC should be required to hire a consultant.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Female financial advisers employed by Morgan Stanley sued under Title VII and the Federal Age Discrimination in Employment Act, alleging that Morgan Stanley had a systemic pattern and practice of discriminating against female employees in compensation, promotions, and other areas.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled, with Morgan Stanley paying $46m in damages, fees, and costs of administration, and agreeing to injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]This case was later consolidated with Amochaev v. Citigroup Global Markets Inc.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 22, 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC") filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against Morgan Stanley Co., Inc. ("MS-GWMG"), formerly known as Morgan Stanley DW Inc., alleging discrimination in violation of federal and applicable state civil rights laws.[SENTMARKER]The Named Plaintiffs alleged that MS-GW MG discriminated against them and a class of similarly situated persons on the basis of their sex in several aspects of their employment.[SENTMARKER]The parties engaged the services of Hunter Hughes, Esq., a highly experienced professional mediator, skilled in mediation of complex class actions, including employment discrimination litigation.[SENTMARKER]On April 23, 2007, the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the settlement agreement were as follows: The parties jointly appointed a diversity monitor ("Diversity Monitor") to monitor MSSB's efforts to carry out its non-Discrimination and anti-Harassment Policy, including its prohibition against retaliation, to all employees upon hire (in hard copy or by electronic mail) and then on an annual basis via email from the CEO of Morgan Stanley.[SENTMARKER]MSSB shall provide all management-level field sales personnel with diversity training no less than every other year.[SENTMARKER]The complaint reporting process and the Diversity Monitor's role in the review of individual complaints will expire on September 30, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The term for the programmatic provisions of the Settlement is five years.[SENTMARKER]On July 17, 2007, the District Court granted the parties' Joint Motion for Approval of the Class Action Settlement Agreement.[SENTMARKER]On October 26, 2007, the United States District Court of Columbia granted final approval of the Morgan Stanley Settlement Agreement and dismissed this Action.

pegasus_output_sents: On August 2, 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Delaware against I.G.[SENTMARKER]Burton Company, Inc., a subsidiary of LG.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that LG.[SENTMARKER]Burton subjected certain individuals to disparate treatment on the basis of their ages, seventy-five (75) and above, by discharging them from employment based on their age.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Consent Decree, which was final and binding.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree provided for monetary relief in the amount of $222,,000.00, less all lawful deductions to John Collison.[SENTMARKER]The decree also provided for training on the requirements of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967, as amended, 29 U.N.C.[SENTMARKER]621-24 (the "ADEA"), and required the defendant to provide the EEOC with any and all copies of pamphlets, brochures, outlines or other M'itlen matials provided to the participants of the training sessions upon request.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated the ADEA by terminating the complainants based on age, and that the complaint was filed prior to the date of the defendant's receipt of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The complainants alleged that they were terminated from their positions as "Runners" because they were older than 75 years old.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also allegedly terminated them from their position as runners based on the fact that they did not speak English.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on October 2, 2007.

gold_sents: On June 30, 2004, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this Title VII sex discrimination and retaliation suit in the Fort Lauderdale U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida against DTG Operations, Inc., (doing business as Dollar Rent A Car) on behalf of a female employee.[SENTMARKER]The employee intevened in the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent decree that provided for monetary relief ($395,000) and injunctive relief, such as antidiscrimination, antiretaliation, training, and notice-posting provisions.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 30, 2004, the Miami District Office of the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida against DTG Operations, Inc. d/b/a Dollar Rent a Car, a nationwide rental car company, under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant subjected a female employee to a sexually hostile work environment and retaliated against her for opposing sexual harassment by discharging her from her position.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree on October 7, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the defendant to: provide a complete copy of its policy against sexual harassment and retaliation within thirty days of the entry of this Decree; provide the EEOC with the name, home address, and home phone number of any person who alleges that he/she has been subjected to sex harassment while working at any of Defendant's Ft. Lauderdale facilities during the preceding six months; certify to the EEOC every six months that it is in compliance with all aspects of this decree; and conduct a four-hour annual training for all of its managers, supervisory personnel, and lead agents, at its Fort Lauderdale facilities, with specific emphasis on sex harassment discrimination and the proper procedure to be followed if they become aware of sexual harassment in the workplace and/or if they receive a complaint of such discrimination.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendant agreed to pay a total of $395,000 in monetary relief to the charging party, who was the victim of a physical battery at the hands of the defendant's employee, Carlos Tobar.

gold_sents: On January 2013, the EEOC filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida against Bay State Milling Company, alleging violations of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA) and the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). .[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought injunctive and monetary relief as well reinstatement of the affected individual.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed upon a settlement agreement on November 12, 2013.
pegasus_output_sents: The Miami District Office of the EEOC brought this suit against Bay State Milling Company in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA) by failing to hire a qualified applicant for a vacant Miller position because of his age.[SENTMARKER]The parties attempted to reach a pre-litigation settlement through conciliation.[SENTMARKER]On November 5, 2013, the parties filed a joint motion for approval of a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree provided that Bay State would pay the applicant $80,185.66, in two payments of $40,092.83, to settle the EEOC's lawsuit.[SENTMARKER]The decree also included mandatory training for the hiring manager, interviewing officials and the company's human resources department, with an emphasis on age-related discriminatory practices and age sensitivity.[SENTMARKER]The monetary award included back pay and liquidated damages.

gold_sents: In September 2002, the Chicago District Office of the EEOC filed this lawsuit against HQ Global Workplaces, Inc. in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois alleging discrimination on the basis of disability and retaliation in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the EEOC alleged that the defendant maintained policies on leave and part-time status availability precluding reasonable accommodation in violation of the ADA, terminated complainant based on her disability, and disciplined complainant's manager for providing complainant with a reasonable accommodation.[SENTMARKER]Following some discovery, the parties jointly dismissed the lawsuit in May 2003.

gold_sents: The EEOC filed suit against Sears Roebuck and Company, alleging that Sears violated the Americans with Disabilities Act by enacting an inflexible workers compensation policy, and failing to provide reasonable accommodations to employees seeking to return to work after injury.[SENTMARKER]The court approved a consent decree, which required payment to individual claimants, revision of policies, recordkeeping, reporting, and training.[SENTMARKER]The matter appears to be closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 10, 2004, the Chicago office of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against Sears, Roebuck and Company.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Sears violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to accommodate a class of employees with disabilities by terminating them at the end of a period of leave rather than accommodating them.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, one of the employees, John Bava, was terminated because Sears' inflexible one year leave policy did not provide for reasonable accommodation and which instead provided for termination of employment, all in violation of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the EEOC's motion to dismiss the case on September 29, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which Sears agreed to pay the EEOC $75,000 in damages and to provide reasonable accommodation to all of its Chicago-area employees who lost their jobs because of Sears' one-year worker's compensation or medical-disability leave policy.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also required Sears to provide the EEOC with a copy of its policies and procedures regarding disability and medical leave.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed not to discriminate on the basis of race, color, religion, sex, pregnancy, or national origin in the future.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On February 9, 2006, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Illinois filed this lawsuit against the Board of Trustees of Southern Illinois University ("SIU Board"), alleging that the Board violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 ("Title VII").[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the SIU Board maintained and continued to maintain paid fellowship programs open only to students who are either of a specified race and/or national origin or who are female.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree on February 9, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The decree, which was entered by Judge J. gold_sents: In 2001, four former employees of Mid-West Wire Specialties, Inc. filed this class action complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendant discriminated against them on the basis of their sex, female, in violation of Title VII, in that they were sexually harassed by other employees of the defendant and faced retaliation for resisting the sexual advances.[SENTMARKER]In 2002, the parties reached a settlement that awarded monetary damages and backpay for for class members.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in August 2002.
pegasus_output_sents: In August 2001, two female employees of Mid-West Wire Specialties, Inc. filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were subjected to a hostile work environment, quid pro quo sexual harassment, and retaliation in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendant agreed to pay approximately $500 (five hundred dollars) to each of approximately 47 female temporary workers who rendered services at MWWS for at least 20 continuous work days during the period from January 1, 1998 to December 3, 2002.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to implement a new anti-harassment policy with respect to its employees, officers, and supervisors with regard to sexual harassment of female employees.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was preliminarily approved by the court in August 2001 and the parties filed a motion for summary judgment in February 2002.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the motion and entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs in August 2002.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

They alleged DaimlerChrysler engaged in age discrimination, gender discrimination, race discrimination, and violations of the American with Disabilities Act (ADA).[SENTMARKER]As discovery progressed various plaintiffs were added and some were dismissed from the case.[SENTMARKER]Settlement negations concerning the remaining plaintiffs resulted in individual settlement agreements.[SENTMARKER]The exact terms of these settlements are not available.[SENTMARKER]The case was completely dismissed on October 29th, 2002.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 21, 1991, a group of African-American and female employees of DaimlerChrysler filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA), and Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DaimlerChrysler violated the ADA by creating and condoned a work environment that is hostile to women and African-Americans with regard to promotion, training, and skills qualification.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that the defendant discriminated against them by denying them the same rights as enjoyed by white employees as regards the making, performance, modification and termination of their employment relationship with DaimlerChrysler and to the enjoyment of all benefits, privileges, terms and conditions of that relationship.[SENTMARKER]On July 12, 2000, the plaintiffs filed a charge of discrimination in violation of the ADA against DaimlerChrysler Corporation and the International Union of the United Auto Workers Local Union.[SENTMARKER]On November 30, 2000, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss the complaint pursuant to Fed.R.Civ.P.[SENTMARKER]United States District Court  4.03 (Rockford) V.[SENTMARKER]Defendant DaimlerChrysler Corporation FINAL REPLY memorandum by defendant Daimler Chrysler in support of its motion to dismissal [31] (FCe) (Entered: 03/01/2001).[SENTMARKER]On July 26, 2001, the District Court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the case was closed.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Financial advisors who sued their employer, Merrill Lynch & Co., Inc., for race and gender discrimination in compensation did not state a plausible claim, so their complaint was dismissed pursuant to Title VII Section 703(h), which allows employers to compensate employees differently on the basis of seniority, merit, or quality or quantity of production.[SENTMARKER]The differences in compensation are only unlawful when they result from an intention to discriminate because of race, color, religion, sex or national origin.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2005, a group of black brokers at Merrill Lynch filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 against Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith Incorporated and Bank of America Corporation.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged racial discrimination in hiring, compensation, account distribution, and “teaming” (the grouping of brokers that handle particular accounts) and seeking to litigate the claims as a class.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the plaintiffs’ initial motion for class certification in August 2010 and dismissed the entire case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]In July 2012, the plaintiffs appealed to the United States Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs, and the district court granted the plaintiffs' motion to amend the complaint.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: In December 2013, the EEOC brought this suit against Bright Petroleum for scrutinizing, disciplining and discharging against its female employee who filed a charge of sex discrimination with the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC and Bright Petroleum entered a three-year consent decree on December 12, 2014.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 23, 2013, the Indianapolis District Office of the EEOC filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Indiana against The Bright Market, Inc. and its owners, June and Jay Tucker.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the defendants violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by subjecting a female employee to scrutiny, discipline, and termination because she filed a charge of discrimination with the Commission.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a pre-litigation settlement on December 19, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree, which was approved by Judge Sarah Evans Barker.[SENTMARKER]The decree requires the defendants to pay $15,000 in back wages plus interest and compensatory and punitive damages to the employee.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed not to retaliate against any employee or former employee who files a complaint with the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: On December 19, 2005 a group of former employees of the Boeing Company filed suit in the United States District Court of Kansas against the Boeing Company (Boeing), Spirit Aerosystems Inc. (Spirit), the Onex Corporation (Onex) and Midwestern Aircraft (Midwestern).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory, injunctive and monetary relief as well as class certification, alleging pattern or practice of age discrimination, disparate impact and disparate treatment by the defendants during the layoff and rehire process, in connection with Boeing's sale of its commercial airplane manufacturing facilities to Onex.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs brought eight claims, two of which were dismissed during the pleading stage, five were dismissed as the District Court granted summary judgment in the defendants' favor in two separate opinions.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the 10th Circuit Court, but the 10th Circuit affirmed the lower court's decisions.[SENTMARKER]The remaining claim in the case after the Circuit Court decision was the plaintiffs' ADEA claim of disparate treatment.[SENTMARKER]A number of individual plaintiffs settled with defendants.[SENTMARKER]After the plaintiffs failed to appear at a hearing on a motion to dismiss, Judge Melgran granted the motion.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed on February 9, 2015, and the appeal was dismissed on June 16, 2015 for failure to prosecute.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 24, 2008, former employees of The Boeing Company (Boeing) filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Kansas against The Onex Corporation (Onex) and its parent company, Professional Risk Management, Inc. gold_sents: In February 2001, the EEOC brought this Title VII sex discrimination action against the Jonesboro Manufacturing Company on behalf of an employee who claimed that a male coworker repeatedly made inappropriate sexual comments to her, and after she complained nothing was done.[SENTMARKER]The defense immediately filed a motion to dismiss for failure to timely serve the summons and complaint.[SENTMARKER]While this motion was pending, the EEOC voluntarily dismissed the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 20, 1996, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (ECF) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Louisiana against Jonesboro Manufacturing Co., a Monroe, Louisiana-based manufacturing company.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant had engaged in unlawful employment practices in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the complaint alleged a pattern of sexual harassment and retaliation against female employees who complained to the Defendant's management about the defendant's treatment of female employees.[SENTMARKER]The defendant agreed to pay a total of $100,000 to the complainants.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: On August 22, 2005, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this Title VII retaliation claim against Tasa, Inc., (doing business as Orr Minden Country Chevrolet) on behalf of a black employee who had a pending race discrimination charge and no discipline or warnings at the time of his firing.[SENTMARKER]The complaint was filed with a joint motion for a consent decree, which the Court (Donald E. Walter) approved on November 11, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the decree provided for damages ($60,000 to the employee) and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties bore their own costs.[SENTMARKER]Under the decree, Tasa, Inc., had to provide annual Title VII training to all employees in Louisiana, to post an EEOC poster in a conspicuous location, to report to the EEOC annually the date, attendees, and subject matters of the Title VII trainings, and to institute and follow a promotion policy.[SENTMARKER]The promotion policy required that all vacant positions be posted before an employee is promoted to the positions, that all qualified candidates be interviewed, and that all applications, resumes, and interview notes be maintained.[SENTMARKER]The decree expired automatically after three years.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 17, 2003, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Louisiana against Tasa, Inc. d/b/a Orr Minden Country Chevrolet.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by discharging an African American employee in retaliation for filing a charge of discrimination against the defendant with the Commission.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendant agreed to pay the plaintiff injunctive and monetary relief, to institute and follow promotion policies and procedures pursuant to which, for the duration of this decree, it shall post all vacant positions before promoting any employee to the position, and to conduct an annual training program for all of its officials, managers, supervisors and employees.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the defendant to provide the plaintiff with a copy of its anti-retaliation policy and procedures.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is subject to final approval by the court.

gold_sents: On April 13, 2015, a transgender man who was fired when he refused to sign an agreement to present and be treated as a woman at work as a condition of his employment filed a Title VII sex discrimination claim in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC later intervened in the case.[SENTMARKER]District Judge Carl Barbier directed the parties to arbitrate the case pursuant to an arbitration agreement between the plaintiff and his employer.[SENTMARKER]After the conclusion of the arbitration, which yielded monetary relief for the individual plaintiff, the EEOC continued to litigate the case to obtain injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]Judge Barbier entered an 18-month consent decree which required the defendant retrain its employees and post notice of what constitutes a violation of equal employment opportunity policies.
pegasus_output_sents: The EEOC brought this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana against First Tower Loan, LLC, doing business as Tower Loan of Lake Charles, alleging that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Louisiana Employment Discrimination Law by terminating a transgender employee because of his sex.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the termination constituted unlawful discrimination on the basis of gender identity, sex stereotypes, and gender identity in violation of Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed by Judge Carl Barbier on December 10, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree on December 5, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the defendant to comply with the terms of its anti-discrimination policies and to report any complaints of discrimination to its Human Resources office.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the defendants to pay the EEOC's costs and attorney's fees incurred in the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be dismissed because the defendant had not admitted or specifically denied any unlawful employment practices.
