pegasus_output_sents: On July 8, 2004, the Baltimore District Office of the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against Avado Brands, Inc. d/b/a Don Pablo's Restaurant.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by engaging in racial discrimination and retaliation against a female employee.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendant agreed to pay the female employee in the amount of $50,000.00 for her economic losses, compensatory damages, and punitive damages in accordance with the defendant's Chapter 11 Joint Plan of Reorganization approved by the United States Bankruptcy Court.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the defendant to provide two (2) hours of anti-harassment training to all management employees at its Maryland facilities concerning race and national origin, prohibition against retaliation and other laws enforced by the EEOC, and provide a list of all employees who have attended and compieted training within a period of two (2) years from the date of the entry of this Decree.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also agreed to post in all or places where notices to employees are customarily posted in the state of Maryland, and maintain tor two years from date of posting, a copy of the 1'oticc attached hereto as Exhihit Band Inude a part hereof.[SENTMARKER]Each party shall hear its OVn costs.[SENTMARKER]The court retained jurisdiction of this action to ensure compliance with the decree.

gold_sents: On September 30, 2004, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC"), on behalf of an African American employee (plaintiff-intervenor), filed a lawsuit in the District Court of Maryland, under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991, against Coca-Cola Enterprises, Inc.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought injunctive relief, compensatory damages, punitive damages, attorneys' fees, and other forms of affirmative relief claiming that the defendant did not promote the plaintiff-intervenor because of his race, African American.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree where the defendant, among other things, agreed to promote the plaintiff-intervenor to a higher-paying position as well as pay him $60,500.
pegasus_output_sents: The Baltimore District Office of the EEOC brought this suit against Coca-Cola Enterprises, Inc. in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by refusing to promote Mark Mason to the position of Field Service Manager because of his race, African-American.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also allegedly discriminated on the basis of race in the wages and other compensation and benefits that were paid to Mr. Mason.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendant agreed to pay the plaintiff $150,000 in damages and provide two hours of training for all managers above the grade 15 level in the Baltimore/Washington Cooler Service Department.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered by Judge Benson Everett Legdale on October 1, 2005.

gold_sents: The case was brought by African American employees of Friedman's, a jewelry store, and sought equitable and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged they had suffered from working in a racially hostile work environment and alleged that Friedman's had engaged in a pattern and practice of racial discrimination in hiring, promotion, compensation, and other terms and privileges of employment.[SENTMARKER]The case was finally settled on February 12, 2009, after Friedman's had entered into bankruptcy two times.[SENTMARKER]The named plaintiffs and class members received over a million dollars for costs with a portion to cover attorneys' fees.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 6, 2003, African American employees of Friedman's, Inc. filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against St. Paul Mercury Insurance Company (St. Paul) alleging racial discrimination in employment practices.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Friedman’s had created and maintained a system-wide policy and/or pattern or practice of race-based disparate treatment that limits the employment opportunities of African Americans.[SENTMARKER]The parties sought declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as monetary and punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]On September 30, 2004, the parties filed a bankruptcy petition in the Southern District of Georgia.[SENTMARKER]On January 14, 2005, the parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the parties agreed to pay a total of $1 million to African American applicants who applied for employment at the company in any retail store or in the store organization between March 6, 1999 and December 9, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to create an Employee Settlement Pool, which would be used to fund the settlement.[SENTMARKER]On March 26, 2003, the parties engaged in mediation, but the mediation failed to produc a settlement and the case was administratively closed on September 30, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a motion for summary judgment, which was denied by the court on January 14, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties are continuing to negotiate the settlement agreement.

gold_sents: On August 28, 2017, six transgender individuals currently serving in the United States military filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Maryland Maryland contesting the President's ban on transgender service in the U.S. military.[SENTMARKER]Judge Garbis initially granted a motion for a preliminary injunction in September, but this was later stayed in 2019 when the Supreme Court issued a stay of this nationwide injunction in two factually similar cases contesting the ban.[SENTMARKER]This case changed dramatically in 2018 when the government altered its policy on transgender service in the military, eliminating an outright ban and instead putting new guidance on transgender men and women entering the service.[SENTMARKER]Judge Russell, reassigned to the case in 2018, dissolved the preliminary injunction, saying that it was only meant to stay a complete ban on transgender service in the military.[SENTMARKER]This also dismissed all claims against the 2017 outright ban as moot, and removed all plaintiffs that were already in the service and not seeking to join.[SENTMARKER]Discovery is ongoing in the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 9, 2017, a group of transgender service members filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Defense (D.C.) alleging that the Defense Department's new policy on transgender personnel violated the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction, enjoining enforcement of the Accession and Retention Directives and reverting the policy to the status quo that had existed before the Presidential Memorandum Id.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted in part and denied in part the plaintiffs' cross-motions for summary judgment and remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]In light of the Supreme Court's decision in the case, the defendants moved for the Court to stay the nationwide effect of the District Court’s preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]On January 4, 2019, the Court vacated without prejudice the preliminary injunction and remanded.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit issued its decision in Karnoski on June 16, 2019, concluding that Plaintiffs had established a likelihood of success on the merits of their equal protection claim.[SENTMARKER]The Court also dismissed Plaintiffs’ claim with regard to declaratory relief.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2016, three Pocomoke City, Maryland police officers filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they suffered racial discrimination and retaliation by their employer in violation of their First and Fourteenth Amendment rights and the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]In 2019, two of the officers reached a partial settlement with Pocomoke City requiring adoption of anti-discrimination policies and procedures by the police department and awarding monetary damages to the officers.[SENTMARKER]As of September 30, 2020, the case is still ongoing pending a final settlement.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 26, 2015, the Baltimore District Office of the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the Pocomoke City Police Department, the Worcester County Sheriff's Office, and the State of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs alleged racial discrimination in violation of Title VII and retaliation for complaining of racial harassment.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree on March 16, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The decree, which was entered into with the consent of the parties, requires the defendants to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and other costs.[SENTMARKER]The decree is subject to final approval by the court.

gold_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this Title VII racial-harassment and retaliation suit against A & R Truss Company for violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 U.S.C. § 2000e et.[SENTMARKER]seq.).[SENTMARKER]Alleging that Defendant had repeatedly subjected a black employee at the New Buffalo facility to racially offensive epithets and had met the employee's complaints with threats and intimidation, the EEOC sought monetary and injunctive relief, including compensation for emotional harm and punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a one-year consent decree that provided monetary and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The employee received $20,000.[SENTMARKER]A & R Truss was subject to an array of anti-harassment, anti-retaliation, training, policy, and notice provisions.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 15, 2005, the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Michigan against A R Truss Company.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant engaged in unlawful employment practices or otherwise ratified such practices which violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and its prohibitions against racial harassment of its employees.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on March 2, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay $25,000 in non-pecuniary damages to the complainant and to implement a race discrimination and harassment policy and complaint procedure.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the defendant to provide training to its current managers, and any new managers hired during the effective dates of this decree, on Title VII, as amended and its prohibited harassment based on race and other protected status.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendant agreed to post a notice in a conspicuous place which sets forth its anti-harassment policy within ten days of its first day of work, and to provide new employees with its employee handbook within one year of its entry into the decree.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is subject to final approval by the court.

gold_sents: In December 2013, the EEOC brought this suit against Guardsmark, LLC for discharging its employee who opposed sexually inappropriate conduct in the workplace.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent decree in September 2016, which provided Guardsmark would not retaliate against employees, would train employees on retaliation and sexual harassment, and Guardsmark would pay 115,000 in monetary relief to plaintiff-intervenor.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 24, 2013, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against Guardsmark, LLC, a security company that provides security services to General Dynamics Land Systems, Inc., alleging that Guardsmark violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by discharging an employee in retaliation for his role in a woman's sexual harassment complaint.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant retaliated against the employee by firing him in response to his opposing sexually inappropriate conduct in the workplace.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought monetary compensation for the employee, including back pay and compensatory damages for emotional distress, as well as punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree on July 9, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The decree was entered by Judge Victoria A. Melonie and was effective on September 6, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The decree requires the defendant to pay the employee back pay, provide training on sexual harassment and retaliation to all employees assigned to the General Dynamics facility in Sterling Heights, Michigan, and not withhold any amounts from payment of compensatory damages or attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The decree also prohibits the defendant from retaliating against an employee who has made an internal complaint of employment discrimination or contacted the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is subject to final approval by the court.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs filed an age discrimination action against Seagate US, LLC. pegasus_output_sents: On December 23, 2008, a group of former Seagate employees filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Minnesota under the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA) against Seagate Technology, Inc. and Seagate Holdings, LLC.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Seagate engaged in a pattern or practice of age discrimination in connection with terminations, selection process, opportunities for open positions and hiring, and that the plaintiffs were disparately impacted by Seagate's practices, policies and procedures, in violation of the ADEA.[SENTMARKER]The class sought declaratory and injunctive relief, including the enforcement of a release and waiver that was signed by many of the plaintiffs upon the termination of their employment with Seagate.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for decertification in part and denied the motion for certification in part.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In December 2004 plaintiff, a quadriplegic who was not hired by defendant, alleged that defendant's employment practices were discriminatory under Title I of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 and under Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991.[SENTMARKER]The case went to trial and the jury found in favor of the defendant and awarded $11,478.87 in costs against the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff appealed the judgment to the 11th Circuit and on March 13, 2009 the appellate court issued an opinion affirming the lower court.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On September 21, 2007, the EEOC filed a claim in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991 on behalf of two aggrieved female employees.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that Defendant, Bodega Bars, engaged in unlawful employment practices on the basis of sex.[SENTMARKER]In 2008, the parties entered into a consent decree that required the Defendant to not engage in sex discrimination or sexual harassment of employees, establish a sexual harassment policy and training program for employees, as well as pay monetary damages to the two aggrieved employees.[SENTMARKER]The case is presumed closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 21, 2007, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri against Bodega Bars USA, d/b/a Mosaic Restaurant.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by committing unlawful employment practices with respect to its employees, Aimee Boss and Morgan Hagedon, subjecting them to sexual harassment by its customer and investor, and constructively discharging them.[SENTMARKER]On July 2, 2008, the court entered a Consent Decree, which required the defendant to adopt a sexual harassment policy, develop and post a complaint procedure notice on its employee bulletin board or similar location in all of its restaurants, post a copy of its sexual harassment training to all managers, and keep records of any and all internal complaints of possible sexual harassment received during the term of the Consent Decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was in force for a period of two years from the date of receipt of each complaint, and the parties were responsible for their own attorneys' fees and costs of this litigation.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendant agreed to pay a total of $10,000, exclusive of interest, to the plaintiff-intervenors.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the settlement agreement were subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was subject to the defendant's compliance with the terms and conditions of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this Title VII retaliation suit against Quik-Chek, Inc. on behalf of a black employee.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that Quik-Chek had fired the employee in retaliation for complaining about racial discrimination and threatening litigation over the discrimination and the company's response to her complaints.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in mediation, which the Court entered as a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The decree provided $11,500 to the employee and contained an array of injunctive provisions.[SENTMARKER]Defendant had ceased business operations, and the decree included provisions, such as antidiscrimination training and EEOC reporting, that would activate if Defendant resumed business activities.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 28, 2006, the EEOC filed this suit against Quik-Chek, Inc. in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by discharging Wanda Smith in retaliation for her complaints about racial discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendant agreed not to discriminate against any person on the basis of race or any other protected category within the meaning of Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the defendant to report compliance with Title VII to the EEOC within fifteen days of the entry of the decree, to provide a neutral letter of reference to Smith, and to provide an annual training program to all of its managers, supervisors, and employees.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed to pay Smith the sum of $11,500.00 in settlement of the claims raised in this action.[SENTMARKER]The term of this decree was five years from its entry by the Court.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: In August 2006, the EEOC brought this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina on behalf of two female employees of Cinelli's restaurant.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the company violated Title VII by subjecting two female employees to a sexually hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]In 2008, the court entered a default judgment because the defendant failed to respond.[SENTMARKER]The employees were awarded approximately $87,674 in back pay, compensatory damages, and punitive damages.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 3, 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina against S.G.T.[SENTMARKER]Cinelli's, Inc., d/b/a Cinelli’s Ristorante, Inc, alleging that the defendants violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and Title I of the civil rights act of 1991 by subjecting a class of similarly situated women to a hostile work environment and by constructively discharging them as a result of the harassment.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the harassment included, but was not limited to, unwelcome sexual comments and gestures, as well as touching such as hugging, kissing and biting the women's buttocks.[SENTMARKER]The harassment was perpetrated by one of the defendants' managers who was in the women’s direct line of supervision.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought a permanent injunction, damages, and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the EEOC's motion for summary judgment, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the defendants to pay the EEOC a total of $325,000.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to implement anti-harassment and anti-discrimination policies and procedures.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: EEOC's Charlotte, NC office filed this lawsuit alleging discrimination based on national origin against the defendant, Sears, Roebuck & Co. in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina (Eastern Division) on 09/16/1998.[SENTMARKER]EEOC alleged on behalf of a job applicant who was a naturalized American of Mexican origin that the defendant refused to hire him because of his national origin and specifically Spanish accent.[SENTMARKER]The district court's granting of summary judgement to the defendant was reversed on appeal.[SENTMARKER]The defendant and the applicant settled and voluntarily dismissed his part of the case, while the EEOC and the defendant entered into a 1-year consent decree, which prohibited national origin discrimination and mandated training and posting of an Equal Employment notice.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 16, 1998, the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina, alleging that Sears, Roebuck and Company failed or refused to hire Francisco G. Santana because of his national origin, Hispanic (Mexican-American) in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII by failing or refusing to hire Santana because he was Hispanic.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted Sears's motion for summary judgment, but the parties appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The appeals court remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a consent decree, which required the defendant to: (a) post an Employee Notice in a place where it is visible to all employees at its Morehead City, North Carolina store; .[SENTMARKER](b) provide annual training to all managers concerning the federal employment discrimination laws, particularly as they apply to Title VII and discrimination due to national origin; .[SENTMARKER](c) provide a copy of its nondiscrimination policy at the time of hire or transfer; and (d) ensure that all management, supervisory and other employees abide by the requirements of that policy, and that employees will not be subjected to discrimination because of national origin.[SENTMARKER]The decree was entered on May 31, 2001 and was for one year from the date of its entry by the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on June 30, 2002.

gold_sents: On August 7, 2007, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) filed a lawsuit under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 against the University of North Carolina in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ, alleging that the defendant discriminated against two female employees by subjecting them to sexual harassment.[SENTMARKER]On April 28, 2008, the Court (Judge Thomas D. Schroeder) entered a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The contained injunctions on gender discrimination and retaliation, and orders to modify harassment complaints procedure, and to provide anti-discrimination training.[SENTMARKER]Individuals received monetary damages of $55,000 total.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 7, 2007, the U.S. Department of Justice's Office of Civil Rights and the Office of Equal Employment Opportunity (EEOC) filed this suit against North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University (NCATSU) in the United States District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by subjecting two female employees to sexual harassment that affected their terms, conditions, and privileges in violation of Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree on April 28, 2008.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the defendant to: (a) modify its anti-discrimination policies and procedures that prohibit sex discrimination under Title VII; .[SENTMARKER](b) provide, at its own cost, mandatory training on the law of equal employment opportunity and prohibited discrimination based on sex to all supervisory employees in NCATSU’s Department of Police and Public Safety, including the Chief, Majors, Captains, Lieutenants, Sergeants, and Sergeants; .[SENTMARKER](c) pay the two employees a total of $266,000; .[SENTMARKER](d) distribute and post all General Orders pertaining to complaints and investigations of sexual harassment in the DPPS; and (e) provide the defendants with a copy of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The decree is subject to review by the court at any time.

gold_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this Title VII retaliation suit against Blackwell's Book Services on behalf of a black employee.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the employee was  abruptly fired in retaliation for passing on complaints of racial discrimination and harassment and in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 U.S.C. § 2000e et.[SENTMARKER]seq.).[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought its costs and monetary and injunctive relief for the employee, including a retaliation prohibition, back pay, job search expenses, compensation for emotional harm, and punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]The employee intervened, bringing claims for hostile work environment, impairment of contract, and violation of New Jersey law.[SENTMARKER]The employee later dismissed her claims voluntarily, and the EEOC and Blackwell's entered a settlement agreement, which the Court entered as a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]Under the2-year decree, the employee received $65,000, and Balckwell's was subject to an array of injunctive provisions.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 3, 2004, the Philadelphia District Office of the EEOC brought this suit against Blackwell's Book Services, Inc. in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by firing an African American employee after she complained about racial harassment by a white supervisor at the defendant's facility.[SENTMARKER]The defendant denied the EEOC's allegations.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree, which was entered into on May 31, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendant to pay the plaintiff injunctive and monetary relief, provide training to its employees, maintain records of all actions it took to prevent discrimination and harassment during the term of its employment, post a notice of its compliance with Title VII, and provide the EEOC with copies of all written materials provided to at least one of its facilities.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the EEOC to certify to the EEOC in writing within 10 business days after the training sessions required by the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on May 30, 2005.

On May 27, 2008, the court ruled in favor of the defendants and awarded no relief.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 6, 2005, the New Jersey District Office of the EEOC brought this suit against U.S. Aluminum, Inc., United Automobile, Aerospace Agricultural Implement Workers of America Local 1668, and United States Bronze Powders Inc. in the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA) by reducing the severance benefits of two employees because of their age.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also allegedly violated the National Labor Relations Act (NLRA) and the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA).[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to pay the two employees a total of $140,000 in back pay, liquidated damages, and attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was entered into by the parties on June 10, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to a joint and several joint motion for summary judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on June 11, 2006.

gold_sents: On August 9, 2004, the plaintiff filed this class action lawsuit in the Eastern District of New York on behalf of all Hispanic and/or non-white refreshment concession personnel who were hired, employed or offered employment by the defendants, Restaurant Associates and RA Tennis Corp.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants engaged in unlawful employment discrimination on the basis of national origin and race respecting the assignment of positions and locations to food vendors employed at the U.S. Open Tennis Tournament.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, they alleged that the defendants were deliberately and overwhelmingly assigning beer wagons to non-Hispanic white people over other demographics.[SENTMARKER]The parties soon reached a settlement which was approved by U.S. District Court Judge Robert M.[SENTMARKER]Levy, and Restaurant Associates agreed to pay damages.[SENTMARKER]This case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 10, 2004, a former employee of Restaurant Associates, Inc. and RA Tennis Corp. filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants discriminated against Hispanic and non-white employees of the US Open Tennis Tournament in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the New York City Employment Non-Discrimination Act.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay a total of $90,000 to each of the 279 class members.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was approved by Judge Dora Lizette Irizarry of the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit on September 10, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion for class certification in December of 2005, which was denied by the Court.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: This case was brought in 2004 by a class of plaintiffs (composed of nearly 1,000 black current and former employees of Kodak) against Eastman Kodak Co. in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York, alleging that Kodak engaged in an ongoing pattern or practice of racial discrimination against African-American employees.[SENTMARKER]This case was settled in 2009 with Defendants agreeing to implement non-discriminatory employment practices and to pay damamges to the class.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 30, 2004, a former employee of Eastman Kodak Co. filed a class-wide discrimination complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York against the company.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Kodak discriminated against African American employees by creating a hostile work environment and by retaliating against employees who participated in protected activities.[SENTMARKER]Kodak agreed to pay $21,376,500 to settle the case.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the United States District Court in the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]On March 11, 2004, the district court granted Texaco's motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on March 1, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The agreement provides for the payment of $10 million in back pay, as well as $3 million in annual raises, to correct race and gender inequalities dating to 1996.[SENTMARKER]Kodak will continue to maintain its existing non-discrimination and anti-retaliation policies designed to assure equal employment opportunity for its employees.

gold_sents: This 2017 lawsuit was brought by three detectives of the NYPD in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the City of New York and various agents of the NYPD had violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by implementing a secretive policy of refusing to promote deserving African American detectives solely based on race.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a confidential settlement that was reported to include $700,000 in damages to cover backpay and loss of reputation.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 14, 2011, the EEOC filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the New York City Police Department (NYPD) alleging that the NYPD's Intelligence Division discriminated against African-American detectives by denying or delaying their promotions solely based on race.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the Intelligence Division's secretive and unstructured promotions policy, administered by white supervisors, violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 42 U.C.[SENTMARKER]2000e et seq., and New York's Executive Law  141.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the Circuit Court for Seminole County, Florida on September 14, 2016.[SENTMARKER]On March 4, 2016, the EEOC issued a final determination in favor of the charging parties, concluding that there is reasonable cause to believe that the City violated the Title VII individually and collectively.[SENTMARKER]After conciliation failed, the EEOC referred the case to the United States Department of Justice, which reviewed the matter and determined that it did not file suit.[SENTMARKER]On June 26, 2017, DOJ issued a notice stating that Named Plaintiffs had 90 days from receipt of that notice to file suit against the NYPD.[SENTMARKER]On September 26, 2018, the case was assigned to Judge Gregory H. Summons of the Court.[SENTMARKER]The deadline for the parties to submit a stipulation of settlement and dismissal is extended to May 1, 2019.[SENTMARKER]On May 17, 2019, the parties submitted a follow-up letter to the Court requesting that the case be dismissed on behalf of a class of all others similarly situated.[SENTMARKER]On November 26, 2019, the Court granted the parties' motion for summary judgment, and the parties agreed to a settlement agreement.

gold_sents: Current and former Black FDNY employees sued the City of New York alleging racial discrimination in their hiring, promotion, and compensation practices.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought to represent a class of individuals similarly situated who suffered from FDNY's policies that afforded too much discretion to higher-level individuals and fostered a culture of favoritism that harmed Black candidates for hiring and advancement.[SENTMARKER]The City filed a motion to dismiss and the Court partially granted the motion, but sustained the plaintiffs' claims related to the hiring and promotion practices with the FDNY.[SENTMARKER]The City moved for partial summary judgment in May 2020, arguing that the retired class representatives could not seek relief.[SENTMARKER]At the same time, the plaintiffs moved to certify the class.[SENTMARKER]Both motions were pending as of February 11, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: In December 2017, a group of African American employees of the Fire Department of New York (the "FDNY") filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of the New York, alleging that the FDNY discriminated against African American non-uniformed ("Civilian") employees and job applicants in hiring, placement, advancement, and compensation decisions.[SENTMARKER]In response to the ongoing discrimination, the United States brought suit in May 2007 under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, alleging that FDNY's procedures for screening and selecting applicants for entry-level firefighter positions discriminated against black and Hispanic applicants under a disparate impact theory.[SENTMARKER]In September 2007, the court granted the intervenors' motion for summary judgment on their pattern-or-practice claims as well.[SENTMARKER]The next year, the parties entered into a settlement concerning both monetary relief and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]Two years later, in 2015, the parties agreed to settle the case for racial discrimination and retaliation.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) and the plaintiff-intervenor, the complainant, filed this class action lawsuit against Pitt-Ohio  Express, Inc., a transport company, in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Pitt-Ohio discriminated against women by refusing to hire women as truck drivers or dockworkers, in violation of Title VII 42 U.S.C. § 2000e.[SENTMARKER]On October 1, 2008, the court approved a settlement agreement between the plaintiff-intervenor and Pitt-Ohio.[SENTMARKER]The defendant agreed to pay $265,000 in monetary relief and  $305,000 in attorney fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]That same month, the court approved a consent decree between EEOC and Pitt-Ohio.[SENTMARKER]This decree required the defendant to pay $$2,430,000 to EEOC (to be distributed to women that were affected by the defendant’s discrimination), to adopt anti-discrimination policies, to offer driver and/or dockworker positions to the women that were discriminated against, and regularly report to the EEOC to ensure compliance.[SENTMARKER]This decree had a duration of five years.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 31, 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio against Pitt Ohio Express, LLC (Pitt Ohio) alleging that Pitt Ohio violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by failing to hire a qualified female applicant who applied for a truck driver position at its Cleveland, Ohio terminal.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC's complaint alleged that since September 1997, Pitt Ohio refused to hire or offer positions to qualified female applicants based on their sex.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the EEOC alleged that the defendant failed to comply with Title VII's hiring practices and procedures and recordkeeping violations.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which Pitt Ohio agreed to pay $50,000 to the EEOC, provide training to its executives, managers, and employees, and to implement an equal opportunity component to its policies and procedures.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered on October 8, 2008 and is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In August 2001, the Cleveland District Office filed this lawsuit against Sundance Rehabilitation Corporation in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio alleging violation of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act, Title I of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, the Equal Pay Act of 1963, and Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The complaint specifically alleged that the defendant required terminated employees to sign a waiver of claims against the defendant, including EEO violations, in order to receive severance pay.[SENTMARKER]Following discovery and motions for summary judgment for both parties, the District Court granted summary judgment to the EEOC in July 2004.[SENTMARKER]The defendant appealed the decision to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit in September 2004.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals reversed the District Court's judgment in October 2006.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. Supreme Court granted an extension of time to file a petition for a writ of certiorari in June 2007.[SENTMARKER]However, the docket does not indicate that this option was exercised.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) brought this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio against SunDance Rehabilitation Corporation.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the defendant violated Title VII by requiring employees fired in a reduction in force to waive their rights to file an EEOC charge and to participate in EEOC proceedings as a condition of receiving severance pay.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the EEOC's motion for summary judgment on liability and the EEOC appealed to the Ohio Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court denied the appeal and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 25, 2007 the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) filed a lawsuit against the Village of Woodmere, Ohio in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio to enforce Title VII, 42 U.S.C. §2000e, et seq.[SENTMARKER]The D.O.J.[SENTMARKER]asked the court for injunctive and compensatory relief, alleging the defendant had violated Title VII by discriminating against two employees in the defendant's police department on the basis of their race (white) in termination of their employment.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement and the Court entered a three year consent decree on May 23, 2008.[SENTMARKER]The defendant agreed to implement new policies to deal with racial discrimination complaints and provide mandatory nondiscrimination training.[SENTMARKER]The individuals were to receive monetary awards, and one of them receive reinstatement.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 24, 2008, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio against the Village of Woodmere, Ohio, alleging that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by discharging two former police officers on the basis of their race.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendant agreed to pay the two former officers a total of $26,000 and to implement a policy that prohibits discrimination based on race, including the name and contact information of the former officers.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the defendant to report to the United States any complaint of discrimination made by any individual pursuant to Woodmere's written policies and procedures referenced in paragraph 4 of the decree.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed without further order of the court on July 24, 2008.

gold_sents: On December 9, 2011, an openly gay former employee of Ohio Bell Telephone Company filed suit in U.S District Court for the Northern District of Ohio alleging that he had been dismissed in violation of the ADA, Title VII of the Civil Rights Act, and multiple sections of Ohio's Civil Rights Act. Plaintiff took his husband's last name after the couple was married in Massachusetts and had AIDS and alleged he was fired for those reasons.[SENTMARKER]The court denied Defendant's motion to dismiss and the case settled in September 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 3, 2012, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio against The Ohio Bell Telephone Company (Ohio Bell) alleging discrimination in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (OCRA) and Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (Title VII).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Ohio Bell discriminated against Plaintiff because he was HIV-positive and his same sex partner had been married in another state which recognized same-sex marriages.[SENTMARKER]On October 30, 2009, Ohio Bell terminated Plaintiff's employment because of his seven unexcused absences for his father's funeral.[SENTMARKER]Ohio Bell's Collective Bargaining Agreement with the Communication Workers of America (CWA) indicated which employees were entitled to excused bereavement time off.[SENTMARKER]The CWA filed a motion for summary judgment on all of Koren's claims, arguing that there was no evidence that the plaintiff's termination was based on his gender, and that his termination was unrelated to his disability.[SENTMARKER]Judge James S. Gwin granted summary judgment to Ohio Bell, finding that the CWA's collective bargaining agreement with Ohio Bell did not discriminate against Koren because he is homosexual and that Koren was not converted to a regular sales consultant.[SENTMARKER]Judge Gwin also granted the defendant's motion to dismiss on the basis that it was not a violation of Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On January 18, 2001, the U.S. Department of Justice ("D.O.J.")[SENTMARKER]filed a lawsuit under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 against the City of Sulphur in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Oklahoma alleging that the City discriminated against a Mexican-American employee on the basis of his national origin, when it failed or refused to promote him and took no action to remedy the effects of discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The D.O.J.[SENTMARKER]sought injunctive and monetary relief.[SENTMARKER]On February 23, 2001, the Court entered a consent decree, containing injunctions on discrimination and retaliation, with orders to the defendant to implement a nondiscriminatory policy and antidiscrimination training.[SENTMARKER]The individual received $45,000.[SENTMARKER]The decree expired after five years.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Oklahoma on February 26, 2001 against the City of Sulphur, Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by failing or refusing to hire or promote an employee on the basis of his national origin, Mexican-American, when the employee was denied a promotion to the position of Sanitation Department Superintendent.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree, which was entered by Judge Frank H. Seay on February 21, 2002.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the defendant to comply with the terms of Title VII and to pay the employee in full.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the city to provide training to all of its supervisory personnel on the prohibition against employment discrimination based on national origin.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was subject to approval by the court.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents:
On November 3, 2003, African-American employees of Kraft Foods filed a lawsuit against their employer in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged violations of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 42 U.S.C. 2000e, contending that Kraft had discriminated with regard to discipline and hiring.[SENTMARKER]

The court approved a preliminary settlement agreement on May 1, 2007 in which Kraft agreed to pay $1.325 million and grant other forms of non-monetary relief.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 3, 1999, two current and one former African-American hourly employees of Kraft Foods filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 42 U.S.C.  200e et seq., against Kraft Foods North America, Inc. (Kraft) alleging that Kraft discriminated against African-Americans with respect to job discipline and classification in violation of the terms and conditions of employment because of their race.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Kraft retaliated against African American employees who complained about discrimination in the workplace.[SENTMARKER]According to the plaintiffs' complaint, the plaintiffs allege that Kraft's continued policies and practices of racial discrimination were not remedied by Kraft when Kraft took over the Nabisco brand in 2007.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief, declaratory relief, and equitable financial relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement, which was approved by the court on December 31, 2006.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the settlement, all current and former hourly employees employed at the Kraft Philadelphia Bakery shall be annually and anonymously surveyed to determine their attitudes with regard to workplace fairness.[SENTMARKER]Beginning in 2007, all present hourly employees at the Philadelphia bakery shall be annual and anonymous surveys to determine how they feel about workplace fairness, and the parties agreed that the litigation against Kraft would be stayed except to the extent necessary to effect the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to the court's approval.

gold_sents: Four plaintiffs, on behalf of themselves and others similarly situated, filed a lawsuit against Latrobe Specialty Steel Company for violations of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA).[SENTMARKER]All four plaintiffs were over the age of fifty and were terminated following the discovery of inappropriate emails on their work email accounts.[SENTMARKER]Despite the plaintiffs' claims that the emails were a pretext for age discrimination, the court held that there was no evidence that but for their ages, the plaintiffs would not have been terminated.[SENTMARKER]Thus, the court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendant, which was affirmed by the appellate court.[SENTMARKER]Taxation was assessed against the plaintiffs in the amount of $21,863.88.
pegasus_output_sents: In October 2007, a group of former employees of Latrobe Specialty Steel Company (LSS) filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania under the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA) against LSS.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that LSS targeted a class of employees over the age of forty for termination based largely, if not exclusively, on their age.[SENTMARKER]In fact, the four that were fired, were among the oldest employees in the company.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment in favor of LSS, concluding that the plaintiffs had failed to demonstrate that "but for" their ages, LSS would not have terminated their employment.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Third Circuit affirmed the district court's decision, finding that plaintiffs had not demonstrated that their age was a factor in their termination.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On April 30, 2010, the plaintiff, an African American job applicant with a felony criminal record, filed this class action lawsuit against the defendants, a company and its affiliates which specialized in training truck drivers and placing them with trucking companies.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants refused to procure placement for applicants with a felony conviction, and because of this practice, disparately impacted African American and Latino applicants.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled on August 17, 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 17, 2012, a former truck driver filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against Driver Solutions, Inc., Driver Holdings, LLC, and C&S Acquisitions, Inc, alleging that the defendants violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by denying employment opportunities to African American and Latino applicants based on their criminal histories.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement on January 17, 2012 involving monetary relief of $475,000 and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was entered into voluntarily between the parties and their attorneys without any findings of liability.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the parties' request for a further stay of litigation so that they could revive settlement negotiations in advance of private mediation.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This sexual harassment case was brought by the Memphis office of the EEOC in 2006.[SENTMARKER]The case was resolved by Consent Decree in November 2007 which provided individual relief and also required anti-discrimination training, posting of policies and reports to the EEOC.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 28, 2004, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission brought this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Tennessee against A&I Products, Inc. (A&I) on behalf of two female employees who were subjected to sexual harassment by a co-worker and retaliated against them after they filed a charge of discrimination with the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC's complaint alleged that the two women were subject to unwelcome sexual harassment because of their sex and that the harassment created a hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree, which was approved by Judge Samuel H. Mays Jr. on December 7, 2007.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendant to pay $15,000 to each of the female employees, provide two reports to the EEOC describing the investigation conducted by the defendant in response to each complaint, and provide two hours of employment-discrimination training to all personnel employed at its Memphis facility.[SENTMARKER]The court of appeals reversed the district court's grant of summary judgment on the retaliation claim, and the case is now closed.[SENTMARKER]The case is still ongoing.

gold_sents: The Memphis Office of the EEOC brought this suit against Paramount Staffing, Inc. in September 2006 in the United States District Court for the Western District of Tennessee (Memphis).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged discrimination and retaliation based on race (African American) and national origin (American).[SENTMARKER]The parties settled out of court on a two-year consent decree.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 22, 2004, the Memphis District Office of the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Tennessee against Paramount Staffing, Inc., a Memphis-based temporary staffing agency.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the agency violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by failing to place African-American employees into temporary positions because of their race and national origin and by retaliating against one individual who complained about alleged discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in August 2010.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the agency to post its hiring and placement policies in English and Spanish, publish its non-discrimination and Equal Employment Opportunity policy, and provide training to its management employees to ensure that it has a work environment that is free of discrimination in any form.[SENTMARKER]The decree also prohibited the agency from discriminating on the basis of race, national origin, or retaliation against any employee who participated in the EEOC’s investigation or who otherwise may complain about any discrimination in the workplace.[SENTMARKER]On August 19, 2010, the parties filed a joint motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The motion was denied and the parties agreed to settle the case without further litigation.

gold_sents: In 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) brought this suit against Sharp Manufacturing Company in the U.S. District for the Western District of Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Sharp violated the Americans with Disabilities Act by failing to provide the complainant with reasonable accommodation and discharged her because of her disability.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought injunctive and monetary relief as well as punitive damages against the defendant.[SENTMARKER]In 2009, the court approved the parties’ consent decree.[SENTMARKER]This decree had a duration of one year and instructed the defendant to: refrain from unlawful employment discrimination and retaliation; report to the EEOC on compliance with Title VII; revise its policies on reasonable accommodations; post notices of this agreement in their offices; pay $30,000.00 to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 26, 2004, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Tennessee against Sharp Manufacturing Company of America, a division of Sharp Electronics Corporation.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the defendant violated Title I of the Americans with Disabilities Act (the ADA) by failing to provide a reasonable accommodation and discharging a former employee because of her disability, osteoarthritis.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree on January 23, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the defendant to post a notice at its Memphis, Tennessee facility for an extended period of time containing the terms of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered by Judge S. Thomas Anderson on January 22, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a permanent injunction enjoining the defendant from further discrimination on the basis of disability, as well as back pay, punitive damages, and other forms of relief.[SENTMARKER]The decree is effective for one year.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendant was required to post the notice in its Memphis facility for six months commencing within ten days after entry of the decree by the Court.[SENTMARKER]The defendant was also required to submit two reports to the Commission regarding its compliance with the decree.

gold_sents: On January 22, 2004 a group of Fairfield Resorts employees filed this class action lawsuit against Cendant Corporation, Fairfield Resorts, and 15 individuals working at Fairfield Resorts in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee, Nashville Division.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were filing suit over alleged sexual harassment, gender discrimination, and retaliation they experienced on the job.[SENTMARKER]On October 28, 2005, Judge William J. Haynes approved a consent decree granting monetary relief to plaintiffs and other female employees.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 22, 2004, a group of former and current female employees of Fairfield Resorts, Inc. filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee, Nashville Division.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were subjected to sexual harassment, gender discrimination, and retaliation in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as well as the Tennessee Human Rights Act, Tennessee  421-102(2) and   118.[SENTMARKER]As part of the settlement, Cendant Corp. and Fairfield Resorts agreed to pay $50,000 to each of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed not to retaliate against each other in the future.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed to publicize in each of its work locations the specific identity of the individual(s) to whom any complaints of harassment, discrimination, or retaliation can be made.[SENTMARKER]In the event that the parties do not mutually agree to mediate the dispute, then either party may apply to the Court for appropriate relief to enforce the provisions of this consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On September 28, 2006, The Dallas District Office of the EEOC filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued Beall Concrete Enterprises, Inc., a wholly-owned subsidiary of U.S. Concrete, Inc. under the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 and the Age Discrimination in Employment Act. On April 3, 2008, Judge Reed O'Connor approved a consent decree over the remaining claim that the defendant had violated the Age Discrimination in Employment Act.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendant to pay the complainant $50,000 in backpay, conduct ADEA training for its employees for two years, and post a notice about federal anti-discrimination employment laws.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 17, 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas against Beall Concrete Enterprises, Inc., a Dallas-based concrete company.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the defendant violated the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADEA) by failing to provide reasonable accommodation and then terminating its employees due to a record of a disability.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendant agreed to pay $50,000 to the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was signed on April 17, 2007.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed not to appeal the summary judgment ruling on the EEOC's ADA claims until the term of the consent decree expired in two years.

gold_sents: On November 9, 1999, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC"), on behalf of a female employee, filed a lawsuit in the Northern District Court of Texas, under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended, and Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991, as amended, against Parfumes De Couer Limited, Inc.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought reinstatement of the applicant, injunctive relief, compensatory damages, punitive damages, attorneys' fees, and other forms of affirmative relief claiming that the defendant fired the complainant based on her sex because she was pregnant.[SENTMARKER]On March 23, 2001, the District Court entered a consent decree where the defendant, among other things, agreed to pay the complainant $5,000.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 26, 1998, the Dallas District Office of the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas against Parfumes De Couer, Ltd., Inc., alleging that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by discharging a female employee based on her sex, female, and because of her pregnancy.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Confidential Settlement Agreement in which Parfums de Couer agreed to pay a total of $100,000 to the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required the defendant to institute and carry out policies, practices, and programs that provide equal employment opportunities for all of its female employees, and eradicate the effects of the Defendant's past and present unlawful practices.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendant agreed to post and distribute its anti-discrimination policy on the employee bulletin board within ten (10) days after the entry of this Consent Decree.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the settlement agreement are subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: On September 19, 2002, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC"), on behalf of a black employee, filed a lawsuit in the Western District Court of Texas against Union Pacific Railroad Company.[SENTMARKER]On January 21, 2004, the District Court (Judge David Briones) entered a consent decree where the defendant, among other things, agreed to pay the plaintiff-intervenor $84,000.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 19, 2002, the El Paso, Texas Office of the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against Union Pacific Railroad Company (hereafter "Union Pacific"), alleging that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 ("Title VII") by discharging an African American employee because of his race.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendant agreed to pay $84,000 to the charging party, who had been reinstated to his job (without back pay) through defendant's internal complaint process approximately 20 months after his discharge.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendant was enjoined from retaliating in any manner whatsoever against any employee employed by the Railroad for opposing any employment practice made unlawful by Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered by Judge David Briones on February 3, 2004 and the parties filed a motion for summary judgment on July 21, 2003.[SENTMARKER]The motion was denied by Judge Briones.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This class action suit was filed on January 12, 2006, under 38 U.S.C. § 4301, et seq. ("USERRA") in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff class consisted of all past and present pilots of American Airlines who are or were members of the United States Armed Services and who took military leave from January 2001 to 2006.[SENTMARKER]They asked the court for injunctive and declaratory relief, alleging that American Airlines had violated USERRA by discriminating against pilots who took military leaves of absence.[SENTMARKER]They claimed that they were unfairly charged fewer "in service" days which prevented them from bidding on a number of benefits including flight schedules, paid vacation time, and earned sick leave.[SENTMARKER]Pilots who had taken comparable types of non-military leave were not similarly penalized.[SENTMARKER]After filing two amended complaints, and the court denying the defendants' second motion to dismiss, the plaintiffs motion to certify class, preliminarily approve settlement agreement, and approve forms of class notice.[SENTMARKER]This motion was granted by U.S. District Court Judge Barbara M.G.[SENTMARKER]Lynn in a final order on August 1, 2008.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 2, 2006, three former American Airlines pilots filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that American Airlines violated the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act of 1994 by denying them the ability to bid on flight schedules based on their seniority status and to earn other employment benefits, including earned paid vacation time and earned sick leave.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Collective Bargaining Agreement in 1997 that required American Airlines to credit each pilot with 1.33 days of sick leave for each month the pilot was "in service" during the year.[SENTMARKER]In 2003, American Airlines agreed to credit the pilots with five hours of leave for every month they took military leave, including but not limited to sick leave, union service leave or jury duty leave.[SENTMARKER]On September 28, 2008, the court entered a Final Order enjoining American Airlines from denying the plaintiffs' claims.[SENTMARKER]The Final Order is subject to final approval by the court.[SENTMARKER]In addition, American Airlines is required to provide all current employed pilots who take military leave with vacation and sick leave benefits that would be afforded such pilots if they were not discharged for such military leave.

gold_sents: On August 22, 2003, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC"), on behalf of a female employee, filed a lawsuit in the Eastern District Court of Washington, under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended by Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991, against Huntwood Industries, Inc.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought injunctive relief, compensatory damages, punitive damages, attorneys' fees, and other forms of affirmative relief claiming that the defendant subjected the plaintiff-intervenor to a sexually hostile work environment because of her sex, female, resulting in her constructive discharge.[SENTMARKER]On July 21, 2004, the District Court (Judge Frederick Van Sickle) entered a consent decree where the defendant, among other things, agreed to pay the complainant $100,000.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 20, 2003, the Seattle District Office of the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Washington against T R A Industries, Inc., a Spokane-based manufacturer of custom cabinets.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by subjecting a female employee to a sexually hostile work environment because of her sex, resulting in her constructive discharge.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendant agreed to pay $100,000 to the plaintiff and to implement a number of anti-discrimination and anti-sexual harassment policies.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the defendant to develop and present to all managers and supervisors in its 13 Spokane facility four (4) hours of training on employment discrimination, including 14 discrimination against applicants and/or employees based on sex, during the years 2005 15 and 2006.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also agreed not to impose any discipline upon any supervisor or manager who discriminates against any applicant or employee on the basis of sex.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is effective for three (3) years plus 90 days beginning the date this court entered it.

gold_sents: In March 2002, the Seattle District Office of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission sued Laidlaw Inc., a school bus company, in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington for alleged violations of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The complainant intervened in May 2002, alleging that the defendant violated the Washington Law Against Discrimination and state tort law by discriminating against her on the basis of sex.[SENTMARKER]The defendant moved for summary judgment, which was granted in part and denied in part.[SENTMARKER]The case went to trial in June 2003.[SENTMARKER]The court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs on their federal and state law claims and in favor of the defendant with regard to punitive and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The court awarded $3,029.78 in economic damages and $30,000 in non-economic damages.[SENTMARKER]The parties appealed in September 2004, but the appeals were dismissed in October 2004.
pegasus_output_sents: In May 2002, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against Laidlaw Transit, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Laidlaw Transportation Services Corp., under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that Laidlaw violated Title VII by subjecting its female employees to disparate treatment on the basis of their sex.[SENTMARKER]The parties stipulated to the dismissal of these appeals with prejudice, and the case was dismissed with prejudice on April 1, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendant agreed to pay the EEOC $3,029.78 in economic damages and $30,000 in non-economic damages with costs and attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required the defendant to institute policies, practices, and programs which prov equal employment opportunities for all employees.

gold_sents: In June 2006, the EEOC filed suit in U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin against the restaurant chain International House of Pancakes (IHOP), its former president, and another company that together with IHOP operated restaurants throughout Illinois and Wisconsin.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sued under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 U.S.C. § 2000e) and Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991 (42 U.S.C. § 1981a) on behalf of two female employees and similarly situated employees of the Defendants.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the EEOC alleged that the Defendants engaged in unlawful employment practices on the basis of sex and retaliation, and that they had subjected female employees to a sexually hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]In 2009, the jury held for the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]In 2012, the parties settled, and the Court approved a Consent Decree/Settlement Agreement (lasting 2 years) that awarded monetary damages to two female claimants and promised injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 27, 2007, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin on behalf of two female servers at an International House of Pancakes (IHOP) franchise in Racine, Wisconsin.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the servers were sexually harassed in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by an assistant manager at the IHOP restaurant who subjected them to a sexually hostile work environment based on their gender.[SENTMARKER]The jury found in favor of the two servers, finding that the assistant manager had violated the policy by engaging in sexual harassment.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the jury found that one of the employees was discharged in retaliation for her refusal to submit to the harassment and her opposition to such unlawful employment practices.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to pay $50,000 in damages to the two female employees, and to create a new sexual harassment training program for all employees under its direct or indirect supervision that emphasizes the responsibility of supervisors to prevent and correct promptly and sexually harassing behavior.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also agreed to post, at all restaurants that it manages, a toll-free number for harassment and discrimination complaints by employees and a written anti-harassment and anti-discrimination policy.

gold_sents: Five non-profit organizations focused on environmental justice filed this lawsuit against the Environmental Protection Agency for failing to issue preliminary findings in Title VI complaints.[SENTMARKER]Judge Armstrong granted the plaintiffs' motion to dismiss with regard to each individual claim addressing a specific complaint in which the EPA failed to issue preliminary findings.[SENTMARKER]Judge Armstrong granted the defendant's motion to dismiss with regard to the claim that the EPA's pattern and practice of failing to issue preliminary findings violated the APA.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered settlement talks which have, as of October 2019, been unsuccessful, and the case is ongoing.

gold_sents: In 2013, Bishop Zubik, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Pittsburg and the Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Pittsburg filed a U.S. District Court lawsuit in the Western District of Pennsylvania against the Federal Government challenging the the contraception mandate of the Affordable Care Act. pegasus_output_sents: On May 21, 2012, Catholic Charities and the Catholic Diocese of Pittsburgh filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania against the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) under the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) and the First Amendment against the Affordable Care Act (ACA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the HHS mandate violated their rights of religious conscience under RFRA and their First Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction, a permanent injunction, and a declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was remanded to the Third, Fifth, Tenth, and D C Circuits for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.[SENTMARKER]On December 23, 2014, the Supreme Court of the United States (S.C.) issued its decision in Burwell v. Hobby Lobby Stores, Inc., 134 S.Ct.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court held that Hobby Lobby was not required to comply with the contraceptive mandate because it was not a religious employer.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the HHS required Catholic Charities to provide free, quality preventive and primary care to its employees.[SENTMARKER]The Catholic Charities plan is not dependent upon its contract with its insurance company.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to pay $3 million in costs and fees to the plaintiffs.

gold_sents: On November 22, 2013, a group of nonprofit religious organizations filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee under the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, the Administrative Procedure Act and the First Amendment against the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services.[SENTMARKER]On December 26, 2013, United States District Court (Judge Todd J. Campbell) denied plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The same day, the plaintiff filed an appeal with the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 6th Circuit (No. 13-6640).[SENTMARKER]On June 11, 2013, the 6th Circuit affirmed, holding that the ACA did not unlawfully burden the plaintiffs' religion.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded back to the 6th Circuit in light of a Supreme Court case Zubik v. Burwell.[SENTMARKER]Following the Zubik decision, the Departments of Health and Human Services, Labor, and Treasury adopted new rules on October 6, 2017 that allowed for religious and moral objections to providing contraceptives under the ACA.[SENTMARKER]As a result, on January 28, 2018 the plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 12, 2012, the Michigan Catholic Conference filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee, alleging that the Affordable Care Act's contraceptive coverage requirement violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, the Free Speech, Free Exercise, and Establishment Clauses of the First Amendment, and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the mandate required them to provide, pay for, and facilitate access to contraceptive services related to abortion-inducing products, contraception, and sterilization for their employees.[SENTMARKER]On November 22, 2013, the plaintiffs moved for preliminary injunctions in their respective district courts.[SENTMARKER]The district courts denied the plaintiffs' requests for a preliminary injunction on all claims.[SENTMARKER]In November 2014, the plaintiffs filed a petition for a writ of certiorari in the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals for the United States, which remanded the case back to the district courts for further consideration in light of the Supreme Court's decision in Burwell v. Hobby Lobby Stores, Inc.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On February 1, 2012, Criswell College, an evangelical Protestant college located in Dallas, filed a lawsuit in the Northern District of Texas against the Federal Government seeking to enjoin enforcement of provisions of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) extending universal contraception coverage in employer-sponsored private health insurance coverage.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs contend that this mandatory contraception coverage violates their sincerely held religious beliefs.[SENTMARKER]On April 9, 2013, the case was dismissed for lack of jurisdiction because it was not ripe for review.
