pegasus_output_sents: On March 23, 2010, The Criswell College, a Texas non-profit corporation, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas against the Departments of Health and Human Services and Treasury alleging violations of the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA), the First and Fifth Amendments of the United States Constitution, and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act of 2010 (ACA) and the Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act (Health Care and Reconciliation Act).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the RFRA by requiring the college to provide health insurance coverage for abortion, abortifacients, embryo-harming pharmaceuticals, and related education and counseling, or providing plans that cause access to the same through its insurance company.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the case on April 9, 2013 without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: The lawsuit was based on fair housing testing that DOJ had conducted between July 2008 and January 2009, in which rental agents made a series of racialized remarks, steering white testers away from certain locations, and implying that black applicants were more likely to fail criminal background checks.[SENTMARKER]On July 21, 2009, the United States Department of Justice filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Alabama under the Fair Housing Act, 42 U.S.C. §3601, against operators of the Rolling Oaks Apartments, seeking injunctive and monetary relief for race discrimination.[SENTMARKER]After the court (Judge Mark Fuller) denied cross-motions for summary judgment, the matter settled.[SENTMARKER]In February 2011, the Court entered a four-year consent decree enjoining the Defendants from discriminating on the basis of race in the operation of the Rolling Oaks Apartments and ordering  $15,500 in civil penalties.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 21, 2009, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Alabama against the owner, manager, and assistant manager of a residential apartment complex in Clanton, Alabama.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ alleged that the defendants had engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of race or color, in violation of the Fair Housing Amendments Act of 1988 and Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1968.[SENTMARKER]The defendants allegedly discriminated against black tenants by making statements indicating that a sign for a credit check and police background check was adopted to discourage black potential tenants from applying for an apartment.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also allegedly denied black tenants the right to apply for a unit because of a preference against them.[SENTMARKER]On February 3, 2011, the parties entered into a consent decree, which required the defendants to: (a) provide and process rental applications on a non-discriminatory basis; .[SENTMARKER](b) maintain all rental applications, whether deemed complete or incomplete, and any correspondence about the availability of dwelling units; .[SENTMARKER](c) post an easily readable "For Rent" or "Vacancy" sign or notice at the apartment building in which the dwelling unit is available; .[SENTMARKER](d) hold in-person training for all new Management Agents; .[SENTMARKER](e) maintain a list setting forth the occupancy of all dwelling units at each apartment complex; .[SENTMARKER](f) provide a list of the number of individual dwelling units in each apartment building; .[SENTMARKER](g) provide an easily accessible phone number for tenants to call if they have any questions; .[SENTMARKER](h) post a notice on the building's website.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered by Judge Mark E. Fuller of the Montgomery District Court.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to dismiss the case with prejudice after four years.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: On September 30, 2009 the United States Department of Justice filed a lawsuit against First United Security Bank under the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. claimed that the Bank had engaged in a pattern or practice of home-mortgage lending discrimination against black applicants.[SENTMARKER]On November 18, 2009 an agreement was entered that required the Bank to change several of its practices and to pay monetary damages to some African-American borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the agreement were satisfied and the case dismissed in April 2016.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 22, 2014, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Alabama filed this lawsuit against First United Security Bank, now known as First US Bank, alleging that the bank violated the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act by charging African-American borrowers higher rates than similarly situated white borrowers on home mortgage-related loans.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant charged African-Americans higher rates for first-lien refinance loans originated in 2004 for owner-occupied one-to-four family houses in west central Alabama on an equal basis with majority-white tracts.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into an amended consent decree in October 2014 that requires the defendant to post and display in each of its branches a notice of non-discrimination in the setting of interest rates.[SENTMARKER]The agreement also requires the bank to post an equal housing opportunity, slogan, or statement in all of its print advertising and promotional materials.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendant is prohibited from discriminating on the basis of race or color in any aspect of a residential real estate-related or credit transaction.

gold_sents: In November 2011, two undocumented Mexican immigrants and three fair housing groups filed this class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Alabama against the State of Alabama.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that a state statute violated the Fair Housing Act and was preempted by federal immigration law because it required mobile home owners to pay for a government-issued registration while prohibiting undocumented residents from making payments to government officials.[SENTMARKER]Because the law made it illegal to possess a mobile home without registration and because it was illegal for undocumented residents to obtain the registration, the law effectively made such persons homeless.[SENTMARKER]The District Court (Judge Myron H. Thompson) enjoined the State from enforcing the law.[SENTMARKER]The State appealed, but the Eleventh Circuit rendered it moot because in May 2012 the Alabama legislature amended the statute to exclude mobile home registration.[SENTMARKER]The District Court dismissed the case in May 2014, upon stipulation of the parties.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 18, 2011, the plaintiffs filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Alabama against the State of Alabama, the Alabama Revenue Commissioner, and the Elmore County Probate Judge.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' enforcement of  30 of the Beason-Hammon Alabama Taxpayer and Citizen Protection Act, 2011 Alabama, violated the Supremacy Clause and Due Process Clause of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order, with the order set to expire on December 7, 2011.[SENTMARKER]On December 12, 2011, the defendants filed a motion to dissolve the restraining order.[SENTMARKER]The Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals granted in part and denied in part.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: This case resulted in the largest residential fair lending settlement in U.S. history, with $335 million being paid to compensate African-American and Hispanic borrowers who were allegedly charged more based on their race or national origin.
pegasus_output_sents: The Department of Justice's Office of Civil Rights filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against Countrywide Home Loans, Inc. and its subsidiaries, alleging that Countrywide discriminated against African-American and Hispanic borrowers and non-applicant spouses of married mortgage loan applicants by charging them higher fees and interest rates than non-Hispanic white borrowers in both retail and wholesale lending.[SENTMARKER]Countrywide's policies and practices, as alleged herein, were intentional, willful, or implemented with reckless disregard for the rights of Hispanic and African- American borrowers and their spouses.[SENTMARKER]The complaint further alleges that, as a result of Countrywide’s policies, qualified African-Americans and Hispanics were placed in subprime loans rather than prime loans, even when similarly-qualified non- Hispanic white borrowers received prime loans.[SENTMARKER]The settlement, which is subject to court approval, requires Countrywide to retain jurisdiction over its residential lending business for the duration of the next four years, implement policies to prevent discrimination if it returns to the lending business during that time, and pay $500,000 to each of the affected borrowers.[SENTMARKER]In addition, Countrywide was required to collect, maintain, and report data with respect to certain loan terms and borrower information for residential loans, including the race and national origin of each retail home loan borrower, pursuant to the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act (HMDA).

gold_sents: On September 26, 2013, the United States of America filed a lawsuit in the Southern District of California against Plaza Home Mortgage, Inc., under the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act, alleging that the defendant discriminated against African American and Hispanic borrowers because of race and national origin in its residential mortgage lending.[SENTMARKER]On December 1, 2013, the District Court entered a consent order that prohibited the defendant from discriminating on the basis of race or national origin and required the defendant to  place $3 million into a settlement fund.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in 2016 after the defendant had substantially complied with the consent order.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 26, 2013, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of California filed this lawsuit against Plaza Home Mortgage, Inc. in the United States District Court for the San Diego District.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Plaza discriminated against African-American and Hispanic borrowers in its residential mortgage lending practices by allowing its wholesale mortgage brokers to charge higher broker fees for residential real estate-related loans than non-Hispanic white borrowers.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, African-Americans or Hispanic borrowers paid, on average, hundreds of dollars more for a Plaza loan than white borrowers because of Plaza's discriminatory practices.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on December 29, 2016, and the parties entered into a consent order.[SENTMARKER]The consent order requires Plaza to implement a loan pricing policy, specific, race- and national origin-neutral standards for the assess ment of broker fees on residential real- 19 estate related loans that Plaza underwrote, post and prominently display a notice of fees on each application, and retain a national non-profit fair housing organization to review its policies and recommend initiatives designed to prevent discrimination.[SENTMARKER]In addition, Plaza has hired a nationally recognized civil rights law firm to help implement and manage its compliance program, and retained the services of a national fair housing group to review Plaza’s policies and recommendations designed to avoid discrimination.[SENTMARKER]As part of the consent order, Plaza will also have to pay $150,000 to the federal government, post a notice in each location where applications for loans originated by Plaza are accepted, and pay $150,000 in disgorgement and prejudgment interest.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a final judgment in favor of the government.

gold_sents: On May 30, 2014, the City of Los Angeles  filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against JP Morgan Chase Bank, under Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA) and Fair Housing Act/Fair Housing Amendments Act (FHAA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought damages, declaratory and injunctive relief, alleging that the defendants lending practices were predatory and intentionally discriminated against minority borrowers, and had a disparate impact on minorities.[SENTMARKER]On August 6, 2015, the plaintiff field an ex parte application to stay the case pending appeal of related action.[SENTMARKER]On September 2, 2015, the case was dismissed as stipulated.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2012, the City of Los Angeles filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against JPMorgan Chase Co., JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A., and Chase Manhattan Bank USA, alleging that the defendants violated the Fair Housing Act by discriminating against minority borrowers in their residential real estate-related lending transactions.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the City alleged that the defendant violated the FHA by denying credit to certain neighborhoods based on race, color, or national origin.[SENTMARKER]The City sought injunctive relief and damages for the injuries caused by foreclosure on minority borrowers and to minority borrowers that are the result of JPMorgan’s unlawful and discriminatory lending practices.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a global settlement in 2012 with the Department of Justice, HUD, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, and the 25 state attorneys general.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the settlement required the defendants to pay the City approximately $1 million in damages and to pay a civil penalty.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice, and each party shall bear its own costs and expenses.

gold_sents: This sex discrimination fair housing case was brought by the United States in 2010 in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Iowa against the owners of an apartment complex and their manager, alleging sexual harassment by the manager of two female tenants.[SENTMARKER]The women claimed they were subjected to offers of maintenance services in return for sex, pervasive, unwanted touching, gestures and remarks.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff claimed these actions constituted a pattern and practice of sexual discrimination in violation of the Fair Housing Act.[SENTMARKER]Though the owners had gone out of business during the course of the litigation, they entered into a five-year Consent Decree that included detailed prohibitions against sex discrimination, should they ever again engage in the business.[SENTMARKER]The manager was forever banned from any job involved in any aspect of the operation of any dwelling.[SENTMARKER]Defendants agreed to pay $80,000 in compensatory damages to aggrieved persons identified by Plaintiff and $15,000 in civil penalties.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 22, 2011, the U.S. Department of Justice's Civil Rights Division filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Iowa.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of sex in violation of the Fair Housing Act of 1968 (the "Fair Housing Act").[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the complaint alleged discrimination in the rental of units at Park Towers Apartments in Waterloo, Towa (''Park Towe rs').[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent order on September 22, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The consent order required the defendants to adopt a written Nondiscrimination Policy, provide a copy of the HUD booklet, Fair Housing; Equ.al Opportunity for A ll," to each household occopying a unit at each rentn l property, and provide a statement certifying under penalty of perjury that they have distributed the Nondiscrimination Po li cy and HUD booklet in compliance with the provisions of the consent order.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to dismiss the case with prejudice five years after the date of the entry of the Consent Order.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: On February 1, 2008, minority homeowners on behalf of similarly situated minority homeowners filed a class-action complaint in U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against H&R Block Inc., H&R Block Bank and its wholly-owned subsidiary,under the Equal Credit Opportunity Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1691, et seq. ("ECOA") and the Fair Housing Act, 42 U.S.C. § 3601 et seq.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants maintained a pattern or practice that had a discriminatory impact on minority applicants in their home financing policies and practices.[SENTMARKER]On August 21, 2013, the plaintiffs filed a stipulation to dismiss the case with prejudice.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 7, 2013, a group of African-American homeowners brought suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against H&R Block, Inc. and its wholly-owned subsidiaries, San Canyon Corp., f/k/a Option One Mortgage Corporation and Ada Services Corporation, alleging that the defendants violated the Equal Credit Opportunity Act, the Fair Housing Act, and Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, disgorgement, and restitution of monies disparately obtained from minority borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: The defendant to this 2008 family-status discrimination lawsuit brought by the United States in the District of Nebraska, was a condominium association whose "Amended Master Deed and Declaration" stated that no unit should be "sold or leased to a person who has a child under the age of 16 who will occupy or reside in the unit 180 days or more a year."[SENTMARKER]The suit's complainants alleged that this clause posed an obstacle to their intended sale of their condo units.[SENTMARKER]After discovery, the parties entered mediation, and on March 3, 2010, District Judge Warren K. Urbom approved a three-year consent decree.[SENTMARKER]In addition to a general prohibition against discrimination in the sale or rental of the condominium units, the decree required the defendants to develop and post a non-discrimination policy and to amend the master deed to excise  the prohibition against families with children.[SENTMARKER]Defendants agreed to pay $77,500 to the complainants, an additional $35,000 to other aggrieved parties, and a $15,000 civil penalty to the United States.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 29, 2008, the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) filed this lawsuit against The Latvian Tower Condominium Association, Inc. and its president, Karl Tegtmeyer, in the United States District Court for the District of Nebraska.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated Title VIII of the Civil Rights Act of 1968 and the Fair Housing Amendments Act of 1988 by discriminating against prospective buyers because of their familial status.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent order on November 12, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The consent order required the defendants to adopt and enforce a Master Deed and By-Laws that prohibited children under the age of 16 from occupying or residing in a condominium unit in the Latvian Tower condominium complex in Omaha, Nebraska.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendants agreed to post a fair housing sign in all common areas of the condominium complex, post a notice that they operate and manage the property on a nondiscriminatory basis, and to pay the complainants' attorney's fees and court costs, except as provided for in Section IX below.

gold_sents: An association of residents of a New Jersey neighborhood filled a lawsuit claiming that the defendants' redevelopment plan for the Gardens neighborhood represented a violation of the Fair Housing Act and the United States and New Jersey Constitutions.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that the defendants' redevelopment plan, which razed numerous homes in a minority neighborhood, was discriminatory.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed the District Court's pretrial decision in favor of the town to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, which reversed, and found that the plaintiffs were entitled to a trial.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted certiorari to review the question whether disparate impact claims were available under the Fair Housing Act.  About two weeks prior to the scheduled argument, the parties settled; the city will construct 44 new homes, 20 for current residents in exchange for allowing redevelopment.[SENTMARKER]Seven households that elected to relocate will be compensated.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 5, 2005, a group of residents of the Mount Holly Gardens neighborhood of Mount Holly, New Jersey, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Solebury Township's denial of a building permit for the redevelopment of the neighborhood violated the Fair Housing Act.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the plaintiffs' claims without prejudice as unripe.[SENTMARKER]On May 6, 2005, the plaintiffs appealed the district court's grant of summary judgment to the Third Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Third Circuit reversed the District Court's decision, finding that the plaintiffs had established a prima facie case of disparate impact sufficient to withstand summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs a total of $325,000.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Low-income minority individuals in need of affordable housing filed a lawsuit under the Fair Housing Act, the Civil Rights Act of 1866, the Civil Rights Act of 1871, 42 U.S.C. § 1983, and the Civil Rights Act of 1964 against the Town of Smithtown, complaining that  Smithtown operated its voucher program with a residency preference that discriminated on the basis of race, color, and national origin.[SENTMARKER]The court entered an order and final judgment approving the parties' settlement agreement under which the Town of Smithtown agreed to implement an anti-discrimination educational program, to affirmatively market the Section 8 Program to minority persons, to inform the public of its non-discriminatory policies, to maintain and preserve records for purposes of recordkeeping and reporting, and to pay $925,000 to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]This settlement remains in effect until 2019.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 13, 2007, a group of African-American and Hispanic residents of Smithtown, New York filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Smithtown violated the Fair Housing Act and the equal protection clause of the United States Constitution by using a residency preference for allocation of Section 8 housing vouchers in the Smithtown Section 8 Voucher Program.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which Smithtown agreed to: (i) open its Section 8 waitlist only when there are fewer than 100 applicants on the waitlist; .[SENTMARKER](ii) provide mandatory training to all of its current employees and agents involved with the program; .[SENTMARKER](iii) promote the program to minority applicants; .[SENTMARKER](iv) pay a settlement fund to the plaintiffs; and (v) post a notice of the settlement in the local press.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice as to Smithtown without costs except as provided in the settlement.

gold_sents: On December 06, 2010, the United States filed suit under 42 U.S.C. 3601 of the Fair Housing Act against the owner of the Burgundy Gardens Apartments, LLC in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York (Judge Kenneth Karas).[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff, represented by the Untied States Department of Justice asked the Court to 1) declare the Defendant's conduct a violation of the Fair Housing Act, 2) enjoin the Defendant from discriminating on the basis of race in the rental of dwellings, 3) award monetary damages and 4) assess a civil penalty.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the Plaintiff claims the Defendant's rental practices discriminated against African American prospective tenants.[SENTMARKER]On April 4,2012, the parties reached a settlement.[SENTMARKER]The Defendant was enjoined from further discriminatory rental practices on the basis of rate, and paid $150,000 in damages and $25,000 as a civil penalty.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 5, 2010, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York filed this lawsuit against Burgundy Gardens Apartments, LLC, d/b/a Burgundy Gardens, alleging that Burgundy Gardens discriminated against African Americans who were seeking rental housing because of race or color.[SENTMARKER]Burgundy Gardens agreed to pay $150,000 into a victim fund that will be available to compensate people who were harmed by the discriminatory rental practices of BURGUNDYS, and to pay a civil penalty of $25,000.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree on April 16, 2012 (the "Conviction Decree"), which required Burgundy Gardens to implement a nondiscrimination policy, educate its employees on federal and state housing discrimination laws, and submit periodic reports to the Government containing information about its rental activity.[SENTMARKER]In addition, Burgundy Gardens was required to distribute the Nondiscrimination Policy to all of its current tenants, employees, agents, and anyone acting under the direction of Defendant, who has responsibility for showing, renting, or managing any and all dwelling units at the subject property.[SENTMARKER]The Court retained jurisdiction for the duration of the Consent Decree to enforce its tenns, after which time the case shall be dismissed with prejudice.

gold_sents: The United States filed a lawsuit under the Fair Housing Act against architects and developers of an apartment building claiming that the defendants designed and constructed the building so that it was inaccessible to persons with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff entered into two separate three-year consent decrees; one requiring the architect to make all of its future designs compliant with the FHA and to pay a $20,000 civil penalty; the other with the developers requiring extensive retrofits to the building, $60,000 in damages and a $35,000 civil penalty.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 14, 2011, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York and the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development filed this lawsuit against Larkspur, LLC, a New York-based real estate development company, and its architect, Larsen Sheinsberg, alleging that the defendants violated the Fair Housing Act by failing to design and construct a residential apartment complex accessible to persons with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the apartment complex was inaccessible to persons who use wheelchairs.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendants agreed to pay a total of 35,000 dollars to the United States.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree, which was entered by Judge Deborah A. Batts on October 5, 2011, requires the defendants to post a conspicuous location, post a statement that the dwelling units include features required by the Fair housing Act, post advertisements in newspapers and electronic media, and post a notice in the apartment listing websites of the city's housing agencies.[SENTMARKER]The decree also requires the developer to make available to the general public and to governmental and charitable groups, including the Disabled American Veterans, New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, and the mayor's office for people with disabilities, a list of available apartment listings to be published on each group's respective website.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed without prejudice as to the developer.

gold_sents: On April 12, 2012, the United States sued GFI Mortgage Bankers under the Fair Housing Act and Equal Credit Opportunity Act for charging African American and Hispanic borrowers higher fees and costs for home mortgage loans than it charged similarly situated white borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a Consent Decree on August 27, 2012, which required GFI to pay $3.555 million and implement fair lending policies and a fair lending monitoring system.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 2, 2012, the Department of Justice's Office for the Southern District of New York filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against GFI Mortgage Bankers, Inc., a New York-based mortgage banker, under the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that GFI engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of race and national origin by charging African-American and Hispanic borrowers higher interest rates and fees on home mortgage loans compared to similarly-situated non-Hispanic white borrowers.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, GFI's home-loan pricing policy resulted in significant disparities in the cost of home loans for African-Americans and Hispanics.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the complaint alleged GFI charged higher fees and interest rates on home loans that were, on average, 102 basis points higher in 2005 and 2007, 105 basis points lower in 2006, 105 basis point higher in 2007, and 73 basis points more in 2009, than the fees it charged to similarly situated white borrowers in the same period.[SENTMARKER]The case was referred to the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division by the HUD's Housing and Economic Development Office in 2010 and the case was closed in 2011.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was entered in 2012 and requires GFI to adopt policies and procedures that require its employees and agents, in the process of an applicant's selection of a loan product, to explain the benefits and consequences of each loan product discussed.[SENTMARKER]GFI shall also develop a fair lending program designed to ensure compliance with this Order, the FHA, and the ECOA.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In 2014, a non-profit organization that provides housing assistance to formerly incarcerated individuals filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for Eastern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendant, who owned and managed a multi-building apartment complex, had a discriminatory policy that unlawfully prohibited anyone with a criminal record from renting an apartment.[SENTMARKER]After years of discovery and litigation, the parties settled for over $1 million.
pegasus_output_sents: In October 2014, The Fortune Society filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York against Sandcastle Towers Housing Development Fund Corporation, Sarasota Gold LLC, E M Associates LLC, and Weissman Realty Group LLC, alleging that the defendants had engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of race and color at The Sand Castle, a multi-building apartment complex they own and manage in Queens, New York.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that defendants had a policy of categorically excluding applicants who had felony or non-traffic misdemeanor convictions from tenancy, which caused an unjustified disparate impact on African-American and Hispanic applicants in violation of the Fair Housing Act.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' motion to dismiss for lack of standing was denied.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 12, 2005, individual New York residents and the New York ACORN local chapter filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Easter District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued Nassau County and the Village of Garden City under the Fair Housing Act, the Civil Rights Act of 1866, the Civil Rights Act of 1964, and the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs asked the court to enjoin the defendants from proceeding with discriminatory zoning practices; to order Garden City to approve a proposed zoning that would allow for affordable housing; and to order the defendants to take all actions necessary to assure that the Social Service Site be redeveloped to maximize the availability of affordable and integrated housing.[SENTMARKER]On February 15, 2012, Judge Arthur D. Spatt granted defendant County's motion for summary judgment dismissing all claims against it.[SENTMARKER]On April 22, 2014, Judge Spatt issued a final order for the plaintiffs and ordered Defendant Garden City to take a number of steps to prevent discrimination and to increase access to affordable housing.[SENTMARKER]After Judge Spatt's order, both parties appealed the decision.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit affirmed in part and remanded in part.[SENTMARKER]The case is back in the lower courts on remand.[SENTMARKER]On remand, Judge Spatt found that the plaintiffs had met their burden at trial in demonstrating that the Garden City’s proffered reasons for its chosen zoning change could have been met by another practice, such as R-M zoning, that had a less discriminatory effect.[SENTMARKER]Magistrate Judge Arlene R. Lindsay thereafter awarded plaintiffs $5,255,108.94 in attorneys fees and costs from Garden City.[SENTMARKER]On March 15, 2019, Judge Spatt signed the parties’ stipulation of discontinuance with prejudice, except without prejudice as to the court’s jurisdiction for the purpose of interpretation or enforcement of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the County to pay $5,400,000 to the plaintiffs to be used for the purpose of furthering and promoting mixed-income affordable housing; $120,000 to NYCC to be used for activities related to fair and affordable housing; and $400,000 to plaintiffs’ counsel for attorneys’ fees.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 12, 2005, MHANY Management, Inc. and the New York Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now (NY ACORN) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York against the Village of Garden City and the Garden City Board of Trustees (collectively, the "Village Defendants"), alleging that the Village violated the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Protection Clause of the United States Constitution by changing the zoning of a certain area of the Village.[SENTMARKER]The Village Defendants moved to dismiss the case for lack of standing and failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the County's motion for summary judgment in part and dismissed the case against the County on February 12, 2012.[SENTMARKER]On July 28, 2016, the Second Circuit affirmed the District Court's final judgment, in part, and remanded the case to the Court for further proceedings.

gold_sents: This 2011 federal fair lending lawsuit in the Western District of Texas was brought by the United States against a local bank the U.S. alleged had engaged in a pattern or practice of providing loans to Hispanics only at higher rates than to non-Hispanics, without justification.[SENTMARKER]In the settlement, submitted simultaneously with the complaint, the bank agreed to develop and establish uniform pricing policies and procedures designed to ensure nondiscriminatory pricing, and to numerous other implementation provisions, including fair credit training, systemic monitoring, complaint resolution processes, and $91,000 in damages to aggrieved persons.[SENTMARKER]The provisions of the order were scheduled to last 4 and 1/4 years.
pegasus_output_sents: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Western District of Texas brought this suit against Nixon State Bank in the United States District Court in San Antonio, Texas, under the Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA) and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Nixon charged higher interest rates on unsecured consumer loans to Hispanic borrowers as compared to non-Hispanic borrowers from at least 2006 through December 31, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the bank did not properly instruct its loan officers regarding their obligation to treat prospective customers without regard to national origin, and the bank failed to supervise or monitor the performance of its Loan Officers effectively to ensure compliance with fair lending laws.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a final judgment in favor of the bank, which required the bank to pay a total of $91,600 to its Hispanic borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The bank also agreed to implement a complaint resolution program to address consumer complaints alleging discrimination regarding loans originated by Nixon.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the bank agreed to provide equal credit opportunity training to its management officials, loan officers, and any other employees or agents who participate in the origination of the loans covered by this Order.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: The United States Department of Justice filed a lawsuit under the Fair Housing and Equal Credit Opportunity Acts against PrimeLending, claiming that the defendant displayed a pattern or practice of discrimination in lending on the basis of race against African-American borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent order in which Primelending agreed to refrain from practicing race based discrimination, submit to a monitoring and reporting program, provide borrowers with a general notice of nondiscrimination, provide equal credit opportunity training to its employees, provide a total of $2 million to be distributed among those aggrieved,  allocate any unclaimed portion of the $2 million to organizations that provide general financial education to African-American borrowers, and maintain a complaint resolution program to resolve discrimination claims.
pegasus_output_sents: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Northern District of Texas brought this suit against Prime Lending, Inc., a Dallas-based retail mortgage lender, under the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged discrimination on the basis of race in the terms, conditions, or privileges of the provision of services in connection with sale of a dwelling.[SENTMARKER]The defendant agreed to pay $22,000 to the Urban League of Greater Dallas and to implement a complaint resolution program to address consumer complaints alleging discrimination regarding loans secured by residential real estate originated by the Defendant.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendant agreed not to charge more than 100 basis points in origination fees and costs to certain African-American borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice at the end of the trial.

gold_sents: On December 19, 2013,  the U.S. Department of Justice filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against Fort Davis State Bank, alleging that it charged Hispanic borrowers higher interest rates on unsecured consumer loans compared to the rates it charged white borrowers, in violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]In January 2014, the District Court (Judge Robert A. Junell) approved a consent order in which the bank agreed to implement a variety of practices to address these alleged violations and to pay damages to aggrieved borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The consent order remained in effect until early 2017.[SENTMARKER]Since there has been no substantive docket activity after 2014, the case is presumably closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 22, 2011, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation ( FDIC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against Fort Davis State Bank (FDSB) alleging that FDSB engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of national origin in the pricing of unsecured consumer loans in violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA).[SENTMARKER]According to the FDIC's complaint, between January 1, 2008 and December 30, 2010, FDSB charged higher interest rates on consumer loans to Hispanic borrowers than to similarly situated non-Hispanic white borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The FDIC further alleged that the Bank did not properly instruct its loan officers regarding their obligation to treat prospective customers without regard to national origin, and the Bank failed to supervise or monitor the performance of its Loan Officers to ensure compliance with fair lending laws.[SENTMARKER]On November 22, 2011, Judge Robert A. Junell entered a consent order (Conviction Order) requiring FDSB to pay $159,000 to compensate Hispanic borrowers who may have suffered monetary damages as a result of the Bank's alleged violations of ECOA.[SENTMARKER]The Court also ordered the Bank to create a complaint resolution program to address consumer complaints alleging discrimination regarding loans originated by the Bank and to monitor the Bank for potential disparities based on national origin.[SENTMARKER]As part of the consent order, FDSB also agreed to provide equal credit opportunity training to its management officials, loan officers, and any other employees or agents who participate in the origination of the bank's loans covered by this Consent Order.[SENTMARKER]The Bank also agreed not to charge higher rates of interest on any unsecured consumer loan that it originated from January 1, 2008, to December 31, 2010, and to provide a notice of non-discrimination that provides substantially the same information to the borrower as is contained in Appendix A.

gold_sents: On September 26, 2013, the United States of America filed a lawsuit in the Eastern District of Wisconsin against Southport Bank, under the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, represented by the Civil Rights Division of the Department of Justice, sought a declaratory judgment, injunctive relief, compensatory damages to all of the victims of the defendant's discriminatory policies, and a civil penalty, alleging that the defendant discriminated against African American and Hispanic borrowers because of race and national origin in its residential mortgage lending.[SENTMARKER]On October 11, 2013, the District Court (Judge Joseph Peter Stadtmueller) entered a consent order between the parties.[SENTMARKER]The defendant did not admit to any pattern or practice of discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The order enjoined the defendant from engaging in any act or practice that discriminates on the basis of race or national origin in any aspect of a residential real estate-related transaction in violation of the Fair Housing Act or any credit transaction in violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.  Among other things, the defendant's employees will have to participate in a fair lending training program and will be subject to monitoring and reporting requirements.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also has to place $687,000 into a settlement fund to compensate for monetary damages that aggrieved persons may have suffered.[SENTMARKER]The order terminates after three years if the defendant has complied during that time period.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 11, 2013, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of Wisconsin filed this lawsuit against Southport Bank of Kenosha, Wisconsin.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the bank discriminated against African-American and Hispanic borrowers in its residential mortgage lending by allowing its wholesale mortgage brokers to charge higher fees than non-Hispanic white borrowers because of their race and national origin.[SENTMARKER]The case was brought under the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA) and the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act (HMDA), which prohibit financial institutions from discriminating on the basis of race or national origin in their mortgage lending practices.[SENTMARKER]On December 31, 2008, the court entered an order enjoining the bank from engaging in any act or practice that discriminates in any aspect of a residential real estate-related transaction in violation of the FHA, ECOA, or in any of its other policies, procedures, or practices.[SENTMARKER]The court also ordered the bank to pay $20,000 in disgorgement and prejudgment interest to African-Americans and Hispanics who were charged higher broker fees than white borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The order was entered by Judge J P. Stadtmueller of the United States District Court for the district of Wisconsin on October 11, 2013.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: Following an investigation by the United States Department of Justice, the U.S. filed this lawsuit against the State of Connecticut, its Department of Mental Retardation, and the Director of Southbury Training School (Southbury) on July 25, 1986, alleging that living conditions at Southbury placed residents in grave danger of bodily harm and death.[SENTMARKER]On the same day, the parties also entered into a consent decree that required Southbury to provide better programming, disciplinary procedures, medical care, recordkeeping, and increase staffing.[SENTMARKER]After some problems with compliance and placing the state in contempt, the Court assigned a special master to monitor Southbury.[SENTMARKER]After making significant progress, on March 25, 2006, the court ended judicial oversight, but retained jurisdiction over the consent decree and remedial plan.[SENTMARKER]On November 2, 2009, the Court granted a joint motion to dismiss the case because the parties agreed that the consent decree and remedial plan were fully implemented.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 11, 1985, the Department of Justice ("DOJ") filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Connecticut under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act ("CRIPA") against the State of Connecticut, its governor, the state's Department of Mental Retardation ("DMR"), and the director of the Southbury Training School ("STS"), a Connecticut institution for persons with developmental disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the CRIPA by failing to provide adequate medical care to all of its residents, failing to comply with the terms of the consent decree, and failing to submit quarterly compliance reports to the court.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree which required the defendants to submit an implementation plan addressing the procedures by which the decree would be effectuated.[SENTMARKER]The district court found the defendants in contempt of court, and the defendants appealed.[SENTMARKER]On June 19, 1996, the court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the complaint and dismissed the complaint.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit affirmed the district court's decision.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Disability Rights Washington filed this class action on behalf of individuals with intellectual disabilities in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington in April 2014.[SENTMARKER]They sued the State healthcare authority and department of social services, alleging that budget cuts resulted in inadequate services in violation of the Nursing Home Reform Act.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a preliminary settlement one year later and the final settlement was approved in January 2017.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is ongoing and under court supervision through September 30, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 16, 2014, a resident of a privately-operated nursing facility filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against the Secretary of the Washington State Department of Social and Health Services (DSHS) and the Director of Washington State Health Care Authority (HCA) alleging violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the Nursing Home Reform Act (NHRA), and the Medicaid Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants did not have an adequate system in place for persons with intellectual disabilities and related conditions living in private-operated Medicaid-certified nursing facilities to be screened, assessed and/or receive specialized services, in violation of the 21 Medicaid Act and the NHRA.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement that provided for a 14 comprehensive reform of the defendants' Pre-Admission Screening and Resident Referral (PASRR) system, required under the Nursing home Reform Act. Under the terms of the settlement, the defendants will continue to provide annual PASRR training to PASRR Level I screeners, including but not limited to employees of hospitals and nursing facilities, and post a notice on their website.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required the defendants to post the 20 class notice on its website.[SENTMARKER]If the defendants achieve full compliance with each and every 18 compliance metric in advance of September 30, 2020, the parties will jointly move the 19 Court for an order asking for early termination of the Agreement and dismissal of the 20 case.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the petition for permission to appeal.

gold_sents: Individuals with intellectual disabilities residing in the Wyoming State Training School filed this lawsuit in 1990 to challenge conditions at the School and a lack of community placement options.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed in 1991 to a settlement that was designed not only to improve conditions in the institution, but also to prevent unnecessary institutionalization and create options for community living for individuals with intellectual disabilities in Wyoming.[SENTMARKER]The court's jurisdiction was ended in 1994.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 3, 1990, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Wyoming on behalf of individuals with mental retardation residing at the Wyoming State Training School (WSTS).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants failed to provide alternative services for them in their communities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive and declaratory relief against the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Stipulation Agreement on June 15, 1990.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the parties would engage in good faith negotiations to resolve this dispute.[SENTMARKER]On October 12, 1994, the parties filed a motion for summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion, and the parties entered a consent decree on October 12, 1994.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the defendants to provide adequate transportation and services for individuals with developmental disabilities in the state.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to provide the plaintiffs with an individual education plan.[SENTMARKER]The final decision was entered by the district court on October 13, 1994.[SENTMARKER]The parties are continuing to negotiate a settlement.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: These 2007 consolidated cases were brought in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona to challenge the "Legal Arizona Workers Act", which mandates investigation and prosecution of employers who knowingly or intentionally employ unauthorized aliens and requires the revocation of the licenses of employers found to have done so.[SENTMARKER]It also makes mandatory a previously voluntary verification process.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. Supreme Court affirmed the lower courts' rulings, holding that the Act fell within ICRA's savings clause and thus was not expressly preempted by federal law.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 29, 2007, a group of business, labor, and civil rights organizations filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona against the Arizona Attorney General, the Governor of Arizona, the Arizona Farm Bureau Federation, and the Director of the Department of Revenue of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs challenged the validity of the Arizona Migrant and Seasonal Worker Protection Act (AWPA), which seeks to regulate employment eligibility and immigration status verification.[SENTMARKER]The district court held that the law was not preempted by federal immigration law.[SENTMARKER]On September 17, 2008, the Ninth Circuit entered judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]On March 9, 2009, the plaintiffs filed a petition for a writ of certiorari to review the decision and judgment of the Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit denied the plaintiffs' motion for rehearing and rehearing en banc.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On July 6, 2010, the United States filed a lawsuit under the Supremacy Clause and the Commerce Clause of the U.S. Constitution against the state of Arizona and the Governor of Arizona in her official capacity in the U.S. District Court of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff claimed that the recently enacted S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070, which contains several provisions designed to "discourage and deter the unlawful entry and presence of aliens" in Arizona, impermissibly infringes on the federal government's right to enact and enforce immigration policy.[SENTMARKER]On July 28, 2010, the district court issued a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The defendant appealed the grant of the injunction.[SENTMARKER]On April 11, 2011, the U.S. Court of Appeals, 9th Circuit, issued an opinion upholding the injunction.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. Supreme Court granted cert on December 12, 2011 and issued their opinion on June 25, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court affirmed in part and reversed in part, striking down most of the challenged provisions of S.B.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 6, 2010, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the District of Arizona filed this lawsuit against the State of Arizona and Arizona Governor Jan Brewer in the United States District Court for the district of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit challenged the constitutionality of Arizona's "alien smuggling prohibition" (S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070), which requires the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to achieve and maintain 5 "operational control" of the border.[SENTMARKER]The United States filed a motion for injunctive relief seeking to enjoin implementation of S.B, and the district court granted the motion for a preliminary injunction in part, enjoining enforcement.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings consistent with this action.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit held that the District Court did not abuse its discretion in granting the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals for the 9th Circuit affirmed the district judge's decision to grant the injunction, but remanded the case to the lower court to reconsider its decision.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case was closed.

gold_sents: On May 17, 2010, a group of organizations and individuals filed a lawsuit against the Sheriff and Attorney of each of the 15 counties in Arizona, in their official capacities, in the U.S. District Court of Arizona, Phoenix Division.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, represented by organizations such as the ACLU and the National Immigration Law Center along with private counsel, sought declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming that the recently enacted S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070 was a violation of the Supremacy Clause of the U.S. Constitution.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiff contends that S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070 conflicts with federal law and procedures and that local law enforcement agencies are ill equipped to deal with the complexities of immigration law.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction in February 2012, which the defendants appealed.[SENTMARKER]In a related case, Arizona v. United States, the U.S. Supreme Court struck down most of S.B.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed a Motion for Preliminary Injunction against the remaining provisions of S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070 and while the parties were going through discovery disputes, the defendant filed a motion for summary judgment on March 17, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff filed a response to the defendant's summary judgment and on September 4, 2015, the district court ruled in favor of the defendant with regard to plaintiff's claims under the Supremacy Clause, Equal Protection Clause, the Fourth Amendment, Article II, Section 8 of the Arizona Constitution, the Due Process Clause, and 42 U.S.C. §1981.[SENTMARKER]Notably, the court also entered a judgment in favor of the plaintiffs on count three claim which was appealed.[SENTMARKER]Finally, on September 15, 2016, both parties conferred and filed a joint case disposition in which the plaintiff settled for $1.4 million.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 17, 2010, a group of non-profit organizations and individuals filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona challenging Arizona Senate Bill 1070, a comprehensive set of state immigration laws that purport to create an immigration policy of "attrition through enforcement" in the State of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the law violated their First Amendment rights by prohibiting them from hiring or attempting to hire a person for work at another location from a stopped car that impedes traffic, or for a person to be hired in such a manner.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction barring enforcement of two provisions of S.B.[SENTMARKER]2010, which make it unlawful for a motor vehicle occupant to hire or attempt to hire an individual for work from another location, and for the city of Chandler to enforce a parking ban.[SENTMARKER]On September 16, 2011, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals reversed the district court's preliminary injunction and held that a Redondo Beach ordinance prohibiting the solicitation of business, employment, and contributions on streets and highways was not narrowly tailored to achieve the city's interest in promoting traffic flow and safety.[SENTMARKER]On February 29, 2012, the District Court entered a preliminary injunction enjoining the enforcement of the two provisions.[SENTMARKER]On July 11, 2012, the plaintiffs filed an interlocutory appeal, which was denied by the Court.[SENTMARKER]The Court found that the plaintiffs' First Amendment claims were likely to succeed on the merits of their claims.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit affirmed the district Court's grant of an injunction barring the city from enforcing the parking ban, and the case is now resolved.

gold_sents: On June 8, 2015, civil detainees confined in the Tucson Sector of the U.S. Border Patrol filed a class action lawsuit, alleging violations of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment and the APA due to inhumane and punitive conditions while they were detained in holding cells.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a PI mandating that defendants must maintain conditions of confinement adequate for the detainees' physical needs and provide detainees with mats and blankets after 12 hours.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit affirmed the PI order.[SENTMARKER]In 2018 the plaintiffs filed a motion for partial summary judgment on the issue of defendants' obligation to provide raised beds for detainees held for any period requiring sleep; the district court denied this motion.[SENTMARKER]After a 7-day trial in January 2020, the district court held that these extended confinement conditions violated the Constitution and issued an order enjoining the defendants from holding detainees for longer than 48 unless they provided conditions of confinement that meet basic human needs.[SENTMARKER]This permanent injunction was ordered and has been in effect since April 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 8, 2015, three civil immigration detainees filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona, alleging that the conditions of their detention at the Tucson Sector Border Patrol facility violated their Eighth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The district court certified a class of all individuals who are now or in the future will be detained at a CBP facility within the Border Patrol’s Tucson Sector.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction, which was granted by the district court in the fall of 2016.[SENTMARKER]On March 21, 2018, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed the entry of the preliminary injunction in part.[SENTMARKER]The court granted summary judgment for the defendants, concluding that the existing conditions violated the Eighth Amendment.

gold_sents: In 2018, former Latino/a guests at Motel 6 locations in Arizona filed this class action complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that Motel 6's policy of disclosing guests' information to DHS and ICE agents without requiring a warrant or reasonable suspicion of criminal activity violated the United States Constitution and federal and state law.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged Motel 6 conspired with DHS and ICE agents to violate guests’ Fourth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]In February 2020, the parties agreed to class action settlement terms and the district court approved the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The court retains jurisdiction over the matter for the duration of the consent decree.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 24, 2018, Motel 6 Operating, L.P., G6 Hospitality LLC, and Does 1-10 ( collectively referred to as Motel 6) filed a class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Motel 6 violated federal and state law by disclosing guest registration information, including personal information, of its guests to federal immigration agents without a warrant or reasonable suspicion of criminal activity, in violation of Motel 6's written assurances that it protects the privacy of its guest, and to assist DHS and ICE agents in unlawfully arresting or detaining guests.[SENTMARKER]On June 15, 2018, the parties engaged in a day-long mediation with Martin F. Scheinman, Esq., a professional mediator, and the parties reached a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to allocate thirty-five percent two (35%) of the Cy Pres Fund to the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund (MALDEF), fifteen percent 11 (15%) to TheDream.US., and fifteen percent 20 ( 15%) to the Arizona Immigrant and Refugee Rights Project (FIRRP).[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to provide training to Motel 6 employees that if they have 10 questions about this policy, they should call the 24-Hour Hotline.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is subject to final approval by the court.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Following his arrest and confinement at the Coconino County Detention Facility (CCDF), plaintiff challenged the prolonged detention of inmates at CCDF triggered by detainer requests from the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement Agency (ICE).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff claimed this policy violated Article II, section 8 of the Arizona Constitution and the Fourth   and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]He sought class-wide declaratory and injunctive relief for all CCDF detainees subject to this prolonged detention policy despite their eligibility for pretrial release.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. District Court for the district of Arizona denied the plaintiff's motion for a preliminary injunction, citing his inability to demonstrate a likelihood of success on the merits of his claims.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff moved to dismiss the case thereafter, which was accepted by the court.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 30, 2018, a group of Arizona residents filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona against the Coconino County Sheriff's Office, the CoConino County Jail District, and members of the County Board of Supervisors challenging the County's unconstitutional policy of prolonging detention of inmates for whom it receives a "detainer" request from ICE.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that this policy violated the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution, and Article II, Section 8 of the Arizona Constitution, which provides that "No person shall be disturbed in his private when Plaintiff actually posts bond and ICE takes custody of him."[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive and declaratory relief, seeking to enjoin the County from detaining an unauthorized immigrant at the request of federal immigration authorities.[SENTMARKER]On May 8, 2018, the Court denied the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]On July 2, 2018, the District Court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: In June 2017, the Center for Biological Diversity sued DHS and CBP, bringing challenges to the Trump Administration's proposed border wall (FOIA, environmental statutes, APA, IIRIRA).[SENTMARKER]After consolidation with several cases, on Feb.[SENTMARKER]2018, the Court granted the government's motion to dismiss (except for the FOIA claim) and denied plaintiffs' SJ cross-motions.[SENTMARKER]The parties jointly moved to dismiss the FOIA claim.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the district court's order.[SENTMARKER]Lastly, the Supreme Court denied the plaintiff's petition for writ of certiorari regarding the constitutional issue of separation of powers in the IIRIRA.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 2, 2017, the Center for Biological Diversity filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and Customs and Border Protection (CBP) seeking declaratory and/or injunctive relief under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA).[SENTMARKER]The Center's complaint alleged that DHS and CBP violated FOIA, the APA, and NEPA by failing to comply with FOIA requests for records related to the agencies' compliance with NEPA, the ESA, and other laws in relation to the border wall prototype project.[SENTMARKER]In August 2017, the District Court granted DHS summary judgment on the plaintiffs' "ultra vires" claims, finding that the waivers in violation of NEPA and the APA were precluded by the Secretary's waiver of the Coastal Zone Management Act (CZMA) and the EPA.[SENTMARKER]The district court also granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case for lack of jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a joint appeal to the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit reversed the district court's grant of summary judgment to DHS on the ultra vires claims, holding that the waiver waivers were unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 23, 2018 the ACLU of Northern California filed this lawsuit against Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) under the Freedom of Information Act, alleging that ICE had not provided the ACLU with documents they had requested related to ICE's purchase of automated license plate reader data.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a schedule for the documents to be released on a rolling basis, which was completed in November 2018.[SENTMARKER]A settlement also required ICE to pay attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 19, 2018, the American Civil Liberties Union of Northern California (ACLU-NC) filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, seeking information related to contracts between Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and private companies for access and use of automated license plate reader (ALPR) technology to track the movements of drivers on 5 America's streets.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that ICE wrongfully withheld the requested records in violation of FOIA and sought declaratory and injunctive relief with respect to the search, release and disclosure of requested agency records, as well as attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]On May 23, 2018, the parties entered into a proposed settlement agreement, which was approved by the court on July 20, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for partial summary judgment and dismissed the case with prejudice.

gold_sents: Two San Francisco Bay Area fathers filed this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California after being detained for over 6 months in ICE custody without a bond hearing.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction and class certification ordering that individuals detained pursuant to 8 U.S.C. § 1231(a)(6) pending a determination as to whether they can remain in the United States with “live claims”  before an adjudicative body cannot be detained for more than 180 days without a bond hearing.[SENTMARKER]The government appealed both orders to the Ninth Circuit, and on April 7, 2020, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the district court's order.[SENTMARKER]Following plaintiffs' motion to enforce the preliminary injunction, the court granted it in part, finding that the defendants had not substantially complied with certain requirements, but denied it in part.[SENTMARKER]As of April 16, 2021, this case is pending a writ of certiorari in front of the Supreme Court.
pegasus_output_sents: In November 2008, a group of noncitizens detained pursuant to 8 U.S.C.  1231(a) filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief under the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and the Fifth Amendment due process clause.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification on their statutory and constitutional claims, and granted a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit reversed the district court's grant of the preliminary injunction, and the Supreme Court remanded for consideration of the plaintiffs’ constitutional due process challenges to the statutes at issue in the case.[SENTMARKER]On April 7, 2020, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the District Court's June 2018 order.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court held that Title I of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) requires only a showing that disability was a motivating factor to prove a violation of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On June 7, 2018, Community Legal Services in East Palo Alto and the National Immigration Project of the National Lawyers Guild filed this lawsuit against the U.S. Department of Homeland Security and the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement for failure to comply with a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request submitted on March 2, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled in August 2020, resulting in a $16,000 litigation expenses and the release of the requested documents.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 2, 2017, Community Legal Services in East Palo Alto and the National Immigration Project of the National Lawyers Guild brought this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) against the United States Department of Homeland Security (DHS).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that DHS violated the FOIA by failing to respond to a FOIA request filed by the plaintiffs in March 2017.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the defendants failed to produce any records responsive to the FOIA request.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment and ordered the defendants to pay $16,350.10 (Sixteen thousand three hundred-fifty dollars and ten cents) to the plaintiffs for their fees, costs, and litigation expenses under the FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: A group of Iranian refugees and their U.S. sponsors filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California after the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) denied their refugee resettlement applications en masse in February 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs applied for refugee resettlement through the Vienna, Austria-based Lautenberg-Specter program for Iranian religious minorities, but received mass denials with the sole explanation that they were denied "as a matter of discretion."[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that this violated the Lautenberg Amendment, which mandates that the denial state "to the maximum extent feasible, the reason for the denial," as well as Fifth Amendment due process and DHS's own regulations.[SENTMARKER]On July 2018, the court declared the denial notices unlawful, and ordered DHS to re-issue new notices.[SENTMARKER]As of June 3, 2020, the case is still ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 19, 2018, a group of Iranian refugees filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) alleging that DHS violated the Lautenberg Amendment and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by denying their applications for refugee admission to the United States.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the denials of their applications were based on the content of the Notices of Ineligibility issued by DHS, which stated that the refugees' applications were denied as a matter of discretion, without further explanation, without any further statement of the reason for the denial, and failed to comply with applicable agency procedures.[SENTMARKER]On April 20, 2018, the Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment and granted their motion for class certification.[SENTMARKER]On May 13, 2019, the Court denied the government's motion to stay the case, finding that there was no genuine issue of material fact for purposes of purposes of determining whether the Notices were unlawful.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: The city and county of San Francisco brought this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, alleging that the Department of Justice (DOJ) had unlawfully conditioned states' acceptance of certain federal funds on their compliance with federal immigration enforcement efforts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that these conditions violated the Spending Clause and the separation of powers under the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted summary judgment for the plaintiff in March, 2019.
pegasus_output_sents: In August 2018, California and San Francisco filed lawsuits in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Department of Justice (DOJ) challenging the DOJ's authority to impose immigration-related conditions on federal law enforcement funding.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief that the conditions were unconstitutional violations of the Separation of Powers and the Spending Clause of the United States Constitution and to enjoin the DOJ from enforcing the challenged conditions or withholding Byrne JAG funds based on those 3 requirements.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ moved for partial dismissal or summary judgment, insisting that the nondisclosure and information 24 conditions are sufficiently related to the federal interests in the program to be dismissed or dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the DOJ’s motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit affirmed the district court’s 10 judgment in favor of San Francisco on the merits of the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On February 14, 2019, a group of asylum seekers from Central America and several legal organizations filed this lawsuit against the Trump Administration in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Administration's new policy of forcing asylum seekers to return to Mexico while awaiting their court hearings (the Migrant Protection Protocols), violated the INA and APA.[SENTMARKER]The district court issued a nationwide injunction which was later affirmed by the Ninth Circuit, but the U.S. Supreme Court subsequently halted the injunction, leaving the MPP in effect nationwide.On April 10, 2020, the government filed a petitino for certiorari with the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]On October 19, 2020, the Supreme Court granted certi.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 28, 2020, a group of non-Mexican asylum seekers brought this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and Customs and Border Protection (CBP) seeking relief under the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) and the 8 Administrative Procedure Act (APA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the new policy of forcing asylum seekers to return to Mexico while they await their removal proceedings violated the 4 humanitarian protections to which they are entitled under United States and international law.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, finding that the plaintiffs had shown a likelihood of success on the merits of their claim that the return-to-Mexico requirement of the Migrant Protection Protocols (MPP) is inconsistent with the statutory non-refoulement obligations of the United States.[SENTMARKER]On April 10, 2020, the court issued an emergency stay of the preliminary injunction pending the outcome of DHS' appeal of the district court's decision.[SENTMARKER]On October 1, 2020, the Court of Appeals for the 9th Circuit granted the government's motion to stay the injunction pending its appeal.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On June 16, 2019, plaintiffs--three immigration attorneys and two noncitizens who filed FOIA (FOIA) requests for individual immigration case files (known as A-Files)--filed this class-action suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs, represented by the American Immigration Council and the Northwest Immigrant Rights Project, sought declaratory relief that defendants’ failure to make timely determinations on plaintiffs’ and proposed classes’ A-File FOIA requests violates FOIA, and a nationwide injunction requiring defendants to make timely determinations.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' request for declaratory and injunctive relief and ordered the defendants to provide quarterly reports on their compliance with the FOIA.
