pegasus_output_sents: On June 16, 2019, three immigration attorneys and two noncitizens filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California on behalf of individuals who filed Freedom of Information Act requests for individual immigration case files, also known as Alien 4 Registration Files or A-Files.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated FOIA by failing to meet the statutory deadline with respect to A-File FOIA requests.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in 1992, in which the parties agreed to implement expedited processing of FOIA requests where the requester demonstrates that an individual’s life or personal safety would be jeopardized or that substantial due process rights would be impaired by the failure to process a request immediately.[SENTMARKER]On August 28, 2020, the Ninth Circuit reversed and remanded on a separate issue, granting preliminary injunctive relief to plaintiff organizations that serve low-income applicants for immigration benefits and staying USCIS rule fee changes for immigration benefit requests.[SENTMARKER]On March 29, 2020, the parties filed a joint status report by March 30, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The parties shall file a joint case management statement by June 30, 2021.

gold_sents: This lawsuit was filed in response to a July 6, 2020 ICE directive that would effectively force out of the country many international students studying remotely during the 2020 coronavirus pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The University of California filed suit claiming that the directive was in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act. Plaintiffs sought a temporary restraining order and an order vacating and setting aside the policy.[SENTMARKER]They also sought declarative relief and attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]In a different lawsuit filed against the administration over the same July directive, the plaintiffs met with counsel for the government and worked to get the regulations rescinded.[SENTMARKER]In order to effectuate the rescission, ICE removed the guidance from its website and replaced it with the previous guidance and as a result, plaintiffs withdrew their motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs in this case continued to monitor the alterations ICE made to its website between July and September and filed a notice of voluntary dismissal on October 6, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 6, 2020, the Regents of the University of California filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security and the Student and Exchange Visitor Program (SEVP), a division of ICE.[SENTMARKER]The Regents sought a temporary restraining order enjoining the defendants from implementing their July 6, 2020 memorandum and news release, which announced that schools adopting a hybrid model – that is, a mixture of online and in person classes – must certify to SEVP for each F-1 visa student attending such school by August 4, 2020, and that the student is taking the minimum number of online classes required to make normal progress in their degree program.[SENTMARKER]On March 13, 2020, the defendants issued an exemption to a preexisting regulation that required international students on F-1 visas to attend classes in person if they wished to remain in this country.[SENTMARKER]On July 10, 2020, The Regents served Defendants with the summons and complaint filed in this matter, as well as a Motion for Temporary Restraining Order and Order to Show Cause re: Preliminary Injunction (TRO Motion) to enjoin Defendants from implementing the Directive.[SENTMARKER]The TRO Motion was granted, and the TRO was entered on July 11, 2020.[SENTMARKER]On July 12, 2020, the court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Seven unnamed individuals sued ICE and DHS over their new directive that would effectively force international students to take in-person classes or risk deportation.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged violations of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Due Process Clause.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought injunctive relief prohibiting the enforcement of the directive and an order vacating the directive.[SENTMARKER]On July 15, in a different lawsuit filed against the administration over the same July directive, plaintiffs met with counsel for the government and worked to get the regulations rescinded.[SENTMARKER]In order to effectuate the rescission, ICE removed the guidance from its website and replaced it with the previous guidance, but the plaintiffs in this case filed an amended complaint that sought a formal declaration that the July 6 directive was improperly issued and an order that the government administer the student visa program in accordance with the March guidance for the duration of the emergency.[SENTMARKER]The court found that the students' claims were mooted by the rescission and granted the government's motion to dismiss on October 1, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 10, 2020, a group of graduate students studying at California universities on F-1 visas filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against the Department of Homeland Security's Student and Exchange Visa Program (SEVP) and the acting director of the SEVP.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a temporary restraining order (TRO) enjoining the implementation of a July 6 policy change that barred student visa holders from remaining in the United States during the upcoming fall semester if their universities cancelled in-person classes in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]On July 11, 2020, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment on the grounds that the policy change was unlawful and unlawful promulgated.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2020, the State of California, the City of Los Angeles, the City of Long Beach, the City of Oakland, and the Los Angeles Unified School District filed this lawsuit in the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that President Trump's Memorandum violated the constitutional mandates for the census (actual enumeration and apportionment) and separation of powers, as well as violating the Census Act and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing as of September 28, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 6, 2020, the City of Los Angeles and the Los Angeles Unified School District filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory, injunctive, mandamus, and other relief to prevent the Census Bureau from taking any action to exclude undocumented immigrants from the 2020 3 Census apportionment count.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the Bureau's decision to add a citizenship question to the 2020 Census questionnaire on citizenship status violated the Administrative Procedure Act, the Constitution, and the Voting Rights Act.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court agreed and affirmed the Supreme Court's vacatur of the Secretary of Commerce's earlier decision to remove the citizenship question from the census.[SENTMARKER]The Court also agreed that the Census Act requires the Bureau to include all persons 15 counted in each state, including undocumented immigrants, in the apportionment base used to apportion congressional representatives.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs are entitled to a declaration that the Constitution and the census act require the Census bureau to include undocumented immigrants in his apportionment report to Congress issued under 2 U.s.C.  2(a) and that the census bureau's failure to comply with the notice-and-comment rulemaking requirement before dispensing with the Residence Rule caused ongoing harm to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: The Civil Rights Education and Enforcement Center (CREEC) filed this suit against DHS and ICE under FOIA, seeking information regarding substandard and abusive conditions of confinement against individuals detained at two immigration detention facilities.[SENTMARKER]As of March 25, 2021, a settlement has been reached as to the evidence, but litigation continues for the plaintiff's attorney's fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 7, 2018, Civil Rights Education and Enforcement Center, a non-profit organization that provides legal assistance, advocacy, and public education concerning actions, practices, and policies that abridge or threaten the civil rights of individuals in the United States, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) seeking declaratory and injunctive relief to effect the release by the Defendants of agency records that Plaintiff has requested from the Defendants pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA).[SENTMARKER]On April 3, 2018, CREEC electronically filed an FOIA request with DHS seeking certain agency records regarding conditions of confinement at all facilities used by ICE for detention of individuals during their immigration proceedings, limited to ten discrete categories of information related to detainees having disabilities.[SENTMARKER]As a result of the defendants' failure to respond to CREEC's requests pursuant to FOIA, the court granted the plaintiff's motion for partial summary judgment, and granted the plaintiffs' motion for a permanent injunction.[SENTMARKER]On February 8, 2019, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiff, permanently enjoining the defendants from charging CREEC any retrieval fees, duplication charges, or review fees as a condition of providing the requested records.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the Plaintiff's request for a partial injunction.

gold_sents: On August 10, 2007, attorneys and Yale Law student interns filed a lawsuit under the Freedom of Information Act seeking documents from the U.S. Department of Homeland Security regarding an immigration raid in New Haven.[SENTMARKER]After several rounds of in camera reviews by the District Court (Judge Mark R. Kravitz), the parties settled the dispute in November of 2009.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 10, 2007, two community groups based in New Haven, Connecticut filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Connecticut against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) seeking the release of records related to a federal immigration enforcement action that resulted in the arrest of approximately 30 men and women in the city of New Haven on June 6, 2007.[SENTMARKER]The parties sought records relating to the Municipal Identification Card Program and the June 6, 2007 immigration enforcement operation to the city.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a joint motion for summary judgment, which was denied by the Court.[SENTMARKER]On November 4, 2009, the Court entered a judgment in favor of the parties, requiring the parties to pay all costs and attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]On January 15, 2010, the parties agreed to a settlement agreement, which included the release to those individuals for whom Plaintiffs had provided a consent form, the portion of the document that concerns that particular individual.

gold_sents: On Jan.[SENTMARKER]6, 2015, Central American immigrant mothers and children filed a class action lawsuit against DHS and ICE, challenging their "No-Release Policy" in making custody determinations for asylum-seeking families.[SENTMARKER]On Feb.[SENTMARKER]20, 2015, the Court granted a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]Defendants ended the policy in May 2015.[SENTMARKER]This case is now administratively closed.[SENTMARKER]If the defendants reinstate a policy of considering deterrence in determining whether to detain a family, they must notify the court and the plaintiffs may move to administratively reopen the case.[SENTMARKER]Since June 2015, there has been no additional activity in the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 6, 2015, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and two ICE officials under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' policy of detention without individualized determination of flight risk and danger to the community, but rather to deter other migrants from coming to the United States, violated the Fifth Amendment and the Due Process Clause of the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive and declaratory relief, and sought a preliminary injunction to prevent DHS from applying this policy until a final determination has been reached on the merits of this action.[SENTMARKER]The parties subsequently conferred and submitted a joint proposal for moving forward.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion to proceed anonymously and granted their motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On April 18, 2017, the American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Council filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, seeking for the court to compel United States Customs and Border Patrol to comply with a Freedom of Information Act request.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought records of CBP action revoking, suspending, or terminating participation int he Global Entry System for certain Arab and Muslim U.S.[SENTMARKER]Citizens and Lawful Permanent Residents.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered joint status updates.[SENTMARKER]In March 2019, the parties informed the court that they had resolved the records production dispute.[SENTMARKER]In July 2019, they informed the court that they had reached an agreement regarding attorneys’ fees and costs, and requesting that the case be dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the case on July 26, 2019.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 3, 2017, the American Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee ( ADC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against U.s. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) seeking expedited processing of FOIA requests related to CBP's actions to revoke, suspend, or terminate participation in the Global Entry System (GES) for certain Arab and Muslim American citizens and Lawful Permanent Residents (LPRs) without any legal justification.[SENTMARKER]ADC sought declaratory and injunctive relief under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) to compel CBP to search for and produce the records requested by ADC.[SENTMARKER]On February 15, 2019, the parties filed a joint status report in which the parties agreed to resolve their differences as to the parties' respective FOIA requests.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that CBP would produce to ADC on an expedited basis all agency records responsive to ADC's requests, not exempt pursuant to FOIA; would pay ADC reasonable attorneys' fees and costs; and would submit a proposed plan for resolution of any unresolved issue with respect to attorneys’ fees on or before March 1, 2019.[SENTMARKER]In light of the parties’ most recent status report, the parties shall file an updated joint report by July 5, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The parties shall submit an updated FOIA status report by March 22, 2019 to update the Court on their anticipated course of action.[SENTMARKER]The only remaining issue for the parties to discuss is possible attorney's fees.

gold_sents: On Oct. 24, 2017, the Protect Democracy Project sued DHS and CBP in D.D.C.[SENTMARKER]under FOIA.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff sought disclosure of agency records on the extent to which defendants cooperate with armed private militia groups along the U.S.-Mexico border.[SENTMARKER]This case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 24, 2017, The Protect Democracy Project, Inc. filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and Customs and Border Protection (CBP) under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) seeking information concerning the extent to which DHS and CBP cooperate with armed private militia groups along the United States-Mexico border.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff's FOIA requests sought information about the role of unaffiliated border enforcement groups in the Trump Administration's immigration policy.[SENTMARKER]Defendants have failed to process these requests in the manner required by FOIA, and failed to respond to the requests within the deadline mandated by FOIA.[SENTMARKER]On May 19, 2020, the parties filed a joint status report in which the parties stated that they are working together to resolve the outstanding issues in this FOIA case.[SENTMARKER]The parties also requested an explanation from DHS in connection with redactions made in the case.[SENTMARKER]On June 12, 2020, the court ordered that the parties file a further status report on or before June 12, 2020.[SENTMARKER]By joint request of the parties, the parties agreed to a partial index from DHS for the remaining pages identified by Plaintiff; and (iii) attorneys' fees.

gold_sents: On August 23, 2018, Muslim Advocates filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia against the United States Department of Justice [DOJ] and United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement [ICE].[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged violations of the Freedom of Information Act [FOIA], 5 U.S.C. § 552(a).[SENTMARKER]Muslim Advocates had requested information from both defendants regarding Operation Janus, where the DOJ reviewed the files of naturalized citizens and began intensive denaturalization efforts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case moved to settlement negotiations; an agreement on all FOIA issues was reached on January 13, 2020, but negotiations over attorneys fees are ongoing as of June 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 11, 2018, Muslim Advocates, a not-for-profit legal advocacy and educational organization, filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Justice's National Security Division (NSD) and the United States Department of Homeland Security's (DHS) Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) seeking documents related to the federal government's denaturalization efforts, including but not limited to "Operation Janus," a joint initiative between DOJ and DHS.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the DOJ's Civil Division and DHS's component agency, USCIS, violated FOIA by failing to process and release responsive documents to Muslim Advocates.[SENTMARKER]On July 6, 2018, the court granted Muslim Advocates' request for declaratory, injunctive, and other appropriate relief.[SENTMARKER]On June 15, 2018, the parties filed a joint status report in which the parties agreed to comply with the court's orders.[SENTMARKER]The parties' Joint Status Report was filed on or before April 10, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that they would file a joint report by May 29, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for partial dismissal of the case on June 15, 2018.

gold_sents: On November 20, 2018, a group of asylum seekers challenged a federal government policy of denying asylum to people who entered the United States, without inspection, along the southern border.[SENTMARKER]They claimed violations of the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and the William Wilberforce Trafficking Victims Protection Act, and sought declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]This case was later consolidated with S.M.S.R.[SENTMARKER]v. Trump.[SENTMARKER]The court granted class certification and partial summary judgment to the plaintiffs on August 2, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the ruling.[SENTMARKER]As of August 2020, the case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 9, 2018, a group of noncitizens who entered the United States illegally and who wish to seek asylum filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Secretary of DHS.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the DHS's categorical bar on asylum eligibility for individuals and families entering the US across the southern border outside designated ports of entry violated the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On November 19, 2018, the court issued a temporary restraining order enjoining the implementation of the Rule nationwide.[SENTMARKER]On December 7, 2018, the Ninth Circuit issued its opinion denying the Government's request for an emergency administrative stay and stay pending appeal of the district court's temporary restraining orders.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: 37 families detained at three ICE-managed family residential centers sued the U.S. Department of Homeland Security alleging violations of their Fifth Amendment constitutional rights, violations of the Administrative Procedure Act, and violations of the Flores Settlement Agreement.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the congregate environment and unsanitary conditions of the detention centers make them a tinderbox for a COVID-19 outbreak.[SENTMARKER]They sought immediate release until proper protocols could be implemented.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs moved for a temporary restraining order which was granted in part and denied in part on March 30.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered ICE to provide appropriate infection protocols for the adults (a similar order from another case, Flores, applies to the children), to comply with CDC guidelines for congregate institutions, and to file a report regarding FRC capacity, implementation of the CDC guidelines, the number of detainees released, and videotape of the living conditions at the FRCs.[SENTMARKER]On May 26, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss and a motion in opposition to the temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the plaintiffs' later motion for a preliminary injunction demanding wholesale release of detainees on July 22.[SENTMARKER]On December 10, the court dismissed the claim under the APA and the writs of mandamus.[SENTMARKER]A hearing is scheduled for February 16, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 21, 2020, a group of noncitizen parents and minor children seeking asylum in the United States filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against the Department of Homeland Security's Office of Civil Rights and Civil Liberties (CRCL) and William Wolf, acting Secretary of DHS.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the government was failing to adequately protect them from contracting COVID-19 during the removal process and that the facilities in which they were detained did not comply with the terms of a 1997 class-wide consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction and ordered the government to provide the plaintiffs with adequate medical and mental health care.[SENTMARKER]On March 22, 2020, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On April 23, 2020, a group of transgender people in civil immigration detention filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs requested an injunction ordering supervised release of all transgender people in immigration detention in light of the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]On June 2, the court denied the plaintiff's motion for TRO and motion for class certification.[SENTMARKER]After filing an amended complaint in August, 2020, the case was dismissed on January 6, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 5, 2020, a group of transgender immigrants filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Homeland Security's (DHS) Office of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) seeking the release of all transgender people in ICE detention facilities nationwide.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that ICE's failure to adequately protect transgender detainees from the COVID-19 pandemic has increased the risk of illness and death in the detention centers.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought a temporary restraining order (TRO) directing ICE to provide transgender detainees with medically necessary, gender-affirming care, including hormone replacement therapy and other gendering care.[SENTMARKER]They also sought to certify a nationwide class of transgender detainees in any ICE detention center or facility across the country.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction and granted their motion for class certification.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Three non-citizen soldiers in the U.S. military brought this class-action lawsuit against the Department of Defense in September 2017.[SENTMARKER]The Department was refusing to certify their honorable military service for purposes of expedited naturalization under the Immigration and Nationality Act.[SENTMARKER]The court issued a preliminary injunction in October 2017, requiring the Department to certify honorable service within 2 days of a soldier’s request, without imposing additional procedural or substantive requirements.[SENTMARKER]As of August 2020, the plaintiffs and the Department of Defense are in mediation.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 24, 2017, ten individuals who enlisted in the Army Reserve’s Selected Reserve of the Ready Reserve filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Defense (DOD), United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS), and others.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants’ refusal to issue them N-426 forms was unlawful under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Constitution of the United States (  706).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that USCIS’s decision to put their naturalization applications on hold pending DOD’s completion of the enhanced security screening required for MAVNI enlistees prior to initial entry training (IET) or active-duty service was unlawful in violation of  1440.[SENTMARKER]On September 1, 2017, the plaintiffs filed a motion for class certification, seeking to certify a class that would include MAVNIs who were serving honorably in the Selected Reserve but had not yet served in an active duty capacity, and those who had not received a completed Form N.426.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a joint status report on August 5, 2017, and the parties agreed to settle the case.[SENTMARKER]On December 16, 2017, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, granted the class certification motion, and ordered the parties to file a joint proposal for resolving the case by August 5.

gold_sents: Non-citizen soldiers in the U.S. military brought this lawsuit in May 2017, challenging policies of the Department of Homeland Security and the Department of Defense that unlawfully delayed their naturalization applications.[SENTMARKER]The court certified a class and granted a preliminary injunction against the agencies on October 27, 2017.[SENTMARKER]On May 22, 2019, the court granted summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, ruling that the agencies’ policy of delaying naturalization applications was arbitrary and capricious, in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The court issued a permanent injunction on August 20, 2020, and retained jurisdiction to enforce the injunction.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 7, 2017, a group of non-citizens enlisted in the U.S. Army's Selected Reserve of the Ready Reserve filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Defense (DOD) and its sub-agency, United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants unlawfully placed their naturalization applications on hold pending the successful completion of specialized background investigations done by the military for DoD purposes (and not required by the laws governing naturalization).[SENTMARKER]The defendants' policies apply to certain MAVNI enlistees who have applied for – or are eligible to apply for – naturalization but have not yet been granted citizenship.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, finding that they had not shown that they were likely to succeed on the merits of their claims.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On August 21, 2020, a 15-year-old unaccompanied minor from Guatemala filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) alleging that the government violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Foreign Affairs Reform and Restructuring Act (FARRA) by deporting him without any hearing, even where, as here, the minor has no symptoms of COVID-19.[SENTMARKER]On June 29, 2020, the government filed a motion to dismiss the case as moot.[SENTMARKER]On August 6, 2020, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a joint motion for a preliminary injunction on August 20, 2020, which was granted by the court.[SENTMARKER]On July 31, 2020, the Supreme Court issued a writ of certiorari.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court reversed the lower court's decision, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: Plaintiff human rights organization sued the Acting Secretary of Homeland Security alleging that revisions to asylum eligibility violated several laws.[SENTMARKER]Federal courts reviewing similar suits in other districts granted a nationwide preliminary injunction that applied here, and the cases are pending review and revision by the Biden administration.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 8, 2019, Human Rights First filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Attorney General of the United States (AG) seeking declaratory, injunctive, and other relief under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), and the Federal Vacancies Reform Act (FVRA) against the DHS and AG.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff's complaint alleged that the DHS's attempt to abrogate the asylum protections codified in the INA and the APA was unlawful in many respects, including the lack of sufficient notice, opportunity for public comment, and the failure to release the full report publicly.[SENTMARKER]On December 11, 2020, the DHS published the final version of the Rule.[SENTMARKER]The final Rule was published in the Federal Register and lists an effective date of January 11, 2021.[SENTMARKER]On January 10, 2020, the District Court granted a preliminary injunction against the rule.[SENTMARKER]On January 11, 2021, the Court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: In 2020, immigrant detainees in three Florida detention centers filed this class action complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The detainees alleged that their detention violated their Due Process rights because the detention centers were not adhering to CDC guidelines to protect them against COVID-19.[SENTMARKER]The court partially granted a temporary restraining order on April 30, 2020, requiring the respondents to implement CDC guidelines for sanitation.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction on June 6 and certified the class.[SENTMARKER]On July 17, the court appointed a Special Master to oversee compliance.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 13, 2020, 341 civil immigration detainees filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida against Miami-Dade County and the Miami Field Office of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) alleging that they were being held at three detention centers in Miami, Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the detention centers were ill-equipped to deal with the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction requiring the defendants to employ numerous safety measures to prevent the spread of COVID19, as well as imposing extensive reporting requirements.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed to the Eleventh Circuit, which granted a stay of the injunction pending an appeal by the defendants.[SENTMARKER]In a 2-1 published opinion with a written dissent, our Appellate Court in Swain granted a motion to stay the District Court’s preliminary injunction pending the appeal.[SENTMARKER]The parties have not been able to reach a mutually agreeable resolution as to the ongoing conditions at the facilities.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 25, 2011, three foreign residents of Indiana filed a class action lawsuit against the cities of Indianapolis and Franklin and the counties of Marion and Johnson, seeking to enjoin enforcement of Indiana's Senate Enrolled Act 590, which would allow local law enforcement officers to make warrantless arrests of people who were subject to a removal order issued by an immigration court or a detainer or notice of action issued by the Department of Homeland Security, or who had been indicted or convicted of an aggravated felony, and would make the use of consular identification cards for identification within the state a civil infraction punishable by fine.[SENTMARKER]On March 28, 2013, the District Court (Judge Barker) ruled in favor of plaintiffs, granting their motion for summary judgment, and permanently enjoining defendants from enforcing Sections 18 and 20 of SEA 590.[SENTMARKER]Because plaintiffs' suit was dependent upon enforcement of these sections, the matter was dismissed without prejudice.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 25, 2011, two citizens of the United States filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Indiana against the City of Indianapolis, the Johnson County Sheriff, and the Office of the Attorney General challenging the constitutionality of two sections of the recently enacted Senate Enrolled Act 590 (SEA 590) of Indiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief on behalf of a class of persons who regularly use their consular identification cards for identification purposes, including, among other things, when banking or interacting with consular officials.[SENTMARKER]On June 24, 2011, the Court entered a preliminary injunction enjoining the State of Indiana from enforcing the two challenged sections of SEA 590 until further order from the Court.[SENTMARKER]On November 20, 2011, the plaintiffs filed a motion for summary judgment, which the Court denied.[SENTMARKER]On December 21, 2011, the court entered a final injunction against the defendants.[SENTMARKER]On January 5, 2012, the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia issued a ruling in favor of the plaintiffs in the Coleman v. Raines case.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court held that the plaintiffs had standing to sue the state of Indiana for violations of the Fourth Amendment, principles of due process, and federal preemption for immigration matters.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On February 1, 2017, an Iranian-born researcher and J-1 visa holder filed this lawsuit after being prevented from boarding a flight to the United States on both January 28, 2017 and January 30, 2017, pursuant to an executive order issued by President Donald Trump on January 27, 2017.[SENTMARKER]On February 2, 2017 the plaintiff filed an emergency motion seeking a Temporary Restraining Order against the defendants, but on February 3, 2017 the plaintiff requested that the hearing on the TRO be cancelled, as she was able to travel to the United States and clear customs.[SENTMARKER]On March 6, 2017, the President rescinded the January 27 Executive Order and replaced it with a narrower one.[SENTMARKER]On May 31, plaintiff filed a notice of voluntary dismissal without prejudice, mentioning the Fourth Circuit's injunction of the revised Executive Order in IRAP v. Trump.[SENTMARKER]This case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 29, 2017, Dr. Samira Asgari filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the President of the United States, the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, and the Director of the Boston Field Office of Customs and Border Protection.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that President Trump's January 27, 2017 executive order barring entry into the United states by nationals of certain Muslim majority countries, including Iran, Iraq, Syria, Sudan, Libya, Somalia, and Yemen, was unlawful and violated the federal immigration laws.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the Plaintiff's request for a temporary restraining order (TRO) on February 2, 2017.[SENTMARKER]On May 31, 2017, Judge Allison D. Burroughs issued a TRO enjoining the Defendants from enforcing the President's executive order until June 5, 2017 and suspending the implementation of the Executive Order for a period of approximately sixty (60) days.[SENTMARKER]On June 6, 2017, Judge Burroughs granted the Defendants' motion to dismiss the case without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The TRO was granted by Judge Burroughs and Judge Judith Gail Dein.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a joint motion for summary judgment on June 7, 2017.[SENTMARKER]On June 8, 2017, the parties filed a motion for a preliminary injunction, which was granted on June 10, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a permanent injunction on June 11, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In February 2018, an undocumented immigrant who was married to a U.S. citizen filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that her unexpected arrest and detainment without notice or a hearing violated her due process rights under the Fourteenth Amendment, the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA).[SENTMARKER]In April 2018, nine more plaintiffs were added, and they sought class certification, which was approved on May 17, 2019.[SENTMARKER]On June 27, the district court instructed the defendants to begin providing monthly reports to class counsel regarding class members.[SENTMARKER]On March 24, 2020 the plaintiffs filed a motion for immediate release of that class member because he was detained in a facility where an employee tested positive for COVID-19.[SENTMARKER]On April 16, the parties filed a joint status report that altered the terms of release for the class member and the court lifted the stay on the class member's removal by ICE.[SENTMARKER]ICE imposed conditions of supervision pursuant to the parties' agreement.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss on November 18, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In November 2016, two immigrants filed a petition in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts, claiming that they were detained under color of the authority of the United States, in violation of the Constitution, laws, or treaties.[SENTMARKER]The parties stipulated to dismissal of the case on February 12, 2018.[SENTMARKER]On February 12, 2018, the parties reported that they had not agreed on a settlement.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered that the parties confer concerning whether they could reach an agreement to resolve this case.[SENTMARKER]On February 5, 2018, the court granted the defendants' motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then filed a motion for writ of habeas corpus, seeking to enjoin the defendants from attempting to remove their alien spouses.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed, and the parties have agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: On July 27, 2020, Haitian-Americans United, Inc., Brazilian Worker Center, Chelsea Collaborative, Inc. and Centro Presente filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District Of Massachusetts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Presidential Memorandum titled “Excluding Illegal Aliens from the Apportionment Base Following the 2020 Census” is unconstitutional and that any compliance violates §§ 706(2) of the APA because it is contrary to constitutional power, right, privilege, or immunity and in excess of statutory jurisdiction and authority, and without observance of procedure required by law.[SENTMARKER]The case has been approved for a three-judge court and is awaiting the defendants' answer.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 21, 2020, Haitian-Americans United, Inc. and Centro Presente filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the United States Department of Commerce, Secretary of Commerce Wilbur Ross, and the Census Bureau.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs allege that the defendants' plan to exclude undocumented immigrants from the congressional apportionment base for the first time in our nation's history violates the constitutional rights of immigrants of color, non-citizens, undocumented residents, and foreign-born individuals.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs are seeking declaratory and injunctive relief, including the production of population tabulations excluding undocumented individuals for the purposes of congressional apportionment.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction on July 22, 2020, and the case is ongoing.

gold_sents: On Jan.[SENTMARKER]24, 2018, the NAACP sued the DHS over its Nov. 2017 revocation of Temporary Protected Status (first implemented after the Jan.[SENTMARKER]2017 revocation of Temporary Protected Status (first implemented after the Jan.[SENTMARKER]2010 Haitian earthquake) for Haitians living in the United States.[SENTMARKER]The NAACP alleged that DHS violated the 5th Amendment by relying on racially discriminatory stereotypes to deprive Haitians of rights and sought mandamus and declaratory relief.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss, which was granted in part and denied in part by the court on March 12, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The court allowed the plaintiffs' 5th Amendment claims to move forward.[SENTMARKER]Due to ongoing parallel litigation over the revocation of TPS for Haitians, the defendants requested a stay in this case.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the stay in March 2020.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 20, 2017, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) and Haitian Women for Haitian Refugees (HLA) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the former acting DHS Secretary, Elaine C. gold_sents: This is a habeas action seeking the release of immigration detainees housed in ICE facilities in Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The court initially denied the detainees' TRO, but eventually granted two preliminary injunctions that ordered the release of several detainees from their respective detention centers.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the petitioners' motion for class certification.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 23, 2020, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the Department of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and the Howard County Department of Corrections.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Fourteenth Amendment due process rights of immigration detainees by putting them in extreme danger of exposure to COVID-19, a lethal virus with no vaccine or cure.[SENTMARKER]On April 3, 2020, the Court issued a memorandum opinion and order denying without prejudice a Motion for a Temporary Restraining Order (TRO) in which the plaintiffs sought their immediate release from ICE detention.[SENTMARKER]The Court held that the plaintiffs had not shown they were likely to succeed on the merits of their claims that their continued ICE detention violated their right to due process under the 14th Amendment to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]On March 24, 2020, the plaintiffs filed a petition for a writ of Habeas Corpus and a motion for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief, along with a TRO seeking their release from the detention facility entirely.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order on April 27, 2020.[SENTMARKER]On April 28, 2020, the court issued a Memorandum Opinion and Order denying the defendants' motion to dismiss the case without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On September 22, 2006, Windhover, Inc. and others filed suit in the Circuit Court for the County of St. Louis against the City of Valley Park, Missouri, challenging two City Ordinances that were intended to eliminate the housing and hiring of illegal immigrants within the City.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the ordinances violated the Fair Housing Act, 42 U.S.C.  3601, et seq., and the Open Meetings Law.[SENTMARKER]On August 3, 2007, the district court dismissed the case with prejudice, holding that there was no longer a case or controversy.[SENTMARKER]On March 14, 2007, the plaintiffs filed a motion for summary judgment, seeking attorney's fees and a declaration that the case was not moot.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the City's motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This is a habeas action filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi, seeking the release of seven medically vulnerable detainees in light of COVID-19, citing constitutional violations associated with their continued detention.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a TRO, but it was denied on June 3, 2020, and the plaintiffs dismissed the case on August 4, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 1, 2020, a group of immigrants detained at Adams County Detention Center in Natchez, Mississippi, filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that their detention violated their right to substantive and procedural due process under the Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution and the right to be free from cruel and unusual punishment under the Eighth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On May 22, 2020, the court denied the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order, finding that the plaintiffs had not shown that they were likely to succeed on the merits of their case at hand.[SENTMARKER]The case is now pending appeal to the Fifth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The court also denied the defendants' motion to dismiss the case without prejudice.

pegasus_output_sents: On October 7, 2013, the Montana Human Rights Bureau filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Montana against the Montana Highway Patrol, the Montana Department of Justice, and the Montana Attorney General.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' practice of detaining Latino passengers in a vehicle to investigate their immigration status without reasonable suspicion that the passenger is committing a criminal violation violated the plaintiffs' Fourteenth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed by Judge Dana L. pegasus_output_sents: On June 16, 1997, a group of foreign nationals seeking asylum in the United States filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania, alleging that a private detention center in Elizabeth, New Jersey violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) by denying them access to a law library and legal materials.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that their personal property was confiscated or destroyed while they were detained at the facility.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was remanded to the Fifth Circuit for further consideration.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit reversed the district court's judgment of fees, holding that the plaintiffs were not prevailing parties, and were thus ineligible for fees under  1988.[SENTMARKER]The court remanded the matter to the District Court to make a discretionary determination in the first instance.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the plaintiffs have no further legal recourse.

pegasus_output_sents: On September 20, 2007, the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund (PRLDEF) and the international law firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene MacRae LLP filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the Department of Homeland Security and the New York Regional Office of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their constitutional rights by unlawfully searching their homes and targeting Latinos for arrest.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief along with back-pay and punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment in part and denied the defendants' motion to dismiss the claims on the pleadings.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on July 2, 2009, and the defendants appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the 2nd Circuit.[SENTMARKER]On May 19, 2011, the appeals court dismissed the case on the grounds that the district court did not have standing to grant a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The appeals court found that the plaintiffs had standing to file this suit.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs, and the case is closed.

gold_sents: This case was brought to challenge the U.S. government's failure to timely adjudicate applications for naturalization by lawful permanent residents of the state of New York.[SENTMARKER]The case was resolve by a settlement whose terms are not available.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 11, 2008, the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund and the New York Legal Assistance Group filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on behalf of all lawful permanent residents in the United States who had submitted complete applications for naturalization that had not been adjudicated within a reasonable time.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the delays resulted from the imposition of the FBI name check requirement, which required that a complete FBI criminal background investigation be conducted on each applicant for citizenship prior to receiving the results of the name check.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case on September 11, 2008 and the case was remanded to the Second Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit remanded the case to the district court to consider the merits of the plaintiffs' class certification motion on January 26, 2010.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 18, 2010, two organizations comprised of day laborers and/or predominately Latino immigrant workers filed a class action lawsuit in the Eastern District Court of New York under the First and Fourteenth Amendments against the Town of Oyster Bay.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by the ACLU and LatinoJustice PRLDEF, sought injunctive relief, declaratory relief, and attorneys' fees and costs, claiming that the defendants, through the passage of an ordinance prohibiting the solicitation of labor from the town's streets and sidewalks, unlawfully prohibited speech related to employment and had a discriminatory animus against predominately Latino immigrant day laborers.[SENTMARKER]After defeating the defendant's partial motion for summary judgment due to lack of standing, plaintiff's motion for summary judgment was successful.[SENTMARKER]On September 3, 2015, the District Court enjoined the ordinance and declared it unconstitutional as it violated the first amendment.[SENTMARKER]On August 22, 2017, the Second Circuit affirmed the District Court's decision.[SENTMARKER]In July 2019, the court assessed attorney fees against the defendants, and the case closed later that year.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 18, 2010, two organizations of day laborers in Oyster Bay, New York filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York against the Town of Oyster Bay and its Supervisor.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Town's new law prohibiting day laborers from standing on a public street from stopping or attempting to stop vehicles for employment-related purposes violated their constitutional rights to free speech and equal protection of the laws.[SENTMARKER]On June 18, 2013, the District Court entered a preliminary injunction on free speech grounds.[SENTMARKER]The Town appealed to the Second Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit dismissed the appeal, and the parties agreed to leave the preliminary injunction in effect.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
