pegasus_output_sents: On July 29, 2014, the American Immigration Council, the National Immigration Project of the National Lawyers Guild, and the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) action in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and its component agencies under the Immigration and Nationality Act and the Due Process Clause.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought expedited processing records related to the implementation of expedited removal at the Artesia detention facility.[SENTMARKER]The defendants denied the plaintiffs' request for expedited processing and denied their request for a fee waiver.[SENTMARKER]On October 21, 2014, the court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment and dismissed the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Sixteen states filed this lawsuit against the federal government on September 6, 2017 in response to the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) memorandum issued on Sept.[SENTMARKER]5 ending Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA).[SENTMARKER]The states sought to enjoin the federal government from carrying out portions of the DHS memorandum and from using information about DACA grantees gathered in their applications to enforce immigration policy.[SENTMARKER]While the district court granted in part the government’s motion to dismiss, the plaintiffs obtained a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]On June 18, 2020, the Supreme Court held that DHS's decision to rescind DACA was subject to judicial review under the APA and that the rescission was unlawful.[SENTMARKER]Shortly thereafter, the Acting DHS Secretary issued a memorandum suspending DACA while DHS reviewed it.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed an amended complaint alleging that the Acting Secretary lacked the authority to issue the memorandum because he had not been lawfully appointed to his position.[SENTMARKER]The district court agreed.[SENTMARKER]Accordingly, the court vacated the memorandum and ordered DHS to resume processing DACA applications.[SENTMARKER]This case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 5, 2017, the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) announced that it would end the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program.[SENTMARKER]In response to the President's rescission of the DACA program, a number of states and the District of Columbia filed suit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DHS's policy regarding the use of DACA applicants' information for immigration-enforcement purposes violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment and denied the defendants' motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit affirmed the district court's judgment by an equally divided vote.[SENTMARKER]In a related appeal, the Fifth Circuit denied the government's motion for a preliminary injunction, finding that the policy was arbitrary and capricious under the APA.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on October 5, 2018.

gold_sents: In 2018, several states filed a complaint against the Department of Justice in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the immigration-related conditions being placed on funding disbursed by the Department of Justice violated the Separation of Powers, the APA and the Tenth Amendment Anti-Commandeering.[SENTMARKER]In 2018, a judge granted partial summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]In 2019, the defendants appealed this judgment.[SENTMARKER]And later, the plaintiffs made a motion for summary judgment on the 2018 immigration-related conditions.[SENTMARKER]In February 2020, a Second Circuit panel reversed the district court's order granting partial summary judgment, vacated the mandate and injunction, and remanded the case to the district court, concluding that the Attorney General was statutorily authorized to impose the challenged conditions and that the imposition of these conditions was not arbitrary and capricious.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment is currently pending before the district court.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 26, 2020, the State of California and the City of San Francisco filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the Department of Justice (DOJ) and the Attorney General (AG) seeking declaratory and permanent injunctions enjoining the DOJ from imposing certain immigration-related conditions on the Byrne Program Criminal Justice Assistance grant funds.[SENTMARKER]The conditions required the States and localities to (1) provide access to their correctional facilities for federal immigration enforcement agents (the "access condition"); and (2) enjoin the AG from imposing these conditions on any Byrne JAG applicant in order to receive the funds.[SENTMARKER]On June 18, 2020, the district court granted partial judgment in favor of plaintiffs, enjoining enforcement of the challenged conditions as to them and mandating the release of 2017 Byrne grant funds to plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the District Court vacated the partial judgment and remanded the case for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of the United States (S.C.) affirmed the lower court's decision.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In July 2020, several immigration advocacy and nonprofit organizations filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that by excluding “undocumented immigrants from: (a) the tabulation of the total population of the states; .[SENTMARKER](b) the calculation and statement of the whole number of persons in each state; and (c) the calculation and statement of the apportionment of the House of Representatives among the states” the federal government were violating the Enumeration and Apportionment clauses of the United States Constitution, Equal Protection under the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments, the Separation of Powers, the Census Act, and.[SENTMARKER]In August 2020, this case was consolidated with State of New York v. Trump.[SENTMARKER]For additional information, on this case, please see State of New York v. Trump.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 21, 2020, the Immigration Coalition of the Mid-Atlantic and the American-Arab Immigration Coalition (AAIC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the Department of Commerce and the Bureau of the Census.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory, injunctive, and/or mandamus relief to prohibit Defendants from excluding undocumented immigrants from the population count used to apportion congressional seats for purposes of apportioning congressional seats to states.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs alleged that the President's July 21, 2020 Memorandum on Excluding Illegal Aliens From the Apportionment Base Following the 2020 Census violated the Constitution, the Census Act, and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment on July 28, 2020.[SENTMARKER]On September 10, 2020, the court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On February 1, 2008, national, state and local chambers of commerce and other nonprofit organizations advocating for their members' business interests filed a lawsuit against the State of Oklahoma, claiming that Sections 7 and 9 of the Oklahoma Taxpayer and Citizen Protection Act, which impose tax penalties on businesses that don't check the work eligibility of all of their employees in a federal database and allow discharged employees to bring discrimination suits against their employers for employing unauthorized workers, were preempted by the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the plaintiffs a preliminary injunction on June 4, 2008, and on appeal to the Tenth Circuit the injunction was upheld except for as to the verification requirement.[SENTMARKER]On remand to the District Court, the case was stayed pending the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Whiting, which Supreme Court later held that an Arizona law requiring employers to use E-Verify was not preempted by federal law.[SENTMARKER]Pursuant to this decision, the district court entered in a judgment on December 19th, 2012, holding that Oklahoma can require persons to contract with the State to use the employment authorization system.[SENTMARKER]However, the provision creating a cause of action for discrimination against employers who terminate an authorized employee while retaining an unauthorized employee and the provision requiring businesses to verify individual independent contractors’ authorization status and creating a withholding for work performed by individual independent contractors, were both struck down.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 1, 2008, the Tulsa Chamber of Commerce and the Oklahoma Restaurant Association filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to prevent implementation of sections 7(b), 7(c), and 9 of the Oklahoma Taxpayer and Citizen Protection Act of 2007 ("H.B.[SENTMARKER]2385.32), which prohibits the use of social security numbers to check the Social Security numbers of any non-employee, including independent contractors.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that there was a conflict between the federal employment verification regime and that of the state statute.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction against enforcement of Section 7(B) of the Act, but the case was appealed to the Tenth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Tenth Circuit affirmed the district court's grant of the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to dismiss the case.

gold_sents: In 2008, two detainees filed a habeas petition and class action suit in the Western District of Pennsylvania against the Warden of Allegheny County Jail challenging their continued detention pursuant to immigration detainers and alleging violations of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought habeas relief and class certification.[SENTMARKER]On July 23, 2008, the district court (Judge David S. Cercone) denied the habeas petition as moot, dismissed the action, and denied the motion for class certification because ICE had assumed custody of both petitioners.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 23, 2008, Wilmer Urbina, Omar Romero-Villegas and others filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania against the Allegheny County Sheriff's Office.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were detained in the county jail without due process and based solely on an immigration detainer which does not authorize their detention.[SENTMARKER]On July 15, 2008, Judge David S. Cercone entered an order denying the plaintiffs' motion for writ of habeas corpus.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on July 23, 2008.

gold_sents: On August 23, 2012, ICE Agents and the State of Mississippi filed claims alleging that deferred action Directive commands ICE officers to violate federal law, compels them to violate their oaths of office, violates the Administrative Procedure Act ("APA"), unconstitutionally usurps and encroaches upon the legislative powers of Congress, as defined in Article I of the United States Constitution, and violates the obligation of the executive branch to faithfully execute the law, as required by Article II, Section 3, of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]On January 24, 2013, the Court found that ICE Agent Plaintiffs had standing to proceed, but the State of Mississippi did not.[SENTMARKER]On July 31, 2013, the Court dismissed Plaintiff's claims without prejudice for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction, finding that the dispute must be governed by the Civil Service Reform Act.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit affirmed the judgment of the District Court.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 23, 2012, several Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents and deportation officers filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas against the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and other DHS officials, challenging the constitutional and statutory validity of the DHS's Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, seeking to prevent the DHS from taking any adverse action against them for failure to follow the Directive and related provisions of the Morton Memorandum.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the plaintiffs' claims for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The case eventually made its way to the Supreme Court of the United States.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court upheld the district court's dismissal of Mississippi's claims, finding that the plaintiffs had not alleged a sufficient injury in fact to satisfy the requirements of constitutional standing and that the District Court had no jurisdiction to hear the case.

gold_sents: On Aug.[SENTMARKER]7, 2013, 16 Indian guestworkers filed a lawsuit in E.D.Tx.[SENTMARKER]for harm suffered as a result of an allegedly fraudulent and coercive employment recruitment scheme by Defendant Signal International.[SENTMARKER]As of July 5, 2018, 20 of the 21 plaintiffs had reached a settlement with the Burnett defendants; the remaining plaintiff's claim was dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing as to the Signal defendants and Dewan defendants.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 7, 2013, a group of non-Indian and U.S. citizen workers filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Texas against Signal International LLC, Signal International Texas, L.P., Global Resources, Inc., and J M Marine Industrial, LLC.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were subjected to an objectively hostile and abusive work environment on account of their race and alienage.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that the defendants violated the federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO), the Civil Rights Act of 1866, and the Occupational Safety and Health Act (OSHA) by subjecting them to a hostile work environment and failing to allow them to live and/or pay for accommodations in their labor camps.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement on May 4, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay the plaintiffs a total of $325,000.[SENTMARKER]The settlement proceeds will be divided between the plaintiffs and the defendants, with the plaintiffs receiving a safety bonus in addition to their regular hourly wage.

gold_sents: On October 26, 2015, sixteen undocumented immigrants formerly detained in Dallas County, Texas, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued Dallas County and the Dallas County Sheriff under 42 USC §1983 for violations of the Fourth, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought damages and an injunction preventing the defendants from detaining the plaintiffs solely based on a request from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), an immigration hold, or an immigration detainer.[SENTMARKER]Over time, the case was consolidated with two other lawsuits with identical claims.[SENTMARKER]The state of Texas also intervened as a defendant.[SENTMARKER]The district court initially granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, but allowed the plaintiffs to file an amended complaint.[SENTMARKER]The court then dismissed the plaintiffs' due process claims, allowing them to move forward only with their Fourth Amendment claims.[SENTMARKER]By October 18, 2018, only one plaintiff was still represented by counsel and pursuing a claim (26 had dismissed their claims with prejudice, and 18 had fallen out of contact with counsel and were designated as pro se; their claims were later dismissed).[SENTMARKER]That plaintiff reached a private settlement with the defendants and the court ordered entry of the final judgment on December 4, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff was to be paid $9,500.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 7, 2019, a group of immigrants brought this lawsuit against Dallas County, Texas in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas, alleging that Dallas County violated their Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment rights by refusing to grant them immediate release on bond and by detaining them based on immigration holds after they were otherwise eligible for release.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were held in detention by Dallas County in connection with state criminal charges, while they were subject to federal immigration detainers issued by the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Form I-247, issued by ICE, a component of DHS.[SENTMARKER]Dallas County's practice of refusing immediate release to individuals with immigration holds resulted in pretrial detention.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a motion for new trial in April 2015, and the case was dismissed on January 7, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This suit challenges Texas's "Sanctuary City" legislation, Senate Bill 4 (SB4), which requires local Texas law enforcement to cooperate with federal immigration officials and punishes them if they do not.[SENTMARKER]Unlike the other suits in this special collection, this suit does not challenge President Trump's "Sanctuary City" Executive Order.[SENTMARKER]This case was quickly consolidated with the two other before Judge Orlando L. Garcia; please refer to El Cenizo v. Texas for further information and updates.[SENTMARKER]This case was administratively closed on Oct. 24, 2017 in light of the consolidation.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 7, 2017, the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund (MALDEF) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against the State of Texas, Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton, Texas Department of Public Safety (DPS), and Texas Governor Greg Abbott.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, El Paso County and its Sheriff, Richard Wiles, sought declaratory and injunctive relief for the following legal violations in connection with the enactment, administration, and prospective enforcement of Senate Bill 4 (SB 4), also known as the 'Show Me Your Papers Bill'.[SENTMARKER]SB 4 is an unprecedented, cruel, and vague law that is aimed at the heart of Texas.[SENTMARKER]El Paso has over 800,000 residents, is over 82% Hispanic and over 25% of its residents are foreign born.[SENTMARKER]For instance, the County is under a federal court settlement agreement where it created a policy prohibiting the enforcement of civil immigration laws.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the county attorney's office has adopted a policy that prohibits its investigators from making inquiries into the citizenship or residency status for the purpose of determining whether an individual has violated civil immigration law or for the purposes of enforcing those laws.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the plaintiffs sought a declaration that El Paso's current policies regarding federal immigration enforcement comply with state and federal law and do not violate SB 4.[SENTMARKER]The case was assigned to Chief Judge Orlando L. Garcia.

gold_sents: An individual unlawfully detained in the Bexar County Adult Detention Center filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the United States under the Federal Tort Claims Act for damages.[SENTMARKER]The case settled in November 2019.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 24, 2017, the Plaintiff filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), Bexar County, and other federal defendants.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that he was unlawfully detained in the Bexar County Adult Detention Center (BCADC) from March 24, 2016 until June 8, 2016 without his consent, without notice of any charges, without a warrant, notice to appear in removal proceedings, or an order of removal, and in violation of law.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that ICE's detainer practice exceeds the authority granted to it under the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA).[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff also alleged that the Plaintiff was detained pursuant to a detainer request issued by the ICE San Antonio Field Office.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the defendants' motion for partial summary judgment in part and denied the motion for declaratory relief in part.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This is one in a series of cases challenging comprehensive state immigration laws.[SENTMARKER]In this case, a coalition of immigrant rights groups and individual immigrants challenged Utah's law, HB 497, on preemption grounds and as a violation of equal protection, the right to travel, and the Fourth Amendment prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures.[SENTMARKER]A preemption case brought by the Department of Justice was later consolidated with this case.[SENTMARKER]In 2011, the District Court for the District of Utah has issued a temporary restraining order enjoining the statute.[SENTMARKER]Following the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Arizona, the Court ruled on the motions for preliminary injunctions in June 2014 and ruled against the key provisions of HB 497.[SENTMARKER]In November 2014, the parties filed a joint report, in which the State of Utah agreed to permanently scrap the key problematic provisions of HB 497.[SENTMARKER]On December 4, 2014, the Court entered a judgment per the parties' proposed final agreement and dismissed the remaining claims without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled on attorney fees and costs and the case closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 3, 2011, the Utah Coalition of La Raza, Service Employees International Union (SEIU), and Centro Civico Mexicano filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of Utah against the State of Utah, the Department of Justice, and the Governor of Utah.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the state's immigration enforcement law, House 4 Bill 497, violated the Supremacy Clause, the Fourth Amendment, the Right to Travel, and Section 10 of the Immigration and Nationality Act.[SENTMARKER]The parties sought declaratory and injunctive relief and a temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]On June 25, 2012, the Supreme Court of the United States ruled in Arizona v. Arizona that the federal government's deferred action program, Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA), violated immigration statutes and violated the Constitution and the Administrative Procedure Act. On November 22, 2012, the parties filed a parallel action in the same court.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for preliminary injunction and enjoined the state from enacting and enforcing Section 10 and 11 of the immigration law.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on June 25, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a second motion to consolidate the two cases and the parties agreed to settle the case without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]On July 11, 2012, the court issued a final judgment in favor of the state.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court has not yet issued a decision on the case.

gold_sents: In 2018, Migrant Justice and four individual members of the organization filed this complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Vermont.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the Department of Homeland Security and U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) implemented retaliatory policies in response to their activism on behalf of immigrant farm workers, including extensive surveillance and false imprisonment, in violation of their First Amendment Rights and that the Vermont Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) aided these practices by consistently and intentionally sharing personally identifying information about the plaintiffs with ICE in a manner that violated their Fourteenth Amendment Equal Protection rights.[SENTMARKER]On January 21, 2020, the plaintiffs and the DMV settled, and the DMV agreed to implement new protocols to protect against disclosing immigration and citizenship information with ICE.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs then settled with the remaining defendants on October 28, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement included $100,000 in damages, deferred action for the plaintiffs so they would not be deported, and ICE informing its employees that all immigrants are protected by the First Amendment.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 22, 2018, the ACLU of Vermont and Migrant Justice filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Vermont against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Vermont Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) seeking declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as monetary damages against the United States.[SENTMARKER]Migrant Justice fights for the rights of the approximately 1,500 migrant farm workers in Vermont.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' conduct has caused a number of Vermont-based farm owners to discourage their employees from participating in Migrant Justice activities for fear that their workers would be detained.[SENTMARKER]In April 2016, the Sheriffs Department settled 12 with Migrant Justice and the Human Rights Commission for nearly $30,000.[SENTMARKER]On July 24, 2018, in Racine, Wisconsin, the League of United Latin American Citizens ("LULAC"), the Council President of the local League of Mexican American Citizens, Ricardo Fierro, was arrested and detained by ICE.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants' retaliatory agenda with the assistance of the DMV led to the arrest and detention of two Migrant Justice members after learning about their association with the group.[SENTMARKER]In October 2018, the court granted a motion for summary judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the case in April 2019, and the case is closed.

gold_sents: On July 31, 2018, two non-profit organizations and fifteen individuals filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs challenged the Trump Administration's implementation of the waiver provision of the Travel Ban (Presidential Proclamation No. 9645), alleging that it violates the Administrative Procedure Act and the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]After the Trump Administration concluded, President Biden revoked the Travel Ban and ordered that visa applications resume processing on January 20, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 13, 2018, a group of individuals and organizations filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) in the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the DHS had failed to follow its own policies and procedures in implementing the waiver provision of President Trump's Proclamation No. 9645, "Enhancing Vetting Capabilities and Processes for Detecting Attempted Entry into the United States By Terrorists or other Public-Safety Threats" ("Proclamation").[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief, monetary relief, and other equitable relief under the Administrative Procedure Act and the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]On July 31, 2018, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and denied the defendants' motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]On August 1, 2018, the case was transferred to the federal district court in San Francisco, where the parties agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: In March 2020, during the outbreak of COVID-19 in the Seattle area, persons critically vulnerable to the disease and held in an immigration detention facility near Seattle filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued ICE and its directors for violation of their constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that continued detention in the face of a potential outbreak in the detention facility would expose the plaintiffs to substantial harm and amount to punishment in violation of the Due Process Clause.[SENTMARKER]On March 19, the court denied the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order seeking immediate release.[SENTMARKER]The court also denied the plaintiffs' second motion for a temporary restraining order on April 8.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss on April 30, which the court has not yet resolved.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 16, 2020, immigration detainees at the Tacoma Northwest Detention Center (NWDC) filed a petition in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington, seeking a writ of habeas corpus, injunctive relief, and an order to reopen their immigration cases.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' conditions of confinement subject them to heightened risk of contracting COVID-19, for which there is no vaccine, known treatment, or cure.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed by the Board of Immigration Appeals (BIA) on December 2, 2019.[SENTMARKER]On April 3, 2020, the BIA dismissed the case for lack of standing.[SENTMARKER]The BIA held that the plaintiffs had not demonstrated that their detention at the NWIPC violated due process solely because of the Coronavirus 6 Disease pandemic in the United States.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This class-action case was brought challenging the Santa Cruz County Jail's practice of strip searching individuals held in the jail.[SENTMARKER]The case settled and was dismissed.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 28, 2009, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the County of Santa Cruz, the Santa Cruz County Sheriff's Office, and the San Jose Division of the United States Department of Justice.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' practice of subjecting arrestees to strip and/or visual body cavity searches prior to arraignment violated the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The class included all persons who were subject to such searches without reasonable suspicion to believe that the searches would be productive of contraband.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay a maximum of $3,875,000 to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to approval by the Court.

gold_sents: A female arrestee filed this strip search case against the Humboldt County Jail and various officials challenging the jail's mandatory, blanket strip search policy.[SENTMARKER]The court found no pattern or practice.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff refiled, naming the deputy sheriff who conducted (and videotaped) the search, and the case was settled.[SENTMARKER]We have no further information about this case.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 23, 2004, a woman arrested for allegedly driving under the influence of alcohol brought this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Humboldt County Sheriff's Department.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendant violated her Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment rights by subjecting her to a strip search without reasonable suspicion that the search would be productive of contraband or weapons.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendant's motion for summary judgment on May 23, 2006, and the case was closed on June 23, 2006.[SENTMARKER]On October 26, 2006, the parties filed an appeal to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The appeal was denied on October 26, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On April 16, 2007, Plaintiff, represented by private attorney Mark E. Merin, filed a 42 U.S.C. § 1983 class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California challenging the Solano County Sheriff's policies and practices concerning the use of strip and visual body cavity searches in Solano County Jail.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff alleged that such searches, conducted in the absence of any reasonable suspicion of contraband or weapons, violated the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution.[SENTMARKER]In September 2009, two years after the defendants revised their search policies to comply with federal law, the parties settled with the defendant paying $110,000 in damages and $100,000 in attorney fees.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 1, 2008, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California against the Solano County Sheriff's Office and Solano County Jail.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' policy of subjecting pre-arraignm detainees to strip and/or visual body cavity searches without recording in writing, a reasonable suspicion that the searches would be productive of contraband or weapons, and the plaintiffs sought injunctive and class relief for all those who were subject to the searches.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on September 28, 2009 with prejudice of the plaintiffs' claims.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs $12,500 in damages, injunctive relief, and attorney's fees and costs.

gold_sents: In 2011, several inmates of the Fresno County Adult Detention Facilities filed a lawsuit against the County of Fresno, California, alleging that it violated prisoners' Constitutional rights by maintaining dangerous facilities and failing to provide basic health care.[SENTMARKER]In 2015, the parties settled the case.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to implement a remedial plan and to pay $900,000 in attorneys' fees and $40,000 per year for monitoring fees and expenses.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 13, 2011, two inmates of the Fresno County Jail filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the conditions of confinement in the Jail violated the constitutional and statutory rights of all prisoners who were or will be housed in the jail.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in May 2015 to address alleged deficiencies in four conditions, including timely access to health care.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the County to provide timely access and treatment to all prisoners, including those with serious health conditions, to ensure that their health care was not disrupted.[SENTMARKER]The County agreed to pay plaintiffs' counsel $40,000 per calendar year, or a pro-rated portion thereof, for all fees and expenses related to monitoring the implementation of the consent decree and the consent plan.[SENTMARKER]The Court appointed the Prison Law Office as class counsel to represent the class of prisoners.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for final approval of their class action settlement on December 13, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion for preliminary approval of the Consent Decree in March 2016.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the parties agreed to suspend discovery for the purpose of settlement negotiations.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This is a class action suit brought in 1993 by prisoners at the Merced County Jail to challenge their conditions of confinement.[SENTMARKER]The District Court for the Eastern District of California issued some initial injunctive relief to prevent overcrowding, and a settlement was preliminarily approved but seemingly never finalized.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed in 2000.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 4, 1993, a group of inmates of the Merced County Jail filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California against the County of Merced, the Sheriff's Office, and the Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (DCR).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had violated the inmates' civil rights by failing to provide them with adequate housing, failing to release them when their beds were full, and refusing to accept newly-committed inmates when they were released from the jail.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief, injunctive and ancillary relief, and injunctive monetary relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction in September 1993, and the case was closed in April 1994.[SENTMARKER]On August 5, 1994, the parties filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case was re-opened and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the defendants to post a copy of the settlement agreement on every floor level of the jail facility and to provide inmates with access to the settlement notice.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to pay the plaintiffs a total of $100,000 in damages.[SENTMARKER]On August 6, 1994, the case went to trial.[SENTMARKER]The trial was scheduled to take place on September 14, 1994.

gold_sents: This 2011 lawsuit alleged that Alameda County had violated the decedent's constitutional rights in its agents' use of excessive force.[SENTMARKER]The suit further alleged that Corizon Health, Inc. was negligent in its failure to provide decedent with treatment for alcohol withdrawal.[SENTMARKER]In February, 2015, the parties settled for $8,300,000 in damages and injunctive relief that included health training.[SENTMARKER]The injunctive relief is set to end February 1, 2019, and little activity had appeared on the docket since 2016.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 10, 2011, the son of a pretrial detainee of the Alameda County Sheriff's Department filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendant, Corizon Health, Inc., violated Title 42 of the United States Code, Sections 1983 and 1988, and the First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendments by denying the Plaintiff access to appropriate, competent, and necessary care for serious medical and psychiatric needs.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff also alleged excessive force and cruel and unusual punishment by the Defendant Deputy Sheriffs.[SENTMARKER]On February 12, 2012, the District Court assigned the case to Judge Jon S. Tigar, who granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment on all of the plaintiff's claims.[SENTMARKER]On January 5, 2014, the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the following terms: The defendant agreed to pay $20,000 to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also agreed to provide all inmates in Alameda County Jails, and in all facilities throughout the State of California, with a physician's assistant or nurse practitioner to conduct all receiving screenings and patient 19 assessments on all inmates.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the defendant's motion for partial summary judgment in part and denied the motion for full summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2016, prisoners in the Santa Clara County Jail System filed this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the jail facilities were not accessible to inmates with mobility disabilities in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Rehabilitation Act, and state law.[SENTMARKER]In 2019, the parties jointly settled the case under a consent decree which would force Santa Clara County to make its jails accessible.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing
pegasus_output_sents: On November 14, 2016, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California on behalf of inmates with mobility disabilities incarcerated in Santa Clara County's Main Jail North, Main Jail South, and Elmwood Correctional Facility (collectively, the "Jails").[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Jails violated the Americans with Disabilities Act ("ADA") and the Rehabilitation Act ("Rehabilitation Act") by failing to provide access to programs, services, and activities for inmates with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief, monetary relief, and other relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent decree in which the County agreed to implement a policy of providing a safe and secure shower chair which shall be readily accessible and provided immediately upon request.[SENTMARKER]The County also agreed to provide a chair for an inmate with a mobility disability in the jail's X-ray changing room.[SENTMARKER]The Court has preliminarily approved the settlement of this matter.

pegasus_output_sents: On June 25, 2013, a group of female prisoners in the custody of the Alameda County Sheriff's Office filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Fourth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments by failing to provide adequate food, medical care, education, and transportation for their pregnant prisoners and their unborn children at Santa Rita Jail in Santa Rita, California.[SENTMARKER]According to the plaintiffs, two of the pregnant prisoners suffered miscarriages, and a third woman gave birth alone and unattended in a solitary confinement cell.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff's attorneys filed a motion for a preliminary injunction, which was granted by the court on June 25, 2013.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled the issues set to be tried on June 25.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to provide the plaintiffs with adequate food and medical care.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This putative class-action lawsuit, brought by inmates in Orange County Jail, argued that county and the sheriff violated the U.S. Constitution, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act in failing to provide adequate care amidst the 2020 coronavirus pandemic.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought habeas corpus, injunctive relief, declaratory relief, and attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted class certification and partially granted a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction, which mandated more social distancing, providing for more PPE, and improved sanitation policies.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed this decision to the Ninth Circuit, and applied in both the district court and the Ninth Circuit to stay the case in the lower court until the appeals court had ruled.[SENTMARKER]Both denied these applications, however the Ninth Circuit remanded to the district court saying that the defendants could try to modify the injunction if there were any changed circumstances.[SENTMARKER]Defendants did so, but the district court denied any modifications once again.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed this decision to the Ninth Circuit, which likewise rejected the defendants' motion.[SENTMARKER]Finally, the defendants went to the Supreme Court and asked them to stay the injunction while the Ninth Circuit heard the case on the merits.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court obliged on August 5, staying the injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing as of February 17, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 30, 2020, a group of inmates at the Orange County Jail filed a class action suit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California alleging that the conditions of confinement at the jail violated their constitutional and other statutor rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants failed to take adequate measures to prevent the spread of COVID-19 within the jail.[SENTMARKER]On May 26, 2020, the district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction to implement protections against the COVID pandemic.[SENTMARKER]On June 2, 2020, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals granted the defendants' motion to stay the case pending an appeal of the PI Order.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed an emergency appeal to the Fifth Circuit, which granted a stay of the District Court's preliminary injunction Id.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit denied the appeal, and the parties filed a rehearing motion on June 10, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed rehearing motions on June 17, 2020, and the case was dismissed on June 24, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: In 2005, a group of former inmates of the District of Columbia’s Department of Corrections (D.O.C.)[SENTMARKER]filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court in Washington, DC.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the District had a long and documented history of overdetaining and strip searching inmates past their release dates.[SENTMARKER]The District moved for summary judgment, the Court denied that motion, and shortly thereafter the parties settled the case.[SENTMARKER]This is the second of two virtually identical class actions filed against the District in the past ten years involving overdetentions and strip searches at the District’s jails.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in August of 2005, which provided monetary relief to individual class members who had been overdetained, plus $250 per day for each calendar day they were supposed to be released, or subjected to a strip search after they had been to court appearance and were entitled to release because of their appearance.[SENTMARKER]The district agreed to pay a class member a sum of $1,000.00, no matter how many times the SCM was subjected to strip searches during the Class Period.[SENTMARKER]The case is still pending, and there is a proposed settlement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement may affect the rights of certain people who were incarcerated in the District.

pegasus_output_sents: In 2002, a class of women arrested in the District of Columbia were taken to the Superior Court for presentment on D.C. warrants or code offenses and were subjected to blanket strip, visual body cavity, and/or squat searches while being held in the cell block awaiting presentment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive and declaratory relief, seeking damages and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied both motions and certified two classes: a Fourth Amendment Class and a Fifth Amendment Class.[SENTMARKER]After the parties filed briefs in this matter, the Third Circuit weighed in for the first time and similarly found the blanket strip search of arrestees prior to introduction into a general jail population did not violate the Fourth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the District's motion for summary judgment, and the District was dismissed as a party in this case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 1999, inmates at the Foster County Jail in Atlanta, Georgia, who had tested positive for HIV, filed this class action lawsuit against county officials.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by the Southern Center for Human Rights, brought the suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]In 2000, the parties reached a settlement agreement that required improved medical care and reduced overcrowding.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 8, 1999, a group of HIV-positive inmates at the Fulton County Jail in Atlanta, Georgia filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had violated their Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights by failing to provide adequate medical care to the inmates.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that they had been denied even the most minimal medical care by the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on April 16, 1999, based on the defendants' representation that the Grady Health System would continue to provide medical appointments to HIV-infected inmates.[SENTMARKER]On April 22, 1999, the parties submitted for the Court’s approval, and the Court approved and entered, a Consent Order on Class certification.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed their responses on December 5, 2001, and the parties filed for the prel consent order on January 24, 2002.[SENTMARKER]On January 24, 2002, the parties entered a Final Settlement Agreement, which was approved by Judge Shoob.[SENTMARKER]The final settlement agreement required the defendants to provide all necessary medical care, including HIV-related care, to all inmates in the jail.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendants were required to monitor the quality of healthcare services provided at the jail and to provide a report to the court on the jail's overcrowding.[SENTMARKER]The court granted class certification on May 6, 2002.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and no further action is pending.

gold_sents: In June 2014, an inmate at the Cook County Jail filed a class action lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against Cook County.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought compensatory damages, punitive damages, attorneys' fees, and costs, alleging overcrowding and lack of funding that led to violations of Indiana state law and the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the case based on counsel's representation that the alleged counts were unsupported.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 6, 2014, a pre-trial detainee at the Cook County Jail filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois alleging that he was subject to barbaric living conditions in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that he and other similarly situated pretrial detainees were forced to sleep in the common area of a cell block which was under construction without any mattress, pillows, or blankets, was moved after two hours’ sleep to a day room where he again was required to sleep on the floor, and was frequently moved thereafter to various holding areas over several days, at least one of which did not have access to a bathroom, forcing Plaintiff to urinate on himself.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff also alleged that as a result of the policy and custom of instituting and allowing cruel and unusual conditions of confinement at the Jail, pretrial detainees have been subjected to barbaric and unusual living conditions.[SENTMARKER]The complaint included a Monell claim against Toni Preckwinkle, Thomas Dart, Cara Smith and Cook County based on the policy, practice and procedure of underfunding the Jail.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss on the grounds that: (1) they were improper defendants; .[SENTMARKER](2) they failed to adequately allege the Monell claims; and (3) Plaintiff does not allege that the defendants’ operation of the Jail is unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the motion for leave to file an amended complaint.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

pegasus_output_sents: In December 2014, a class action was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Indiana against the Marion County Sheriff's Department and the City of Indianapolis.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the sheriff's practice of not releasing inmates at the conclusion of their sentences, but rather keeping them in jail until Community Corrections is "ready" to process them as a group, is unreasonable and results in substantial delays in the release of these individuals.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted class certification as to two of the five subclasses, but denied class certification for the remaining three.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the district court for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Indiana Supreme Court granted the defendants' motion to transfer the case to the Indiana Court of Appeals.

gold_sents: Built in 1991, the Campbell County Detention Center was designed to hold 135 prisoners.[SENTMARKER]It quickly became overcrowded.[SENTMARKER]In the weeks before this lawsuit was filed in the district court for the Eastern District of Kentucky, on April 29, 2005, the jail's population reached a high of 276 prisoners, many of whom were forced to sleep on the floor.[SENTMARKER]Many of the inmates were awaiting transfer to the Kentucky Department of Corrections (KDOC), which was also named as a defendant in the lawsuit.[SENTMARKER]The KDOC addressed overcrowding at the jail by simply reducing the required floor space for each prisoner from 50 to 40 square feet.[SENTMARKER]This lawsuit, filed pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 1983 by attorney Robert B. Newman of the Cincinnati, Ohio, law firm Newman & Meeks, alleged the overcrowding violated the prisoners' Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, the class of inmates at the detention center, sought injunctive relief and nominal damages.
pegasus_output_sents: In August 2005, inmates at the Campbell County Detention Center in Newport, Kentucky filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky against Campbell County, Campbell County Jailer Greg Buckler, and the Kentucky Department of Corrections.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the detention center was overcrowded and that such overcrowding caused unconstitutional conditions of confinement to exist at the Detention Center.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree, which was signed by Judge William Ovington on November 30, 2005.[SENTMARKER]According to the decree, the parties agreed to implement a process for and implement a Retrial Conditional Release Program.[SENTMARKER]The decree also stated that the parties would lobby the General Assembly in support of legislation that would provide adequate funding to reimburse county correctional facilities for medical expenses incurred for the medical treatment of convicted felons housed in their facilities.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to submit a proposed consent decree on or before 11/30/2005.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the consent decree are attached hereto in Appendix 1.

gold_sents: In April 2020, pretrial and post-conviction detainees at Prince George's County Jail filed this class action complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that in light of COVID-19, they were being held in conditions that violated their Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]A subclass of pretrial, medically vulnerable plaintiffs also alleged that they are being held in violation of the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On May 21, the court granted in part the plaintiff's motion for temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]Defendant appealed and were denied a stay pending their appeal.[SENTMARKER]On July 7, the plaintiffs submitted an amended complaint, pointing to the lack of mental health services during an indefinite lockdown.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a joint motion to stay proceedings on August 27 pending settlement talks.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 21, 2020, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the Prince George's County Department of Corrections (PGCDOC) and Mary Lou McDonough, the Director of the PGCDOC.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the jail's inadequate response to the COVID-19 pandemic violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs sought injunctive relief, including the release of COVID-positive prisoners who had paid bail until the jail deemed them non-contagious.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order, and the parties entered a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the jail to limit the number of operational entrances and exits to the facility, provide adequate medical monitoring of sick prisoners in isolation, and limit the use of solitary confinement.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to provide access to the New Haven Syringe Services Program (SA-15), a program that provides services and access to care among participants in the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On April 8, 2003, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey on behalf of individuals charged with non-indictable or minor offenses in the City of Camden, New Jersey.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Camden County Department of Corrections and its corrections officers engaged in the practice of illegally strip searching all individuals who were admitted to the County's correctional facility.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit alleged that this practice violated the unreasonable search provisions of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which each class member will be entitled to an equal share of a $7.5 million settlement fund, after payment of administrative costs, incentive awards to the representative plaintiffs, and attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also addresses the alleged practice of Camden County in unlawfully detaining many members of the settlement class after they posted bail in the city of Camden.[SENTMARKER]The defendants maintain that their current written policy is constitutional.

gold_sents: In March of 2002, the Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice, acting pursuant to the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act ("CRIPA"), 42 U.S.C. § 1997 et seq., commenced an investigation into the conditions of confinement at the Santa Fe County Adult Detention Center in Santa Fe, New Mexico.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ concluded that the conditions and practices at the Detention Center violated the constitutional rights of convicted inmates and pre-trial detainees.[SENTMARKER]On November 11, 2004, the DOJ and Sante Fe County entered into a Memorandum of Agreement, which detailed the agreed reforms and set forth timetables for completion.[SENTMARKER]By its terms, the Agreement was to last for a period of three years, and remedy unconstitutional practices relating to: (1) medical and mental health care; .[SENTMARKER](2) suicide prevention; .[SENTMARKER](3) protection of inmates from harm; .[SENTMARKER](4) fire safety; .[SENTMARKER](5) sanitation; and (6) inmate grievance procedures (including court access).[SENTMARKER]On November 1, 2009, after a two year extension to compel Santa Fe County to meet the benchmarks in the agreement, the DOJ allowed the terms of the agreement to expire.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ is no longer monitoring the county.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 20, 2002, the Department of Justice ("DOJ") filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Mexico against the Santa Fe County Adult Detention Center ("SFCADC" or "the Detention Center").[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the detention center violated the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act ("CRIPA") by failing to provide a medically appropriate diet for inmates with conditions that require the inmates to receive special diets, inadequate prenatal care for pregnant inmates, and inadequate treatment, housing, and medical supervision for drug and alcohol withdrawal.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement ("Agreement"), which was entered into on November 1, 2007, and terminated two years from its effective date.[SENTMARKER]Under the Agreement, the Detention Center was required to provide appropriate treatment and housing for drug withdrawal, provide appropriate care for the identification, treatment, and control of Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus Aureus ("MRSA"), and provide appropriate discharge planning for pregnant women.[SENTMARKER]The Agreement also required the County to implement timely and appropriate care, including discharge planning, for all inmates.[SENTMARKER]The County was also required to implement a plan to identify, treat and control MRSA, and provide treatment and supervision for the treatment and treatment of the MRSA.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the County's motion to dismiss the complaint, and the case was closed.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
