gold_sents: This case was brought by a woman who was arested, subjected to excessive force and a strip/cavity search all on the basis of a false complaint filed by a family member.[SENTMARKER]A jury awarded her $19,645 in compensatory damages and $5,000,000 in punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit reversed the punitive damages award as not available against municipalities, and reduced the compensatory damages award because Plaintiff had been offered slightly more as settlement.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 7, 1999, a woman brought suit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York under 42 U.S.C.  1983 against the New York Police Department, the NYPD, and the individual officers involved in her arrest and strip search.[SENTMARKER]She alleged that she had been falsely arrested, that the police had employed excessive force during the arrest, and that her strip search violated her Fourth Amendment right against unreasonable search and seizure.[SENTMARKER]After a jury trial, the jury found in favor of the defendants on the claims of unlawful arrest, excessive force, and battery, and awarded her $5,000,000 in punitive damages, as well as $19,645 in compensatory damages.[SENTMARKER]The District Court dismissed the case, but the case was re-opened and the District Court granted the City's motion for entry of judgment in accordance with this opinion.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit reversed the district court's decision, finding that the strip search was pursuant to an official City policy that was contrary to the settled law of the Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court, however, reversed the award of punitive damages against the City.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2009, former inmates at the Delaware County Jail filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Sheriff's Office of Delaware County was guilty of rape, sodomy, sexual battery, and blackmail.[SENTMARKER]The alleged negligence and misconduct of jailers deprived inmates of their the Fourth, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendments Rights.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in 2011 for monetary damages.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in May 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 11, 2008, a group of female inmates in the Delaware County, Oklahoma jail filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the jailers would "bargain" with the female inmates to show their breasts in exchange for cigarettes, cupcakes, snacks, candy, personal items, and other things they could not obtain for themselves while in the jail.[SENTMARKER]In response to the retaliation, the women who came forward with the complaints wrote a letter, which they all signed, begging for help from the outside.[SENTMARKER]The letter resulted in an investigation by the Sheriff, which resulted in the Sheriff's resignation.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed by Judge James H. Payne on December 1, 2011.

gold_sents:
On April 21, 2005, a woman filed a class action lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]She alleged that the City of Philadelphia of had an unconstitutional practice of strip searching all pre-trial detainees, regardless of criminal charge or reasonable suspicion.[SENTMARKER]On February 20, 2009, the parties entered into a $5.9 million settlement.[SENTMARKER]
The Court entered final approval of the settlement on November 3, 2009.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 17, 2006, a class action lawsuit was filed in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against the Philadelphia Prison System and the City of Philadelphia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendant's policy of strip-searching all pretrial detainees upon admission was unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendant agreed to pay a total of $5,900,000 to settle the litigation.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was approved by Judge Mary A. McLaughlin on March 6, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that all corrections officers would be required to abide by the strip search policy.[SENTMARKER]The court denied both parties' summary judgment motions without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On August 22, 2007, the plaintiff filed suit against the County of Lancaster and the Lancaster County Prison Board in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]He alleged that his constitutional rights were violated when he was strip searched in front of other inmates upon arrival at the Lancaster County Prison after being arrested for a parole violation.[SENTMARKER]He sought class action certification, declaratory judgment, a preliminary and permanent injunction, and punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a settlement agreement with the court on July 29, 2009 that affirmed a new policy of not strip searching detainees arrested for minor offenses and created a fund to compensate those who had been strip searched.[SENTMARKER]The case ended on April 9, 2010 when the court certified the class and granted final approval to the settlement.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 22, 2007, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against the County of Lancaster and the Lancaster County Prison Board.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Fourth Amendment by conducting strip searches of all individuals who enter the county prison and are placed in prison clothing, regardless of the nature of their charged crime or violation, without reasonable suspicion to believe that the individual was concealing a weapon or contraband.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, seeking to change practices at LCP.[SENTMARKER]On July 28, 2009, the parties entered into a settlement agreement, which provided for a $2,507,200 settlement fund, with an initial contribution of $1,946,860.[SENTMARKER]The parties also vigorously litigated class certification.[SENTMARKER]On September 1, 2009, Judge Paul Diamond granted the parties' motion for preliminary approval of the settlement agreement and conditionally certified the class.[SENTMARKER]On November 11, 2007, the parties moved for class certification, which was granted on November 11, 2007.[SENTMARKER]On November 12, 2007, Judge Diamond issued an order requiring the defendants to revise their strip search policy and employ a new Strip Search Checklist approved by Class Counsel.[SENTMARKER]On March 23, 2009, Judge Diamond approved the settlement, and the parties agreed to settle this matter on March 23, 2009.[SENTMARKER]Judge Diamond granted class certification on September 1, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion for preliminarily approval on September 2, 2009, and the case was closed on September 10, 2009.

gold_sents: Plaintiff, a county jail inmate who suffered scarring and isolation from multiple MRSA infections was successful in obtaining a settlement against county defendants for their alleged failure to implement appropriate quarantine protocols and correct medical care, and for maintaining unsanitary conditions at the jail.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 19, 2009, an inmate at the Northampton County Prison in Easton, Pennsylvania filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The inmate alleged that he was denied his Eighth Amendment rights under the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution in violation of the Civil Rights Act of 1866.[SENTMARKER]He also alleged that the conditions of the prison and its medical unit were inhumane and unsanitary.[SENTMARKER]The defendant, Prime Care Medical, Inc., a Pennsylvania corporation, was under contract with Northampton County to provide medical care and services to inmates at the prison, including Mr. Fernandez.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendant's motion for summary judgment, finding that the defendant had not violated the plaintiff's constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This class action case was brought by prisoners of the Dauphin County Prison against the County of Dauphin, PA, seeking monetary, declaratory, and injunctive relief for conducting unconstitutional and unnecessary strip searches upon all persons placed in the Dauphin County Prison, as of September 16, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled in 2009, resulting in monetary and injunctive relief granted.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 16, 2007, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania against the County of Dauphin and its Corrections Officers.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants strip searched all individuals who were charged with misdemeanor crimes, violations of probation or parole or intermediate punishment, or other minor offenses upon their admission to the Dauphin County Prison, in violation of the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to pay $2,160,500 to settle the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on January 26, 2009 and the case was dismissed on March 12, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the defendant would not strip search misdemeanor detainees in the absence of reasonable suspicion to believe that the individuals were concealing a weapon or contraband.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also agreed to revise its strip search policy to no longer strip search detainees on a blanket basis, and to provide the plaintiffs with a list of Class members.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants in March 2009.

gold_sents: The ACLU of Pennsylvania filed this class action suit on behalf of pretrial detainees in a PA jail with subclasses of those who were at a heightened risk of contracting COVID-19.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the conditions in the jail failed to meet CDC recommendations and amounted to a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction on April 9, 2020 seeking immediate release from ACJ.[SENTMARKER]The parties then began working on a consent order to implement public health measures to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 in the jail, which was approved by the court on May 27.[SENTMARKER]The consent order was extended on August 24 and the plaintiffs habeas and ADA claims remain in dispute.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 24, 2020, a group of inmates at the Allegheny County Jail filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged violations of the Fourteenth Amendment and the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1983.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought release from the jail in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]On April 7, 2020, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunctive relief and granted their motion for release from ICE detention.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a consent decree that required the jail to implement a number of measures to protect inmates and employees from the virus.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also required that the jail take reasonable steps to prevent the spread of the virus within the jail.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the jail would not require inmates to work or have any contact with minors under the age of 18.[SENTMARKER]The jail also agreed to pay the plaintiffs in full.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On October 6, 2010, the Prison Legal News filed a class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for South Carolina under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against Berkeley County.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by public interest counsel, asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as damages, claiming that the defendants' unlawfully censored and excluded the plaintiff's books and magazines protected by the 1st and 14th Amendments, which are sent to individual subscribers in custody at the Berkeley County Detention Center (BCDC).[SENTMARKER]On May 3, 2011, the United States filed a Complaint in intervention pursuant to the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act, 42 U.S.C. § 14141, and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized 42 Persons Act of 2000, U.S.C. § 2000cc.[SENTMARKER]On January 13, 2012, Judge Sol Blatt, Jr., issued the consent injunction requiring the defendants to implement new policies regarding incoming mail and access to religious materials.
pegasus_output_sents: The Human Rights Defense Center and Prison Legal News filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina against the Berkeley County Sheriff's Office and the Sheriffs Office.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the detention center's policy of prohibiting all publications sent by mail to detainees violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Act (RLUIPA) of 1994.[SENTMARKER]The parties sought injunctive and declaratory relief, including access to non-Christian religious texts, and the right to receive expressive material through the mail.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the parties agreed to allow detainees to order from a publisher, and receive by mail, a soft-cover Bible, but no other books, magazines, or newspapers.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the Detention Center to provide all detainees with access to a library to read books and magazines.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for summary judgment and granted their motion for partial summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This 2017 class action lawsuit was brought by a former inmate of the Davidson County Jail in the U.S. District for the Middle District of Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendant violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments in failing to prevent the spread of scabies in the prison.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff has not yet filed a motion to certify class.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2017, a former inmate of the Metro-Davidson County Detention Facility filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee against CoreCivic of Tennessee, LLC, a private company that owns and operates the detention facility.[SENTMARKER]The inmate alleged that the Defendant failed to adequately screen those entering its facility, respond to inmate requests for medical attention, treat those infected with the parasite, quarantine the infected individuals in its care, or to take any other precautions to prevent the spread of scabies outside the facility.[SENTMARKER]As a result of the Defendant's deliberate indifference to the inmate's medical needs, the inmate and other inmates were forced to endure painful, itching rashes and sleeplessness while they were housed at the facility and incurred the costs of medical treatment, which is ongoing.[SENTMARKER]The class is defined as all male inmates exposed to and infested with scabies, who are, who have been, or who in the future may become, housed at CoreCivic's facility in Davidson County.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff and the class members have complied with all requirements of the Prison Litigation Reform Act (PLRA) and had exhausted their administrative remedies.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the Plaintiff's motion for summary judgment, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: A deaf prisoner of the El Paso County jails sued the County in the United States District Court for the Western District of Texas for their failure to accommodate his disability.[SENTMARKER]He was held for eleven days without access to an attorney or an interpreter, in violation of the Americans With disabilities Act ans Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. A private settlement was reached in July 2012 which, according to reports, required installation of videophones in the County jails.[SENTMARKER]We have no further information about this case.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 9, 2012, a deaf man filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against the County of El Paso, Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, Jose Luis Rodriguez, was arrested for violating the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, and Chapter 121 of the Texas Human Resources Code, TEX HUM RES.[SENTMARKER]He sought injunctive and declaratory relief, actual damages, attorneys' fees, litigation expenses, and costs as redress from El Paso County for their unlawful discrimination based on his disability.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiff's motion for summary judgment, finding that the defendant had violated the ADA and Section 504 by failing to make reasonable accommodations in its services, programs, activities, and facilities on the basis of his disability, and that the plaintiff was the prevailing party and was entitled to attorney's fees, costs, and expenses pursuant to the ADA, Section 504, and the Texas Declaratory Judgments Act.

gold_sents: On March 15, 2012, a group of juvenile prisoners filed a lawsuit in the Middle District of Florida against the Polk County Jail, claiming violations of their physical and medical care.[SENTMARKER]Preliminary injunction was denied.[SENTMARKER]Class certification was granted.[SENTMARKER]A bench trial was held on from November 18, 2013 to December 18, 2013.[SENTMARKER]On April 16, 2015, Judge Merryday issued an opinion denying relief to the plaintiffs, holding that plaintiffs failed to show defendants' violations of their constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in 2016.
pegasus_output_sents: The Southern Poverty Law Center (SPLC) filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida against the Polk County Sheriff's Office, the Florida Department of Juvenile Justice, and Corizon Health, Inc., a health care provider retained by the Sheriff, on April 30, 2013 in Tampa, Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their Eighth Amendment rights under the Fourteenth Amendment by subjecting them to conditions of confinement that violate their rights.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that they were deprived of adequate mental health care and were prohibited from participating in education, recreation, or from communicating with their families.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment for the Sheriff but denied the officers' claim of qualified immunity.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court reversed the Fifth Circuit and addressed the question whether an application of excessive force can result in an Eighth Amendment violation "if the inmate does not suffer serious injury."[SENTMARKER]The district judge directed a verdict for the prison officials.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Three minors represented by the Southern Poverty Law Center, Florida Justice Institute, Inc., and Florida Legal Services, filed suit on September 4, 2019 in the Northern District of Florida against the Florida Department of Juvenile Justice (DJJ).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought class action certification to represent children subject to solitary confinement in DJJ-run detention centers.[SENTMARKER]The defendant's summary judgment motion on the merits was denied on December 6, 2019, and the case is in ongoing mediation talks.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 24, 2018, the Florida Department of Juvenile Justice (DJJ) was sued in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Florida by a group of children in solitary confinement for failing to attend school.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the DJJ's solitary confinement policies and practices violated the Fourteenth and Eighth Amendments to the United States Constitution and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case is closed.

gold_sents: DOJ's investigation of the conditions at the Hawaii Youth Correctional Facility ("HYCF") in August 2004 concluded that the facility lacked policies to protect the detained youth from abuse or suicide risks.[SENTMARKER]DOJ recommended reforms at the HYCF through a Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) that was executed by the parties.[SENTMARKER]This case was brought to retain jurisdiction of the district court of Hawaii's jurisdiction over the case until a final order is entered to dismiss the case with prejudice.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 16, 2004, the Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Hawaii against the State of Hawaii, the Hawaii Youth Correctional Facility (HYCF), and the Hawai'i Department of Human Services (HDHS).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged violations of the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994, and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1974 (Section 504).[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the complaint alleged that the defendants failed to provide access to medical and mental health care, adequate special education instruction, and supervision for youth at the facility.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a memorandum of agreement (Memorandum of Agreement) in which the parties agreed that the DOJ would have the right to conduct unannounced visits to the facilities, provided that the Special Litigation Section would notify the State in the event that the United States Attorney’s Office for the district of Hawai’i accesses youth or records at HYCF.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the Memorandum of Agreement were not subject to State or federal court enforcement other than the reinstatement of the Complaint that this Agreement settled.[SENTMARKER]On February 9, 2006, the parties filed a joint stipulation to dismiss with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The Honorable Samuel P. King of the District Court of Hawaii granted the parties' motion for summary judgment, and the parties entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: The Attorney General filed suit against the state of Ohio, its governor, the director of youth services, and the superintendents of its juvenile correctional facilities pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 14141 for an alleged pattern or practice of violating the rights of juvenile detainees under the 14th Amendment, the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.[SENTMARKER]The United States alleged that Ohio failed to protect the youth at its facilities from harm and undue risk of harm, failed to meet their medical and mental health needs, and failed to provide adequate special education services.[SENTMARKER]The suit was filed as a result of Department of Justice (DOJ) investigations into the conditions of confinement at the Scioto and Marion centers that began in 2005.[SENTMARKER]The Marion facility closed soon after the first injunction in this case.[SENTMARKER]Ohio achieved substantial compliance in 2015, and the consent decree was terminated on December 3, 2015.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 16, 2005, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) and the State of Ohio (the State) filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the Scioto Juvenile Correctional Facility (Scioto) in Delaware, Ohio, violated the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act and the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 by failing to protect from harm, medical care, mental health care, and special education at Scioto.[SENTMARKER]On June 4, 2008, the State signed a stipulation for injunctive relief (the Stipulation) concerning conditions at the facility.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached an agreement on the resolution of the plaintiffs’ claims, which the Court approved on March 29, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The parties also entered into a consent decree with the State to remedy conditions at all DYS facilities.[SENTMARKER]On December 19, 2012, the State closed the Marion facility.[SENTMARKER]Since then, the parties have amended their agreement twice, and the parties agreed to withdraw without prejudice its motion for a temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]On March 29, 2011, the parties filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the motion and set a joint settlement conference for January 29, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a final judgment in favor of the State.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment is subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: The juvenile plaintiff brought suit against the Minnehaha County Juvenile Detention Center, challenging the center's policy of strip-searching all juveniles admitted to the Detention Center, without any reasonable suspicion that the juveniles were concealing weapons or contraband.[SENTMARKER]The Eighth Circuit overturned the District Court's ruling, holding that the search of the named plaintiff did not violate the Fourth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On remand, the parties reached a monetary settlement before having to relitigate the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 1, 2000, a former juvenile detainee at the Minnehaha County Juvenile Detention Center in Sioux Falls, South Dakota, filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Dakota alleging that her civil rights were violated by the detention center's policy of strip searches of all minors regardless of the type of offense they were arrested for or whether there was reason to believe that the minors had weapons or contraband.[SENTMARKER]The district court certified two classes of plaintiffs, one for injunctive relief and one for punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]On September 27, 2004, the district court granted partial summary judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]On February 4, 2009, the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the defendants would not strip search or question the religious beliefs or practices of any of the plaintiffs, and that the plaintiffs would be required to pay the defendants' costs.[SENTMARKER]On August 9, 2006, the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals remanded the case for further proceedings consistent with its decision in NG v. Connecticut, 382 F.3d 225 (2d Cir.[SENTMARKER]2004), which held that the JDC's written search policy in effect in August 1999 was unconstitutional and the subsequent changes to the policy did not cure the constitutional defects.

gold_sents: This suit was filed May 7, 2004.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs were individuals who had been involuntarily civilly confined pursuant to Sexually Violent Predator Act into the custody of the Florida Dept.[SENTMARKER]of Children and Families in the Florida Civil Commitment Center (FCCC).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs argued that the State failed to provide adequate rehabilitive treatment necessary for their eventual recovery and release.[SENTMARKER]In November 2009, after five years of discovery and motions practice, the case settled, with the State agreeing to implement policies that addressed all the plaintiffs' allegations.
pegasus_output_sents: In May 2004, a group of sex offenders who were civilly detained at the Florida Civil Commitment Center (FCCC) filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida against the Florida Department of Children and Families (DCFII) and Liberty Behavioral Healthcare Corporation.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their constitutional rights by failing to provide adequate treatment, mental health services, and on-site medical services to the residents confined at FCCC.[SENTMARKER]In particular, the parties agreed that plaintiffs' experts would conduct a visit and inspection of the facility over a four-day period in March 2006.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the defendants' motion for approval of a class-action settlement and dismissed the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a joint motion for dismissal of the case in June 2009.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a Final Action Plan, which was approved by the District Court, and the case was dismissed with prejudice on June 4, 2009.

gold_sents: On February 27, 2002, four individuals involuntarily detained by the Illinois Department of Human Services ("DHS") pursuant to the Sexually Violent Persons Commitment Act (“SVP Act”) on behalf of themselves and all others similarly situated filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for Northern Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the defendants failed to provide adequate and meaningful health treatment to the plaintiffs and those similarly situated and the treatment and care that was given was punitive and Constitutionally inadequate.[SENTMARKER]In 2005, Judge Leinenweber granted the plaintiffs’ demand for declaratory relief concerning the previous Special or Secure Management Status (“SMS”) used at the Joliet Treatment and Detention Facility (the “TDF”) stating that it was unconstitutional; however all of the plaintiffs’ remaining claims were denied including the claim of inadequate treatment.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 14, 2005, three individuals who had been civilly committed under the Illinois Sexually Violent Persons Commitment Act, 725 ILCS 207/1et seq., filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against the Illinois Department of Human Services (DHS) and the director of the Joliet Treatment and Detention Facility (TDF).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their civil rights by failing to provide them with adequate treatment, confinement, education, and vocational services.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for declaratory and injunctive relief, finding that the plaintiffs were not a "prevailing party" for purposes of the claims.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed without prejudice and without costs with leave to move to reinstate, enforce, or extend the time in which to enforce the settlement agreement.

gold_sents: On Aug.[SENTMARKER]14, 2014, a number of prisoners in Louisiana filed a class action under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 claiming that the state violated the ADA, Rehabilitation Act, and their 14th Amendment due process rights by keeping them incarcerated despite their being found not guilty by reason of insanity and committed by the court to the state's mental health facility.[SENTMARKER]On July 18, 2016, the Court dismissed the case without prejudice to the right to reopen it within sixty days if the parties did not settle.[SENTMARKER]The parties subsequently settled, agreeing to send individuals found not guilty due to insanity to mental health institutions.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 19, 2014, the Advocacy Center of Louisiana filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana against the Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals (DHH) on behalf of individuals with mental illness who have been found not guilty by reason of insanity (NGRI) in state courts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DHH violated the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA), and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (RA) by denying them access to a mental health facility pursuant to Louisiana law.[SENTMARKER]The class was represented by counsel experienced in the prosecution of class actions.[SENTMARKER]On November 16, 2016, the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay the plaintiffs' reasonable attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]In the event that the parties cannot resolve a future claim for attorney's fees or costs, the parties will have thirty days from the date of the settlement agreement to come into or establish compliance with this settlement.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: This was a class-action lawsuit in which the plaintiffs alleged that the Commonwealth of Massachusetts had failed to provide medically necessary services as required under the federal Medicaid Act, and that it had failed to inform parents and children that they were entitled to these covered services.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that the Commonwealth violated provisions of the federal Medicaid Act by failing to provide home-based services to thousands of children across the state.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the district court approved a remedial plan intended to restructure the children’s mental health system by incorporating intensive home-based services, including behavioral health screenings, assessments, case management, crisis intervention and in-home therapeutic supports.[SENTMARKER]It also appointed a monitor to oversee implementation and compliance.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to extend the monitor’s appointment several times, with the final extension expiring on December 31, 2018.[SENTMARKER]In July 2019, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motion to again extend the monitor’s appointment; the First Circuit overturned this ruling on May 4, 2020.[SENTMARKER]As of August 2020, the extension is before the district court on remand.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 31, 2001, a group of Medicaid-eligible children, acting through their parents or guardians, filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Massachusetts Medicaid program violated the Medicaid Act by failing to provide home-based mental health services to children suffering from serious emotional disturbances.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss and certified a class of children under twenty-one years of age, who were (or might become) eligible to receive, but were not receiving, what Plaintiffs described as "intensive home- based services."[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed and the case was remanded to the First Circuit for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The First Circuit affirmed the district court's judgment, finding that the Commonwealth had not met its burden to demonstrate good cause and that the plaintiffs had not demonstrated substantial compliance with the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a joint remedial plan, which was largely adopted by the parties.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: The U.S. sued the State of Mississippi under the Americans with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. alleged that the State knowingly failed to provide adequate mental health programs for adults with mental illness and segregated adults with disabilities in their State-run hospitals.[SENTMARKER]After a four-week bench trial, the court found that the health system violated the ADA and required a special master to determine and oversee the remedial process.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In August 2016, the Department of Justice filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi against the State of Mississippi, alleging that the State was violating Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to provide services to qualified individuals with mental illness and developmental disabilities in the most integrated settings appropriate to their needs.[SENTMARKER]In December 2018, the State filed two motions for summary judgment, one of which alleged that the United States lacked standing to bring such a suit, and one alleging that it had not properly articulated a necessary element of the claim.[SENTMARKER]On February 13, 2019, the District Court granted the State's motion to dismiss, finding that the parties had reached a settlement agreement and that the case was closed.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Plaintiff, a student at Hunter College of the City University of New York, brought this action against the College and its administrators on August 20, 2004, in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff, who was diagnosed with Major Depressive Disorder and Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder, brought claims under the Fair Housing Act, the ADA, and Section 504 after the College forced her to leave its dormitory following her suicide attempt in June 2004.[SENTMARKER]The case eventually settled, with defendants paying plaintiff attorneys' fees and damages.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 7, 2004, a student with a disability filed an amended complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York alleging intentional discrimination and disparate impact under the Fair Housing Act, Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 against Hunter College, the owner and manager of Brookdale Residence Hall, a dormitory, and Hunter College's president and vice president.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the ADA by wrongfully evicting her and denying her residence in dormitory housing on the basis of disability.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiff's application for a preliminary injunction, finding that an additional year's delay in her medical studies would irreparably harm her, while he concluded that NYU would suffer no hardships.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit reversed the district court's decision, finding inter alia that the plaintiff had not in fact demonstrated irreparable injury, it was her disability, and that she was not entitled to injunctive and declaratory relief pursuant to the ADA, Rehabilitation Act, or Fair Housing Amendments Act.

gold_sents: On March 15, 1996, the United States filed a lawsuit under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), 42 U.S.C. § 1997, against the State of Tennessee, the Tennessee Department of Mental Health and Mental Retardation (DMH/MR) and the Memphis Mental Health Institute (MMHI), in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Tennessee, Memphis Division.[SENTMARKER]On March 15, 1996, the same day as the complaint was filed, the parties submitted a joint motion for entry of a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]Under the settlement agreement the defendants agreed to implement all policies, systems, procedures and rules currently in place, to provide quarterly status reports, provide the government access to the facilities, records, patients, and employees of MMHI, and to confer in good faith on the provisions of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]On May 21, 1997, the Court entered judgment in accordance with the consent decree and terminated the case, retaining jurisdiction for necessary enforcement of the decree.[SENTMARKER]And, on September 18, 1998, the District Court (Judge Gibbons) granted the parties' joint motion for a stipulation and order, effectuating the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]On June 21, 2005, the District Court (Judge Bernice B. Donald) granted the parties' joint motion for an order partially terminating the consent decree and approved the parties' stipulation for supplemental relief.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 12, 1990, the Department of Justice's Civil Rights Division filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Tennessee against the Tennessee Department of Mental Health and Mental Retardation and the Memphis Mental Health Institute.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the rights of mentally ill patients by failing to provide adequate, professional nursing care to their patients and by placing patients in a locked-door room without adequate medical and emergency care.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a consent decree, which was entered on March 15, 1996.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the defendants to: (1) cease the practice of restraining patients and placing them in the locked room immediately; .[SENTMARKER](2) provide adequate nursing care, including professional nursing, to patients; .[SENTMARKER](3) provide patients with adequate access to emergency medical care; and (4) ensure the safety and freedom from undue bodily and chemical restraints.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the state of Tennessee to pay $50,000 to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: On February 17, 2004 the United States filed a complaint against Breathitt County, Kentucky, and Breathitt County Geriatric Corporation for violating CRIPA, 42 U.S.C. §1997, after the county failed to take action to remedy the violations laid out after the Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice ("DOJ") conducted an investigation of conditions at the Nim Henson.[SENTMARKER]On February 19, 2004, a settlement agreement was entered with the cour, and two years after the settlement agreement, the government found that the Nim Henson Nursing Home had been complying with all the terms of the settlement agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 20, 2002, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of Kentucky filed this lawsuit against Breathitt County, Kentucky and the Nim Henson Geriatric Center.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and implementing regulations by failing to provide adequate medical, nursing, nutritional, wound, restorative, and psychiatric care and services to Nim Henson residents.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to comply with the terms of the agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was entered into by Judge Karl S. Warrix of the Court of Appeals for the 6th Circuit on February 18, 2004 and was finalized on March 6, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: On January 31, 2006, subscribers to or customers of telephone or internet services that AT&T provided filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against AT&T Corp. and AT&T Inc., claiming that the defendants' participation in the federal government's program to monitor and collect Americans' telephone and internet communications was unlawful.[SENTMARKER]The United States quickly intervened as a defendant.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit was dismissed based upon retroactive legislation.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed the dismissal and the Supreme Court declined to hear the case.
pegasus_output_sents: In December 2005, a group of California residents filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against AT&T and the National Security Agency.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants participated in a secret and illegal government program to intercept and analyze vast quantities of Americans' telephone and Internet communications without the authorization of a court and in violation of the First and Fourth Amendments to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss for lack of standing, and the case was dismissed on April 28, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The case was consolidated in August 2006 under the multidistrict litigation "MDL" provisions of  1407 and  802 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act ("FISA"), which allows for immunity for telecommunication companies participating in the government's electronic surveillance programs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In March 2018, the American Civil Liberties Union of Northern California filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the Transportation Security Administration violated the Freedom of Information Act for wrongfully withholding its records about electronic device searches.[SENTMARKER]The TSA ultimately provided a letter stating it does not conduct device searches, and the ACLU agreed to dismiss the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 20, 2017, the American Civil Liberties Union of Northern California (ACLU-NC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) seeking information about TSA's policies, procedures, and protocols regarding the search of airplane passengers' electronic devices.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that TSA violated the First and Fourth Amendments to the Constitution by conducting warrantless searches of electronic devices at international border crossings without probable cause to support the search.[SENTMARKER]In response to the complaint, TSA issued a final decision on August 23, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The final decision stated that TSA will not engage in any further processing of your FOIA request, and this matter is now closed.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on January 2, 2019.

gold_sents: This Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) complaint, filed on June 27, 2017, seeks to enhance knowledge about discriminatory immigration policy regarding Muslims, Latinos, and other members of groups disfavored by the Department of State (DOS) and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS).[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the FOIA requests sought greater understanding of the administration's immigration enforcement policies out of a concern that the defendants have targeted individuals on the basis of actual or perceived religion, ethnicity, race, or national origin in enforcing their immigration policies.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs sought "disclosure of agency policies, communications, and statistics related to visa processing and visa issuances for individuals applying abroad; to adjudication of entry document applications; and to screening and searching of individuals arriving at U.S. ports of entry."[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 28, 2017, the Council on American-Islamic Relations (CAIR) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York against the Department of State (DOS) and US Customs and Border Protection (CBP) seeking declaratory and injunctive relief under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) for discrimination against Muslims, Latinos, and other members of disfavored groups in immigration enforcement.[SENTMARKER]On February 3, 2017, a nationwide class action was filed in federal court in the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]The court issued a nationwide order suspending enforcement of several provisions of EO1, including the entry of refugees and nationals of the seven enumerated countries.[SENTMARKER]On April 12, 2017, CAIR filed a FOIA request to USCIS, CBP, and DOS seeking documents related to the search, screening, and processing of individuals by CBP at ports of entry and preclearance locations, as well as records related to such custody conditions during such search and screening.[SENTMARKER]CAIR also sought expedited processing and a fee waiver and expedited processing.[SENTMARKER]On November 15, 2019, the court granted CAIR's motion for partial summary judgment and ordered the parties to comply with the court's orders.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement agreement that required the release of certain documents to CAIR and CBP.[SENTMARKER]In addition, CAIR agreed to pay CAIR $50,000 in attorney's fees and costs.

pegasus_output_sents: On January 13, 2010, the ACLU and the American Civil Liberties Union Foundation filed a FOIA request under the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C.  552, seeking records relating to the use of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) by the CIA and the Armed Forces for the purpose of targeting and killing individuals since September 11, 2001.[SENTMARKER]The defendants were the Department of Defense, Department of Justice (DOJ), Department of State (DS), and the Office of Legal Counsel (OLC).[SENTMARKER]The defendants denied the FOIA request, claiming that they had not provided any basis for withholding responsive records.[SENTMARKER]On September 9, 2011, the district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment in favor of the CIA, granting the CIA's proffered "no-number no-list" response to the parties' FOIA requests, because details about the records, including their nature and number, had not been waived by official public acknowledgment.[SENTMARKER]On October 26, 2011, the parties voluntarily dismissed the remaining defendants, and the case became final.[SENTMARKER]The ACLU appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The appeals court denied the ACLU's motion for partial summary judgment on October 26, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: When the FBI received in 2004 a “FISA Alert Report Form” seeking information on the plaintiff in this case, it was assumed to be related to the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, when it was in fact merely from a private company called Financial Institutions Security Association.[SENTMARKER]As a result of the misunderstanding, the plaintiff’s name was erroneously placed on government watchlists, and she was fired from her job as a nurse working at the Federal Reserve Board.[SENTMARKER]After unsuccessfully filing a Freedom of Information Act request seeking records relating to the error, she brought this lawsuit against several federal agencies, seeking to force the agencies to produce the requested records.
pegasus_output_sents: In June 2005, a woman filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request with the FBI seeking all records about her, dated on or after 26 March 2004, relating to her work as a National Security Counselor with the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System (FRB).[SENTMARKER]The FBI refused her request because the records were classified as "Confidential," and the FBI conducted a search for responsive records, which resulted in 13 responsive documents.[SENTMARKER]On November 8, 2011, the plaintiffs filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, alleging that the FBI failed to comply with FOIA and the Privacy Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as an award of damages.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice on November 8, 2011.[SENTMARKER]On November 19, 2012, the plaintiffs amended their complaint to include allegations that the DOJ violated the Administrative Procedure Act and the Fifth Amendment by failing to timely apprise the AAG-Admin of the action.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the case, and the case was closed.

pegasus_output_sents: In December 2005, the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) and the National Security Archive Fund, Inc. (NSAF) filed FOIA requests seeking the release of records related to the NSA’s secret surveillance program to intercept, without prior judicial authorization, the telephone and Internet communications gold_sents: Muslim Advocates filed this suit against DHS under FOIA, seeking information regarding the government's border searches of electronic devices in the possession of persons from the seven Muslim-majority countries covered by President Trump's Jan.[SENTMARKER]27 and Mar.[SENTMARKER]6 Executive Orders, as well as by all persons whom CBP agents "perceived to be Muslim."
pegasus_output_sents: On March 7, 2017, Muslim Advocates of Washington, D.C. filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) seeking records related to the government's border searches of electronic devices in the possession of persons from seven Muslim-majority countries covered by President Donald Trump's January 27, 2017 Executive Order.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that DHS violated FOIA by failing to determine whether to comply with the request within 30 business days, failing to immediately thereafter notify Plaintiff of such determination and the reasons therefor, and failing to provide reasonable costs and attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]On January 19, 2017, the parties filed a joint status report in which the parties agreed to the following terms: The parties shall file additional joint status reports at subsequent intervals of 45 days; the parties shall make the requested referral to the Office of Public Affairs to determine the scope of Plaintiff's obligation under Item 1(o) of the FOIA; and CBP agreed to conduct a search within its complaint management system for complaint summaries containing the terms "iPad," "twitter," "password," "cell," and "cell."[SENTMARKER]The parties have sought confirmation from the Government that it will honor the terms agreed to by the parties, Muslim Advocates and the Government.[SENTMARKER]The parties are continuing to discuss the terms of the joint report.

pegasus_output_sents: On February 15, 2017, The Protect Democracy Project, Inc. filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Justice under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) seeking records related to Executive Order 13769, "Protecting the Nation From Foreign Terrorist Entry Into the United States", which was issued on January 27, 2017.[SENTMARKER]On February 27, 2017, Plaintiff sent a FOIA request to the DOJ's Executive Office for Immigration Review.[SENTMARKER]On March 2, 2017, Plaintiff received a letter from Defendant's Office of Information Policy stating that no responsive records were located and closing the review.[SENTMARKER]On May 4, 2017, the Court granted Plaintiff's request for a fee waiver and ordered the DOJ to produce to Plaintiff any and all non-exempt records responsive to the FOIA request within 20 business days.[SENTMARKER]The Court also granted Plaintiff an award of attorney fees and other reasonable litigation costs pursuant to FOIA  552(a)(4)(E) and  552(1)(A).[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2017, the American Civil Liberties Union Foundation filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia on behalf of an American citizen being detained by the United States military in Iraq.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the Secretary of Defense under the federal habeas corpus statute, 28 U.S.C. §2241, the Non-Detention Act of 1971, and 18 U.S.C. § 4001(a) for injunctive relief, claiming violations of the Fourth, Fifth, and Sixth Amendments to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The Defense Department had detained the plaintiff since on or around September 14, 2017, after Syrian forces transferred him to U.S.[SENTMARKER]Custody.[SENTMARKER]On October 28, 2018, the Defense Department released the plaintiff and the case was dismissed with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]On November 7, 2018, the court dismissed this case with prejudice and order each party to bear its own costs and fees.[SENTMARKER]In April 2019, the plaintiff sought to unseal the documents relating to the government’s proposed forcible transfer of the plaintiff into Syria.[SENTMARKER]The court reissued an unredacted version of the opinion on June 28, 2019.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 14, 2017, the American Civil Liberties Union Foundation (ACLUF) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Defense (D.C.) seeking habeas relief on behalf of a detained American citizen in Iraq.[SENTMARKER]The ACLUF argued that the detainee was being held without charge, without access to a court, or other meaningful opportunity to challenge his detention before a neutral decisionmaker.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the ACLUF's motion for a temporary restraining order and a preliminary injunction, finding that the ACLU had standing to bring the action on the detainee's behalf.[SENTMARKER]On January 5, 2018, the court granted an emergency injunction, requiring the government to provide 72 hours' notice before transferring the detainee to any other country.[SENTMARKER]On April 19, 2018, the parties reached an agreement in principle that will resolve the case without the need for further litigation.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to dismiss the case for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On November 27, 2020, an informal foreign policy advisor to the Trump 2016 presidential campaign filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, alleging that the Department of Justice (DOJ), the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and various former DOJ and FBI officials that sought the warrant against him in their personal capacity violated his right to be free of unreasonable searches and seizures in connection with Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) warrants issued against him during the 2016 campaign.[SENTMARKER]He sought $75 million in compensatory damages, punitive damages, injunctive relief, and attorneys' fees for this case and a related Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) case used to gain information for this litigation under FISA, Bivens, the Federal Tort Claims Act, and the Privacy Act.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

Page filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Justice (DOJ) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) for violating his rights under the Privacy Act and the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA).[SENTMARKER]Page alleged that the DOJ and FBI targeted him because of his lawful association with the 2016 Presidential campaign of Donald Trump and his involvement in coordinating activities with the Government of Russia.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the DOJ's actions allowed them to illegally spy (domestically and internationally) on Dr.[SENTMARKER]Page, a patriotic American citizen.[SENTMARKER]Page was dismissed by the President of the United States on May 9, 2017.[SENTMARKER]He was also terminated by the FBI in June 2017.[SENTMARKER]The complaint seeks injunctive relief, including punitive damages, for violations of Page's rights under  552a(d)(3)(D) of the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed without prejudice on November 12, 2019.

Waterman S.S.[SENTMARKER]was filed in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the government's investigation of the defendant did not violate the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA),  1801 et seq., and the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The district court ordered the government to disclose to defense counsel highly sensitive classified FISA applications and orders to determine the legality of the challenged FISA collection, despite failing to find that disclosure is "necessary" to determine its legality, as required by FISA.[SENTMARKER]On June 2, 2014, the Seventh Circuit reversed the district court's order to disclose classified material to the defense, holding that the court had abused its discretion.[SENTMARKER]On November 26, 2014, the court granted the defendant's motion for summary judgment and denied the motion in part.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On October 17, 2013, the ACLU filed a lawsuit requesting an injunction forcing the DOJ to comply with a FOIA request regarding their policy on giving notice to criminal defendants against whom it intends to use evidence obtained from warrantless surveillance, including information obtained under surveillance orders authorized by the FISA Amendments Act § 702.[SENTMARKER]On March 3, 2105, the court granted part of each party's motion for summary judgment, and issued an order requiring the DOJ to conduct a further search for responsive documents, and disclose any that were not subject to FOIA exemptions.[SENTMARKER]On September 27, 2016, the court granted part of each party's motion for summary judgment, ruling that the DOJ's searches were adequate, and that all but one of the documents found by the DOJ were protected by FOIA's Exemption 5.[SENTMARKER]On May 2, 2017, the Court granted DOJ's renewed motion for summary judgment, finding that the remaining documents were properly withheld under FOIA Exemption 5.

gold_sents: In June 2020, the Trump Administration's Department of Health and Human Services issued a revised regulation under Section 1557 of the Affordable Care Act that limited protections for discrimination against LGBTQ individuals.[SENTMARKER]A group of LGBTQ-focused private healthcare providers, organizations providing community services, health professional associations, and individual providers filed this lawsuit in the District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the revised rule violated the Administrative Procedure Act, First Amendment, and the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On September 2, the court found that the plaintiffs had standing for most of their claims, and enjoined the Administration from implementing two provisions: (1) the 2020 Rule's elimination of "sex stereotyping" from the 2016 Rule's definition of "discrimination on the basis of sex" and (2) the 2020 Rule's use of Title IX's exemption of certain religious organizations from the statute’s nondiscrimination mandate.[SENTMARKER]It denied relief for the 2020 Rule's elimination of the 2016 Rule’s prohibition on categorical coverage exclusions for gender-affirming care, repeal of the 2020 Rule's notice requirements, and alleged violation of Section 1554, in addition to the plaintiffs' constitutional claims.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

pegasus_output_sents: In 2010, two individuals with spinal cord injuries filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida against the Florida Agency for Health Care Administration (AHCA) and the State Surgeon General.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Rehabilitation Act of 1973 by failing to provide adequate home and community-based services to qualified individuals who are at risk of institutionalization.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted partial summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, holding that the State had violated the ADA and rejected the State’s defense that inadequate funding, rather than discrimination, was the reason for retaining the plaintiffs in an institution.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Eleventh Circuit affirmed the district court's decision, but remanded for a reassessment of the State's cost-based defense.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to this court and the parties disagree as to the nature of the relief sought.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the State agreed to provide the plaintiffs with in-home personal care assistance as part of its TBI/SCI waiver program.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required the State to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees.

pegasus_output_sents: On September 10, 2010, a group of individuals with mental disabilities filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia against the State of Georgia and the Georgia Department of Community Health.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief for violation of Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (Section 504).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants were placing them at serious risk of hospitalization by terminating the Medicaid-funded services they needed to remain in their current settings without offering any alternative support services.[SENTMARKER]On December 18, 2012, the parties entered a settlement agreement that required the defendants to continue to provide the plaintiffs with services for as long as they satisfy the eligibility criteria for such services.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to pay the Atlanta Aid Society, Inc. a total of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000) as attorney's fees and court costs.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was in the best interests of the parties and the public.

gold_sents: In September of 2011, one eighteen-year-old and four minor residents of Georgia with significant medical issues sued the agency responsible for administering Medicaid in Georgia.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that the agency's decisions to deny or reduce hours of in-home, private nursing care violated the Medicaid act, the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments, and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).[SENTMARKER]Two of the Plaintiffs settled and some of the Medicare, as well as the Fifth an Fourteenth Amendment Allegations were dismissed on summary Judgment, however, the District Court found for the Defendants on the remaining allegations.[SENTMARKER]The defendant appealed this decision and the Court of Appeals dismissed the appeal.[SENTMARKER]The district court also awarded attorneys' fees to the plaintiff, which was affirmed by the Court of Appeals.

(GMCF), a non-profit corporation that provides private duty nursing services through the Georgia Pediatric Program (GAPP), a Medicaid program administered by the Department of Health and Human Services (DHC).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that GMCF violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments, and the Georgia Public Health Act (GPH).[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that the defendants violated the ADA by denying or reducing the number of skilled nursing hours that the plaintiffs needed to correct or ameliorate their medical conditions.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment in part and denied the defendants' motion to certify a class.[SENTMARKER]On August 2, 2012, the court granted a declaratory judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, finding that the defendant had discriminated against the plaintiffs in violation of the ADA and the GPH's policies and procedures of the GAPP program.[SENTMARKER]On September 14, 2011, the parties filed a joint motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the case and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the defendant to provide the plaintiffs with the amount of nursing care which was medically necessary for the plaintiff's medical condition.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to pay the plaintiffs for their medical expenses.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On March 25, 2010, plaintiffs, minors with serious disabilities who were Medicaid recipients, filed this class-action lawsuit was filed in federal court against the Secretary of the Indiana Family and Social Services Administration (FSSA) and Director of the Office of Medicaid Policy and Planning of FSSA.[SENTMARKER]They all had been receiving medically necessary therapies paid for by the State's Medicaid program, administered by the FSAA, for several years.[SENTMARKER]These therapies were necessary to ensure the plaintiffs' conditions would not deteriorate and that they would not lose functional ability.[SENTMARKER]The FSSA had denied the named plaintiffs and others similarly situated continuing access to these therapies, citing two provisions of the Indiana Administrative Code.[SENTMARKER]On February 10, 2011, the Court granted summary judgment in favor of the Plaintiffs, issuing a permanent injunction preventing the Defendants and their successors from limiting or denying coverage for prescribed physical, occupational, or respiratory therapy, and/or speech pathology, for any person under 21 enrolled in the State's Medicaid program when such denial or limitation was based upon the two disputed provisions.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 25, 2010, a group of seriously disabled Medicaid recipients filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Indiana against the Indiana Family and Social Services Administration (FSSA) alleging that the FSSA's policy and practice of denying or limiting coverage for therapies prescribed by a Medicaid recipient's physician, refusing to cover maintenance therapy, and/or denying to cover therapies for more than two years without a significant change in medical condition violated federal Medicaid law.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' request for summary judgment and a permanent injunction.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit affirmed the district court's decision to grant summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]On November 10, 2010, the plaintiffs filed a Motion for Partial Judgment on the Pleadings.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that between May 1, 2008 and May 1, 2010, FSSA denied 49 requests from Medicaid recipients who had further treatment pre-scribed by their providers.[SENTMARKER]On May 17, 2010, the defendants filed their Motion to Dismiss (R Doc.[SENTMARKER]in Supp.[SENTMARKER]in 2011), seeking to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs then filed a motion for partial judgment on the claims of the class.[SENTMARKER]The court granted partial judgment, and the parties agreed not to enforce  (b)(6) or (b)(4).[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On March 28, 2018, the NAACP and Prince George’s County, Maryland filed a claim against the U.S. Census Bureau and President Donald Trump for neglecting their constitutional duty to administer a fair and accurate census of the US population.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that underfunding and the flawed design of the 2020 Census might lead to undercounts of the US population in violation of the Enumeration Clause and to the detriment of minority populations, as the census count is tied to both public funding and governmental representation.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs requested an injunction to require the US to develop a plan to ensure a fair and accurate count.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the claim for injunctive relief as unripe because census preparations were ongoing, but allowed the claim on underfunding to continue.[SENTMARKER]The court also allowed the plaintiffs to add two claims under the Administrative Procedure Act. On April 16, 2020, the court granted the government’s motion to dismiss; the case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 28, 2018, the Prince George's County, Maryland NAACP filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the Bureau of the Census, the Department of Commerce, and the President of the United States.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Administrative Procedures Act (APA) by failing to adequately prepare for and implement the 2020 Census.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the plaintiffs' claims for failure to state a claim and for lack of justiciability.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion in its entirety.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the plaintiffs appealed the district court's dismissal of the APA claims.[SENTMARKER]On December 19, 2019, the plaintiffs filed a motion for preliminary injunction, which was denied.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On December 18, 2009 three young adult residents of Maine who were Medicaid recipients and who were diagnosed with cerebral palsy, filed a lawsuit against the Commissioner of the Maine Department of Health and Human Services in her official capacity.[SENTMARKER]The suit was filed in the United States District Court for the District of Maine.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DHHS had violated Title II of the ADA and other federal laws.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs alleged that the State had failed to accommodate Plaintiffs' disabilities and to provide medically necessary treatment in the most integrated setting possible, instead forcing them into nursing homes where they were functionally segregated from the outside world.[SENTMARKER]In August, 2010, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint reframing the case as a class action on behalf of all similarly situated Maine residents.[SENTMARKER]The parties began settlement discussions shortly thereafter.[SENTMARKER]On May 2, 2012, the Court (Judge Nancy Torresen) approved the settlement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the State to establish a Medicaid Home and Community Based Waiver (HCBW) program, which would provide a limited number of qualifying class-members the opportunity to live in community-based settings.[SENTMARKER]The case is presumably closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 18, 2009, three individuals with developmental disabilities brought a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maine against the Maine Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) seeking declaratory and injunctive relief under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the Medicaid Act, and the Nursing Home Reform Amendments to the federal Medicaid Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DHHS violated the ADA by failing to provide the plaintiffs with medically necessary services in a community-based, integrated setting that could meet their physical needs and allow them to live more independently.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment and granted their motion for class certification.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which DHHS agreed to provide services to the plaintiffs and other similarly situated individuals under Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (Section 794(a)) of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required DHHS to provide specialized services, prevent the unnecessary segregation and institutionalization of plaintiffs and class members, provide community based services to plaintiffs, and provide a one-time notice to all nursing facilities in Maine regarding the terms of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs on July 15, 1999, finding that the defendants had violated Section 504.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment required the defendants to: provide the named plaintiffs with the services and services they were entitled to under the ADA; prevent unnecessary segregation, institutionalization, and other violations of Section 504; and provide services that could enable plaintiffs to live in the community.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to pay the Plaintiffs' costs of this litigation and their reasonable attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On July 1, 2011, a group of Medicaid recipients filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina against the Secretary of the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) alleging violations of the Social Security Act and the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief with respect to the defendants' practice of issuing notices that improperly state services are initially denied when services are being reduced or terminated.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction in the form of a temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]On March 29, 2012, the district court ruled that the defendants had failed to comply with those requirements and granted a motion for approval for a permanent injunction.[SENTMARKER]The court further ruled that defendants had violated the due process clause by refusing to rescind their requests to rescind the proposed reductions.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to dismiss the case.

pegasus_output_sents: In 2003, a group of developmentally disabled Nebraska residents filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Nebraska against the Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services Finance and Support and two department directors in their official capacities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (Section 504), Medicaid laws and regulations, and the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by failing to properly allocate funding to individuals with developmental disabilities who are eligible for home and community-based Medicaid-funded services.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case with prejudice, holding that the plaintiffs were not prevailing parties and denied their application for attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a joint motion and stipulation for approval of the settlement, which the district court retained jurisdiction to decide.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the case on various grounds, including that they were not entitled to attorney's fees under the ADA, Section 504, or Medicaid laws.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss with prejudice and denied the plaintiffs' application for attorney’s fees.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the plaintiffs appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the 8th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the case is closed.

gold_sents: On March 29, 2018, four transgender persons filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Ohio.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued the Director of the Ohio Department of Health under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]Represented by the ACLU, the plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief as well as attorneys’ fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs summary judgment on December 16, 2020, following a failed attempt by the government to have the case dismissed for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]On February 1, 2021, the plaintiffs filed a motion for attorney fees.[SENTMARKER]On March 26, the court stayed this motion pending a joint status report detailing the discussions between the parties on the attorney fees motion and the government's compliance with the December 16 order.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered that a joint status report be submitted no later than July 26, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 29, 2018, four transgender individuals, Stacie Ray, Basil Argento, Ashley Breda, and Jane Doe, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Ohio against the Ohio Department of Health (ODH), the Ohio Bureau of Motor Vehicles (Ohio BMV), and the State Registrar of the Office of Vital Statistics (OVS).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs allege that Ohio's policy prohibiting transgender persons from correcting the gender marker on their birth certificates to match their gender identity violates their constitutional rights to equal protection, due process, and freedom of speech.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also allege that the Ohio BMV allows transgender people to change the sex on their driver's license and state ID card to reflect an individual's gender identity.[SENTMARKER]On July 6, 2018, the court granted the defendants' emergency motion to dismiss the case for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
