pegasus_output_sents: On December 20, 2010, a group of individuals with developmental disabilities and their families filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against the State of Texas and Texas Community Service Programs.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the Rehabilitation Act, and the Nursing Home Reform Amendments Act (NHRA) by failing to provide them access to the community-based services and supports they need to live safely in the community.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that they were at risk of placement in nursing facilities due to the defendants' failure to provide their access to those supports and services.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion to abate and stayed all proceedings in the case.[SENTMARKER]On May 17, 2016, the court denied the State's motion to dismiss, finding that the state's compliance with the ADA and NHRA cannot be secured by voluntary means.

gold_sents: In 2016, states and religiously affiliated healthcare providers filed this lawsuit in the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Affordable Care Act's regulation prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sex (which included gender identity and termination of pregnancy) violated the Administrative Procedure Act, Religious Freedom Restoration Act and constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]In October 2016, plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction enjoining enforcement of this regulation, which was granted on December 31, 2016.[SENTMARKER]Defendants' motion to stay the preliminary injunction was denied in January 2017.[SENTMARKER]In May 2017, the defendants filed a motion for voluntary remand and stay, arguing that HHS should be given the opportunity to reconsider the regulation at issue in this case, which would conserve the resources of both parties and the court.[SENTMARKER]In July 2017, Judge O’Connor declined to remand the case, but imposed a stay of all proceedings while HHS reconsidered the regulation.[SENTMARKER]He clarified that the December 31, 2016 preliminary injunction order would be unaffected by the stay and would remain in full force and effect throughout the stay.[SENTMARKER]In December 2018, the stay was lifted, and the parties resumed litigating the case.[SENTMARKER]In September 2019, Judge O'Connor vacated the rule's challenged provisions.[SENTMARKER]An appeal is pending before the Fifth Circuit.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 23, 2016, Franciscan Alliance, a Catholic organization that provides medical services to women who have miscarried a baby, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas against the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and HHS Secretary Sylvia Burwell.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that HHS's new nondiscrimination rule, which requires HHS to provide health insurance coverage for any services related to gender transition, violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (APA) and the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that the new rule violated their religious rights.[SENTMARKER]On October 21, 2016, the District Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment, or in the alternative, a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]On December 31, 2016, the Court granted Plaintiffs' motions for preliminary injunctions, finding they were likely to succeed on their APA and RFRA claims.[SENTMARKER]On July 10, 2017, after a hearing, the Court stayed the case pending reconsideration of the Rule.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted Defendants' requests to lift the stay and set a briefing schedule for the parties to intervene.[SENTMARKER]On January 25, 2018, the Court issued a final judgment in favor of Defendants, concluding that the Rule was not unlawful under the APA or RFRA.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment also provided for enforcement proceedings by the DOJ and private lawsuits for damages and attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Same sex-couples filed suit in August 2013 against the State of Virginia challenging Virginia laws denying same-sex couples the right to marry and refusing to recognize same-sex marriages entered into in other states as unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The case is pending but stayed, awaiting the Fourth Circuit's resolution of another case raising the same issue.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 31, 2014, a group of same-sex couples filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Virginia against the Commonwealth of Virginia, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief on the grounds that the Commonwealth's exclusion from marriage and refusal to recognize their valid marriages from other jurisdictions violate the due process and equal protection guarantees of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]On July 28, 2014, the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals ruled in favor of the appellees and the Harris class, holding that Virginia’s laws prohibiting the marriage and recognition of such marriages were unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On October 6, 2014, the Supreme Court denied all three petitions for certiorari, and the Court stayed the effect of the judgment pending appeal and severed Plaintiffs' claims for attorneys' fees and costs for consideration after the final disposition of the appeal.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On March 10, 1997, the United States filed a complaint against the State of Arizona and Gov. Symington in the District of Arizona (Judge Roslyn Silver), alleging that the Defendants were violating the constitutional rights of female inmates to be free from sexual misconduct and unlawful invasions of privacy.[SENTMARKER]Symington in the District of Arizona (Judge Roslyn Silver), alleging that the Defendants were violating the constitutional rights of female inmates to be free from sexual misconduct and unlawful invasions of privacy.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement, which was filed on March 11, 1999.[SENTMARKER]As part of the settlement, defendants did not admit any constitutional violations, but agreed to adopt policy and procedures from the Federal Bureau of Prisons, improve screening and training of employees, promote inmate awareness and comfort in reporting abuse, and thoroughly investigate allegations of abuse.[SENTMARKER]On December 13, 1999, the parties jointly filed a stipulation to dismiss which Judge Silver granted in a December 17, 1999 order.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 8, 1996, the U.S. Department of Justice's Civil Rights Division filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Arizona against the Arizona Department of Corrections (ADOC) alleging that the ADOC violated the Eighth Amendment rights of female inmates by failing to protect them from sexual misconduct by correctional officers and staff.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that ADOC and contract employees had engaged in sexual misconduct and invasions of privacy in Arizona women's prisons without being disciplined.[SENTMARKER]On March 10, 1997, the court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]Under the settlement agreement, ADOC will conduct an investigation of all allegations of sexual misconduct in ADOC facilities.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also requires ADOC to implement policies and procedures to ensure that inmates are not subjected to sexual misconduct.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on December 17, 1997.

gold_sents: This case litigated by the ACLU in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California dealt with sanitation, classification, legal access and other conditions at the California Institute for Men (Chino).[SENTMARKER]In 1988, the prison and the plaintiffs entered a settlement agreement, which provided for various improvements and compliance monitoring that ended in 1993.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 29, 1988, the ACLU Foundation of 10 Southern California filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against the California Department of Corrections and the Director of the California Institute for Men.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had violated the Eighth Amendment of the United States Constitution by intentionally inflicting mental stress upon the prisoners confined in the Chino Reception Guidance Center.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' intentional infliction of mental stress violated the cruel and unusual punishment clause of the Fifth, Sixth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case with prejudice, and the parties entered into a memorandum of understanding.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay the plaintiffs $22,000 in compensation for each day of barbarous and unconstitutional confinement in the 14 gym area of the Chino reception center.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendants agreed to provide the plaintiffs with an adequate time to eat, adequate access to the 15 courts, and to make good faith library improvements.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2008, a California inmate filed a lawsuit against the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation, alleging that the CDCR acted unconstitutionally by segregating the prisoners by race and locking down an entire race of prisoners due to the actions of certain prisoners of that race.[SENTMARKER]The case survived the defendants' motion to dismiss and class certification was granted.[SENTMARKER]In October 2014, the parties entered into a stipulated settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the agreement, the CDCR agreed to a number of terms, including to cease implementation of race-based modified programs or lockdowns; to provide outdoor activity to prisoners in a modified program or lockdown for longer than fourteen days; to revise its policies concerning modified programs and lockdowns, and to train its staff on modified programs and lockdowns.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to pay attorneys fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The court retained jurisdiction for 18 months to enforce compliance with the agreement, and on December 20, 2016, the parties filed notice that the court’s jurisdiction to enforce the settlement agreement had terminated and that the case was dismissed with prejudice in its entirety.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 18, 2006, a prisoner at High Desert State Prison filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California against the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR) alleging that the CDCR's Race-Based Lockdown Policy violated the Eighth Amendment and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the prisoner alleged that he was subjected to cruel and unusual punishment as a result of the race-based lockdowns and that the lockdowns violated his rights to 8 equal protection and due process.[SENTMARKER]The case went to trial and a jury found that defendants violated Norwood's Eighth Amendment right to outdoor exercise by imposing a lockdown on all prisoners who were racially classified as "Other" after an incident involving a prisoner classified as African-American.[SENTMARKER]The court granted summary judgment to the defendants and dismissed the case as moot.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement, which was approved by the court on February 11, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to implement a modified program and lockdown policy that would not discriminate on the basis of race or gender.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to pay a total of $1 million to settle the case.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: On May 16, 2020, five individuals filed a class action against Lompoc, a low-security prison facing one of the largest outbreaks of COVID-19 among U.S federal prisons, for immediate relief.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs proposed a class of all current and future people in post-conviction custody at Lompoc, and sought enlargement of custody to include home confinement, and if the conditions of confinement violated constitutional rights, for prisoners to be released.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also sought a TRO (temporary restraining order), and a preliminary injunction requiring Lompoc to undertake health and safety measures, and attorney fees.[SENTMARKER]On September 18, the court denied the defendant's motion to dismiss the case and on October 8, the court granted plaintiff's motion to enforce compliance with the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]In January 2021, the plaintiffs filed another motion to enforce compliance with the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 27, 2020, inmates at the Federal Bureau of Prisons filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the BOP had failed to respond effectively to the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]They sought injunctive relief, including the release of inmates to home confinement.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion to decertify the class and denied their motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]On July 14, 2020, the court dismissed the class action on the basis that the defendants had not complied with the court's orders.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: On August 22, 1980, inmates filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Connecticut against the Connecticut Corrections Department.[SENTMARKER]This case was consolidated and named lead case with five other cases filed against the defendant in 1981 and 1982.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were represented by the Connecticut Civil Liberties Union and Legal Assistance to Prisoners.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the plaintiff's rights under the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments were violated because the facility was overcrowded, unsanitary, lacking in security, and unable to provide adequately the basics of general human living needs.[SENTMARKER]Judgments were reached that required screening of all admitted inmates, individualized health care summaries for HIV-positive inmates, routine health examinations, and the use of drug therapies for HIV-positive inmates; as well as requiring that the prison not increase its inmate population, continue operating as a medium security facility, and allow plaintiffs' lawyers access to the facility.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 15, 1988, a group of inmates at the Connecticut Correctional Institution at Somers filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Connecticut against the Connecticut Department of Correction.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' policies and practices concerning HIV-infection, medical and mental health care provided to inmates with HIV, and access to medical care for HIV-infected inmates violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution and the Connecticut Civil Rights Act.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in May 1994.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a general agreement in which the defendants agreed to provide additional personnel for counseling and support services for counseling personnel.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required the defendants to provide all of its employees a minimum of one hour of training annually on HIV-related subjects, including its non-disclosure provisions.[SENTMARKER]The agreement was approved by Judge Holly B. Fitzsimmons on March 26, 1996 and is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In 1986, the prisoners at the Occoquan Facilites of the District of Columbia's Lorton Correctional Complex filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the District of Columbia government officials' overcrowding of the facility violated their Eighth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The court held that the defendants had violated the constitution, and required that the prison minimize its population.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in 2003.
pegasus_output_sents: In the wake of a prison riot, inmates at the District of Columbia's facilities in Occoquan, Virginia, brought suit in federal court under 42 U.S.C.  1983 alleging that conditions at the prison violated the Eighth Amendment's prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted class certification and a preliminary injunction imposing a limit on the number of prisoners who could be housed at the facility.[SENTMARKER]In September, the District Court found that the District had deliberately failed to obey its orders concerning overcrowding at the jail and held the District in civil contempt.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court vacated and remanded, finding that the population cap was too broad a remedy.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement that required the District to pay $100,000 to the D.C Prisoners' Legal Services Project, Inc., $53,498.00 to the National Center on Institutions and Alternatives, and $26,400.00 in full settlement of any claims by plaintiffs for attorney's fees or costs.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the district court for further proceedings consistent with the Supreme Court's decision.

gold_sents:
On August 6, 2006, Prison Legal News (PLN) submitted a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) seeking documents related to litigation expenses.[SENTMARKER]They asked the BOP to waive all search and duplication fees under the FOIA.[SENTMARKER]BOP refused to grant the fee waiver and PLN appealed the decision to the Department of Justice.

The DOJ upheld the denial of the request, so on September 13, 2005, PLN filed this lawsuit in the US District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]After several years of litigation, the parties settled in 2017.[SENTMARKER]The BOP produced the requested documents and agreed to pay $420,000 in attorneys' fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 13, 2005, Prison Legal News, a non-profit legal journal, filed this Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) and the Department of Justice (DOJ).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought declaratory and injunctive relief and an order compelling the defendants to provide it with all documents responsive to its FOIA requests without any cost.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff also challenged the Bureau's search for responsive records and its utilization of the FOIA exemptions to withhold the redacted information and other documents that it claims have not been produced at all.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the plaintiff's motion for summary judgment and ordered the Bureau to conduct the search without costs to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendant's summary judgment motion in part and denied its motion to dismiss without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Four overdetained former Delaware prisoners, represented by private counsel, filed this § 1983 action against the Delaware Department of Corrections (DDOC) and Central Offender Records (COR).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that inadequate staff, training, discipline, and hours of operation, along with a host of other policies, caused dysfunction and frequent over-detention.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs brought suit individually and as a class on behalf of all those incarcerated in a DDOC facility as of October 1, 2008 or later who were not or will not be released within 12 hours of the expiration of their sentence or the forwarding of a court order for release.[SENTMARKER]In 2015, the district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment because the plaintiffs' failed to demonstrate that the defendants were deliberately indifferent to the overdetention problem.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Third Circuit affirmed the district court's decision to grant summary judgment to the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 1, 2012, inmates of the Delaware Department of Correction (DDOC) filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Delaware.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the DDOC had violated the Fourth, Fifth, and Eighth Amendments of the United States Constitution by over-detaining inmates and inmates past their release dates.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs also alleged that DDOC violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments by failing to ensure timely release.[SENTMARKER]On September 29, 2014, the Court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants and denied the plaintiffs' motion for class certification.[SENTMARKER]The parties shall file a joint status report by October 6, 2014.

gold_sents: In 2004, a Mental Health Unit (MHU) prisoner at Georgia's Phillips State Prison brought this §1983 suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia.[SENTMARKER]Represented by the Southern Center for Human Rights, , plaintiff contended that the defendant prison administrators denied Eighth Amendment protections against cruel and unusual punishment by understaffing the MHU, as well as by staffing it with correctional officers without adequate mental health training.[SENTMARKER]Class certification was sought but not granted.[SENTMARKER]On January 31, 2005, the day before dispositive motions were due to be filed, the Court approved the parties' joint stipulation for dismissal.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 22, 2003, a prisoner at Phillips State Prison in Buford, Georgia filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia against the Georgia Department of Corrections.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution by failing to protect seriously mentally ill prisoners from the risk of harm.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in which the parties agreed to dismiss the case due to mootness.[SENTMARKER]On July 9, 2004, the court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the parties entered into a joint settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement provided for the dismissal of all claims against the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment and granted their motion for class certification.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: In January of 2008, several inmates filed suit against the Georgia Department of Corrections, alleging that it established a pattern and practice of systematic abuse of the inmates.[SENTMARKER]Several claims and defendants were dismissed for failure to exhaust administrative remedies and failure to plead claims in adequate details.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the case in July 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 15, 2011, a group of inmates at Valdosta State Prison filed a civil rights action in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Georgia against the State of Georgia, the Georgia Department of Corrections, and the Department of Juvenile Justice.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Eighth Amendment of the Constitution and the civil rights laws of the United States by systematically beating and kicking restrained inmates in violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss for failure to exhaust administrative remedies, which was granted by the district court.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the claims of the plaintiffs, but the Eleventh Circuit reversed and remanded the case, finding that the prisoner did exhaust the required administrative remedies.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the case is closed.

gold_sents: Plaintiff is a trans woman housed in a male prison in Georgia.[SENTMARKER]She filed suit in the Souther District of Georgia alleging prison officials' deliberate indifference to her repeated sexual assault.[SENTMARKER]The district court ruled in favor of the prison administration, grating their motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Eleventh Circuit affirmed, similarly finding that no violation of the Eighth or Fourteenth Amendments.
pegasus_output_sents: In May 2014, a transgender prisoner filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Georgia against the Georgia Department of Corrections, alleging that the prison officials had violated his Eighth Amendment rights by failing to protect him from a fellow transgender inmate who sexually assaulted him.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants, finding that the defendants did not violate the Constitution and that they were therefore immune from suit because they were entitled to qualified immunity.[SENTMARKER]Green appealed the district court's decision to dismiss his supervisory liability claims.[SENTMARKER]The case was re-opened and the parties filed a motion for summary judgment on August 26, 2016.[SENTMARKER]On January 6, 2019, the court granted the defendants summary judgment and dismissed Green's supervisory liability claim.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed an appeal, which was granted on January 6, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: Hawaiian residents of Native Hawaiian ancestry held in for-profit prisons in Arizona filed this class action lawsuit against the State of Hawaii and CoreCivic.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendant prisons prohibited them from exercising their constitutional and statutory rights to practice their religion.[SENTMARKER]The case involved extensive litigation, with class and sub-class certification granted.[SENTMARKER]However, the case resolved via a settlement that the court held as valid under principles of contract law.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 7, 2011, inmates of Saguaro Correctional Center and Red Rock Correctional Center filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Hawaii against CoreCivic, formerly known as Corrections Corporation of America, alleging that the defendants violated their rights under the federal Constitution and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act of 2000 (RLUIPA) by preventing them from practicing the native Hawaiian religion during a Makahiki festival at a CCA correctional facility located in Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to transfer the case to the District Court of Arizona pursuant to  1406(a) as it could have been brought there.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the action on the ground that the defendant was not, at the time of service of the summons, "doing business" in the Southern District of Florida, and therefore, the venue requirements of  1391(c) were not met.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the parties entered a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the defendants to allow the inmates to meet with other Native Hawaiian practitioners on a daily basis for group worship, publish in-cell retention list in Saguaro's chapel and add list to [Saguaro's] policy, publish a communal items list in the chapel, and pay $700.00 to the Native Hawaiian Legal Corporation for costs incurred.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On January 23, 2012, a deaf inmate at the Idaho State Correctional Institution (ISCI) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Idaho against the Idaho Department of Correction (IDOC) alleging discrimination under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (Rehabilitation Act).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the IDOC failed to provide the inmate with an opportunity to effectively communicate with persons outside the prison that was equal to that provided to hearing inmates.[SENTMARKER]In light of this, the inmate requested that he be provided the use of a videophone, which would allow him to communicate with an increased number of people using his primary language.[SENTMARKER]In a response dated November 3, 2009, the I DOC denied the request, stating that the ADA does not require state-of-the-art technology as a method of reasonable accommodation.[SENTMARKER]The complaint was dismissed with prejudice on January 23, 2012 and the parties agreed to a settlement conference on October 31, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The settlement conference will be held in Courtroom #1 on the order of Judge B. Lynn Winmill.

gold_sents: In 2016, a group of prisoners of the Illinois Department of Corrections filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were subjected to extreme isolation in violation of the Eight and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the defendant's motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 10, 2017, a group of inmates in the Illinois Department of Corrections (IDOC) filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the IDOC's policies and customs, which place every individual incarcerated in Illinois at risk of being subjected to extraordinarily long and severely harmful extreme isolation, violated their constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, finding that the plaintiffs had not shown that their placement in segregation violated the due process clause, and that the defendants had failed to provide them with due process protections.[SENTMARKER]The case is now on appeal.

gold_sents: In 2009, a group of Muslim prisoners filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Indiana against the warden of the Federal Correctional Institute, alleging that the prison's allowance of only one hour of group prayer per week violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act.[SENTMARKER]The court ultimately issued a permanent injunction against the Federal Correctional Institute in 2013, holding that the prison's policy violated RFRA and, upon further clarification, ordered that the warden "is to allow group prayer during every Muslim prayer time for which the inmates are not confined to their cell."
pegasus_output_sents: In June 2009, a group of Muslim inmates at the Federal Correctional Institution in Terre Haute, Indiana, filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Indiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the prison's policy on group prayer violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment, but denied their motion for class certification.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2007, the Disability Law Center filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, the ADA, and the Rehabilitation Act against the Massachusetts Department of Correction.[SENTMARKER]The DLC claimed that the DOC failed to take into account mental illness when subjecting prisoners to long periods of disciplinary and other forms of isolation and segregation.[SENTMARKER]The case settled in 2011, and the defendants agreed to make sure that mentally ill prisoners were not placed in isolation or segregation without a full evaluation and determination that such placement would not cause further injury; they also agreed to pay attorney fees.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed in 2015 as no one had requested to reopen the case since the settlement monitoring date ended.[SENTMARKER]In 2016 one of the prisoners tried to reopen the case since prison officials were violating the settlement agreement, but the judge refused to reopen the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 8, 2007, Disability Law Center, Inc. ("DLC"), a not-for-profit corporation representing mentally ill inmates in the custody of the Massachusetts Department of Correction ("DOC"), filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the DOC's treatment of inmates with mental illness violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (" Rehabilitation Act"), and the Americans with Disabilities Act ("ADA").[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in November, 2007 that required the DOC to provide mental health services to inmates in segregation.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was approved by the court on April 12, 2012, and the case was dismissed on December 12, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion for a stay of discovery on March 4, 2009, and the court granted a stay on August 12, 2010.[SENTMARKER]On May 20, 2015, the parties filed an amended motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion, and the parties entered into the settlement agreement on May 20, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the court would not enforce the terms of the settlement, and that the parties would pay the court's costs.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to provide the court with a copy of the remaining redacted records.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed, but the court retains jurisdiction.

gold_sents: In November 2015, plaintiff inmates with hearing disabilities sued the Massachusetts Department of Correction and the Massachusetts Partnership for Correctional Healthcare under the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Rehabilitation Act, and the Constitution of the United States.[SENTMARKER]After mediation, the parties settled in 2019.[SENTMARKER]Enforcement of the settlement remains in effect for a period of three years.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 12, 2014, the Massachusetts Department of Correction (DOC) and Massachusetts Partnership for Correctional Healthcare (MPCH) filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the Rehabilitation Act (RLUIPA), the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act of 2000, and the Constitution of the United States by failing to accommodate the needs of deaf and hard-of-hearing inmates in the custody of the DOC.[SENTMARKER]The defendants denied the plaintiffs' requests for videophone services, visual alert and notification systems, and by denying their requests for interpreter services, individual hearing devices, and other auxiliary aids and services.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendants also failed to give consideration to the plaintiffs’ reasonable requests for accommodations by denying them videophones and visual alert systems.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that they discriminated against the plaintiffs in work assignments.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement, which is subject to the Final Approval of the Court, in which the defendants agreed to make videophone technology available at each of its facilities to those inmates who have been identified as deaf or hard of hearing and whose primary language is sign language.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement will be made available by request under the Massachusetts Public Records Law, Mass Gen.[SENTMARKER]40162GAO et al.

gold_sents: COVID-vulnerable inmates of the Maine Department of Corrections, seeking to represent a class of medically vulnerable and disabled inmates, brought this habeas action in an effort to force the Department to de-densify its prisons by releasing prisoners.[SENTMARKER]Filed May 15, 2020 in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maine, the complaint alleged that the Department had refused to grant medical furlough or home confinement to inmates; they alleged that this was in violation of the Eighth Amendment, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The action was assigned to Judge John A. Woodcock, Jr.[SENTMARKER]Although the Department reported its first case of COVID in May 2020, the court dismissed the plaintiffs’ motion for preliminary injunctive relief in June 2020.[SENTMARKER]Motions to dismiss the case and to convert the case to a different form of habeas were pending as of July 28, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 15, 2020, two inmates of the Maine Department of Corrections (MDOC) filed a petition for habeas corpus in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maine (Bangor) on behalf of themselves and a putative class of those similarly situated inmates.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the confinement of inmates with COVID-19 has become unconstitutional because of the pandemic risk associated with the disease.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a joint status report on May 20, 2020, and the Court denied the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO) or preliminary injunction on June 8, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to implement a number of conditions, including limiting the number of operational entrances and exits to the facility, limiting non-essential vendors, volunteers, and tours from entering the facility.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to review the sick leave policies of each employer that operates in the facility and to limit the amount of time inmates spend on medical furloughs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On October 30, 2007, a state prison inmate filed a §1983 lawsuit against the Chief Medical Officer of the Michigan Department of Corrections' Bureau of Health Care Services and three unnamed individual members of the Medical Services Advisory Committee (MSAC).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, who originally filed pro se but was later represented by the University of Michigan Law School General Clinic, sought declarative, monetary, and injunctive relief, claiming that the defendants acted with deliberate indifference to the plaintiff's serious medical needs when they repeatedly denied his request for cataract surgery.[SENTMARKER]On May 30, 2012, following a reversal by the 6th Circuit Court of Appeals, the district court entered an order granting summary judgment in favor of one of the defendants based on qualified immunity.[SENTMARKER]As of November 18, 2014, the case is ongoing against the remaining defendants.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 30, 2007, an inmate in the custody of the Michigan Department of Corrections (MDOC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The inmate alleged that his Eighth Amendment rights were violated when the MDOC denied his request for cataract surgery in his left eye.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged deliberate indifference based on failure to provide him with cataract surgery for one of his eyes but not the other.[SENTMARKER]The defendant, Correctional Medical Services, Inc. (CMS), filed a motion to dismiss the case in January 2008.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the case was closed.[SENTMARKER]In November 2007, the inmate filed a pro se motion for declaratory, injunctive, and monetary relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties completed discovery in November 2009, and the parties filed objections to the Report and Recommendation on March 25, 2010.[SENTMARKER]The Magistrate Judge recommended that the case should be dismissed.[SENTMARKER]On March 31, 2010, the district court granted the defendants summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This 2013 lawsuit was brought by several Muslim inmates of  the Lakeland Correctional Facility in the U.S. District for the Western District of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that, in failing to provide adequate nutrition to prisoners observing Ramadan, the defendants, several agents of the Michigan Department of Corrections, had violated the First, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments as well as the RLUIPA.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In September 2006, prisoners at the Michigan Department of Corrections (MDOC) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Michigan, alleging that the defendants violated their First and Eighth Amendment rights under the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act (RLUIPA) by failing to provide them adequate nutrition during the Islamic month of Ramadan, which lasts for 29 to 30 days.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved for summary judgment, claiming that the plaintiffs could only obtain adequate nutrition by violating their religious beliefs.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' summary judgment motion, concluding that they were shielded by qualified immunity.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the district court dismissed the RLUIPA claims with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed, and the defendants are no longer required to accommodate plaintiffs' requests for nutritionally-adequate meals.

gold_sents: In 2016, a transgender prisoner of the Missouri Department of Corrections filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that the “freeze-frame” policy of refraining from providing transgender prisoners necessary medical care for gender dysphoria unless they previously received such services violated the Eighth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]In 2018, the court declared that the policy violated the Eighth Amendment’s Cruel and Unusual Punishment Clause and issued a permanent injunction against the policy.[SENTMARKER]The court also ordered the defendants to provide the medical care necessary for the plaintiff’s gender dysphoria.[SENTMARKER]Additionally, the court awarded the plaintiff attorney’s fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 22, 2016, a transgender woman in the custody of the Missouri Department of Corrections (MDOC) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri against Corizon Health, LLC, a health care provider for the MDOC, alleging that the defendants violated the Eighth Amendment by denying her medical treatment for gender dysphoria.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiff's motion for injunctive and declaratory relief, and granted the defendants' motion for partial summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The parties then entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to provide the plaintiff with hormone therapy for her medical needs.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also required the defendants to provide hormone therapy to other transgender inmates who were not receiving hormone therapy, and for whom hormone therapy has been recommended by a mental health provider.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: In 2005, the ACLU filed a class-action lawsuit on behalf of inmates confined in Unit 32 of the Mississippi State Penitentiary in Parchman, Mississippi, alleging dangerous and inhumane conditions of confinement.[SENTMARKER]The parties initially settled in 2006.[SENTMARKER]Then, the plaintiffs filed a motion for contempt in late 2006, seeking an order to compel defendants to immediately comply with the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]After two more settlements, the defendants agreed to close Unit 32 in 2010 and the case was dismissed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 22, 2005, the National Prison Project of the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), the Mississippi ACLU, and Holland Knight, LLP, filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Mississippi against the Mississippi Department of Corrections (MDOC) on behalf of prisoners confined in Unit 32 of Mississippi State Penitentiary (MSP), Parchman, Mississippi.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the MDOC violated the Eighth Amendment by subjecting the prisoners to inhumane living conditions and excessive force, deprives them of medical and mental health treatment, and denies them procedural due process in housing them in MSP.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a consent decree, which was signed by Judge Jerry A. Davis on February 20, 2006 (Dkt No. 24, attached here), after a fairness hearing in compliance with Rule 23 (e) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the defendants to provide prisoners with a means for renouncing affiliation with a security threat group that does not require prisoners to provide identities of gang members as a condition for renunciation.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to retain or cause to be retained an additional eight full-time registered nurses (RNs) at MSP to fill existing FTE vacancies at MSP.[SENTMARKER]They also agreed that the Court shall retain jurisdiction to enforce the provisions of this consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed without prejudice.

gold_sents: In 2013, prisoners in the East Mississippi Correctional Facility (EMCF) filed a class-action lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the Mississippi Department of Corrections, claiming that EMCF violated the Eighth Amendment's Cruel and Unusual Punishment Clause.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that the inhumane living conditions at EMCF, a prison for the mentally ill, harmed inmates.[SENTMARKER]In 2015, the court granted class certification.[SENTMARKER]After engaging in discovery and a bench trial, the parties attempted to settle.[SENTMARKER]After the parties submitted their supplemental expert reports, the parties attempted to settle.[SENTMARKER]However, on January 24, 2019, the parties notified the court that the parties were unable to settle and that future settlement conferences would not be productive.[SENTMARKER]As of March 25, 2019, the case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2007, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Mississippi on behalf of prisoners confined at the East Mississippi Correctional Facility in Meridian, Mississippi, which is designed to provide treatment and housing for mentally ill prisoners.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the conditions under which they were confined violated their Eighth Amendment right to be free from cruel and unusual punishment.[SENTMARKER]In addition to the physical conditions and security at the facility, changes were also made with respect to the provision of medical and mental care.[SENTMARKER]After the plaintiffs filed their complaint, the defendants entered into a consent decree that prohibited the housing of seriously mentally ill inmates in long-term solitary confinement in Unit 32 for more than 14 days.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also prohibited the use of chemical agents and physical force on prisoners without warning and in the absence of an immediate threat of danger.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then contracted with a new company, Centurion, to provide mental health care services at the prison.[SENTMARKER]As the case neared trial, the parties met on multiple occasions with the magistrate judge to try to settle the case without success.[SENTMARKER]The magistrate judge denied the parties' motion to appeal that decision.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This case is about the refusal of North Carolina's Department of Public Safety (DPS) to recognize Humanism as a faith group within the North Carolina state prison system.[SENTMARKER]On February 2, 2015, an inmate in a North Carolina prison and the American Humanist Association filed this lawsuit in the Eastern District of North Carolina against officers of the North Carolina Department of Public Safety that are involved in policy decisions related to recognition of faith groups in state prison under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]They alleged violations of the First and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment, and on March 29, 2018, Judge Terrence W. Boyle granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and denied the defendants' motion.[SENTMARKER]He entered a permanent injunction ordering DPS to recognize Humanism as a faith group and to permit a Humanist study group to meet within North Carolina state prisons on the same terms as other faiths are allowed and entered declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]The court also awarded nominal damages and attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]Since the entering of the permanent injunction, there has been no activity in this case.[SENTMARKER]The permanent injunction remains in effect.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 25, 2015, the American Humanist Association (AHA) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina against the North Carolina Department of Public Safety (DPS), the Director of the Division of Adult Correction and Juvenile Justice, and the Deputy Director of Prisons in their official capacities.[SENTMARKER]The AHA alleged that the defendants violated the First Amendment by refusing to allow a North Carolina inmate with sincerely held Humanist convictions to form a Humanist study group to meet on the same terms that Defendants authorize inmates of theistic religious traditions to meet; .Plaintiffs sought injunctive and declaratory relief, permanent injunctive relief, nominal damages, and attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment on March 29, 2018, and the case was dismissed on July 28, 2018.

gold_sents: This was a prison medical care case filed in 2002 in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey, seeking damages and an injunction against contract medical care providers and New Jersey corrections officials.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs that the New Jersey prison system was failing to treat them for Hepatitis C.[SENTMARKER]By the time the court adjudicated the class action issue, in May 2008, the New Jersey Department of Corrections had adopted major changes in how prisoners with HCV were treated; it updated its procedures to match those of the federal Bureau of Prisons, and "backscreened" all the prisoners willing to be screened for the virus.[SENTMARKER]Given that the injunctive relief requested by the plaintiffs was this same set of reforms, Judge Hillman denied the request for injunctive relief as moot.[SENTMARKER]As to two individual class members who had HCV, the court held there was sufficient evidence in the record to go to trial on their constitutional claims (though not on their Americans with Disabilities Act claims), and denied the state's motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]In October 2009, the case settled for money damages.[SENTMARKER](However, it seems from some papers filed by one of the plaintiffs that he may never actually have received  his money.[SENTMARKER]But when he sought the assistance of the court in enforcing the settlement against his lawyer, Judge Hillman ruled that the court lacked jurisdiction, and directed him to file a collection action in state court.  )
pegasus_output_sents: On October 16, 2002, two former inmates of the New Jersey Department of Corrections filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to screen inmates for Hepatitis C (HCV) and exposing them to Hepatitis A and B (HBV) in violation of their Eighth Amendment right to be free from cruel and unusual punishment.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to provide a proper screening mechanism for new inmates.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on May 14, 2008 and the parties filed a motion for summary judgment on August 27, 2008.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a settlement agreement in which they agreed that the parties would not enforce any of the terms of the settlement agreement until the case was settled.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was subject to court approval.

gold_sents: On December 3, 2008, plaintiff, a prisoner who is an ordained Pentecostal minister, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the District of New Jersey under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act, 42 U.S.C. §§ 2000cc, et seq. ("RLUIPA") against the Commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Corrections and the Administrator at the New Jersey State Prison (NJSP).[SENTMARKER]Specifically, plaintiff claimed that defendants violated plaintiff's First Amendment right by implementing a policy banning all prisoners from preaching in the prison.[SENTMARKER]During the litigation, the state changed its policy to allow the plaintiff to preach to groups of six or fewer prisoners, and on November 25, 2009, the parties filed a Stipulation of Dismissal, as the claims in the action had been resolved by the parties.
pegasus_output_sents: In October 2008, a prisoner at New Jersey State Prison ("NJSP"), an ordained Pentecostal minister, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey against the New Jersey Department of Corrections ("NJ DOC"), the NJSP administrator, and the NJ DOC commissioner.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act of 2000 ("RLUIPA") and the Free Exercise Clause of the First Amendment by imposing a blanket ban on inmate preaching in the prison.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendant's motion for summary judgment, but granted the plaintiff's request for declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Court of Appeals for the First Circuit reversed the district court's grant of summary judgment for the defendant, holding that the prison failed to satisfy RLUIPA's burden burden requirements.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In July 2015, an inmate at the Northern Nevada Correctional Center living with hepatitis C filed this lawsuit in the District Court of Nevada in Reno.[SENTMARKER]Representing himself, he claimed that the defendants, medical and administration personnel at the prison, violated his Eighth Amendment rights through deliberate indifference to serious medical needs resulting from his hepatitis C.[SENTMARKER]In May 2016, the parties reached a private settlement agreement, the terms of which are unknown.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 12, 2012, the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia issued a final judgment against a former employee of the United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment enjoined the defendant from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5 of the Exchange Act.[SENTMARKER]The defendant was also ordered to pay a civil penalty of $75,000.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: This case was brought, pro se, by a prisoner housed in the Special Housing Unit of New York's Attica prison, and then litigated by NY Prisoners Legal Services.[SENTMARKER]It concerned conditions of confinement in that unit, including excessive force, religion, sanitation and nutrition, access to courts, and medical and mental health care.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled, piecemeal, between 1992 and 2002.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 6, 1980, inmates of Attica Correctional Facility, a highly restricted disciplinary prison unit, filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants, all state correction officials or prison authorities at Attica, violated the First, Sixth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution by systematically violating the constitutional rights of inmates in the Special Housing Unit (SHU).[SENTMARKER]Specifically, they alleged that they were deprived of their right to free exercise of religion while incarcerated in the SHU.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction on January 29, 1988 and the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit affirmed the district court's order in an opinion dated June 13, 1988; the case was dismissed on January 6, 1998.[SENTMARKER]On March 6, 1998, the plaintiffs appealed to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court denied the appeal, and the case is now closed.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: In 1997, prisoners at various facilities within the New York State Department of Corrections filed a class action lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against Department officials.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by Prisoners Legal Services of New York, brought the suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York, challenging the systemic deprivation of religious rights of Native American prisoners, in violation of the First and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]In 2000, the parties reached a settlement and the court dismissed the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 29, 1997, Native American prisoners in the custody of the New York State Department of Correctional Services (DOCS) filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the DOCS was unlawfully preventing them from conducting religious cerehionies, and discriminated against them by failing to provide them with the opportunity to practice their traditional Native American religion.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in September 1999, and the case was closed on September 8, 2000.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the following conditions: (i) the appointment of a full-time chaplain to serve the religious needs of inmates at each facility; .[SENTMARKER](ii) the hiring of a part-time minister for adherents of the Nation of Islam Faith Faith once their numbers exceed 200; .[SENTMARKER](iii) a limit on the number of guests each inmate may invite to each event; .[SENTMARKER](iv) the use of Native American rugs in their religious communities; and (v) the creation of a visitor hospitality center.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed that the defendants would provide or allow inmates to participate in sweat lodge ceremonies outsjide of the facility.

gold_sents: On September 29, 2003, a group of paraplegic prisoners, proceeding pro se, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against prison officials.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants failed to provide adequate medical care in violation their rights under the Fifth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]After extensive settlement negotiations and mediation, the parties were unable to reach and agreement.[SENTMARKER]This case is proceeding to trial.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 13, 2007, prisoners with disabilities in the custody of the New York State Department of Correctional and Community Supervision (DOCS) filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive and declaratory relief, as well as monetary and attorney's fees, in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (Section 1983).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants failed to make their programs, services, and activities accessible to their disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was closed.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On January 21, 2003, an Oklahoma Department of Corrections prisoner filed a lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. §1983 in the United States District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma, alleging that his Constitutional rights under the Free Exercise Clause were being violated by the Oklahoma Department of Corrections' refusal to provide him with a Kosher diet.[SENTMARKER]The case was consolidated to include the complaints of two other prisoners.[SENTMARKER]The prisoners won both preliminary and permanent injunctive relief requiring the Oklahoma Department of Corrections to provide them a Kosher diet at no personal cost.[SENTMARKER]The permanent injunction, issued February 8, 2006, ordered the Director of the Oklahoma Department of Corrections 'to immediately provide to the plaintiffs Kosher diets at no cost, [while complying with nutritional requirements currently applicable to all other ODOC prisoners].'[SENTMARKER]On September 26, 2012 the Court found that the judgment entered in this case only applies to the claims pursued by the three named plaintiffs, and the permanent injunction relief does not apply to all Oklahoma Department of Corrections inmates.
pegasus_output_sents: In 1996, three inmates of the Colorado Department of Corrections filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado alleging a constitutional and statutory right to receive a kosher diet in accordance with Orthodox Jewish law.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that their rights guaranteed by the First Amendment's free exercise clause had been violated by the Colorado DOC's failure to provide them free of cost with kosher meals consistent with their Orthodox Jewish faith.[SENTMARKER]In 2002, the Tenth Circuit Court of Appeals issued a decision affirming the district court's decision.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction requiring the ColoradoDOC to provide kosher food to the inmate-plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case was re-referred to the United States Magistrate Judge Gary M. Purcell for further proceedings, including a determination whether permanent injunctive relief was warranted.[SENTMARKER]On January 21, 2005, the District Court issued a final judgment ordering the Oklahoma Department of corrections to provide these three plaintiffs with a Kosher diet at no cost.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the final judgment to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court denied the defendants' appeal and the case was closed on January 21, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On November 7, 2013, a trans woman housed in a mens prison in Oklahoma filed a pro se case against prison staff and administration in the District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]She claims that she has been denied appropriate transition related care and accommodations, amounting to a violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]Her request for a TRO and preliminary injunction were denied at the district court level, and the circuit court affirmed the denial of the preliminary injunction without comment on the TRO for lack of jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]On April 3, 2015, the district court granted defendants' motion to dismiss, dismissing the claims against all defendants in their individual capacities without prejudice, and all the claims against them in their official capacity with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]Though the plaintiff objected to the dismissal, the Court denied her motion and affirmed the dismissal.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 28, 2014, a state prisoner in the Oklahoma Department of Corrections filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]The prisoner alleged that the defendants violated her Eighth Amendment rights by denying her the proper level of hormone treatment and allowing her to purchase female undergarments, such as bras and panties.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, but dismissed the complaint for failure to state a claim upon which relief may be granted.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On July 27, 2012, plaintiff, a male prisoner, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the Middle District of Pennsylvania under Bivens against the Federal Bureau of Prisons.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiff claimed that the defendants violated plaintiff's right to be free from cruel and unusual punishment under the Eighth Amendment to the United States Constitution by forcing him to share a cell with a hostile prisoner, which caused a threat of violence, and by placing him in painful restraints that caused injury for prolonged periods on multiple occasions for refusing dangerous cell assignments with hostile prisoners; and that defendants violated his right to due process under the Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution by depriving him of any meaningful process prior to and during their use of punitive measures against him.[SENTMARKER]On April 9, 2013, the U.S. District Court (Judge William B. Nealon) granted in part and denied in part defendant's motion to dismiss, declining to certify the class.[SENTMARKER]The Third Circuit reversed and remanded the district court's denial of class action certification on June 15, 2016, but the district court again denied certification.[SENTMARKER]Litigation is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 7, 2011, a federal prisoner filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania against the Bureau of Prisons (BOP), alleging that the BOP's program to enforce hostile cell assignments violated his Fifth and Eighth Amendment rights by placing him in painful restraints as punishment for refusing to accept dangerous cell assignments with hostile inmates.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed by the District Court, but the parties appealed to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court remanded the case for further proceedings consistent with the opinion in the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be stayed pending further order of court.

gold_sents: In 2015, a prisoner at the Mahanoy State Correctional Institute filed this complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants denied him necessary medical treatment, in violation of his Eighth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]In May 2018, the district judge denied the defendants' motions to dismiss, which the defendants appealed to the Third Circuit.[SENTMARKER]As of March 23, 2020, the case is still ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In May 2015, a prisoner in the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections (DOC) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania alleging that the DOC's policy of prohibiting all communication between hospital patients and their lawyers, family, friends, and others not in the employ of the DOC or Geisinger Medical Center violated his constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the prohibition on visitation and phone calls was the policy of Geisinger and not the DOC.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the plaintiff's motion for a preliminary injunction, which the Court granted in part and denied in part.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the two matters should be consolidated and thereafter filed a joint motion for consolidation.[SENTMARKER]On August 16, 2016, the Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit affirmed the District Court's denial of the defendants' motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The Court found that the defendants had a reasonable likelihood of success on the merits of the case.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed, claiming that they had adopted a new Hepatitis C treatment protocol in response to the new antiviral drugs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In June 2017, three mentally ill prisoners of the U.S. Penitentiary at Lewisburg (USP Lewisburg) filed this class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued USP Lewisburg and the Federal Bureau of Prisons, alleging that the defendants’ failure to provide adequate treatment for prisoners with mental illness constituted cruel and unusual punishment in violation of the Eighth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs eventually dismissed their claims.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 9, 2017, three prisoners at the United States Penitentiary at Lewisburg, Pennsylvania, filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania against the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) and the BOP's Director, Thomas R. Kane.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Eighth Amendment by failing to provide adequate mental health care to prisoners suffering from mental illness in the Special Management Unit (SMU) at USP Lewisburg.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs alleged that there was inadequate screening of the prisoners' mental illnesses in order to determine their suitability for confinement in an SMU facility.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that they were denied treatment for their long-standing mental illness, including manic episodes and PTSD from prior physical and mental abuse.[SENTMARKER]On October 2, 2017, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss, or in the alternative, a motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the defendants' motion for dismissal and denied the plaintiffs' request for discovery.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a declaratory and injunctive order to ensure that these prisoners receive constitutionally adequate mental healthcare.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: 47 inmates at the Beaumont Federal Correctional Institution in Midland, Texas filed a complaint against the United States under the Federal Tort Claims Act. Plaintiffs alleged that the conditions at Beaumont were unsanitary and inhumane, and that as a result of damage to the building caused by Hurricane Rita, they were subjected to confinement in a building unfit for inhabitants.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs also alleged they were entitled to damages for working conditions endured while working in a UNICOR factory manufacturing Kevlar helmets.[SENTMARKER]Defendant moved for dismissal or summary judgment in the alternate.[SENTMARKER]Several years later, but before the district court ruled, plaintiffs' counsel died, and the case was dismissed without prejudice for failure to prosecute.
pegasus_output_sents: In September 2005, inmates at the Federal Correctional Complex Medium in Beaumont, Texas filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Texas under the Federal Tort Claims Act (FTCA) alleging that the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) violated their Eighth Amendment rights by failing to provide them with adequate quarters, safekeeping, care and subsistence in the wake of Hurricane Rita.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were forced to work overtime in a building that contained hazardous vapors; housing them in a condemned building; making them drink contaminated water and take cold showers; and allowing them less than an hour for their personal needs.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that the BOP failed to certify that no part of their contract would be performed under working conditions which are unsanitary or hazardous or dangerous to the health and safety of inmates.[SENTMARKER]The court granted summary judgment on the negligence claim, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 21, 2012, a Native American prisoner incarcerated at the McConnell Unit of the Texas Department of Criminal Justice (TDCJ) filed this pro se federal civil rights lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]He sued multiple TDCJ employees under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]He alleged that TDJC policies that prevented his smoking a prayer pipe during Native American pipe ceremonies, limited his ability to wear a religiously significant medicine bag, and prevented him from growing long hair violated his rights under RLUIPA and the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]He sought declaratory, injunctive, and monetary relief as well as attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]An additional Native American prisoner plaintiff joined the suit shortly after filing.[SENTMARKER]In February 2013, the plaintiffs amended their complaint, consented to proceedings before a Magistrate Judge, and voluntarily dismissed all of their claims except their three RLUIPA challenges against the TDCJ Director in his official capacity and their First Amendment claim seeking damages against the Program Analyst in his individual capacity.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed cross motions for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]On February 27, 2014, the defendant’s motion for summary judgment was granted and a final judgment entered in their favor.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the Fifth Circuit and were successful in getting judgement on the RLUIPA grooming policy claim vacated and remanded.[SENTMARKER]On remand, the defendant’s motion for summary judgment on the RLUIPA grooming claim was denied.[SENTMARKER]As the RLUIPA grooming policy claim moved towards trial, the initial prisoner plaintiff in the case was released and his claims were dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The Court ordered the consolidation of cases Casey v. Davis (2:14-cv-13) and Cobb v. Morris (2:14-cv-22) with this case, as the two cases also were brought by Native American prisoner incarcerated at the McConnell Unit and involved RLUIPA grooming policy claims moving towards trial.[SENTMARKER]After a bench trial, Judge Ramos granted plaintiffs’ request for injunctive relief permitting them to grow their hair long, consistent with their Native American religious beliefs and entered a final judgment on February 26, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The defendant appealed, but moved to dismiss the appeal shortly after.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit granted the motion to dismiss the appeal on July 9, 2019.[SENTMARKER]This case is closed.

gold_sents: In November 1974, several individuals and groups filed a civil rights action against Chicago's mayor and police officials, claiming that they had engaged in unlawful intelligence gathering and electronic surveillance.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that the defendants had violated the plaintiffs' constitutional rights, and they sought both damages and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]After the case was consolidated with a number of related cases, in August 1981, the parties entered into a consent decree settlement.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree barred the City from political spying, harassment, and investigation of certain activities protected by the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]Despite the settlement, decades of litigation addressing enforcement of the decree followed.[SENTMARKER]In April 2011, the district court granted the City's motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The court's order permitted the plaintiffs to file a motion to reinstate the consent decree within 45 days if the City did not conduct an audit showing compliance with the terms of the agreement.[SENTMARKER]There was no further legal action taken by either party.

gold_sents: In May 2014, approximately 125 police officers from the Seattle Police Department (SPD) brought this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that SPD's new policy that limited the amount of force they could use on civilians was a violation of their constitutional right to self-defense.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the case in October 2017, holding that there was no constitutional right to self-defense.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit affirmed the holding.
pegasus_output_sents: In July 2012, a group of Seattle Police Department officers filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against the City of Seattle and the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) alleging that Seattle violated the Second Amendment right of police officers to use firearms for the core lawful purpose of self-defense.[SENTMARKER]On October 17, 2014, the district court granted the City's motion to dismiss, concluding that the new use of force policy did not burden the plaintiffs' right to use force.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice on October 20, 2014 and the parties entered into a consent decree and consent agreement in July 2012.[SENTMARKER]The decree included a plan for a court-appointed monitor to produce a Use of Force Policy that would apply to SPD officers’ use of approved department firearms while on duty.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed that the DOJ would continue to be involved in the implementation of, and training under, the new policy.[SENTMARKER]On January 1, 2014, the DOJ filed a similar suit in the same district court, alleging that SPD's previous use-of-force policy was "vague" and that it violated the right of officers to protect and defend the public and officers from apparent danger in violation of their right of self defense.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ sought injunctive relief and damages.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the DOJ's request for a preliminary injunction, and the case was closed.
