pegasus_output_sents: On June 11, 2020, Calvary Chapel Dayton Valley, a Christian church in Dayton, Nevada, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Nevada against Nevada Governor Steve Sisolak and the Nevada Department of Health in response to the 23 COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the church challenged the Governor's emergency orders prohibiting churches and other places of worship from holding in-person worship services of ten or more people, even when such services could be held in accordance with social distancing and public health guidelines (the "Church Gathering Ban").[SENTMARKER]The church alleged that the Church Gathering Ban violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments and the Church's free speech and assembly rights.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the church's request for a preliminary injunction, and the case is now closed.[SENTMARKER]On June 17, 2020, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the district court's denial of a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: On Mar.[SENTMARKER]16, 2017, the New York Times and one of its reporters sued DOJ under FOIA seeking records on DOJ's review of the legality of Trump's proposed Executive Orders and other matters related to anti-nepotism laws and the Emoluments Clause.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs dismissed the case after the government released documents in response to their request.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 28, 2017, The New York Times Company filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) against the Department of Justice's Office of Legal Counsel (OLC) seeking the release of documents related to the DOJ's investigation into the alleged misuse of public funds by the New York City Police Department (NYPD).[SENTMARKER]On February 27, 2017, plaintiffs filed a FOIA request to the OLC, seeking two categories of OLC records.[SENTMARKER]The OLC responded to plaintiffs' FOIA request, stating that the requested records were subject to the FOIA's discretionary release requirements.[SENTMARKER]On November 10, 2017, the parties agreed that the Government would make a first release and/or response to plaintiffs’ FOIA requests on November 10.[SENTMARKER]On December 15, 2017, and January 15, 2018, the parties will submit an additional status report to the Court on January 19, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The parties have also conferred further regarding a plan for moving forward.[SENTMARKER]On March 20, 2018, the court granted the parties' motion for partial summary judgment and granted the plaintiffs' request for a temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]The parties are continuing to discuss the litigation.

gold_sents: In 2017, the Knight First Amendment Institute at Columbia University sued President Donald Trump and other executive branch officials, alleging unconstitutional violations of the First Amendment right to free speech after the named individual plaintiffs were blocked from the Twitter account @realDonaldTrump for being critical of President Trump and/or his policies.[SENTMARKER]After the Second Circuit affirmed the district court's granting summary judgment to the plaintiffs, the U.S. Supreme Court vacated the opinion and directed the Second Circuit to dismiss the case as moot because there was a change in presidential administrations due to the 2020 election.

gold_sents: A group of Orthodox Jewish synagogues brought this lawsuit against the Governor of New York on October 8, 2020, alleging that the governor's restrictions on gatherings in light of surges in COVID-19 cases violated the Free Exercise Clause.[SENTMARKER]After the district court denied plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, they appealed to the Second Circuit and the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted the injunction in part to block the enforcement of the executive order's attendance caps pending the outcome of the appeal in the Second Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 8, 2020, the Orthodox Jewish group Agudath Israel of America and three synagogues in Brooklyn and Queens filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against New York Governor Andrew Cuomo.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Cuomo's Executive Order and the restrictions it contains will disrupt the religious observance of tens of thousands of Orthodox Jews in New York State, depriving them of their religious worship and holiday observance.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction enjoining Cuomo from enforcing EO 202.68 to restrict the gathering in Plaintiffs’ houses of worship effective on or about October 9, 2020, which is the date on which the first of three successive Jewish holidays begin.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction pending the district court's final judgment.[SENTMARKER]On November 3, 2020, the Second Circuit heard Plaintiffs' appeal of the District Court's decision.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit remanded the case for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 1964, a group of African American families filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the defendant Jefferson Parish School Board had violated their rights under the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by continuing to segregate the school system.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted injunctive relief, mandated desegregation of the school system, and required that the defendants use busing to speed up the integration process.[SENTMARKER]The injunction remained in place for several decades.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the School Board sought to implement a magnet school program in the hopes of boosting academics and increasing school diversity.[SENTMARKER]The parties jointly moved to supplement the desegregation plan to include the magnet school program, and the Court issued Consent Orders in 2008-2009 that enabled the School Board's plans.[SENTMARKER]However, issues arose in the following years with the School Board's implementation of the plan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that the defendants were using the Consent Orders as a pretext to conceal attempts to continue a system of racially segregated schools.[SENTMARKER]After the Consent Orders expired, the parties reached a settlement agreement and the Court declared Jefferson Parish Schools unitary in 2011.

Engelhardt, Jr. on June 30, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a motion to intervene, which was denied by Judge Engelhardt.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to settle the case with prejudice.

gold_sents: On Dec.[SENTMARKER]3, 1997, Barbara Grutter brought this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the University of Michigan Law School.[SENTMARKER]She claimed that, in denying her admission, the school discriminated against her on the basis of her race, and violated the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case made its way to the Supreme Court, which held that the law school's desire to obtain a "critical mass" of underrepresented minority students counted as a narrowly tailored use of race in its admissions process and was not unconstitutional.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 14, 2002, the University of Michigan Law School was sued in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan by two white students who alleged that the law school's admissions policy violated the Equal Protection Clause and Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by using race as a factor in its admissions decisions.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought compensatory and punitive damages, injunctive relief forbidding continuation of the alleged discriminatory admissions process, and admission to the Law School.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the motion, and the court of appeals affirmed the district court's decision in part and reversed in part.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Court of Appeals reversed the District Court's judgment and enjoined the University from continuing to discriminate on the basis of race.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court remanded the case for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On Oct. 14, 1997, two applicants who had been denied admission to the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor brought this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the university.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by public interest counsel, claimed that the university's admissions policy treated race as a predominant factor in granting admission, and that they, as white applicants, had been discriminated against in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case went to the Supreme Court, which held that the school's admission policy that automatically awarded 20 points out of a possible 150 to underrepresented minorities was not narrowly tailored to achieve the compelling interest of diversity in education and so violated the Equal Protection Clause.

Bollinger, upholding the admissions program used by the University and the petitioner in that case sought a writ of certiorari from this Court.[SENTMARKER]The case is remanded for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]In the meantime, the case is dismissed with prejudice and without further award of cos ts or attorneys' fees to any party.

gold_sents: On June 8, 2012, individual and organizational plaintiffs challenged Florida's voter purge procedures in U.S. District Court in Florida's Middle District, Tampa Division.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by the national and Florida ACLU, private counsel, and the Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law, claimed such procedures violated their rights under the Voting Rights Act, 42 U.S.C. §1973c.[SENTMARKER]This case was dismissed with prejudice on July 24, 2013 in accordance with the Supreme Court's decision in Shelby County v Holder.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 11, 2012, the State of Florida filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief under Section 5 of the National Voter Registration Act of 1993 ("NVRA"), seeking to prevent implementation of Chapter 2011-40, Laws of Florida in any of Florida's 67 counties, until preclearance has been obtained for the five counties subject to Section 5, as amended, under the IIRIRA.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the state's new database matching program that results in registered voters being removed from the voter rolls violates federal antidiscrimination and voter registration laws.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the holding in Shelby County warrants dismissal of this action with prejudice, but disagree on the form of the dismissal order.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed that suit for lack of standing, and the Ninth Circuit denied the plaintiffs' request for a temporary restraining order with regard to Arizona's proof of citizenship requirement.[SENTMARKER]On July 30, 2012, the district court denied the Secretary of Homeland Security's motion to dismiss the case with prejudice.

gold_sents: Two third-party nominees for the Georgia State House of Representatives filed this case alleging that, in light of public health risks associated with COVID-19, requiring them to collect over 20,000 signatures to get on the ballot violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]On July 9, the court ordered the defendants to reduce the relevant signature requirements by 30% for the 2020 general election.
pegasus_output_sents: In March 2020, two third-party candidates for U.S. Representative and the Georgia Green Party filed this lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the Northern District of Georgia against the Secretary of State for the State of Georgia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Georgia's ballot-access restrictions unconstitutionally burden their rights under the First and Fourteenth Amendments to the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The court granted summary judgment in favor of the Secretary based upon controlling Supreme Court and Eleventh Circuit precedent upholding the constitutionality of Georgia’s petition requirements.[SENTMARKER]The parties sought a preliminary injunction to reduce the relevant signature requirements by 30% for the 2020 general election.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the motion in part after determining, among other things, that the plaintiffs "have shown a substantial likelihood of success" on their claim.[SENTMARKER]As a remedy, the Court ordered the Secretary to: (1) reduce the number of signatures required to appear on the general-election ballot by 30%; .[SENTMARKER](2) reduce the amount of time required to submit a nomination petition by 50%; and (3) reduce the signature validation process by 50%.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: This is a class-action suit brought by a nonprofit organization and an individual against the state of Georgia to challenge the state’s requirement to purchase postage stamps for mail-in ballots.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief requiring election officials to provide prepaid returnable envelopes for absentee ballots and absentee ballot applications.[SENTMARKER]On April 30, the preliminary injunction was denied for the June primaries and on August 11, the plaintiffs’ motion for preliminary injunction was denied as to Count I of the amended complaint, and which was accordingly dismissed.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 8, 2020, the Black Voters Matter Fund (BVMF) and the Honest Elections Project (BVM) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia against the DeKalb County Board of Registration and the Secretary of State of Georgia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the state's requirement that voters submit their absentee ballot applications through the mail constitutes an unconstitutional poll tax and an undue burden on the fundamental right to vote, especially in light of the current health crisis caused by COVID-19 and the resulting increase in absentee voting.[SENTMARKER]On April 30, 2020, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunctive relief requiring the State to provide prepaid postage for absentee ballots in time for the June 9, 2020 primary election, in part because the State had already begun mailing ballots out to tens of thousands of voters.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the Plaintiffs’ Motion for Preliminary Injunction with respect to the election scheduled for June 9, 2020, but reserved ruling with regard to the relief requested for any August runoff and the November general election.[SENTMARKER]On May 8, 2020, BVM filed an amicus brief with the Fifth Circuit challenging the State's implementation of Texas' voter ID law, which was struck down by the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On April 22, four individuals facing a heightened risk of contracting COVID-19 and the Family Unit, a non-profit organization, filed an action against the enforcement of South Carolina’s witness requirement applied to absentee voters, and the excuse requirement applied in order to vote by an absentee ballot.[SENTMARKER]On May 12, the South Carolina General Assembly passed legislation allowing all qualified South Carolina voters to vote by absentee ballot for the June primaries.[SENTMARKER]On May 25, the court granted the plaintiffs’ preliminary injunction motions in part, pertaining to the witness requirement.[SENTMARKER]On September 18, the Witness Requirement was enjoined for the November 2020 General Election in a separate case, and the district court stayed the case.[SENTMARKER]The defendants sought reconsideration.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 1, 2020, the South Carolina Republican Party filed a motion in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina to intervene in a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of two provisions of the state's absentee voting laws.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, who were both African-American and candidates in the June 9, 2020 primary election, alleged that the laws violated Section 201 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction enjoining the defendants from enforcing South Carolina law that establishes categories of “persons qualified to vote by absentee ballot” (the excuse requirement) and requires a witness signature on the absentee ballot (the witness requirement).[SENTMARKER]On September 18, 2020, the court enjoined the witness requirement for all South Carolina voters in the upcoming November 2020 General Election.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the lower court to specifically examine the statute in its analysis.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to intervene on May 1, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2011 voters in Wisconsin filed this lawsuit in the US District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that their fundamental right to vote had been violated by Act 23, Wisconsin's law implementing a voter ID requirement.[SENTMARKER]After much litigation, in 2016 a judge granted a preliminary injunction allowing voters without IDs to sign an affidavit in place of the ID requirement for the 2016 presidential election.[SENTMARKER]The state appealed the injunction to the Seventh Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit stayed the injunction pending the appeal.[SENTMARKER]As of December 2019, the appeal remained pending in the Seventh Circuit.

gold_sents: On June 21, 2016, individuals who had been forced to pay a $50 "extension fee" for inability to pay their monetary penalties in full, or go to gail for non-payment of court fines and costs, brought a putative class action lawsuit in the District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued the Bogalusa City Court and the sole judge who sits on the Bogalusa City Court, under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 alleging that the defendants (1) systematically jail and threaten to jail individuals who cannot pay fines and court costs that fund the city court; and (2) have created an illegal extension fee to generate additional revenue.[SENTMARKER]Shortly after U.S. District Court Judge Ivan L.R.[SENTMARKER]Lemelle denied the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order, and held their request for a preliminary injunction in abeyance, the parties decided to explore settlement options.[SENTMARKER]They filed a stipulated agreement with the District Court, which was granted.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 21, 2016, the Southern Poverty Law Center filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana against Judge Robert J. Black and the Bogalusa City Court.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Fourteenth Amendment due process and equal protection provisions of the Constitution by systematically jailing the poor for failure to pay fines and court costs that fund the city court.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on June 27, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to dismiss the case against Judge Black for thirty (30) months, to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and expenses, and to provide the plaintiffs with a copy of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is contingent upon the agreement of the parties to retain jurisdiction to enforce the provisions of this agreement for a period of two hundred seventy (270) days.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff's attorneys filed an amended complaint on January 17, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The amended complaint seeks compensatory damages for payment of the extension fee, as well as injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On October 31st, 2016, a group of Plaintiffs who had been jailed for their inability to pay fines owed to the City of Florissant, Missouri for traffic tickets or other minor municipal offenses, sued the City for this violation of due process.[SENTMARKER]This case is still in the discovery stage and has been ongoing for four years.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 23, 2014, ArchCity Defenders filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri against the City of Florissant.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the City kept hundreds of people in its jail for non-payment of cash bond in each of the past five years.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs sought declaratory, injunctive, and compensatory relief.[SENTMARKER]The Court denied the parties' request for additional briefing and held a hearing on March 3, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On June 20, 1989, foster care children of the District of Columbia filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Human Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by Children's Rights and the ACLU, asked the court to order improved policies related to protective services, family preservation and preventive services, child placement, case reviews, adoptions, and staffing, among other issues, claiming violations of 42 U.S.C. § 1983, the Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980 (AACWA), the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act, the District of Columbia Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect Act of 1977, the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act, and the District of Columbia Youth Residential Facilities Licensor Act of 1986.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that caseloads were too large, leaving many children in the foster care system for far too long with unresolved cases.[SENTMARKER]Additionally, the complaint alleged inappropriate placements for children and inadequate efforts to return children home.[SENTMARKER]In 1993, Judge Thomas F. Hogan approved a consent decree directing DHS to develop policies and procedures to rectify the system.[SENTMARKER]After many years of oversight, and periodic contempt orders, the system has gradually improved.[SENTMARKER]However, there is still a monitor in place reporting on the progress of the Child and Family Services Agency (CFSA) created as a result of this case.
pegasus_output_sents: This is a class action lawsuit brought on behalf of abused and neglected children in the District of Columbia under the supervision of the Department of Human Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the District's foster care system violated the children's constitutional rights by failing to protect them from abuse and neglect.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a consent decree, which required the defendants to implement a number of corrective measures.[SENTMARKER]The parties worked out a settlement in which the District agreed to pay the plaintiffs and to create a Family Court for the District.[SENTMARKER]The District appealed the district court's decision to the Fifth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit denied the appeal, and the Supreme Court remanded the case for further review.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On 2017, foster parents and three states filed a suit challenging the constitutionality of the Indian Child Welfare Act (the "ICWA").[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs allege the ICWA violates the Equal Protection Clause and anti-commandeering principles.[SENTMARKER]The district court held the ICWA is unconstitutional which was partially affirmed in a fractured en banc opinion by the Fifth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In January 2018, a Native American couple filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas, alleging that the Texas Department of Family Protective Services (DFPS) violated the Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA) and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by denying them the ability to adopt an American Indian child (A.L.M.)[SENTMARKER]to the Navajo Nation.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that ICWA and the Final Rule violated the Tenth Amendment, the nondelegation doctrine, the anticommandeering doctrine, and the APA.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment in part, finding that the ICWA violated equal protection and the Tenth, and that it was unlawful under the APA, but the district court denied the defendants' motion for summary judgment on all of their claims.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, claiming that Plaintiffs lacked standing to bring each claim.[SENTMARKER]The District Court denied the motion, finding at least one Plaintiff had standing to challenge ICWA.[SENTMARKER]The parties moved to remand the case to the trial court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The Second Court of Appeals granted the parties’ motion on December 7, 2017, setting aside the trial judge’s prior judgment and remanding to the court.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: California recipients of Adult Day Health Care services brought this class action to enjoin California from reducing or eliminating the ADHC program, which would put the plaintiffs at risk of institutionalization.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California granted the plaintiff class a preliminary injunction in September 2009, forbidding California to modify it's adult Day Health Care program until an appropriate alternative could be provided to prevent institutionalization of individuals in the plaintiffs' class.[SENTMARKER]The District Court approved a settlement agreement that created a new program which will help to prevent the institutionalization of ADHC beneficiaries.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 18, 2009, a class action lawsuit was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the California Department of Health Care Services and its Director (Defendants) under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had violated the ADA by cutting the maximum number of days that Adult Day Health Care (ADHC) services could be provided.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment in favor of the State on the basis that the plaintiffs were requesting "new" services which were not required by the ADA and other laws.[SENTMARKER]The Tenth Circuit reversed and held that the cap on prescriptions 16 could violate the ADA's integration mandate.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction and enjoined the defendants from ending the ADHC program.[SENTMARKER]On January 25, 2012, the parties reached a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to provide services to replace ADHC services with the Community Based Adult Services (CBAS) program.[SENTMARKER]The CBAS program is a new law that eliminated ADHC as a Medi-Cal benefit.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Two individuals who use wheelchairs for mobility sued the City of Steamboat Springs, for having inaccessible public transportation and facilities.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree requiring the city to make its services and facilities accessible, pay attorneys' fees and costs, and pay $12,250 to the plaintiffs.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 1, 1999, two individuals with disabilities filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado alleging that the City of Steamboat Springs, Colorado violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (Rehabilitation Act) by failing to make its public transportation system readily accessible to and usable by persons who use wheelchairs.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged violations of Title II of the ADA and of Section 504 of Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the City agreed to modify, as needed to comply with the ADA, a men's and a women's restroom on the east side of the rodeo grounds, and to provide comprehensive training for all bus and van operators, dispatchers, and mechanics.[SENTMARKER]The decree was final and binding on the parties, including all principals, agents, employees of the City.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on December 12, 2000 without prejudice.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs were disabled individuals who sued the Colorado Rockies baseball club after it removed accessible seats in Coors Field and raised prices on others.[SENTMARKER]There was a trial held, after which the court dismissed all claims by stipulation.[SENTMARKER]It is unclear, however, whether the parties settled.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2002, a group of individuals with disabilities brought this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado against the Denver Metropolitan Major League Baseball Stadium District and HOK Sport, the architect of Coors Field, alleging that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to provide wheelchair-accessible seating in the lower level of the stadium.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs alleged that defendants failed to provide a choice of admission prices and lines of sight comparable to those for members of the general public.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved for partial summary judgment on a single issue, stating that the only seats in the back of the infield were clustered in front of those seats for non-disabled patrons to sit near those seating areas.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the defendants to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees, including litigation expenses, and costs.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: On April 29, four individuals with disabilities and Disability Rights New York filed a complaint against Andrew Cuomo, the Governor of New York State.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the absence of live televised American Sign Language (ASL) interpretation in Governor Cuomo’s daily televised briefings on COVID-19 discriminated against populations with disabilities residing in New York by failing to provide a live ASL interpreter.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, declaring the lack of ASL interpretation as a violation under the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also sought a TRO and preliminary injunction requiring the defendant to immediately include live in-frame ASL interpretation for all briefings addressed to New York residents.[SENTMARKER]The preliminary injunction was granted on May 11, and the defendant was ordered to immediately implement live, in-frame ASL interpretation for his daily press briefings.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 3, 2020, Disability Advocates New York (DRNY) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against New York County and Governor Andrew Cuomo.[SENTMARKER]DRNY alleged that the county violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (RA) by failing to provide an in-frame American Sign Language (ASL) interpreter during his daily press briefings regarding the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that there was no ASL interpreter at some of the meetings, and at other meetings the ASL interpretation was "imperfect" because the interpreter spent time interpreting individual discussions instead of interpreting the large-group discussion.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted DRNY's motion for a preliminary injunction on May 11, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The Eighth Circuit affirmed the district court's grant of summary judgment for the county, holding in relevant part that the ADA and RA did not require the county to provide the county with an ASL interpreter at every meeting because based on the interpretation services that were provided the county "effectively communicated" the relevant information to the plaintiffs at the large group meetings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On April 8, 2014, the Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Rhode Island alleging that Rhode Island violated the ADA by segregating individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities in sheltered workshops and facility-based day programs that denied them the opportunity to associate with those who did not have a disability.[SENTMARKER]On April 9, 2014, the District Court approved a Consent Decree where Rhode Island agreed to, among other things, provide employment planning services to individuals with developmental and intellectual disabilities designed to encourage and assist them in working in integrated working environments, provide state support and services for those working in integrated settings and those making the transition to those settings, programs to educate relevant individuals about the programs and benefits that the Rhode Island offers to those working in integrated settings.[SENTMARKER]Rhode Island must also implement policies regarding the services required by the Consent Decree, train its personnel in the new procedures and working with individuals with disabilities, and Rhode Island must help sheltered workshops change their structure to become integrated working environments.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 11, 2013, the Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Rhode Island against the Rhode Island Department of Education (RIDE) and the Providence Public Schools Department (PPSD) under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Olmstead v. L.C.[SENTMARKER]on behalf of individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities (IDD) who received services from a sheltered workshop and a special education program.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the two programs violated Title II of the ADA by unnecessarily segregating individuals in two particular facility-based employment and day settings and placing those individuals at risk of such segregation.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into an Interim Settlement Agreement (ISA) on July 11, 2013 that provided relief to approximately 200 individuals with IDD who received sheltered workshop services from RIDE and the Harold A. Birch Vocational Program (Birch) at Mount Pleasant High School in Providence.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the State to implement a major initiative designed to change the nature and operation of day and employment services furnished to individuals with IIDD who receive publicly financed supports.[SENTMARKER]On September 24, 2014, the State approved the RIDE's Employment First Policy.[SENTMARKER]On July 26, 2016, the State issued a Consent Decree Update.[SENTMARKER]The report detailed the State's compliance with the terms and conditions of the consent decree, including the implementation of a program to provide transportation for those working more than one job.[SENTMARKER]The State also required the City of Providence to provide training to LEAs in three components: Family Employment Awareness Training (FEAT), self-determination, and discovery/employment.[SENTMARKER]The District Court issued a final judgment in favor of the City on July 30, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on September 30, 2016.

gold_sents: In this case, a third-grader plaintiff who had autism and ADHD filed suit against the Kanawha County Schools system under the IDEA, the Rehabilitation Act, Title II of the ADA, the West Virginia Human Rights Act, and West Virginia Policy 2419.[SENTMARKER]The elementary school student had been subject to disciplinary removal from the classroom and his district had failed to provide the behavioral supports and programming required by law.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 22, 2014, two students with disabilities brought this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of West Virginia against the Board of Education of the County of Kanawha (the "BOE"), alleging that the BOE violated the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to provide effective behavior supports for a class of children with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that the defendants violated the ADA and Section 504 of the West Virginia Human Rights Act (W.V.[SENTMARKER]HRA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief, monetary relief, and other relief.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed by the court on October 2, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: In October 2016, a group of Flint schoolchildren (via their parents) sued the state of Michigan and the school district in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan, alleging that the state of Michigan and local educators are in violation of federal law by not screening to identify students who need special education services and violating the rights of students with disabilities in the imposition of school discipline.[SENTMARKER]In April 2018, the parties reached a partial settlement as to one of the plaintiffs' claims, but the rest are still in dispute.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 1, 2017, a group of parents of children with disabilities brought this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against the Michigan Department of Education (MDE), the Genesee Intermediate School District (GISD), and Flint Community Schools (FCS) alleging violations of the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), and Michigan state law.[SENTMARKER]The parents alleged that the defendants failed to provide their children with adequate special education and related services in light of the elevated levels of lead in the drinking water in Flint, Michigan.[SENTMARKER]On September 29, 2017, the district court entered an order denying the defendants' motion to dismiss for failure to exhaust administrative remedies under the IDEA.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement, which was entered into by and between the parties, and the case is currently pending before the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The court has jurisdiction over final decisions of the district courts.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: On November 17, 2014, Students for Fair Admissions, Inc. filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina under The Civil Rights Act of 1964, against the University of North Carolina.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief to prohibit the consideration of race in college admissions, claiming that UNC's current admissions policy discriminated against Asian American applicants.[SENTMARKER]The court denied summary judgement and, as of April 9th, 2020, the suit is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 17, 2014, Students for Fair Admissions, Inc. (SFFA) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina.[SENTMARKER]SFFA alleged that UNC-Chapel Hill's use of race in its undergraduate admissions process violated the Fourteenth Amendment and Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]SFFA sought declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The case was stayed until August 1, 2016, pending the outcome of a Supreme Court decision in Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court held that the University's admissions policy does not merely use race as a "plus" factor in admissions decisions, but that it does not discriminate on the basis of the applicant's race, color, or ethnicity.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a Voluntary Dismissal as to all claims in the case pending the Supreme Court's decision.[SENTMARKER]On July 20, 2015, the parties filed a motion to intervene in defense of the University’s admissions policies.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the motion, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement provided for the University to pay SFFA a one-time assessment of $10 as membership dues.[SENTMARKER]The University has since amended its bylaws to establish a dues policy whereby, as of July 30, 2015, members are required "to pay a one time assessment of $10."[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Former students and an employee of Rhinebeck Central High School filed suit against the School District and the former principal alleging that the District had violated Title IX of the Education Amendment and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by failing to rectify allegations that the principal had sexually harassed the female students.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a Consent Decree in which the District agreed to implement anti-discrimination procedures.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 9, 2003, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York filed this suit against the Rhinebeck Central School District under Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the District and Thomas Mawhinney, then the Principal of the High School, were in violation of Title IX by creating a hostile educational environment for female students.[SENTMARKER]The private plaintiffs amended their complaint to include a claim against the District under the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]On August 29, 2003, the District entered into a consent decree with the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the District to revise its written policy prohibiting harassment and discrimination on the basis of sex and provide concrete examples of sexual harassment.[SENTMARKER]The District also agreed to implement a training program for its employees on how to respond to complaints of harassment or discrimination, including how to tile a formal complaint, what steps the District will take to investigate complaints and discipline those found to have engaged in prohibited conduct, and how to inform students and their parents of the District's policies.[SENTMARKER]The district also agreed not to retaliate against any student who reports an incident of discrimination or harassment in the administration or provision of educational services, programs, opportunities or benefits.[SENTMARKER]The decree was effective immediately upon its entry by the Court and remained in effect for three (3) years from the date of entry or ninety (90) calendar days after the last report under Section VII of the Constitution.

gold_sents: A 16-year old transgender male student sued Kenosha Unified School District No. 1 (Kenosha) in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin on July 19, 2016, arguing that the school violated the Equal Protection Clause and Title IX by denying Plaintiff access to the boys’ restrooms.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiff a preliminary injunction to use the boys' restroom throughout his senior year, which the Seventh Circuit upheld on May 30, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled on January 22, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The settlement required Defendant to pay Plaintiff $800,000, enjoined Defendant from prohibiting Plaintiff from using the boys’ restroom, and required the Defendant to notify all staff about the injunction.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 15, 2016, a transgender student at Tremper High School, a public high school in the Kenosha Unified School District (KUSD), filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin against the KUSD.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the school had violated Title IX by denying him full and equal access to student restrooms and overnight accommodations during school-sponsored trips offered to other male students because of his gender identity.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiff's motion for a declaratory judgment on December 27, 2017.[SENTMARKER]On January 22, 2018, the parties filed a joint motion asking the court to approve and enter a consent judgment in which the parties agreed to pay the plaintiff $800,000 in compensatory damages and reasonable attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed that the consent judgment would remain binding on the defendants for a period of 10 years from the date of filing or until modified by the court on motion with proper cause under Federal Civil Procedure 60 G.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On August 11, 2005 a group of African-Americans filed a consolidated amended complaint Wal-Mart Stores Inc. in United States District Court of the Eastern District of Arkansas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Wal-Mart discriminated against African-Americans in hiring of over-the-road truck drivers.[SENTMARKER]On May 16, 2007, the court certified a class of African Americans who had not been hired or had been deterred from applying for these jobs.[SENTMARKER]Discovery continued in preparation for trial and on January 13, 2009 the court denied the defendant's motions for decertification and summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The parties thereafter reached a settlement that was approved by the court on March 5, 2009.[SENTMARKER]In the settlement Wal-Mart agreed to damages in the amount of $17,500,000 to be distributed to the named representatives, class members, and their attorneys.[SENTMARKER]It also agreed to provide EEO training, actively recruit minorities, impose benchmarks for hiring minority drivers, make specific job opportunities open to minorities, and engage in recordkeeping and reporting.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 16, 2005, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas on behalf of African American over-the-road truck drivers.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. and its transportation division discriminated against African Americans when hiring OTR truck drivers by having its current drivers pass out cards with a 1-800 number to call for an application.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the defendants knew that its body of current drivers was predominantly white and that the practice of having current drivers distribute the 1-800 card was therefore discriminatory.[SENTMARKER]On September 24, 2004, the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the agreement, the parties agreed to pay $17,500,000 to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to provide training regarding equal employment opportunities and specific compliance with the provisions of Title VII.[SENTMARKER]After May 2007, the parties conducted discovery on the merits of the class claims and the parties reached an agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This case was brought by female employees of Citigroup Global Markets against Citigroup Global Markets and its subsidiary, Smith Barney, seeking injunctive and declaratory relief and damages for the company's discriminatory practices against female employees.[SENTMARKER]This case was solved by a class-action settlement on August 13, 2008, resulting in relief granted.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 31, 2005, a female employee of Citigroup Global Markets, Inc., d/b/a Smith Barney, filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that Smith Barney discriminated against her on the basis of gender with respect to business opportunities, compensation, professional support and other terms and conditions of employment in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the California Fair Employment and Housing Act, Cal. Gov't.[SENTMARKER]Code  12940 et seq., and the Equal Employment Opportunity Act of 1992.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff claimed that she was constructively discharged from her employment with Smith Barney after she complained about unfair, discriminatory treatment to the highest levels of 8 the company, including to the Director of Human Resources of Smith Barney.[SENTMARKER]Instead, Smith Barney disclosed the fact that she 12 had complained to her male coworkers and retaliated against her for making such complaints.[SENTMARKER]The Defendant entered into a settlement agreement to resolve the case.[SENTMARKER]The Settlement Agreement required Smith Barney to establish a Settlement Fund and to implement changes to its policies and practices.[SENTMARKER]It also required the Defendant to provide its Human Resources staff with appropriate training regarding compliance with state, federal, and local EEO laws; Smith Barney’s anti-discrimination and harassment policies; and the best practices for complaint investigation and resolution.[SENTMARKER]Smith Barney also agreed to maintain its commitment to its female broker networking 26 meetings.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the Defendant agreed to pay the cost of such binding mediation.

gold_sents: On September 25, 2006, the Denver Field Office and the Phoenix District Office of the EEOC filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sued Moreland Auto Group, LLP under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]Two former female employees sought injunctive relief to enjoin the defendant from discriminating against employees based on gender or from retaliating against employees who complain about discrimination.[SENTMARKER]On August 22, 2008 Judge Edward J. Nottingham approved a settlement agreement that included a $70,000 fund to be dispersed amongst the claimants, and an injunction enjoining the defendants from gender-based discrimination.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 22, 2008, the Denver District Office of the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado against Moreland Auto Group, LLP d/b/a Kids Automotive, Inc., Kids Financial, Inc, and Brandon Financial Inc. alleging discrimination on the basis of gender in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the EEOC alleged that the defendants engaged in a pattern or practice of sexual harassment and retaliation in the workplace.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that, more than 30 days prior to the institution of this lawsuit, two female employees of the defendants filed charges of discrimination with the EEOC alleging that they were subjected to sexual harassment, a hostile work environment, and retaliating against them for complaining about the harassment.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to pay $70,000 to the EEOC, provide annual training to its officers, managers and employees regarding discrimination and retaliation, and to pay its own costs and attorneys fees.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was entered into by Judge Edward W. Nottingham on August 22, 2008 and is subject to final approval by the court.

gold_sents: This case was brought by ten black current and former special agents of the United States Secret Service against the Secretary of the U.S. Department of Treasury and the Secretary of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought equitable relief including back pay, front pay, compensatory damages, a declaratory judgment, and an injunction, alleging that the Secret Service discriminated against them on the basis of race in promotions as well as in transfers, assignments, testing, hiring, and disciplinary practices.[SENTMARKER]The court approved a settlement agreement that awarded $24 million in damages, $8 million in attorney's fees, and $860,000 in costs.[SENTMARKER]The agreement will remain in place until 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 3, 2000, ten (10) African-American Special Agents of the U.S. Secret Service filed this employment discrimination action against the Secret Service under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were discriminated against on the basis of race in the hiring, promotion, transfers, and assignments, performance, bonuses and awards, discipline, retaliation, and the creation of a hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled the case in 1996 and the parties are now disputing the implementation of the settlement.[SENTMARKER]On August 1, 2015, the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia denied review of the district court’s certification order, in In re Johnson, 760 F.3d 66 (D.C Cir.[SENTMARKER]The parties are continuing their litigation in the District Court of Columbia.

gold_sents: This case was brought by eight Hispanic Special Agents against the U.S. Department of Treasury's United States Customs Service.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought equitable relief, compensatory damages, a declaratory judgment, and injunctive relief, alleging there was a pattern and practice of discrimination on the basis of national origin by the U.S. Customs Service.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted Defendant's Motion for Summary Judgment on March 20, 2007, thereby terminating the case.
pegasus_output_sents: The EEOC filed this class action complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) alleging discrimination on the basis of national origin in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the DHS discriminated against Hispanic Special Agents by administering an exam known as the Special Agent OS-14 (SA-14) test, which constituted further retaliation against the complainant for actively prosecuting the case in the EEOC's administrative process.[SENTMARKER]The parties ultimately settled the case, and this Court approved that settlement in 1996; the parties are now before the Court to implement the settlement.

gold_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed suit against Yellow Transportation, Inc., and YRC, Inc., for discriminatory employment practices on behalf of 14 current or former black employees and the class of similarly situated black employees.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that Yellow Transportation (later merged into YRC) had violated §703(a) of Title VII, 42 U.S.C. § 2000e-2(a) by subjecting black employees to greater scrutiny, more frequent and greater discipline, lower paying and less favorable job assignments, more difficult and time-consuming work, and a hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought injunctive and monetary relief, including economic and noneconomic harm to the employees, punitive damages, development of policies and programs to provide equal employment opportunity and eradicate the effects of its past discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC also sought to recover its costs.[SENTMARKER]The charging parties later intervened as plaintiffs on their own behalf, adding claims for retaliation.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement, which was entered as a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The decree resolved this case and the related case Brown v. Yellow Transportation, Inc. , linked below (Clearinghouse code: EE-IL-0329).[SENTMARKER]The decree awarded a total of $11 million ($1.1 million in attorney's fees) and no significant injunctive relief because of a consent decree in other litigation.[SENTMARKER]The case is technically open but effectively closed.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against Yellow Transportation, Inc. and YRC Freight (collectively "YRC" or the "Defendant"), under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 ("Title VII").[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that African-American employees at the Chicago Ridge facility were subjected to harassment and different terms and conditions of employment because of their race.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the defendants created a racially hostile work environment by tolerating the repeated hanging of nooses in conspicuous places at the facility, failing to investigate, and failing to take disciplinary action against those individuals who hung the nooses.[SENTMARKER]The case was consolidated for purposes of entering a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree provides monetary relief to eligible employees and prohibits the defendants from discriminating on the basis of race.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the consent decree requires the defendants to implement anti-harassment and anti-discrimination policies and procedures.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs sued Sprint, alleging ADEA violations pursuant to 29 U.S.C. § 621, the ADA, and 42 U.S.C. §12203.[SENTMARKER]Class comprised just under 1,700 members.[SENTMARKER]Eventually, parties reached $57 million settlement agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 23, 2003, the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Kansas against Sprint/United Management Company (Sprint) alleging age discrimination in violation of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA) in connection with the company's reduction-in-force (RIF) policy.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Sprint discriminated against plaintiffs and opt-ins on the basis of their age by treating younger employees more favorably than older employees in implementing the RIF.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the complaint for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement, which provided $57 million in monetary relief to a class of approximately 1,697 former employees of Sprint.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On April 26, 2004, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, on behalf of a black female applicant, filed a lawsuit in the District Court of Maryland, under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991, against Advancemed Corporation.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the defendant refused to hire the complainant because of her race.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree where the defendant, among other things, agreed to pay the complainant $22, 000.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 27, 2004, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against Advancemed Corporation, a Maryland-based health care company.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that Advancemed violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by refusing to hire a black female for the position of Head Nurse, in favor of a less qualified non-black applicant, because of her race.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which Advancemed agreed to pay a total of $22,000 to the EEOC, provide two hours equal employment opportunity training to all personnel involved in the screening, selection, and hire of employees at its Bethesda, Maryland facility, and pay the EEOC's costs and attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered by Judge Peter J.
