gold_sents: This is a race discrimination class action brought by black police officers in Baltimore, alleging discriminatory discipline and hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]It was filed in December 2004, and settled in June 2009 for $2.5 million in damages to the 15 named plaintiffs and injunctive relief for the class.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 4, 2005, the Baltimore City Police Department (BCPD) and the City of Baltimore filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the BPD engaged in a pattern and practice of disparate discipline with respect to African-American police officers in connection with the administration of the disciplinary system for Baltimore police officers.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged discrimination on the basis of race and color in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 ("Title VII") and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution ("E.P.C.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief, monetary relief, and injunctive and declaratory relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement, which was approved by the court on February 5, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the settlement agreement were as follows: (i) The parties agreed to pay the plaintiffs a total of $155,000; .[SENTMARKER](ii) The settlement agreement was subject to court approval; and (iii) the parties agreed not to use any of the money for any purpose other than to fund and hold leadership training classes during the five-year period following the effective date of the agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to further court approval.

gold_sents: In 2005, the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against the City of Pontiac and the local firefighters' union.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ alleged that the collective bargaining agreements entered by the Pontiac Fire Department and the local firefighters' union discriminated on the basis of sex and race by explicitly creating and maintaining a dual system for hire and promotion requiring that one out of every thee hires or promotions be given to a minority.[SENTMARKER]In 2006, the DOJ and the City of Pontiac reached a settlement that required the City of Pontiac to not engage in any act or practice that discriminated on the basis of race or sex in violation of Title VII in relation to hiring or promotion in the Pontiac Fire Department and to provide remedial relief to those employees and applicants denied hire or promotion as a result of the dual system for hire and promotion.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in October 2008.
pegasus_output_sents: The U.S. Department of Justice and the City of Pontiac, Michigan entered into a consent decree in July 2005 to settle a lawsuit brought by the United States under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 ("Title VII").[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered by Judge George Caram Steeh on August 16, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the City would not enforce a dual hiring or promotional system based on race or sex and would not unlawfully discriminate on the basis of sex in connection with hiring or promotions.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the City agreed to provide a total of 12,200 in monetary relief to two white males who were not hired by the Pontiac Fire Department.

gold_sents: On August 29, 2002, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed suit in the Albuquerque U.S. District Court for the District of New Mexico against Bell Gas, Inc. and related corporations on behalf of a female employee.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the companies had violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 U.S.C. § 2000e et.[SENTMARKER]seq.) by subjecting the employee to a sexually hostile work environment created by verbal and physical harassment from her immediate supervisor, including sexual assault.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Consent Decree, which provided the employee received a total of $180,000; $60,000 up front and monthly payments of $2,000 for 60 months-and subjected Defendants to an array of injunctive provisions.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: The Phoenix District Office of the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Mexico against Bell Gas, Inc., a New Mexico-based gas company.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII by subjecting a female employee to verbal and physical sexual harassment because of her sex, including a sexual assault, which created a hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also retaliated against the employee for complaining about the sexual harassment.[SENTMARKER]The case was stayed until August 18, 2003.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent decree in which the defendant agreed to pay the employee $180,000 and provide training on sex discrimination and harassment to each new employee hired for the duration of this decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is in effect for a five-year period and is secured by a mortgage lien on the defendant's real property.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed not to discriminate or retaliate against each other in the future.

gold_sents: In 2006, the EEOC sued Consolidated Reports in the U.S. District Court for the District of Nevada alleging violations of Title VII's prohibition on sex discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged and employee of the defendant sexually harassed the charging party and created a hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]In 2008, the case settled when the parties agreed to a 1 year consent decree requiring the defendant to pay $55,000 to the charging party, to adopt anti-discrimination policies, provide training to employees, and comply with other requirements.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 7, 2006, the Nevada District Office of the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the 13 District of Nevada against Defendant 24 Consolidated Resorts, Inc. ("Defendant") alleging that Defendant engaged in unlawful employment practices in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 ("Title VII").[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Defendant forced, on four occasions, to perform oral sex on one of its supervisors, under the threat of losing 5 her job.[SENTMARKER]Defendant also allegedly subjected the female employee to unwanted touching of her breasts and private body area, exposed his genitals to her, and made sexually offensive statements to her.[SENTMARKER]In its second suit, the EEOC alleged that defendant terminated a female employee because of her gender.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Consent Decree, which requires Defendant to implement and monitor its compliance with Title VII and the provisions of this Decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also requires the defendant to provide annual training to its managerial employees regarding employee rights and responsibilities under Title VII; provide periodic reports to the EEOC regarding its policies and procedures; and provide an Equal Employment Opportunity Consultant ("Consultant"), to implement its policies, procedures, and policies.[SENTMARKER]The decree also provides monetary relief to the female employees who were adversely affected by the defendant's practices.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: On July 12, 2005, three U.S. farm works from Yakima Valley who were illegally denied or terminated from agricultural employment brought this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Washington against Global Horizons, Green Acre Farms, and Valley Fruit Orchards under the Migrants and Seasonal Agricultural Worker Protection Act, 29 U.S.C. §§ 1801, the Farm Labor Contractors Act, 42 U.S.C § 1981 and the Washington Law Against Discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to go to trial, and after years of litigation the plaintiffs received a judgment in their favor under FLCA, as well as attorneys fees, for both trial and appellate legal work.[SENTMARKER]In January 2014, the Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for incentive payments.[SENTMARKER]There has been no further movement in the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 27, 2001, the Washington Department of Labor filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York against Global Horizons, Inc., Green Acre Farms, LLC, and Valley Fruit Orchards, LLC.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Global violated the Farm Labor Contractors Act, Section 1981, and 23 of the Washington Law Against Discrimination by failing to disclose two production standards for pruning, thinning, harvesting, and other activities in the written statement of the terms and conditions of employment and discharged workers from employment based on national origin and race.[SENTMARKER]On May 25, 2007, the court entered a judgment of 9 $819,686 in the 10 District Court of Maryland in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the plaintiffs' request for injunctive relief and denied their request for punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On December 3, 2013, a non-profit organization filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado under the First Amendment, Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) and the Administrative Procedure Act against the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, represented by the Alliance Defending Freedom, asked the court to rule that the Affordable Care Act's (ACA) contraception insurance mandate, even with the accommodation for non-profit religious organizations, is unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On March 11, 2014, the plaintiff filed a motion for preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]Following the Supreme Court's decision in Hobby Lobby, the plaintiff stipulated to dismissal of the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 13, 2013, the U.S.[SENTMARKER]Conference of Catholic Bishops, at the conclusion of their fall General Assembly in Baltimore, Maryland, issued a "Special Message" regarding the Affordable Care Act (ACA) and its contraceptive coverage requirements.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed this suit in the United States District Court for the District of Colorado, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief as a result of Defendants' implementation of the "preventive care and screenings" provisions in the ACA.[SENTMARKER]In promulgating the mandate, Defendants failed to consider the constitutional and statutory implications of the mandate on FOCUS and similar organizations.[SENTMARKER]On April 29, 2014, the District Court granted a preliminary injunction against Defendants' HHS Contraceptive Mandate.[SENTMARKER]The Court found that the mandate violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) and the First and Fifth Amendments to the US Constitution, and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA).[SENTMARKER]The Court also found that Defendants' requirement that FOCUS provide insurance coverage that includes education and counseling regarding objectionable contraceptives and abortifacients forces FOCUS to speak in a manner contrary to its religious beliefs.[SENTMARKER]On June 11, 2015, the Court entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, finding that the defendants had not violated the RFRA and the APA.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment also enjoined the defendants from enforcing the mandate.

gold_sents: On September 5, 2013, the voting stockholders of a Michigan for-profit corporation filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia asking the court to issue a preliminary and permanent injunction prohibiting enforcement of provisions of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) extending universal contraception coverage to employer-sponsored private health insurance coverage.[SENTMARKER]In light of the ruling in Burwell v. Hobby Lobby the Court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs on October 24, 2014 permanently enjoining the defendants from enforcing compliance with the contraception coverage under the ACA.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 23, 2014, a private company, Midwest Fastener Corp., filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the United States Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and the Department of Justice (D.C.) alleging violations of the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA), the First and Fifth Amendments, and the Affordable Care Act (ACA).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the RFRA by refusing to provide health insurance coverage for abortion-inducing drugs, sterilization procedures, and patient education and counseling for all women with reproductive capacity to which plaintiffs object on religious grounds.[SENTMARKER]In light of a recent Supreme Court ruling in Burwell v. Hobby Lobby Stores, the plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment, and granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This is a case about President Trump's executive order that prohibits racial sensitivity training in federal agencies, contractors, and grant recipients.[SENTMARKER]On October 29, 2020, the National Urban League and National Fair Housing Alliance filed this lawsuit in the District Court for the District of Columbia against the President, the Secretary of Labor, and the Department of Labor, seeking an injunction, declaratory relief, and attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]They claimed that the executive order violated freedom of speech under the First Amendment by denying benefits to private entities that express ideas the Trump Administration doesn't like.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also argued that the executive order violated the Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause because the order was too vague and created with an intent to discriminate on the basis of race, national origin, sex, and/or gender.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 22, 2020, the National Urban League (NUL), the National Fair Housing Alliance (NFFH), and over 200 private, nonprofit fair housing organizations filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against President Donald J. Trump, the Department of Labor, and the White House.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the First Amendment rights of NUL, NFFH, and other members of the Class by prohibiting them from discussing and promoting concepts like, among other things, systemic race and sex discrimination and implicit racial and sex biases in their workplaces.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed to settle the case without further litigation.

gold_sents: On April 22, 2010, homecare providers who did not wish to support the designated labor union filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois seeking an injunction against enforcement of the agency-fee provision of the Illinois Public Labor Relations Act (PLRA) and a declaration that the law violated the personal assistants' fundamental rights.[SENTMARKER]On June 30, 2014, the Supreme Court held that the clearest case on point, Abood v. Detroit Bd.[SENTMARKER]431 U. S.[SENTMARKER]209 (1977), did not apply because the public employees at issue there were distinct from the care providers here.[SENTMARKER]Accordingly, the Court stated the agency-fee provision must serve a compelling state interest that cannot be achieved through means significantly less restrictive of associational freedoms.[SENTMARKER]The Court found insufficient the interests contended by Defendants and held the Illinois PLRA unconstitutional.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2010, a group of home care providers filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, alleging that the Illinois Department of Human Services (DHHS) violated the First Amendment by requiring them to pay union dues and initiation fees to the Service Employees International Union (SEIU) to represent them in collective bargaining negotiations.[SENTMARKER]The DHHS and the union entered into collective bargaining agreements that required the personal assistants to pay a fair share of the union's dues, create a health benefits fund for personal assistants, and establish a joint union-state committee to develop training programs.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the plaintiffs' claims for lack of subject matter jurisdiction because they lacked standing and their claims were not ripe.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the district court with instructions to dismiss the claims of the Disabilities Program plaintiffs without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit affirmed in part, concluding that the case was controlled by this court's decision in Abood v. Detroit Bd.[SENTMARKER]The First Amendment prohibits the collection of an agency fee from personal assistants in the Rehabilitation Program who do not want to join or support the union.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals held that the DHHS's collective bargaining agreement with the SEIU was fair-share provisions, and that the Disability Program plaintiffs had no standing to sue the union because they were not union members.

gold_sents: On May 8, 2018, several Texas organizations filed this lawsuit against the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that HUD suspended a provision of the Fair Housing Act that would require cities to report incidents of housing discrimination and that that this suspension violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA).[SENTMARKER]The defendants' motion to dismiss was granted, and the plaintiffs filed to reopen the case and amend their complaint.[SENTMARKER]This motion was denied on August 26, 2019.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 2, 2018, three non-profit organizations, National Fair Housing Alliance (N.H.A.[SENTMARKER]), Texas Low Income Housing Information Service (Texas Housers), and Texas Appleseed, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that HUD's suspension of the AFFH Rule's requirements as a violation of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) violated the Fair Housing Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief, including a ruling that HUD rescind the January 2018 Notice and take all necessary steps to implement and enforce the AF FH Rule, and attorneys' fees and costs and all other appropriate relief.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the case for lack of subject matter jurisdiction because no plaintiff had standing.[SENTMARKER]On May 29, 2018, the court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment and denied the plaintiffs' request for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: A group of recovering alcoholics and drug addicts filed a lawsuit under the Fair Housing Act, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the City of Boca Raton.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that an ordinance enacted by the city unlawfully prohibited drug and alcohol recovery facilites from operating within residentially zoned areas.[SENTMARKER]The court entered judgment in favor of the plaintiffs as to their Fair Housing Act claims.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were awarded nominal damages and the city was enjoined from enforcing section 2 of Ordinance 4649 and Section 28-2 as applied to recovering individuals.[SENTMARKER]This case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: In March 2003, a group of disabled residents of Boca Raton, Florida filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Boca Raton's zoning ordinance violated the Fair Housing Amendments Act ( FHA), the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), and the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that Boca House and Awakenings, a condominium complex catering to disabled individuals who are part of the residential community, violated the FHA and ADA by failing to provide a reasonable accommodation from the City's purported limitation on four or more unrelated persons living together in a single dwelling unit.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs also alleged that the City violated the ADA by refusing to grant them reasonable accommodations to the city's alleged limitation on persons who are recovering from drug or alcohol addiction and any other persons with a disability who want to live in a supportive drug condominium and alcohol-free environment.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, finding that the plaintiffs lacked standing to bring certain of their claims where they are not disabled or handicapped and that the city failed to grant a requested reasonable accommodation to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the case, with the plaintiffs agreeing to pay the defendants reasonable attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On April 16, 2006, two Hispanic condominium owners filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida against Sunrise Lakes Condominium Apts., Phase 3, Inc., a Florida corporation which serves as the condominium association for the 36 unit condominium complex located in Coral Springs, Broward County, Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendant violated the Fair Housing Act of 1968 by refusing to approve their purchase of a home on the basis of national origin.[SENTMARKER]The parties sought declaratory and injunctive relief, monetary damages, and attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]On October 19, 2007, the court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On June 24, 2010, the United States filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Minnesota, under the Fair Housing Act, against owners and operators of an apartment complex located in Red Wing Minnesota alleging discrimination on the basis of race and sex against an African-American male.[SENTMARKER]On July 29, 2011, Judge Frank approved a two year Consent Decree agreed to by the parties enjoining defendants from continuing to engage in discriminatory practices and ordering defendants to pay $15,000 in damages to the complainant.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 24, 2010, the U.S. District Court for the District of Minnesota entered a consent decree in the Fair Housing Act case of Loki Properties LLC and its owner, Robert Ryan.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree, which was entered on July 28, 2011, requires the parties to: (i) comply with the terms of Title VIII of the Civil Rights Act of 1968, as amended; .[SENTMARKER](ii) educate their employees and agents on the race and sex-related provisions of federal, state, and local fair housing laws, regulations, and ordinances; .[SENTMARKER](iii) provide housing assistance to low-income individuals and families; and (iv) promote the use of the fair housing logo on all billboards, signs, pamphlets, radio, television, Internet, and other promotional literature.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the consent decree are effective immediately upon the entry of this consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: In March 2011, the National Fair Housing Alliance and Paralyzed Veterans of America filed this federal suit the Western District of Virginia under the Fair Housing Act, alleging that real estate development company HHHunt Corporation and affiliated entities discriminated against people with disabilities by designing and building apartment complexes without the required accessible and adaptable features.[SENTMARKER]In October 2012, the District Court (Judge James C. Turk) entered a stipulated order, under which the defendants agreed to make numerous improvements to the subject properties.[SENTMARKER]Following the settlement agreement, claims concerning the liability of an architecture firm lingered, but were ultimately resolved by a stipulated dismissal on January 14, 2014.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the settlement agreement, the District Court retained jurisdiction to resolve disputes between the parties until October 2015.[SENTMARKER]Since there has been no docket activity after 2014, the case is presumed closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 17, 2011, the National Fair Housing Alliance and Paralyzed Veterans of America filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Virginia against HHHunt Corporation, a private, nonprofit, fair housing organization, alleging that the defendant violated the Fair Housing Act by failing to comply with the requirements of Title VIII of the Civil Rights Act of 1968.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs alleged that the defendants failed to provide accessible housing for people with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought monetary, declaratory, and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a Stipulated Judgment, which was entered on October 26, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay the plaintiffs a total of $325,000 in disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendants agreed to provide all of their executives with supervisory responsibility for the design and/or construction of covered multifamily dwellings and on-site management employees with supervision responsibility for all such alterations within a period of thirty-six months.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to post a conspicuous sign in the sales or rental offices of all covered multifamily properties that are owned in whole or in part by the plaintiffs to indicate that all dwellings are available for rental on a nondiscriminatory basis.

gold_sents: In 2011, the plaintiff, an individual with intellectual disabilities filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued then Director for the Agency for Persons with Disabilities pursuant to 42 U.S.C. §§ 1938 & 1988.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff was involuntarily committed to residential services pursuant to Florida statute but never received any periodic review of his continued need for involuntary confinement to residential services.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the Defendant's motion for summary judgment on the basis that the Agency's scheme of review satisfied the Due Process Clause.[SENTMARKER]On October 20, 2015, the US Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit reversed this decision and remanded the case to the lower court.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 25, 2011, the Florida Institute for Persons with Disabilities filed this suit under 42 U.S.C.  1983 against the Florida Department of Children and Family Services (DCF) seeking declaratory judgment that Florida’s statutory scheme for involuntarily admitting intellectually disabled persons to residential services under section 393.11, Florida Statutes, is facially unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendant's policy of involuntary admission to non-secure residential services violated his due process rights under the color of law.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendant’s motion for summary judgment on grounds of qualified immunity.[SENTMARKER]The defendant appealed to the Eleventh Circuit, which certified questions of law to the Florida Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court denied the defendants’ appeal, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: After Illinois initiated the process of closing several State Operated Developmental Centers for adults with severe developmental disabilities, Plaintiffs filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs opposed the closures of the Jackson and Murray centers and the anticipated closure of the rest of the SODCs and brought the suit seeking declaratory relief, attorneys' fees, and an injunction preventing the planned closures.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs brought their claims under The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794), Olmstead v. L.C.(527 U.S. 581 (1999)), 42 U.S.C. § 1983 (for state infringement of equal protection), and various federal and state Medicaid laws.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs' claims brought under the Olmstead mandate were dismissed.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs did obtain a temporary restraining order, but their motion for a preliminary injunction was denied by the district court and upon appeal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 28, 2013, the Illinois League of Advocates for the Developmentally Disabled filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against the Illinois Department of Human Services (DHS) alleging that the DHS violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act (R&A) by failing to provide adequate levels of medically necessary care and services to developmentally disabled residents of two state-operated developmental centers (SODCs) in Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' actions violated the ADA and R&A, and sought injunctive relief preventing the assessment and transfer of Murray residents, the closure of Murray, and the appointment of a monitor.[SENTMARKER]On August 9, 2013, the parties filed a motion to dismiss the case without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]On October 8, 2013, the district court granted the motion and denied the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The parties then appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On December 22, 1995, People First of Tennessee filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee against the State of Tennessee on behalf of residents of the Clover Bottom Developmental Center, Greene Valley Developmental Center, and Winston Developmental Center.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled, and the case is now closed.

Echols on May 7, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The parties then entered into a settlement agreement in which they agreed to dismiss the case with prejudice.

gold_sents: In October of 2006, a class action lawsuit was brought in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of California on behalf of agricultural workers alleging that defendant employers had engaged in a massive scheme to hire undocumented immigrants in an effort to depress employee wages.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed without prejudice in May of 2008 after the plaintiff failed to timely amend his complaint to substitute in a suitable class representative.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 5, 2006, a resident of Marin County, California filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California on behalf of all legal hourly-paid workers employed by Fruit Patch, Inc. of Reedley, California.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants had conspired to employ more than 10 undocumented, illegal aliens in each of the last four years, knowing each was smuggled into the country and/or harbored once they arrived here.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' motion to dismiss was denied on the ground that the complaint failed to adequately allege violation of the predicate act, Section 1324(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit reversed the District Court's denial of the motion for class certification on February 11, 2008.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On July 16, 2019, the East Bay Sanctuary Covenant, Al Otro Lado, Innovation Law Lab, and the Central American Resource Center in Los Angeles brought this suit against the U.S. Attorney General and  Secretary of Homeland Security.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs challenged the federal immigration rule restricting eligibility for asylum for noncitizens who transited through another country prior to reaching the southern U.S. border.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed the rule violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs successfully sought a preliminary nationwide injunction.[SENTMARKER]However, defendants appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit and the nationwide scope of the injunction was stayed.[SENTMARKER]Then the District Court restored the nationwide scope of the injunction on September 9, 2019, but the government again appealed and the U.S. Supreme Court granted a stay pending disposition of the appeal in the 9th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The District Court issued a separate preliminary injunction against another rule issued by the Department of Homeland Security in the closing days of the Trump Administration which was substantially similar to the one already enjoined.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit upheld the original injunction in April, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing but is likely to terminate soon given the change in presidential administrations.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 16, 2019, the East Bay Sanctuary Covenant, Al Otro Lado, Innovation Law Lab, and Central 4 American Resource Center (the "Plaintiffs") filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Department of Justice ("DOJ"), Department of Customs and Border Protection ("CBP"), and the Executive Office for Immigration Review ("EOIR"), alleging that the government's policy of denying asylum to persons who entered the United States at the southern border without first applying for asylum in Mexico or another third country was unlawful under the Administrative Procedures Act ("APA"),  15(a)(1) of the Immigration and Nationality Act ("INA") and  10(b)(2) of the Refugee Convention ("RFC").[SENTMARKER]On December 19, 2019, the district court granted a preliminary injunction preventing the government from taking any action to continue to implement the 2018 Rule.[SENTMARKER]On June 30, 2020, the court granted summary judgment for the plaintiffs and vacated the Interim Rule, finding that it was invalid under the APA for failing to adhere to notice and comment procedures.[SENTMARKER]On July 17, 2019, the organizations filed a motion for temporary restraining order to prevent the Rule from taking effect.[SENTMARKER]The parties appealed that order to the Ninth Circuit and moved for a stay pending appeal.[SENTMARKER]On September 9, 2019, the parties filed a petition for a writ of certiorari.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit granted the stay pending disposition of the appeal.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On August 16, 2019, several health care providers and nonprofit organizations serving immigrant communities filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs challenged the Department of Homeland Security's Final Public Charge Rule (the Rule), which added non-cash benefits to the factors considered in determining whether a person applying for legal permanent residence is likely to become a public charge.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Government violated the Administrative Procedure Act by exceeding its statutory authority, claimed that the Rule was "arbitrary and capricious," and asserted that the Rule violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]In October 2019, a district court judge denied the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction enjoining the government from implementing the Rule, but issued an order for preliminary injunction in a related case that would enjoin the implementation of the rule in California, Oregon, the District of Columbia, Maine, and Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]This preliminary injunction was stayed by the Ninth Circuit in December 2019.[SENTMARKER]It was affirmed a year later in December 2020, but the order was stayed pending petitions to the Supreme Court in the Second, Seventh, and Ninth Circuits.[SENTMARKER]The Rule was abandoned by DHS on March 9, 2021.[SENTMARKER]As of April 15, 2021, the case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 14, 2019, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) published the final rule entitled 22 "Inadmissibility on Public Charge Grounds" in the Federal Register.[SENTMARKER]The final rule is designed to prevent the disenrolling of eligible U.S. citizen children from Medicaid due to fears that their children's health care coverage will affect their ability to seek immigration relief.[SENTMARKER]In response to the rule's implementation, a group of civil rights and social services organizations filed a lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunctive relief, enjoining DHS from using the revised Manual to process immigrant visas applications, and enjoining the government from enforcing the new rule.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On 2014, Joe Arpaio, Sheriff of Maricopa County in Arizona, filed this lawsuit in the D.C. District Court under the Declaratory Judgment Act and the Administrative Procedures Act (APA) against President Obama, the Secretary of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, the Director of U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services, and the U.S. Attorney General, claiming that the federal programs deferring immigration action for various categories of out-of-status aliens were unconstitutional abuses of the President's power, or should have been done via formal rulemaking.[SENTMARKER]In December 2014, the D.C. District (Judge Beryl A. Howell) dismissed the case, holding that Sheriff Arpaio lacked standing.[SENTMARKER]The D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed in August 2015.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 20, 2014, Sheriff Joseph Arpaio of Maricopa County, Arizona, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against President Obama and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) alleging that the President's Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program and Executive Order Amnesty (EOA) programs were unconstitutional abuses of the President’s role in our nation’s constitutional architecture and exceeded his constitutional authority.[SENTMARKER]The District Court denied the plaintiff's motion for a preliminary injunction and dismissed the case for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction, ECF Nos.[SENTMARKER]7 and 6, and granted the defendants' motion to dismiss for non-delegation jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]On December 17, 2014, the District Court granted the defendant's motions for summary judgment and dismissal of the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In May of 2019, asylum seekers detained under the jurisdiction of the New Orleans ICE Field Office filed a class action lawsuit against DHS, ICE, and the New Orleans ICE Field Office, alleging that they were giving blanket parole denials without individualized reviews.[SENTMARKER]In September 2019, the court granted preliminary injunction, enjoining defendants from continuing to detain asylum seekers without individualized consideration.[SENTMARKER]In March 30, 2020, in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, plaintiffs filed an emergency motion for preliminary injunction, seeking immediate reviews of class members still detained.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs then filed a motion for order to show cause why the defendants should not be held in contempt for violating the 2019 preliminary injunction order, expedited discovery, and the appointment of a special master.[SENTMARKER]The court granted limited discovery.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 30, 2019, the Southern Poverty Law Center (SPLC) filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the New Orleans Field Office of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (NOLA ICE) seeking injunctive and declaratory relief setting aside NOLA ICE’s blanket parole denial policy.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, plaintiffs alleged that NOLA ICE's policy of categorically denying parole to asylum-seekers in violation of the Parole Directive of 2009 violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (APA) and the Equal Protection Act (E.D.A.[SENTMARKER]), and that the agency was not following its parole policy in order to protect them from health risks caused by potential and actual exposure to the novel Coronavirus (COVID-19).[SENTMARKER]On October 2, 2019, the parties filed a Joint Status Report (Dkt.CV-01593-JEB) in which the parties agreed to comply with a consent decree and consent order.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to provide the court with a copy of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' request for a preliminary injunction in part and denied the motion to dismiss in part, finding that the parties had not shown that the conditions of detention violated the APA.[SENTMARKER]In part, the court found that the defendants had failed to provide adequate medical care to the plaintiffs, causing significant harm to their health.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: A group of public interest law firms filed this class action lawsuit in June, 2005 on behalf of migrant workers against their former employer, alleging gross underpayment in violation of the Migrant and Seasonal Agricultural Worker Protection Act (AWPA) and the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA).[SENTMARKER]The Court granted, and the Eleventh Circuit affirmed, class certification for the plaintiffs in September, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs won partial summary judgments in 2008 and 2009, resulting in an eventual award of $11 million in a final judgment in October, 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: The Southern Poverty Law Center's Immigrant Justice Project brought this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia on behalf of migrant agricultural workers who were admitted to the United States to work under the H-2B temporary foreign worker visa program.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged violations of their rights under the Migrant and Seasonal Agricultural Worker Protection Act (AWPA) and the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) by Eller Sons Trees, Inc. (Eller Sons) and Jerry Eller (collectively, the Appellants) during their employment at various times from June 1999 through June 2005.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed cross motions for summary judgment on various issues, many of which the Court decided in its October 8, 2008 Order.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the essential nature of Plaintiffs' AWPA claim was breach of their employment contract with Eller Sons, and the Court granted partial summary judgment to Plaintiffs and found class-wide violations of the AWPA.[SENTMARKER]The Court also granted the plaintiffs reasonable attorneys' fees with respect to their Fair Labor standards Act claims.

gold_sents: In May 2018, the Council on American-Islamic Relations - Chicago (CAIR-Chicago) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the U.S. Department of Homeland Security and U.S. Citizenship & Immigration Services for failing to process its FOIA request for immigration records since the 2008 institution of the Controlled Application Review & Resolution Program, alleging that this conduct was a wrongful delay of release of records in violation of FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs dismissed their claims without explanation on June 28, 2019.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 3, 2018, the Council on American-Islamic Relations-Chicago (CAIR-Chicago) filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against the United States Citizenship Immigration Services (USCIS) and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) seeking the release of records concerning the Controlled Application Review Resolution Program (CARRP), which imposes extra-statutory rules and criteria to delay and deny immigration benefits to which applicants are entitled.[SENTMARKER]On August 1, 2017, CAIR-Chicago submitted an electronic FOIA request to the USCIS National Records Center FOIA/PA Office seeking: information on all individuals who have applied for naturalization, change of status, and asylum through forms N-400, I-589, and I-485 since April 11, 2008; the processing time for each application, the number of times each applicant was interviewed by USCIS agents, and the number, if any, of subsidiary applicants and the status of their citizenship applications.[SENTMARKER]The FOIA request also sought expedited processing and a waiver of fees.[SENTMARKER]On May 1, 2018, the court granted CAIR- Chicago's request for declaratory, injunctive, and other appropriate relief, finding that the defendants violated the FOIA by failing to produce in a timely manner records that respond to the FOIA request, failing to provide a date by which processing of the request could be expected to be completed, and failing to make any determination concerning the requested records within the statutory time period.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the plaintiffs' request for injunctive relief with respect to their reasonable costs and fees incurred in this action.

gold_sents: On March 2, 2007, a resident alien and two non-profits filed a class action suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts, challenging the mandatory detention provision of Section 236(c) of the Immigration and Nationality Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff also filed a petition for writ of habeas corpus pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 2241, requesting his immediate release from detention.[SENTMARKER]On July 12, 2007 district court held a hearing on the writ of habeas corpus, however, before ruling on the issue the plaintiff was released from custody.[SENTMARKER]The court then dismissed the remainder of the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 2, 2007, the Political Asylum/Immigration Representation Project (PAIR) and the Catholic Legal Immigration Network, Inc. ( CLINIC) filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief against the federal defendants' misinterpretation of Section 236(c) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) and Section 303(b) ("Transitional Period Custody Rules" or "TPCR"), as amended by the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 ("IIRIRA").[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs sought a determination that the plaintiffs were not subject to mandatory detention without bond of virtually all immigrants who commit a removable offense listed therein upon the immigrant's release from the criminal custody that resulted from the offense.[SENTMARKER]On May 31, 2007, the defendants moved to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, lack of standing as to the plaintiffs, and for failure to state a claim upon which relief may be granted.[SENTMARKER]On June 14, 2007, the parties filed a joint motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]On August 22, 2007, the court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the case was closed.

gold_sents: In September 2019, the Irish International Immigrant Center sued U.S. Citizenship & Immigration Services and President Trump.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff alleged defendants illegally terminated an immigration relief program that granted "deferred action" to seriously ill individuals and their families.[SENTMARKER]Represented by the ACLU, the plaintiff sought injunctive and declaratory relief for violations of Equal Protection and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a joint motion to stay the case on October 31, 2019, so parties could seek a nonjudicial resolution.[SENTMARKER]This followed a USCUS announcement that the deferred action program would return but requests would only be granted “based on compelling facts and circumstances.”[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff voluntarily dismissed the case without prejudice on June 15, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 17, 2019, the Irish International Immigrant Center (IIIC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the acting director of the USCIS.[SENTMARKER]The IIIC represents individuals and families who qualify for deferred action due to serious medical needs.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' termination of deferred action was impermissibly motivated by racial animus and animus based on national origin, in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the Fifth Amendment, and contrary to law.[SENTMARKER]On June 22, 2020, the court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case for mootness.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a joint status report on or before February 16, 2021.[SENTMARKER]On April 16, 2021, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2018, the City of Baltimore filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that certain changes to the Public Charge rule by the U.S. President, Secretary of State, and Department of State were made without following proper administrative procedure and in violation of equal protection.[SENTMARKER]The rule increased the number of immigrants barred from applying for visas for having previously received public assistance.[SENTMARKER]The rule was preliminarily enjoined in a different lawsuit on July 29, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit is ongoing, but proceedings are stayed until May 24, 2021.

gold_sents: On May 4, 2020, two individuals in ICE (US Immigration and Customs Enforcement) custody sued ICE and the Department of Homeland Security.[SENTMARKER]They claimed that restrictions to telephone access by impsing costs and denying access to incoming calls during the COVID-19 pandemic when in-person visitations have been rendered impossible is unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, they alleged that their Fifth and First Amendment rights had been violated by preventing communication with counsel, denying their right to legal representation, and other resources critical to support their cases.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: The ACLU of Northern California filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York on behalf of individuals detained in the custody of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) at the El Paso Service Processing Center and the Otero County Processing Center.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, class certification, appointment of counsel, attorney's fees, and attorneys' fees in violation of their constitutional, statutory, and regulatory rights under, inter alia, the United States Constitution, the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), and the 17 Administrative Procedures Act (APA).[SENTMARKER]The district court certified the class and held a bench trial, finding shortcomings with the prison system, including the training of staff, the updating of legal materials, and the availability of photocopying services.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which ICE and DHS agreed to implement certain procedures and practices that would ensure that class members were able to access free, confidential legal calls in order to speak to their attorneys and to be able to effectuate their constitutional rights in their immigration proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction, or for failure to state a claim.

gold_sents: A group of immigration legal service providers filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon on December 18, 2019, alleging the federal government had manipulated the immigration adjudication system in a way making it virtually impossible for asylum seekers to succeed.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged violations of the Take Care Clause of the U.S. Constitution, as well as provisions of the Immigration and Nationality Act and the Administrative Procedure Act. They sought declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]After the defendants filed a motion to dismiss, the plaintiffs moved for a Temporary Restraining Order due to the COVID-19 pandemic, alleging that the immigration courts had failed to take adequate public health measures to protect judges, respondents, attorneys, and staff.[SENTMARKER]On April 1, 2020, the District Court denied the plaintiffs' motion.[SENTMARKER]On July 31, the court granted in part and denied in part the defendant's motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The defendants sought reconsideration, which was denied on September 10.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 20, 2020, a group of legal advocacy organizations filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon against the Department of Justice (DOJ) alleging that the DOJ's use of video teleconferencing (VTC) in the immigration court system violated the Take Care Clause, the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought an emergency order enjoining the DOJ from invoking in absentia removal procedures, declaratory and injunctive relief, and a temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]In response, the DOJ filed a motion to dismiss the plaintiffs' claims for lack of jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the motion, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: On April 15, 2009, two longtime permanent residents of the United States who had been detained in Pennsylvania prisons for periods exceeding six months while they pursued challenges to decisions to deport them filed a class action lawsuit against the Department of Homeland Security, the Department of Justice, and the prisons that held them, claiming that their prolonged detention without a hearing to determine whether such detention was justified violated the due process clause of the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On August 10, 2009, the Court (Judge John E. pegasus_output_sents: On June 27, 2008, two lawful permanent residents of the United States filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) seeking declaratory and injunctive relief on behalf of themselves and a class of similarly-situated persons.[SENTMARKER]The petitioners alleged that the government's continued detention of them without a hearing violated the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), the Administrative Procedures Act (APA), and the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the petitioners' motion for a preliminary injunction and denied their motion for class certification for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This is a class action lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of a South Carolina immigration law which requires state and local law enforcement officers to investigate the immigration status of any individual they stop, detain, or arrest whenever they have a "reasonable suspicion" that the individual lacks immigration status, allows law enforcement officers to arrest individuals solely for failing to carry registration documents, makes it a crime to harbor or transport an undocumented immigrant or to be harbored or transported by others if one is an undocumented immigrant, and imposes civil liability on the police for failing to enforce its provisions to the maximum extent possible.[SENTMARKER]The law was patterned after Arizona's SB 1070.[SENTMARKER]The District Court has issued a preliminary injunction barring enforcement of the law, and this injunction has been appealed to the Fourth Circuit; in the meantime, the case, along with several others like it from different states, are stayed at the District Court or U.S.[SENTMARKER]Appellate level pending the decision of the Supreme Court in United States v. Arizona.[SENTMARKER]After Arizona v. United States was decided the issue was remanded to the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The district court left in place most of its original preliminary injunction, enjoining the state from enforcing Sections 4, 5, and 6 (B)(2).[SENTMARKER]The 4th Circuit per Judge Davis agreed and affirmed the order on July 13, 2013.[SENTMARKER]In March of 2014 Judge Gergel permanently enjoined South Carolina from enforcing Sections 4, 5, and 6(B)(2).[SENTMARKER]Furthermore the state agreed to more favorable interpretations of Section 7, and the remainder of Section, encouraging the Plaintiffs to dismiss their claims on those sections without prejudice.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2011, a group of individuals and advocacy groups filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina challenging South Carolina's comprehensive immigration law, Senate Bill 20 (S.C. Code  16-9-460, 17-13-170(B)(2), 16-13-480).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive and declaratory relief to prevent serious harm that Plaintiffs and putative class members across the state would suffer if the law went into effect.[SENTMARKER]The district court issued a preliminary injunction enjoining sections of the Act, finding those sections preempted by federal immigration law and regulations.[SENTMARKER]On August 16, 2012, the Fourth Circuit remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]On January 9, 2012, the District Court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment and dismissed the plaintiffs' remaining claims without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On December 15, 2006, a group of employees at Swift Beef Company's meat packing plants filed a class action lawsuit against their employer and related companies, alleging that Swift had engaged in a longstanding scheme of hiring undocumented immigrants for the express purpose of depressing employee wages, and that in furtherance of its scheme, Swift had recruited undocumented immigrants to work in its plants and assisted in providing them with fake immigration documents.[SENTMARKER]After the Court dismissed plaintiffs' illegal hiring claims as insufficiently specific and denied their motion for class certification, the parties stipulated for a dismissal with prejudice on June 18, 2009, and the case was terminated.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 17, 2007, a group of workers at a Texas beef processing plant filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas against Swift Beef Company, Inc. and five John Does, alleging that the defendants engaged in a long-term pattern and practice of violating the Immigration Reform and Control Act and the Immigration and Nationality Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were harmed by Swift's conspiracy to depress the wages paid to its hourly wage earners by knowingly hiring a workforce substantially com posed of illegal aliens.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case for lack of jurisdiction, for failure to join necessary and indispensable parties, for lack standing, and for failing to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]On June 18, 2009, the plaintiffs filed a second a mended complaint in order to reassert their illegalhiring claims.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the parties' motions to dismiss, with prejudice, with each of the parties to bear their own costs and attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: In November 2018, Jewish Family Service of Seattle, Jewish Family Services of Silicon Valley, and Advocates for Youth Mississippi Center for Justice filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the President of the United States, and the Director of National Intelligence (DNI) over the President's Refugee Ban 3.0.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the President violated the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), the First Amendment, and 23 the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in November 2019.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to dismiss the case with prejudice, subject to the terms of the settlement agreement, within 60 days of the date of discovery.

gold_sents: In August 2018, an inmate filed a civil class action lawsuit against the Pulaski County Jail (PCJ) and six PCJ officials in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, on behalf of himself and twenty-two other inmates, asked the court for monetary and injunctive relief, claiming that he and other inmates were being kept locked in their cells because the jail was not properly staffed.[SENTMARKER]On September 12, 2018, U.S. District Judge James Moody Jr. entered an initial order providing guidelines for proceeding pro se and finding that a request for class certification at this stage was premature; accordingly, he severed the case as twenty-three separate lawsuits.[SENTMARKER]Twenty-one of the other cases were eventually all dismissed without prejudice due to lack of prosecution by the other inmates.[SENTMARKER]This instant case and one other case (docket no. 4:18-cv-00552), which was also dismissed without prejudice due to lack of prosecution and reopened, are the only two ongoing cases out of the total twenty-three cases initially filed on this matter.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 20, 2018, a former inmate of the Pulaski County Detention Facility filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants violated his civil rights under the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments by denying him access to a telephone during the one hour a day he was not on lockdown.[SENTMARKER]He also alleged that they violated his rights under PCDF policy and federal law by requiring no more than 80 inmates per officer.[SENTMARKER]On November 1, 2018, the case was dismissed, without prejudice, for lack of prosecution.[SENTMARKER]On March 7, 2019, the plaintiff filed an amended complaint, which was dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The amended complaint alleged that President Donald Trump and Arkansas Governor Asa Hutchinson were defendants.[SENTMARKER]On February 13, 2019, the court granted the plaintiff's Motion to Amend his Complaint to add President Trump and Governor Hutchinson as defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on July 10, 2019.

gold_sents: In 2012, prisoners in the Los Angeles County Jails filed this is a class action in the US District Court for the Central District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged a long-standing and widespread pattern of violence and abuse by deputies against inmates and sought an injunction requiring training, supervision, and disciplinary policies for deputies.[SENTMARKER]In 2015, the parties reached a settlement that required a detailed and far-reaching remedial plan.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing with monitoring.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 19, 2002, two inmates of the Los Angeles County Jail filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against the County of Los Angeles and the Sheriff's Department.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that use of force against inmates in the jails was disproportionately directed at inmates with mental illness, and that the Sheriff did not adequately investigate allegations of abuse against inmates.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement, which was implemented in the rest of the jail facilities effective November 1, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion to Enforce the Settlement Agreement in May 2014, but the parties did not agree on compliance measures before they entered into the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]In May 2014, the parties retained a Panel to prepare an Action Plan relating to certain policies and practices employed in the downtown Los Angeles jails.[SENTMARKER]The Panel was appointed by Judge Dean D. Pregerson of the District Court to ensure compliance with the settlement.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.[SENTMARKER]The ACLU National Prison Project and the ACLU of Southern California are represented by David Shapiro.

gold_sents: On February 29, 2016, two detainees with disabilities filed a class action lawsuit against San Bernardino County under § 1983, the ADA, and the Rehabilitation Act in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the county violated the detainees' Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]In March 2018, the parties reached a settlement and proposed a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The court approved the consent decree on December 14, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The case remains ongoing for enforcement.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 27, 2017, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of California against San Bernardino County.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the county violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (Section 504) by failing to accommodate people with disabilities in its facilities, programs, activities, and services.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a consent decree, which was entered on December 14, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The decree requires the county to: (1) provide timely access to medical, mental health, and dental records for people with physical disabilities; .[SENTMARKER](2) maintain accurate, complete, and organized medical records; .[SENTMARKER](3) provide access to mental health and mental health psychiatrists; .[SENTMARKER](4) provide timely and adequate access to assistive devices and medical supplies; .[SENTMARKER](5) house people in an accessible housing unit; and (6) provide services that are necessary to maintain dental health.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is subject to approval by the Court, unless it is later terminated pursuant to the consent decree.

pegasus_output_sents: On January 24, 2005, the ACLU of Colorado and the ACLU National Prison Project filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado against the El Paso County Sheriff's Office and the Colorado Department of Corrections.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Eighth Amendment and the Fourteenth Amendment by using excessive force against prisoners with mental health problems and by failing to provide adequate mental health care.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]On September 22, 2006, the district court again denied class certification, but this time with reference to Rule 23 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: On May 1, 2013, the U.S. Department of Justice brought suit in the Southern District of Florida on behalf of jail inmates against officials from Miami-Dade County.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ claimed that the defendant failed to provide adequate suicide protection and mental health care to the inmates.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a consent decree, which was entered on May 22, 2013.[SENTMARKER]Timely compliance has been a challenge and as of April 15, 2020 the defendants were still not in compliance.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 2, 2008, the U.S. Department of Justice and the Miami-Dade County Board of County Commissioners filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the county's corrections facilities violated the Civil Rights oflnstitutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA) by failing to provide adequate medical and mental health care to thousands of prisoners with serious mental illness.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Consent Agreement, ECF No. [5-2] ("Consent Agreement"), effective May 22, 2013, that addressed alleged constitutional violations regarding the provision of medical and mentally health care at the correctional facilities operated by the county.[SENTMARKER]On April 20, 2016, the Court held a status conference during which the parties noted that the County was not in full compliance with the Consent Agreement.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the County's motion for summary judgment, and the parties agreed to a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was effective on April 30, 2013 and required the County to provide medical care to all inmates, including those with mental illness and those who have no choice as to their housing and rely upon the government, to comply with the law.[SENTMARKER]The County also agreed to provide mental health services to inmates in the jails operated by MDCR.[SENTMARKER]On May 22, 2014, the County filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the motion, finding that the consent decree did not provide the County with the relief it sought.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2004, plaintiffs filed this class-action lawsuit pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 1983 in the US District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs challenged the Cook County Sheriff's policy of strip searching all males following their return to the Cook County Jail from court after there was a judicial determination that there was no longer a basis for their detention.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled in 2011 and the defendants paid $1.4 million in damages and roughly $2 million in attorney's fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 12, 2004, a group of inmates in the Cook County Department of Corrections filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' policy of strip searching all male inmates returning to the jail after receiving court orders making them eligible for release violated the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments of the U.S. Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed not to strip search any female inmate returning from court, and to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on November 2, 2011.

gold_sents: This was a strip-search case in which a nurse on her way home from Johns Hopkins was pulled over for a traffic violation, taken to the police station, and strip searched in front of a crowd of people.[SENTMARKER]She claimed that the strip search was illegal.[SENTMARKER]This is one of many cases pending that charge the Baltimore police department with illegal strip searches.[SENTMARKER]This case is still ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 2, 2008, four female plaintiffs filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the Baltimore City Police Department, the Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, and the Baltimore Central Booking and Intake Facility (CBIF) alleging that they were subjected to unconstitutional strip searches in violation of the Fourth Amendment following their arrests for minor offenses.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their Fourth Amendment right to be free of an unreasonable search by implementing and maintaining a policy and practice of conducting strip searches and visual body cavity searches of all persons who were admitted to the CBIF, regardless of the nature of charges filed against, or the circumstances surrounding the arrest of, the individual.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss, claiming that the plaintiffs' claims against the city of Baltimore were barred by the fact that the city was not an agency of the state of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment and dismissed the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 27, 2011, inmates at the Suffolk County Correctional Facility filed, pro se, a complaint alleging that the unsanitary conditions of confinement at the two jails, located at Riverhead and Yaphank, violated their constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The Court appointed pro bono counsel on November 22, 2011; they filed the Consolidated Amended Class Action Complaint on April 5, 2012, seeking to represent interests of all inmates as a class action.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the class certification on March 19, 2013, and denied most of the defendants' motion to discuss at the same time.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 27, 2011, an inmate at the Suffolk County Correctional Facility (SCCF) filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York against the County of Suffolk and the New York Civil Liberties Union (NYCLU).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Constitution and the laws of the United States by failing to make reasonable efforts to remedy the conditions of confinement at the SCCF.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief, medical treatment, and monetary damages.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case on April 5, 2012 and denied the motion on October 5, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On November 19, 2009, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of Louisiana filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New Orleans against Terrebonne Parish, Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged violations of the constitutional rights of youth detained at the Terrebonne Juvenile Detention Center (TPJDC) in Terrebonne, Louisiana, pursuant to the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994.[SENTMARKER]The complaint further alleged that the facility failed to adequately protect youth from harm by detention staff, failed to provide an appropriate housing classification system, and failed to hold staff accountable for misconduct related to confinement checks, suicide precautions, and youth supervision.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement, which was approved by the court on April 17, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to implement corrective measures to ensure that the conditions of confinement at TPJDC comply with the terms of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed not to retaliate against each other in the event of any violation of this agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

Mississippi.[SENTMARKER]DRMS sought to enforce its access rights to the Forrest County Juvenile Detention Center pursuant to the Protection and Advocacy for Individuals with Mental Illness Act of 1986
