gold_sents: In 2016, a minor detainee at Rutherford County Juvenile Detention Center filed this class action complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the practice of placing minors in solitary confinement as punishment violated their Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]In 2017, the plaintiff was granted a preliminary injunction and the parties began the settlement process.[SENTMARKER]The case settled in July 2019.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement included a permanent injunction prohibiting Rutherford County from using seclusion as punishment for minors.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 25, 2016, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee against the Tennessee Department of Children's Services (DCS), the Rutherford County Juvenile Detention Center (RCJ), and Rutherford County, Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments by placing a juvenile pretrial detainee in solitary confinement without regard to his age or mental health status for purposes of punishment and/or discipline.[SENTMARKER]The court certified a class of all juveniles detained at the Rutherford JDC, and the parties reached a settlement agreement in April 2016.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the defendant would not use solitary confinement for disciplinary or punitive reasons.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a final settlement agreement on April 25, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The final agreement is subject to approval by the court.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On October 7, 2014, Twitter filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the U.S. Dept.[SENTMARKER]of Justice and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to file a report on information requests received from the government.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted summary judgment for the government in April 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 7, 2014, Twitter, Inc. filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Department of Justice (DOJ), the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and the National Security Agency (NSA) seeking declaratory and injunctive relief under the First Amendment and the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) in the wake of Edward Snowden's disclosures about the scope of the government's surveillance programs.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the Government's restrictions on sharing information about national-security activities were not narrowly tailored and lacked procedural safeguards consistent with strict scrutiny.[SENTMARKER]In its complaint, Twitter alleged that Section 2709 of Title 18, both facially and as 21 applied, is a prior restraint and content-based restriction, which is not narrowlytailored to serve a governmental interest.[SENTMARKER]On October 8, 2014, the court granted the Defendants' motion for summary judgment, finding that the FISA secrecy provisions are well-documented in the Executive Order No. 13526 of the USA FREEDOM Act and that the government’s decision to censor Twitter’s draft 9 Transparency Report was not properly classified.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the defendants’ motion for a summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed, and the parties have agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: On June 3, 2014, the New York Times and its reporter filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the Department of Justice (DOJ) under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) seeking production of Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court (FISC) rulings interpreting surveillance law since 9/11.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged a violation of FOIA because the defendant failed to release these documents in response to a FOIA request.[SENTMARKER]While this litigation was pending, the DOJ produced redacted versions of the FISC documents to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case was voluntarily dismissed on October 28, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 6, 2014, The New York Times Company and its reporter, Charlie Savage, filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) against the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) and its constituent part, the National Security Division (NSD).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the DOJ's failure to produce responsive documents to the plaintiffs' FOIA request violated the FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a joint submission on October 9, 2014 and the parties agreed to release the requested documents in partial response to the FOIA request.[SENTMARKER]On December 8, 2014, the court granted the parties' motion for partial summary judgment and ordered the DOJ to produce documents responsive to categories 3 through 6 of the request.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on October 28, 2015 and the court dismissed the case with prejudice.

gold_sents: This case was brought on behalf of a developmentally disabled girl against Arkansas Department of Human Services (ADHS) because ADHS would not provide Plaintiff with an application to enroll in community/home-based services provided through the state's Medicaid program.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed without prejudice on September 22, 2003, when Defendant agreed to provide Plaintiff with an application for those services.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 25, 2003, a disabled Medicaid recipient filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas against the Arkansas Department of Human Services (ADHS) alleging that ADHS violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by refusing to accept her application for home and community based services under the state's Developmental Disabilities Alternative Community Services Waiver (ACS waiver) Medicaid program.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants violated the ADA by denying her the opportunity to apply for ACS services.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunctive relief, finding that the plaintiffs would suffer irreparable harm without an injunction.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the district court's decision to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court denied the defendants' appeal, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: On January 20, 2010, an employee of the federal judiciary married to her same-sex partner under California law filed a lawsuit against the federal Office of Personnel Management (OPM) in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, San Francisco Division, alleging that the federal Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) violates the Fifth Amendment by refusing to recognize lawful same-sex marriages for purposes of the laws governing spousal health benefits for federal employees, thereby denying her of a benefit that would be available to her if her spouse were of the opposite sex.[SENTMARKER]On February 22, 2012, the District Court granted summary judgment to the plaintiff, holding that the application of DOMA to deny spousal health benefits in this case did not have a rational basis and thus constituted a Fifth Amendment violation.[SENTMARKER]It entered a permanent injunction prohibiting the defendants from interfering with the enrollment of the plaintiff's wife in her family health benefits plan.[SENTMARKER]On July 3, 2012, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a petition in the Supreme Court for certiorari prior to judgment.[SENTMARKER]That petition was held without decision while the Court considered the California Prop.[SENTMARKER]8 case (PB-CA-0029 in this Clearinghouse) and Windsor, the DOMA case from the Second Circuit (PB-NY-0017 in this Clearinghouse), in which the Court granted review on December 7.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed following the decision in Windsor holding § 3 of DOMA unconstitutional.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 11, 2012, the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) filed a consolidated appeal in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California in a case that challenged the constitutionality of Section 3 of the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) in light of the Supreme Court's decision in Windsor.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that DOMA violated the equal protection clause of the Fifth Amendment by denying same-sex married couples equal protection under the law.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with leave to amend on the basis that the court lacked jurisdiction to issue mandamus relief.[SENTMARKER]On March 16, 2011, the court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, finding that the amendment would not necessarily be futile.[SENTMARKER]The district court issued a permanent injunction requiring the defendants not to interfere with the enrollment of Ms. Golinski's wife in her family health benefits plan.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court issued its opinion in Windsor on December 11, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed that the case should be dismissed.

gold_sents: Plaintiff, an individual with muscular dystrophy, filed this lawsuit alleging that the state's planned reduction in his home care nursing services (due to his reaching his 21st birthday and transition into "adult" services) puts him at risk of unnecessary institutionalization in violation of the ADA and Section 504.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement and on August 1, 2013, the case was dismissed.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 4, 2012, California resident Pablo Carranza filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California against the California Department of Health Care Services and the State of California alleging violations of Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, and the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment (D.C.  1983).[SENTMARKER]Carranza's complaint alleged that the defendants violated the ADA by failing to provide written notice that explains their right to a hearing, failing to offer reasonable modifications to their programs and policies to enable Plaintiff to receive medically necessary in-home nursing as ordered by his physicians, and denying him funds for home and community-based services that would otherwise be available for institutional services.[SENTMARKER]On March 29, 2013, the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed not to seek recoupment of any monies paid to Western Home 2 Health Agency pursuant to the settlement agreement, and the parties agreed to pay Carranza $69,500 in attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on August 2, 2013.

gold_sents: Institutionalized individuals with disabilities filed this challenge to the District of Columbia's Medicaid policies.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the District does not have an effective plan to prevent unnecessary institutionalization and that the inability of individuals to access sufficient community-based supports and services under DC's policies violates the ADA.[SENTMARKER]Following trial in 2016, Judge Huvelle found that the plaintiffs had failed to demonstrate entitlement to class-wide relief and entered judgment for the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed the decision; the D.C. circuit reversed and remanded.[SENTMARKER]Discovery is now ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2010, four disabled individuals filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia alleging that the District's long-term care program violated the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the D.C.'s program and activities for persons with disabilities systematically denied or ignored Plaintiffs' choices and preferences for integrated community care, in violation of Title II of the ADA, and violated Section 504.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification in March 2014.[SENTMARKER]In April 2014, the district court entered final judgment in favor of the District, finding that it violated the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA),  1400 et seq., which imposes on the District a number of different obligations with respect to students who require special education services.[SENTMARKER]The District then filed an appeal of the final judgment, which was denied without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs are a same-sex couple who asked a federal court in Louisiana to declare as unconstitutional Louisiana's refusal to issue an amended birth certificate for an adopted child listing both individuals in an unmarried same-sex couple as the legal parents, and, for injunctive relief requiring Louisiana to issue such birth certificate.[SENTMARKER]After the district court held for plaintiffs, the Fifth Circuit reversed and found that Louisiana's recognition of a New York adoption order was not entitled to the Full Faith and Credit Clause of the U.S. Constitution, and that there was no Equal Protection violation.
pegasus_output_sents: In October 2007, a same-sex couple who jointly parent their child as legal parents filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana against the Louisiana Office of Public Health, Vital Records Registry, alleging that the state's refusal to issue a birth certificate with the names of unmarried adoptive parents violated the Full Faith and Credit Clause and the Equal Protection Clause of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The district court held that Louisiana owes full faith and credit to an out-of-state adoption decree and that there is no public policy exception to the Clause.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Louisiana Supreme Court affirmed the district court's decision.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On April 9th, 2014, several same-sex couples residing in North Carolina filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the state of North Carolina.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs asked the court to declare that North Carolina's ban on same-sex is unconstitutional, declare North Carolina laws prohibiting joint adoption by same-sex couples are also unconstitutional,  enjoin the state from enforcing any of its laws banning same-sex marriage, direct the state to recognize same-sex marriages entered into in other states, and award the plaintiffs costs of suit and reasonable attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]The court ruled in the plaintiffs' favor on October 14, 2014, declaring the North Carolina laws in question unconstitutional to the extent they prevent marriage and recognition of same-sex couples.

pegasus_output_sents: On June 12, 2015, a group of same-sex couples filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Nebraska against the State of Nebraska.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief for the violation of their rights under the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution caused by the State's exclusion of gay couples from marriage and its prohibition against recognizing their marriages validly entered into in other states.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, and the case was remanded to the Eighth Circuit for further proceedings consistent with its opinion.[SENTMARKER]The Eighth Circuit remanded the case to this Court for further determination.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2016, a same-sex married couple filed this Civil Rights Act of 1871 complaint in the District Court of South Carolina (Columbia Division).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff sought declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming violations of their fundamental right to marry and other protected liberties related to the differential treatment of birth records for children with same-sex married parents.[SENTMARKER]Summary Judgment was granted in favor of the Plaintiffs and a consent decree entered ordering South Carolina to make changes to the policies of their birth-record keeping, as well as the issuance of corrected birth certificates to the Plaintiffs and all who qualified under the new policies and requested such a correction.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached an undisclosed settlement for attorney’s fees and the case closed in June 2017.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 15, 2017, the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control (DHEC) was sued in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina by a married couple who were denied accurate birth certificates for their newborn twins simply because they are spouses of the same sex.[SENTMARKER]The couple, Casy and Jacqueline Carson, filed this lawsuit under 28 U.N.C.[SENTMARKER]1331, alleging that DHEC's refusal to issue birth certificates listing both same-sex spouses as parents of their children born during marriage violated the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the couple's request for declaratory and injunctive relief, and ordered DHEC to issue two-parent birth certificates on the same terms as those issued to married, different-Sex spouses.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On October 22, 2013, parolees in custody or under supervision of the Illinois Department of Corrections filed a class action lawsuit alleging violations of their due process rights due to procedurally unfair parole review proceedings, which functioned as essentially an automatic approval of parole board recommendations.[SENTMARKER]In January of 2017, the parties reached a settlement agreement which directs Illinois to revise its parole review proceedings and inform parolees of their rights.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 22, 2013, three parolees filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against the Illinois Department of Corrections (DOC) and the Illinois Prisoner Review Board (PRB).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their due process rights by failing to consider whether parolees qualified for the appointment of counsel, and failing to appoint counsel to those parolees who did not qualify.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, and the parties filed a draft settlement agreement on October 24, 2016.[SENTMARKER]On October 27, 2016, the Court certified the class as Supervised Release ("MSR"), which is supervised by the IDOC and who now or in the future will be subject to parole revocation proceedings conducted by the DOC and the PRB.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the parties would share the cost of any such mediation.[SENTMARKER]On January 24, 2017, the parties entered into a final settlement agreement, which was approved by the Court.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement requires the defendants to: (1) prohibit parolees from being held in the custody of the DOC prior to their revocation proceedings from using the telephone; .[SENTMARKER](2) severely restrict non-legal requests for parolees to use the phone; and (3) provide parolees with access to counsel.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted preliminary approval of the settlement on October 27, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a joint motion for class certification, which the Court approved on October 28, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties subsequently filed a motion for preliminary approval on October 29, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The Court approved the class certification on October 30, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The class is comprised of all people who, while on parole/Mandatory Release, are supervised by, or under the supervision of the Illinois DOC and who are subject to the parole revocation process conducted by, the I DOC.[SENTMARKER]The class was certified as a class of all parolees in the state of Illinois who are supervised MSR.[SENTMARKER]The final settlement was approved on January 24, 2017.

gold_sents: A transgender woman incarcerated at a men's prison in Illinois brought this action against the Illinois Department of Corrections and its officers in federal court, for abuse, harassment, and equal protection violations.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought an injunction ordering the Department to transfer her to a women's facility.[SENTMARKER]On November 7, 2018, Judge Nancy Rosenstengel of the Southern District of Illinois granted a preliminary injunction requiring the defendants to provide basic mental health services to the plaintiff and consider all evidence as to whether she should be transferred to a women's prison.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 22, 2019, a transgender inmate in the custody of the Illinois Department of Corrections (IDOC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Illinois against the IDOC, its Director of Prisons, and the Warden of Lawrence Correctional Center.[SENTMARKER]The inmate alleged that the defendants violated her Eighth Amendment rights by failing to provide her with reasonable accommodations for her gender dysphoria disability.[SENTMARKER]She also alleged that she was denied appropriate mental health services and her mental health was deteriorating.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case on August 22, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2018, a former prison inmate from Illinois sued the Illinois Department of Corrections.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff had spent 20 years in solitary confinement, where his mental health declined substantially.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the Department had violated his Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights, as well as the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Rehabilitation act, by placing him in solitary confinement, providing no opportunity to appeal his placement, and providing him with insufficient psychiatric care.[SENTMARKER]As of July 8, 2020, the litigation is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 28, 2019, the Illinois Department of Corrections (IDOC) filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of Illinois on behalf of a mentally ill inmate in solitary confinement.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the IDOC violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act (RA) by denying him medical and mental health care that caused him physical and psychological harm.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiff's motion for summary judgment and ordered the defendants to provide him with a reasonable accommodation for his mental disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the District Court and the parties entered into a settlement agreement on September 16, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The court awarded the plaintiff full costs and attorneys' fees, and the defendants agreed not to segregate disabled and non-disabled persons.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to pay nominal damages to the plaintiff.

gold_sents: On January 21, 2009, the ACLU filed a lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. Section 1983 against the Federal Bureau of Prisons in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Indiana.[SENTMARKER]The complaint challenged the creation of Communication Management Units (CMUs) in the federal prisons.[SENTMARKER]On July 28, 2010, plaintiff filed a motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]This case was dismissed on July 29, 2010 without prejudice in the Southern District of Indiana.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 3, 2006, inmates of the federal prison in Terre Haute, Indiana filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Indiana against the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP), Eric Holder, the Attorney General of the United States, and other BOP employees.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the BOP's "Limited Communication for Terrorist Inmates" policy violated the Equal Access to Justice Act (E.A.J.)[SENTMARKER]and the Administrative Procedures Act (APA) by imposing severe restrictions on inmates' telephone use, visitation, and use of the mail relative to ordinary inmates in the federal system.[SENTMARKER]On June 2, 2006, the plaintiffs filed a motion for summary judgment on behalf of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]On July 29, 2010, the court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the case was closed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2019, a group of current and former prisoners filed a complaint against the Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services for violating their rights under the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Rehabilitation Act, the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, and Maryland State Law.[SENTMARKER]A similar case was consolidated with this one in January 2020, and a motion to dismiss the complaint is pending in federal court.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 30, 2019, two prisoners filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against Wexford Health Sources, Inc. and the Baltimore City Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services (DPSCS).[SENTMARKER]The prisoners alleged that they were denied the opportunity to participate in pre-release programming, including home detention, work release and "outside detail," because of their disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The prisoners also alleged that the defendants failed to engage competent medical service providers to oversee and administer the healthcare needs of prisoners committed to the custody of DPSCS.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief, compensatory and punitive damages, attorneys' fees and costs, and any other available relief.[SENTMARKER]On December 18, 2019, the court granted the defendants' Motion for Summary Judgment in part and denied the motion to dismiss in part, with leave to renew the motion in part.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: A group of prisoners at a North Carolina private prison sued the prison company and the Federal Bureau of Prisons for deliberate indifference to their medical and mental health needs.[SENTMARKER]After lengthy procedural maneuvering involving a change of venue from D.C. to North Carolina and failed attempts at class certification, the last remaining named plaintiff was transferred and the court dismissed the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 25, 2008, two inmates of the Rivers Correctional Institute filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina against the Federal Bureau of Prisons and the private for-profit corporation GEO Group, Inc.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Eighth Amendment by failing to provide medical, dental, and mental health care to inmates at the prison.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to transfer the case to the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction and for failure to state a claim, and granted the plaintiffs' motion for leave to file a third amended complaint.[SENTMARKER]On July 18, 2011, the Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit affirmed the District Court's decision to dismiss the case on the basis of sovereign immunity for the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of the United States later affirmed the district court's dismissal of the case.

gold_sents: On October 23, 2009, an individual plaintiff filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the District of New Jersey under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the Hackensack Police Department, Hackensack Municipal Court, Bergen County Jail in the City of Hackensack, Bergen County Municipal Court, and Bergen County Prosecutor.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, bringing suit pro se, sought compensatory and punitive damages plus special damages for future legal fees.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff specifically claimed that the defendants violated his Second and Fourteenth Amendment rights by attempting to break in and enter his home, threatening to imprison him, fabricating stories to have him incarcerated, and asserting false criminal charges, which led to plaintiff spending three months and five days in county jail.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the defendant’s and plaintiff’s motions for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]In Dec.[SENTMARKER]2014, the Third Circuit affirmed the district court’s decision to deny summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]Settlement discussions have since been unsuccessful and the case is ongoing in the district court, pending trial once public health conditions allow.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 23, 2009, a New Jersey resident filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey against the Hackensack Police Department, the Hackensack Municipal Court, the Bergen County Prosecutor's Office, and the Bergen Regional Medical Center.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants violated his civil rights by violating his rights to due process, false arrest, false imprisonment, malicious prosecution, and conspiracy.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the complaint on April 23, 2010.[SENTMARKER]On October 8, 2010, the court granted in part and denied in part the motions to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a cross-motion for summary judgment, which the district court denied.[SENTMARKER]On December 16, 2013, the parties filed an interlocutory appeal, which was denied by the court.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: A deaf prison inmate who primarily communicates in American Sign Language filed a lawsuit under the Americans with Disabilities Act against the Oregon Department of Corrections, claiming they failed to communicate with him for over 14 years.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit claimed that, instead of providing interpreters, the prison made him train other inmates as his interpreters and they were not qualified to help him and were also privy to confidential information.[SENTMARKER]In May 2016, the Court granted partial summary judgment for the defendant.[SENTMARKER]Following a jury trial on the remaining claims, the Court dismissed the plaintiff's ADA claim for failure to exhaust administrative remedies under the PLRA.[SENTMARKER]The jury awarded the plaintiff $400,000 in noneconomic damages.[SENTMARKER]The Court awarded the plaintiff $683,873.13 in attorneys' fees, $18,155.19 in costs, and $3,924.79 in litigation expenses.[SENTMARKER]Although both parties appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit, they agreed to voluntarily dismiss their appeals in September 2017.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 5, 2014, an inmate at Columbia River Correctional Institution (CRCI) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon against the Oregon Department of Corrections (ODOC) alleging discrimination under Oregon Revised Statute  659A.142 (First Claim), Disability Discrimination under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), and Unjust Enrichment/Quantum Meruit (Third Claim) under the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (Title II).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that ODOC failed to provide him with accommodations for his hearing disability that would allow him to meaningfully participate in prison programs and services provided to inmates.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff also alleged that the defendant failed to engage in effective communication with him as part of offering these programs or services.[SENTMARKER]On June 6, 2014, the court dismissed the plaintiff's claims for injunctive relief, and his alleged emotional distress damages based on his American Disabilities Act claim.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendant's motion for summary judgment, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: On November 10, 2011, the plaintiff--an Oregon Department of Corrections inmate-- filed this lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, in U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the Oregon Department of Corrections violated his First Amendment free speech rights, his Fourteenth Amendment Due Process rights, and his Eighth Amendment right to be free of cruel and unusual punishment, when they rejected a return a letter written to another ODOC inmate because the envelope had a drawing on it.[SENTMARKER]On May 14, 2015, the District Court enjoined the challenged prison policy.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 10, 2011, an inmate of the Oregon Department of Corrections (ODOC) filed this civil rights action in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon.[SENTMARKER]The inmate, Jacob Barrett, alleged that the defendants violated his First Amendment free speech rights and his Fourteenth Amendment due process rights when they rejected his mail containing artwork on the front of the envelope and delayed initiating mental health exams and rehabilitative treatment.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff also alleged that defendants rejected his mailing in retaliation for having filed lawsuits against ODOC and the New Mexico Corrections Department (NMCD).[SENTMARKER]On October 31, 2013, the parties filed a motion for summary judgment on all of the plaintiff's claims.[SENTMARKER]On February 11, 2014, the court granted summary judgment to the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a declaratory judgment that ODOC’s policy violated the plaintiff’s First Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the defendant’s motion for stay of discovery as moot.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: The Disability Rights Network (DRN), a Pennsylvania non-profit, filed this Eighth Amendment suit against the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections (PDOC) for the PDOC's use of solitary confinement with severely mentally ill prisoners.[SENTMARKER]On January 5, 2015, the parties executed a settlement agreement for dismissal of the matter, in which the PDOC agreed to implement certain improvements and to pay $750,000 to DRN.[SENTMARKER]In particular, the PDOC will evaluate all incoming prisoners for serious mental illness, and will place prisoners with serious mental illness in solitary confinement only in "exceptional" circumstances; even then, a prisoner with serious mental illness can be kept in solitary confinement for no longer than 30 days and must be allowed out of their cells for 20 hours per week.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also provided for a monitor to report on compliance, and will remain in effect for 3 years (less if the defendant demonstrates substantial compliance for a period of 18 months).[SENTMARKER]There has been no activity on the docket since May 2015 and the case is presumably closed since the three year time period set in the agreement has lapsed.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 11, 2013, the Disability Rights Network of Pennsylvania (DRN) filed a federal law suit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania against the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections (DOC) alleging that the DOC's policies and practices violate the Eighth Amendment rights of prisoners with serious mental illness.[SENTMARKER]The DRN's complaint alleged that prisoners with mental illness are confined in so-called Restricted Housing Units (RHUs) under horrific conditions, through an unconstitutional process that takes no account of—and exacerbates—their mental illness, and that the treatment of these prisoners can cause grave harm to their mental and physical health.[SENTMARKER]On January 5, 2015, the parties executed a Private Settlement Agreement and General Release between the DRN and the DOC.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the parties would file a Stipulation of Dismissal within twenty days of the execution of the Agreement.[SENTMARKER]The deadline for the parties to file an answer to the Civil Rights Act of 1983 was September 19, 2015.[SENTMARKER]On September 19, 2015, Judge Susan E. Schwab entered an order denying the defendants' motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Incarcerated prisoners, Prison Radio, Human Rights Coalition, a network of educators, and Prison Legal News, filed these two consolidated lawsuits in the Middle District of Pennsylvania under 42 U.S.C.§ 1983 and Pennsylvania state law.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the Penn.[SENTMARKER]Revictimization Relief Act--which banned certain public speeches by those convicted of crimes--violated their free speech rights.[SENTMARKER]The District Court agreed, striking down the law on April 2015.[SENTMARKER]Defendants elected not to appeal the judgment.[SENTMARKER]Since July 2015, there has been no activity on the docket and the case is presumably closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 21, 2014, the Philadelphia City Paper, Pennsylvania Prison Society, Prison Legal News, and Solitary Watch filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania against Kathleen Kane, Attorney General of Pennsylvania, and R. Seth Williams, District Attorney for Philadelphia County.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Revictimization Relief Act, a 2014 amendment to Pennsylvania's Crime Victims Act, was an unconstitutional restriction of free speech in violation of the First and Fifth Amendments of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The defendants sought declaratory and injunctive relief, but the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: In 2013, a prisoner in Pennsylvania state prison filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that his 22 years of solitary confinement violated the Eighth Amendment as well as his Fourteenth Amendment right to due process.[SENTMARKER]In 2016, the parties concluded successful mediation as a result of systemic changes to Pennsylvania's policies concerning solitary confinement and the case was dismissed.
pegasus_output_sents: In May 2013, a prisoner with serious mental illness and intellectual disabilities (SMI/ID) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania against the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections (DOC) and the Secretary of the DOC.[SENTMARKER]The prisoner alleged that his prolonged years in solitary confinement deprived him of physical health and exercise.[SENTMARKER]He also alleged that the conditions of his solitary confinement were cruel and unusual punishment under the Eighth Amendment of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the prisoner was subjected to a mandatory strip search and the possibility of a body-cavity search every time he left his cell.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the prisoner's request for declaratory and injunctive relief, including placement in general population, as well as compensatory and punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]The Department of Justice's investigation was conducted under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), which prohibits a pattern or practice of deprivation of constitutional rights of individuals confined to state or local government-run correctional facilities.[SENTMARKER]The department opened its statewide investigation into the use of solitary confinement on prisoners in May 2013 after finding a pattern of constitutional violations and violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) at the State Correctional Institution in Cresson, Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The case was brought by the ACLU's Special Litigation Section and the Office of the Governor of the Pennsylvania Civil Rights Division.

gold_sents: On February 3, 2010, a group of 11 individuals held in Virginia prisons filed a class action lawsuit against the Virginia Parole Board for denying parole requests because of the nature and circumstances of the crimes they had been convicted of committing.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case with prejudice, and the Fourth Circuit affirmed.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2010, a group of inmates in the custody of the Virginia Department of Corrections (DOC) brought this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia alleging that the Virginia Parole Board's practices, policies and procedures violated their constitutional rights with respect to discretionary parole.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs alleged that the parole board's reliance on the "serious nature and circumstances of the crime" as a basis for denying parole was arbitrary and violated their rights under the Due Process Clause and the Ex Post Facto Clause of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case, but the plaintiffs appealed to the 4th Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The appeals court upheld the district court's dismissal of the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2015, the plaintiff filed this in the U.S. District Court of Vermont alleging disability-based discrimination while incarcerated.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought declaratory, injunctive, compensatory, and punitive relief and the judge dismissed the matter after the parties reached a full settlement.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 7, 2016, Disability Rights Vermont filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Vermont against the State of Vermont, the Vermont Department of Corrections, and the Vermont Agency of Human Services (DAIL) under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Fair Housing and Public Accommodations Act (VFHPAA) against the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants willfully and knowingly caused Plaintiff to be held in unnecessarily segregated circumstances when he would be eligible for community placement if the appropriate, State-funded available community supports and services were implemented.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff was diagnosed with schizo-affective disorder and depression, among other diagnoses, and was incarcerated at the Southern State Correctional Facility in Springfield, Vermont.[SENTMARKER]On information and belief, Plaintiff would have been eligible for State and federal funded community supports, such as Choices for Care (CFC) and Community Rehabilitation Treatment (CRT) services, if released from incarceration.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff has been held in prison despite facts and circumstances demonstrating he is eligible for release into the community but for a lack of community-based supports funded by Defendants.[SENTMARKER]On June 6, 2016, Judge William K. Sessions III entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants, finding that the defendant had violated the ADA and the VFHPAA by failing to have a reasonably functional system in place to identify and implement appropriate disability-related supports in the community to prevent continued, unnecessary and harmful institutionalization.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment ordered the defendants to pay the plaintiff injunctive and punitive damages, with the right to petition, upon good cause shown within 60 days, to reopen the case if settlement is not consummated.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: In 2016, current and former public housing residents filed this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged rampant discrimination on the basis of race and family status, rent overcharges, and a failure to maintain rental units.[SENTMARKER]After participating in settlement conferences, the plaintiffs agreed to dismiss the case with prejudice and without costs in July 2017.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 13, 2017, current and former residents of the Alexander County Housing Authority (ACHA) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that ACHA discriminated against residents of its McBride and Elmwood family housing developments based on their race and familial status, in violation of the Fair Housing Act and Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that the defendants violated ACHA's residential lease by refusing to place families with children in certain public housing developments, such as Connell Smith, Shoemaker, and several of the scattered site developments, and improperly reserved them for seniors and people with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled the case in August 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which ACHA agreed to pay the plaintiffs a total of $325,000.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the defendants to pay a civil penalty of $225,000.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendants agreed to refrain from discriminating on the basis of race and family status in the future.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: The NAACP and individual people sued the city of San Jose and political officials for policing tactics that allegedly deprived them of their First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, protesting systemic racism in policing, alleged that the police used excessive force in a racially motivated manner to end the protests.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 29, 2020, the San Jose Peace and Justice Center (SJPJC) filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the City of San Jose and the San José Police Department.[SENTMARKER]The SJPJC alleged that the defendants violated the plaintiffs' First Amendment rights by imposing a city-wide curfew on demonstrators protesting the police killing of George Floyd on May 29, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive and declaratory relief, including damages, injunctive relief, and attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: This is a lawsuit brought by several black activist groups, legal organizations, and news media outlets, against the heads of various federal agencies, including the DHS, ICE, Federal Protective Services, and the DOJ.[SENTMARKER]They argued that the deployment to Chicago of these federal agencies by President Trump during the protests that ensued after the police killing of George Floyd were unlawful and unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]They argued that the defendants violated the First, Fourth, and Tenth Amendments by using these agents, and that they were in conspiracy to deprive Chicago residents of their rights.[SENTMARKER]When Joe Biden replaced Donald Trump as President, the change in administration mooted the case.[SENTMARKER]It was voluntarily dismissed by the plaintiffs in January 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: The National Lawyers Guild Chicago, Black America, Washington Baltimore News Guild, CWA Local 32035, and First Defense Legal Aid filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and the City of Chicago.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the First, Fourth, and Tenth Amendments by sending law enforcement infiltrators to surveil protest groups and using technology to spy on the communications of protesters and organizers.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order on standing grounds, and plaintiff subsequently dismissed the case.

gold_sents: Individuals issued summonses by the NYPD without probable cause brought a class action suit against the City of New York.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that the NYPD's 'quota' policy is linked to officer promotion and demotion, and as a result, leads to commanding officers ordering police officers to arrest and issue summonses to individuals without probable cause, in contravention of the federal and state constitutions.[SENTMARKER]Judge Sweet, in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York, granted the case class action status in April 2012.[SENTMARKER]On January 24, 2017, Judge Sweet preliminary approved the parties' settlement agreement, in which the parties agreed to settlement benefits of up to seventy-five million dollars.[SENTMARKER]On April 18, 2017, the court granted final approval.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing for compliance purposes.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 25, 2010, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the New York City Police Department (NYPD) and Raymond W. Kelly (together with the City) alleging that the NYPD violated the constitutional rights of New Yorkers by issuing criminal summonses to those who were later dismissed upon a judicial finding of facial insufficiency or who were ticketed without probable cause.[SENTMARKER]The class was represented by Cohen Fitch LLP, a law firm that has previously litigated civil rights actions against the City.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on January 23, 2017, in which the parties agreed to pay $18,500 for attorneys' fees and costs, subject to Court approval.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is non-collusive and does not require the NYPD to train, discipline, or supervise officers regarding their obligation not to issue summonses without a constitutional basis.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: On August 28, 1997, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a complaint against the City of Steubenville pursuant to 42 U.S.C. §14141 in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Ohio to remedy an alleged pattern or practice of unconstitutional misconduct by officers of the Steubenville Police Department.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into consent decree contemporaneously with filing the complaint.[SENTMARKER]Monitoring and reporting continued into 2005, when the parties filed and the court granted a joint motion for termination.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 28, 1997, the U.S. Department of Justice and the City of Steubenville, Ohio filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the City had violated the federal civil rights law by failing to hire a police chief from outside the city.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree on September 3, 1997.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the City to develop and implement an internal affairs policy for all of its police officers as well as to provide training in communications skills and avoid representation by the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]On May 8, 2006, the defendants moved for summary judgment on all of the plaintiffs' claims.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the motion in part, holding that there were genuine issues of material fact on the warrantless-entry, excessive-force, and false-arrest claims.[SENTMARKER]On March 3, 2005, the district court ordered the termination of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss, claiming that the relief sought by the plaintiff was in direct contradiction to the terms of the Consent Decree.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the defendants' Motion to Consolidate on May 8, 2006 and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: In July 2008, the plaintiffs sued the City of Tenaha under the Fourth Amendment (unreasonable search and seizure) and the Fourteenth Amendment (equal protection).[SENTMARKER]They claimed that law enforcement officials in and around the City of Tenaha have developed an illegal practice of targeting, stopping, detaining, searching, and often seizing property from people who appeared to be non-white or who were traveling with non-white passengers.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that they had been victims of such stops and seizures of amounts up to $50,000, as well as false prosecution or detention.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a preliminary settlement in August 2012.[SENTMARKER]Their proposed consent decree included: video and audio recordings of all stops; written documentation with details of the stop; no more dog searches in routine traffic stops; written and oral consent for a search; all asset forfeiture revenue must be donated to nonprofits or used for audio/video equipment or training; and use of an impartial monitor.[SENTMARKER]The court approved the consent decree, which it later extended to early 2021 after the plaintiffs alleged noncompliance by the City.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2008, a group of African-American residents of Shelby County, Texas filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Texas against the Shelby County District Attorney's Office, Shelby County Precinct Constables, and Shelby County Life Insurance Company.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' practice of targeting, stopping, detaining, searching, and often seizing property from individuals who are, or appear to be, members of a racial or ethnic minority and their passengers violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The parties negotiated and agreed to a consent decree in August 2012.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree provided remedies for the plaintiffs' complaints, including that the defendant would not use canines during traffic stops and would provide written notice to any person before a canine sniff is used at a traffic stop and before seeking consent to conduct a search.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to institute internal review procedures every quarter to ensure compliance with the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the consent Decree were preliminarily approved by the court in August 2012 and the parties entered into an interlocal agreement with the district attorney's office.[SENTMARKER]The court stayed its ruling on the motion for class certification pending the Supreme Court's ruling in Wal-Mart the interdiction program.

gold_sents: In 2021, the ACLU and private counsel brought this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California in response to President Trump’s June 11, 2020 Executive Order authorizing economic sanctions against individuals who assist the International Criminal Court in investigating or prosecuting war crimes.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act and §706 of the Administrative Procedure Act. They sought declaratory relief and an injunction that would prevent the Trump Administration from implementing or enforcing the Executive Order.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 15, 2020, the ACLU filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the United States, President Donald J. Trump, Secretary of State Michael R. Pompeo, and the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) and the International Criminal Court (ICC) alleging that the defendants violated the First Amendment rights of the plaintiffs by imposing sanctions on them.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as a declaration invalidating the Executive Order and its implementing steps, and an order enjoining the defendants from implementing or enforcing IEEPA's civil or criminal penalty provisions against the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion for summary judgment, which was denied.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: The Alliance Party and two third-party presidential sued the District of Columbia Board of Elections.[SENTMARKER]The D.C. city government had lowered the signatures required for ballot qualification from 5,007 to 250 on August 6, 2020, the day after petitions to appear on the ballot were due.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs contended that they had ceased collecting signatures because it was "impossible" to collect 5,007 signatures while adhering to social distancing guidelines, but would have continued their efforts if they knew they only had to get 250.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied a motion for temporary restraining order, the 2020 election was held and this case was dismissed soon after.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 5, 2020, the Alliance Party of the District of Columbia filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the district of Columbia against the D.C. Board of Elections.[SENTMARKER]The Alliance Party alleged that the District's failure to reduce the signature requirement for third party and independent presidential candidates violated the First Amendment and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunctive relief and an emergency temporary restraining order enjoining the District from enforcing the deadline for third-party presidential candidates to file election petitions and extending the deadline to September 1, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The Court also granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The parties are continuing to appeal the Court's decision.

gold_sents: In 2015, residents of Jefferson County, Florida filed this action in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the county's 2013 redistricting plan was guilty of "prison-based gerrymandering," and was thus guilty of violating the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought and received a declaration that the 2013 plan was unconstitutional as well as an injunction requiring the defendants to produce an acceptable redistricting plan.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' plan was approved and parties then settled on the attorneys' fees.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 22, 1983, a group of residents of Jefferson County, Florida filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Florida against the Jefferson County Board of Commissioners and Jefferson County School Board.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the county's 2013 redistricting plan violated the Fourteenth Amendment right to equal representation under the "one person, one vote" principle of the Equal Protection Clause.[SENTMARKER]The parties sought declaratory and injunctive relief, and enjoined the county from using county-wide atlarge elections in a manner that violates the Voting Rights Act, ECF No. 52-1, at 7; .<n>Plaintiffs' Cross-Motion for Summary Judgment was granted by Judge Maurice M. Paul, and the parties agreed to settle issues relating to attorney's fees and litigation expense reimbursement.[SENTMARKER]On March 19, 2016, the court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Several citizens and residents of Arizona subject to the death penalty brought suit under 42 U.S.C. §1983 against the Arizona Department of Corrections (ADC) and several associated governmental employees.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that the ADC's lethal injection procedure violated their First Amendment right to access governmental proceedings, the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment, the Eighth Amendment, and the Federal Supremacy Clause.[SENTMARKER]The parties came to a stipulated agreement prohibiting the defendant from using certain chemicals for execution, among other limitation.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing after the Ninth Circuit remanded counts for retrial.

gold_sents: In 2012, plaintiffs filed suit in the Eastern District of Michigan, alleging that the Sex Offender Registration Act (SORA), when applied retroactively, violated their rights to due process, was unconstitutionally vague, violated prohibitions on ex post facto laws, and violated their fundamental rights.[SENTMARKER]In 2018, upon remand from the Sixth Circuit, the district court held that SORA violated the Ex Post Facto clause and could not be applied retroactively.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 16, 2012, two registered sex offenders filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan challenging the constitutionality of Michigan's Sex Offender Registration Act (SORA) as amended in 2011.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that SORA violated the Ex Post Facto clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by imposing a lifetime registration requirement on certain sex offenders who had not been convicted of a sex offense.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that the registration and address verification procedures required under SORA were similar to those required under Megan's Law.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion to dismiss, and the case was dismissed and sealed.[SENTMARKER]The case is now before the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]On September 15, 2016, the court remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be dismissed, but the parties disagreed on the issue of whether SORA's registration requirements for life, rather than for twenty-five years, were narrowly tailored to those government interests and left alternative channels for communication.[SENTMARKER]The Sixth Circuit held that the sex offender registration requirements were not unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of the United States has not yet issued a decision on the case.

gold_sents: On June 28, 2018, Black Love Resists in the Rust and four individual plaintiffs filed this class action lawsuit against the City of Buffalo in the Western District of New York.[SENTMARKER]They claimed that the Buffalo Police Department disproportionately used vehicle checkpoints in Black and Latino communities to generate revenue, resulting in disparate impact on Black and Latino people.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought an injunction to end and remediate these traffic enforcement practices, as well as monetary damages for the financial harm, humiliation, and loss of liberty and property.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed an amended complaint on May 21, 2020; the case is ongoing.

gold_sents: On January 1, 2014, deaf and hard of hearing inmates in the Kentucky prison system filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky against the Commonwealth of Kentucky and the Kentucky Department of Corrections, alleging violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Rehabilitation Act, and the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed that they were denied access to telecommunications and denied interpretative services for religious services, job training, disciplinary hearings, public announcements, educational and vocational training effectively excluding them from many governmental services.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached settlement which was entered by the court in a consent decree in June, 2015.[SENTMARKER]A monitor was appointed, who will submit a  semi-annual report during the five-year term of the settlement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement includes provision of services and accommodations through a qualified interpreter and communication technologies, staffing, and training.

gold_sents: Students in Mobile County schools sued the county for violations of the Fourteenth Amendment Right to Due Process by denying the students a hearing before issuing long-term suspensions and expulsions.[SENTMARKER]The case entered mediation and was settled on the terms of the agreement that amended the school district's disciplinary procedures and practices.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 12, 2011, eight Mobile County Public School students filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Alabama against the Board of School Commissioners of Mobile County (the "Board").[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Board violated their Fourteenth Amendment rights to due process by imposing long-term suspensions on students without providing even the reduced due process required by the District's challenged policy.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the Board agreed to provide the plaintiffs with reasonable career preparation assistance and assistance with the graduation exam.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and dismissed the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2017, four low-income African American mothers filed suit against the numerous officials of the State of Mississippi claiming the state failed to live up to the educational requirements set by the Mississippi Readmission Act of 1870.[SENTMARKER]They sought declaratory relief that the requirements are still intact.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed in 2018 due to the state sovereign immunity under the Eleventh Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the Fifth Circuit which affirmed in part and reversed in part.[SENTMARKER]The defendants requested rehearing en banc, but the Fifth Circuit denied the request.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then filed a petition for review with the Supreme Court and a request to stay the Fifth Circuit's mandate in January 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In May 2017, a group of low-income African-American women filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Mississippi had violated the federal education clause of the Mississippi Constitution by amending the education clause after its ratification following the Civil War.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that the changes had resulted in a grave disparity in the education being provided to students who attend either predominantly White or predominantly Black schools around the state.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case on several grounds, including the Political Question Doctrine, the Mississippi Readmission Act, and the Eleventh Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the plaintiffs moved for leave to amend their complaint to cure the pleading defects that they believe resulted in the dismissal of this case.[SENTMARKER]The case was re-opened and the district court entered an amended Final Judgment dismissing the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to dismiss the case without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]On remand, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion to dismiss under 12(b)(1) and (b)(6), holding that it lacked jurisdiction based on Eleventh Amendment sovereign immunity.

gold_sents: This federal lawsuit was filed in 2000 in the Eastern District of California; in it, a former high school student and the Gay-Straight Alliance Network sued his school district for failure to take effective measures to remedy continuing harassment that he faced based on his sexual orientation.[SENTMARKER]The case settled for a consent decree entered August 15, 2002, which required the defendants to implement a mandatory staff training program, revise its policies, select compliance coordinators, develop systems for reporting harassment and discrimination, allow students to form a gay-straight alliance, and create a community advisory group.[SENTMARKER]The decree implementation period was 6 months.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 8, 2009, a high school student and his younger sister, through their parents and next friends, brought this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York against the Indian River Central School District, its Board of Education, Superintendent, agents, and employees, alleging discrimination based on sexual orientation and sex in violation of Title IX of the Education Amendments Act of 1972 (EAA) and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution (E.C.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants repeatedly denied their requests to form a Gay-Straight Alliance (GSA) organization.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that they were subjected to unwelcome sexual harassment in the form of sexual advances, requests for sexual favors, or other verbal or physical conduct of a sexual nature.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the district court dismissed the case in part and denied the plaintiffs' claim for punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: In August 2002, the New York City Office of the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York, alleging that the City's use of written examinations to select entry-level firefighters violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that black and Hispanic applicants were affected by the City’s examinations.[SENTMARKER]In July 2009, Judge Weinfeld found the City liable for unconstitutionally discriminating against black applicants in violation of Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed letters stating their views on the Wal-Mart effect on June 21, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied certification of both the disparate impact and disparate treatment claims Id.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed in January 2010.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement, which required the City to implement a new hiring policy, post a notice on its website, post the results of the written examinations on the website, and post a message on the social media platforms of the city's employees.[SENTMARKER]The decree did not include a provision of attorneys' fees to counsel for Plaintiff-Intervenors.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted summary judgment to the Teamsters under the terms of the settlement agreement.
