pegasus_output_sents: On June 22, 2006, the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania against Schott North America, Inc. (SchOTT) alleging that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by subjecting the EEOC's female employees and a class of female employees to a discriminatory layoff process which resulted in the loss of their jobs due to their gender.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants had a practice of providing training for workers who transferred from the cold end to the hot end.[SENTMARKER]Male workers decorated their work areas with nude pictures of women from pornographic magazines.[SENTMARKER]The defendants denied that this practice took place.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendants agreed to pay monetary relief to the EEOC, provide anti-discrimination training to all of its supervisory and managerial personnel, and promote supervisor accountability by the following conduct: (a) Requiring all managers and supervisors to report any incidents and/or complaints of sex discrimination of which they become aware to the Defendant's Human Resources Department located at the Duryea, Pennsylvania facility; .[SENTMARKER](b) providing a copy of its policy or policies against sex discrimination to all employees and newly-hired employees within 90 days after entry of this Decree; .[SENTMARKER](c) Imposing on all supervisors and managers a duty to administer their work area to ensure compliance with the policy and policies; and (d) requiring the defendants to provide the EEOC with written reports annually for a period of three years following entry of the Decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered into by the court on June 22, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the following terms: (i) In addition to the training, the defendant agreed to post a notice of Title VII in its Duryea facility, the notice shall remain posted for three (3) years; .[SENTMARKER](ii) the defendant would not discriminate on the basis of sex; .[SENTMARKER](iii) provide its employees with any and all copies of its policies or policies regarding sex discrimination; .[SENTMARKER](iv) require the defendant to maintain records of any incident or complaints of sexual discrimination occurring at the facility during the duration of the consent decree; .[SENTMARKER](v) the defendants would be required to pay the EEOC for its expenses, costs, and attorneys' fees; .[SENTMARKER](vi) the parties would bear their own expenses, and attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]The decree would continue to be in effect for three years.

gold_sents: In June 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed this complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]A month later, the complainant intervened into the case as a plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]Judge T. NIxon was assigned to the case.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged sexual and racial harassment in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The complainant, an African American woman, experienced sexual and racial harassment by a fellow co-worker, a white man, at the Whirlpool Corporation.[SENTMARKER]The complainant’s supervisors failed to take action, and the events escalated until the co-worker physically attacked the complainant.[SENTMARKER]In 2009, the court found in favor of the plaintiffs that granted $1,073,261 in monetary relief.[SENTMARKER]And in 2011, the court awarded $210,039 in attorney fees and costs to the plaintiff.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 6, 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee against Whirlpool Corporation.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged racial and sexual discrimination in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the defendant failed to take reasonable care to prevent or correct the harassing behavior of a co-worker because of her sex and race, and that her complaints to her supervisors were ignored by the defendant.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the EEOC's motion for summary judgment, and the parties settled the case for $1,073,261.00 in front pay and back pay and $300,000.00 in compensatory damages.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a Motion to Alter or Amend the Judgment on January 15, 2010.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the motion on March 31, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion to amend or amend the judgment on June 12, 2008.[SENTMARKER]On July 27, 2008, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment required the defendant to pay the EEOC $37,5141.97 in attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On December 19, 2018 two US Airmen under pseudonym and OutServe-SLDN, a network of LGBTQ military service-people, filed suit against the U.S. Department of Defense, James Mattis, and Heather Wilson in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs argued that the U.S had violated equal protection under the fifth amendment and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs represented by Winston and Strawn LLP, LAMBDA Legal Defense and Education Fund, and Outserve-SLDN (now known as the Modern Military Association of America) sought declaratory and injunctive relief allowing HIV positive service members to continue to serve and damages.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs allege that they were discharged from their duties in the Air Force due to their HIV status.[SENTMARKER]The case was assigned to Judge Leonie M. Brinkema.[SENTMARKER]On January 11, 2019, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction to  prevent the defendants from restricting Roe and Voe and others similarly situated from being promoted, changing duty station, or re-training on the same terms as other service members living with HIV who are not being separated.[SENTMARKER]A hearing was held before Judge Brinkema on February 15, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The same day, Judge Brinkema issued an opinion granting in part and denying in part the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The order enjoined the defendants from separating or dicharging from military service Richard Roe, Victor Voe, and any other similarly situated active-duty member of the Air Force because they are classified as ineligible for worldwide deployment or deployment to the United States Central Command area due to their HIV-positive status.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed to the decision on the preliminary injunction to the Fourth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]Oral argument was held on September 18, 2019 before a panel of Fourth Circuit Judges comprised of Judges James A. Wynn Jr, Albert Diaz, and Henry F. Floyd.[SENTMARKER]In January 2020, the Fourth Circuit issued an opinion affirming the district court's decision.[SENTMARKER]In the district court, both parties have filed motions for summary judgment, and oral argument is set for August 4, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 27, 2020, a group of active-duty members of the U.S. Air Force and a non-profit organization, OutServe-SLDN, Inc., filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia against the Department of Defense and the Secretary of Defense.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act and the equal protection component of the Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the case, arguing that OutServe lacked standing to sue.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss in part and denied the government's motion for a preliminary injunction in part.[SENTMARKER]The parties then appealed to the 4th Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The appeals court upheld the district court's dismissal of the case on May 3, 2019.

gold_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission brought an anti-discrimination lawsuit against United Airlines.[SENTMARKER]The claim was that United Airlines discriminated against its employees when it denied employees with disabilities a reduced hours schedule as an accommodation.[SENTMARKER]On December 17, 2010, the court approved a consent decree which required United Airlines to consider a reduced-hours schedule as a reasonable accommodation for employees with disabilities and awarded the plaintiff $600,000 in damages.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was set to terminate three years from date of entry unless the EEOC asked for a continuation.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed, as there are no further activity on this case's docket as of March 2019.
pegasus_output_sents: The EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against United Air Lines, Inc. (UAL) on September 13, 2008.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that UAL violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by requiring its employees to work a minimum of 30 hours and five days per week in violation of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that United failed to provide reasonable accommodation to its employees with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which United agreed to pay a total of $600,000 in damages.[SENTMARKER]The decree is final and binding upon the parties to it, their successors 27 and assigns.[SENTMARKER]In light of the Ninth Circuit's mandate issued on October 6, 2009, the case is back to active status.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: Private citizens sought an exception to the Affordable Care Act mandate requiring employers to provide contraception coverage on that basis that paying for this insurance plan violated their Catholic religious beliefs.[SENTMARKER]On October 16, 2013, the Eastern District of Missouri (Judge Jean C. Hamilton) dismissed the claim for want of standing, but on July 20, 2015, the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals reversed and remanded for merits decision.[SENTMARKER]Judge Hamilton dismissed all but one of the plaintiff's claims but granted summary judgment in favor of the plaintiff on that claim, enjoining the defendants from requiring the plaintiffs to pay for contraception through their insurance.[SENTMARKER]The government appealed this determination, but following President Trump's May 4, 2017 executive order directing a change in regulations to allow for conscience-based exceptions to the contraceptive-care mandate, the parties agreed to have the case dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 20, 2013, a Missouri couple filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri against the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act of 2010 (ACA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that HHS's enforcement or threatened enforcement of the mandate violated their religious rights under the Religious Freedom Restoration Act of 1993 (RFRA), the First and Fifth Amendments to the United States Constitution, the Free Exercise, Free Speech, and Due Process Clauses, and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction enjoining HHS from requiring that their health benefit plan contain coverage for contraceptives, sterilization procedures and patient education and counseling for all women with reproductive capacity.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the plaintiffs' complaint with prejudice and without reaching the merits.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the district court for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

gold_sents: On May 17, 2018, the plaintiff, a catholic foster care and social services agency, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against the City of Philadelphia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the City's decision to stop referring foster care discriminated against them for their religious beliefs and violated their contract, constitutional rights, and state law.[SENTMARKER]On June 13, 2018, Judge Petrese B. Tucker denied the plaintiffs motion for a preliminary injunction holding that the City of Philadelphia was entitled to suspend the contract for violations of the City Fair Ordinance which prohibited discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed on the same day, and the Third Circuit affirmed the lower court's decision on April 22, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing, and the Supreme Court granted the plaintiff's petition for writ of certiorari on February 24, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 17, 2018, Catholic Social Services (CSS) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against the City of Philadelphia and the Philadelphia Commission on Human Relations.[SENTMARKER]CSS alleged that the City's Fair Practices Ordinance (FPO) violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments by barring it from participating in the city's foster care program.[SENTMARKER]The District Court denied the motion for preliminary injunctive relief, and the parties appealed to the Third Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The Third Circuit affirmed the district court's denial of the plaintiffs' request for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]On April 22, 2019, the court entered judgment in favor of the City, concluding that the FFO was not a violation of CSS's First Amendment rights under the First, Establishment, and Freedom-of-Speech Clauses, as well as under Pennsylvania's Religious Freedom Protection Act.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs challenged a city ordinance prohibiting residents from living in trailers or homes worth less than $7500.[SENTMARKER]Less than a week after plaintiffs filed their complaint suit, the City changed the ordinance and eliminated the provision at issue.[SENTMARKER]Ultimately the parties settled outside of court for roughly $20,000.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 12, 2016, a group of residents of McCrory, Arkansas filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the city's Trailer-Banishment Ordinance was unconstitutional because it banned residents living in mobile homes worth less than $7,500 from being placed within the city.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as damages to compensate for injuries suffered.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In August 2017, the Department of Housing and Urban Development (“HUD”) abruptly announced it would delay, by two years, a rule designed to allow low-income families greater choice in their housing options.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs argued that HUD’s failure to implement the rule violated the Administrative Procedure Act, and they sought a preliminary injunction, which was granted.[SENTMARKER]HUD then agreed to implement the rule and paid the Plaintiffs' attorney's fees.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 15, 2018, a group of low-income housing voucher holders and a nonprofit organization filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) and HUD Secretary Ben Carson.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs challenged HUD's decision to suspend implementation of its own promulgated rule, the Small Area Fair Market Rent Rule (Small Area FMR Rule).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction requiring HUD to implement the rule on its effective date of January 1, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction, finding that the two-year delay of the rule's implementation was arbitrary and capricious.[SENTMARKER]The court also found that HUD had violated the Fair Housing Act of 1968 and the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974 by failing to provide notice or specific evidentiary findings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This case was brought in Indiana federal court and in Michigan federal court by the United States against the developers, builders, and operators of rental apartment complexes in Indiana, Michigan, Illinois, Ohio, Wisconsin, and Virginia.[SENTMARKER]The plantiff claimed the defendants had designed and built apartments that are not accessible to persons with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree that resulted calls for millions of dollars in retrofits to apartments in six different states, and compensatory damages in the amount of $1,060,000.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 18, 2001, and September 3, 2002, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Indiana.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Edward Rose Sons, several affiliate companies, as well as individual architects and architectural firms, have engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination against persons with disabilities by failing to include accessible features required by the Fair Housing Act and the Americans with Disabilities Act in a number of apartment complexes it developed in Indiana, Michigan, Ohio, Wisconsin, Illinois, Virginia, and Nebraska.[SENTMARKER]On February 24, 2003, the court granted a preliminary injunction to enjoin the defendants from occupying or further constructing 19 apartment buildings at Westlake Apartments in Belleville, Michigan and Lake Pointe Apartments in Batavia, Ohio.[SENTMARKER]On August 25, 2004, the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed the decision of the district court granting a preliminary injunctive injunction.[SENTMARKER]On September 30, 2005, the court entered a consent decree, which required the defendants to retrofit 49 apartment complexes to enhance their accessibility to individuals with physical disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree will remain in effect for five years.[SENTMARKER]In the event the parties cannot resolve their differences informally, any party may move the Court for an order compelling compliance with the consent decree.

gold_sents: On September 28, 2020, the Massachusetts Fair Housing Center and Housing Works, Inc. filed a complaint against the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development and the Secretary of HUD in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued the defendants under the Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. §§ 702-703, alleging that a new HUD rule (“the 2020 Rule”) limiting disparate impact claims under the Fair Housing Act was contrary to law and arbitrary and capricious.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought to enjoin the defendants from implementing the 2020 Rule until after this case was resolved and filed a motion for a preliminary injunction on October 6, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs’ motion on October 25, 2020, finding that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits of their claim that the 2020 Rule was arbitrary and capricious.[SENTMARKER]This case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 28, 2020, the Massachusetts Fair Housing Center and Housing Works, Inc. filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) alleging that HUD's implementation of the Fair Housing Act's Disparate Treatment Standard (disparate impact standard) violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Equal Access to Justice Act (E.A.J.).[SENTMARKER]The parties sought declaratory and injunctive relief, including a preliminary injunction, and a temporary restraining order (TRO).[SENTMARKER]The TRO was granted on October 6, 2020, and the parties filed a motion for preliminary injunction and stay on September 29, 2020.[SENTMARKER]On September 29, 2020, the court granted the parties' motion for TRO and granted the plaintiffs' request for a preliminary and stay of the effective date of the 2020 Rule.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a second motion to vacate the final 2020 Rule and set it aside under the Administrative Procedures Act. On February 29, 2019, the court issued a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment is pending entry of the final judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On August 31, 2006, in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky, DOJ simultaneously filed a CRIPA complaint against the state and a settlement agreement between the parties, the latter referencing and attaching the strategic action plan obligating the state to implement remedial measures at the Oakwood Developmental Center.[SENTMARKER]The court monitored implementation of the agreement until 2011, when the case was closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 22, 2001, the U.S. Department of Justice ("DOJ") filed this lawsuit in the U,S.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky against the Commonwealth of Kentucky and the Oakwood Developmental Center, a facility for individuals with developmental disabilities located in Somerset, Kentucky.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act ("CRIPA") by failing to protect its residents from harm due to abuse and mistreatment, failing to maintain a safe environment, inadequate nursing and direct care staff, and inadequate individual support plans ("ISPs") for its residents.[SENTMARKER]On September 29, 2011, the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to implement a Strategic Action Plan ("SAP"), which details methods by which the Commonwealth will operate Oakwood and provide services to residents of the facility.[SENTMARKER]The SAP requires the Commonwealth to implement and maintain a nursing performance improvement process, provide timely and appropriate dental care, and provide residents with adequate preventative medical care designed to keep serious medical problems and disease from developing.[SENTMARKER]The Commonwealth also agreed to provide the DOJ with a copy of the SAP.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on September 29, 2011.

gold_sents: On June 7, 2007, attorneys with the Southern Poverty Law Center filed a class action lawsuit in the U. S.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the Western District of Arkansas on behalf of about 2,700 Mexican migrant workers who entered the United States with H-2A visas and harvested and packed tomatoes and performed other agricultural work in Bradley County, Ark., from 2002 to 2007.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the employers violated the Fair Labor Standards Act ("FLSA"), 29 U.S.C. § 201 et seq. by failing to pay the prevailing wage and overtime wages, and not reimbursing workers for travel, visa and hiring fees.[SENTMARKER]On May 20, 2011, the Court (Judge Harry F. Barnes) granted summary judgment for the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]Later, the parties reached a settlement agreement, and a final version of the agreement was approved by the Court on April 9, 2012, requiring the defendants to pay $1,212,500 in damages and attorney fees to plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]Defendants breached this agreement and the Court entered judgment against them on September 4, 2013.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 31, 2008, a group of Mexican tomato workers filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Arkansas against Candy Brand, LLC, Arkansas Tomato Shippers, LLC and other defendants.[SENTMARKER]The workers alleged that the defendants violated the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) by failing to pay them the minimum and overtime wages required by the FLSA when they worked more than forty hours in a work week in Defendants’ packing shed operations.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the workers claimed that they were not paid properly for their return travel at the end of the season, and did not pay them "subsistence pay" for the days they spent traveling.[SENTMARKER]The class action was certified as a collective action, and the Court conditionally certified the case as a FLSA collective action with respect to the breach of contract claims on October 31, 2008.[SENTMARKER]On December 29, 2011, the Court granted preliminary approval to the class action settlement in this case.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay the workers $1,215,500.00 as part of the settlement.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice, subject to the terms of the agreement.

gold_sents: On August 31, 2010, hourly employees sued their employer under federal and state employment and non-discrimination statutes for requiring plaintiffs to work as many as fourteen hours a day without compensating them with mandatory overtime pay.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs dismissed their federal claims in order to participate in a civil action filed by the U.S. Department of Labor against defendants and the court declined to exercise supplemental jurisdiction over plaintiffs' state law claims.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 21, 2010, a group of current and former employees of Terra Universal, Inc. filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Terra Universal violated the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) by requiring them to work as many as 14 hours a day without overtime pay and, in some cases, without any payment of wages.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs also alleged that the defendants deprived them and other class members of overtime pay on account of their immigration status.[SENTMARKER]On April 14, 2011, the parties submitted a stipulation to dismiss the plaintiffs' claims under the FLSA, which the Court approved on April 18, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs a total of $155,000 in back pay, liquidated damages, and other relief.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: A class-action lawsuit on behalf of people facing deportation proceedings, who are detainees at facilities contracted by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, resulted in a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff-detainees alleged that ICE restricted their telephone access, violating their rights under the First, Fifth, and Sixth Amendments and the Immigration and Nationality Act.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the settlement agreement included provisions for longer access to free and private phone calls in a timely manner, as well as attorneys’ fees.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 16, 2014, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California on behalf of immigration detainees housed in Contra Costa West County Detention Facility, Yuba County Jail, Rio Cosumnes Correctional Center, and Mesa Verde Detention Facility.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the cost of phone calls to the detention facilities was unreasonably expensive, particularly as many detainees were indigent.[SENTMARKER]The court certified the class under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(b)(2).[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in which the parties agreed to pay $405,000 to class counsel to settle claims for attorneys' fees and costs incurred in this litigation.[SENTMARKER]The settlement will be in effect for four years after that.[SENTMARKER]The case is currently pending in the San Francisco Immigration Court.

gold_sents: On June 4, 2013, plaintiffs, natives of Mexico who had agreed to voluntary departure from the United States, filed this class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the Central District of California under the Immigration and Nationality Act ("INA"), 8 U.S.C. §1101, and state law against the acting director of Homeland Security, U.S. Customs and Border Protection ("CBP") and Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement ("ICE").[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendant's agencies in southern California violated INA by coercing plaintiffs into accepting voluntary departure through misstatements, omissions, threats, and/or pressure in violation of defendants' own regulations.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled on March 11, 2015, where defendants agreed to allow applications from the class members that would enable their return to the United States and their legal position prior to acceptance of voluntary departure.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 4, 2013, a group of individuals and three non-profit organizations filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Bureau of Immigration and Custome Enforcement (ICE) seeking declaratory and injunctive relief under the Administrative Procedure Act, the Immigration and Nationality Act, and the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DHS and ICE's voluntary departure program for foreign nationals who were present in the United States without gold_sents: On July 10, 2018, the ACLU of Northern California filed this FOIA suit against U.S. Immigrations and Customs Enforcement.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought records pursuant to a FOIA request about the defendant's use of a contractor to process and transport immigration detainees, some of whom had allegedly suffered injury and death due to the contractor's malfeasance.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought an order from the court that the defendant provide the records.[SENTMARKER]This case was combined with a suit from a private plaintiff alleging mistreatment in ICE and G4S custody in July 2019.[SENTMARKER]Document production appears to be continuing smoothly at a rate of 750 pages per month, but shifting production online due to COVID-19 has yielded some issues in getting documents over to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]Document production is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 18, 2017, the American Civil Liberties Union of Northern California (ACLU-NC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security, Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) seeking information about the treatment of immigration detainees in ICE's San Francisco Area of Responsibility.[SENTMARKER]On April 6, 2018, the ACLU-NC and East Bay Express, a local independent newspaper, submitted a FOIA request to ICE seeking records about the detention and transport of individuals in 11 immigration custody in the San Francisco area (the "First FOIA Request").[SENTMARKER]As of the date of the filing of this complaint, the ACLU has not received a determination from ICE as to whether ICE will comply with the First FOIA Request.[SENTMARKER]ICE has failed to produce any records in response to the Second FOIA Request, which was filed on April 13, 2018 and received by the ICE 13 FOIA Office on April 25, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The ACLU has exhausted the applicable administrative remedies with respect to ICE’s 10 wrongful withholdings of the requested records.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff has suffered irreparable injury from the unlawful withholding of government documents pertaining to the subject of 13 FOIA requests.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the ACLU's motion for injunctive and declaratory relief, and ordered ICE to produce documents responsive to the FOIA requests by the ACLU.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This case was filed in response to the July 6, 2020 directive by ICE that would effectively force international students studying under F-1 and M-1 visas to attend in-person classes or risk deportation.[SENTMARKER]The state of California filed this suit against ICE and DHS on July 9, arguing that the directive was in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) in two ways.[SENTMARKER]First, the directive was arbitrary and capricious in that it failed to take into account students' and universities' reliance interests and the defendants gave no reasoned basis for the new order.[SENTMARKER]Second, the defendants were in violation of procedural elements of the APA, because they failed to use proper notice-and-comment rule-making when issuing the new order.[SENTMARKER]On July 15, in a different lawsuit filed against the administration over the same July directive, plaintiffs met with counsel for the government and worked to get the regulations rescinded.[SENTMARKER]In order to effectuate the rescission, ICE removed the guidance from its website and replaced it with the previous guidance and as a result, plaintiffs withdrew their motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]California continued to monitor the alterations ICE made to its website between July and September and filed a notice of voluntary dismissal on October 19, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 13, 2020, the State of California filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, alleging that the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) rescinded the in-person learning exemption for F-1 and M-1 nonimmigrant students in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) policy.[SENTMARKER]The State alleged that the rescission violated the APA because it was arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, or otherwise not in accordance with law.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to declaratory, injunctive, and other relief.[SENTMARKER]On July 3, 2020, the court granted the State's motion for summary judgment, and granted the defendants' motion for partial summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On July 20, 2010, the American Immigration Lawyers Association (AILA) filed suit against the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia for failing to adequately respond to FOIA requests regarding USCIS procedures for inspecting potential H-1B visa fraud.[SENTMARKER]On March 30, 2012, the District Court ordered DHS to provide adequate description of the exempted information in response to the FOIA request so that AILA could make a proper segregability determination.[SENTMARKER]This was the last action in this case.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 29, 2011, the American Immigration Lawyers Association (AILA) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA).[SENTMARKER]AILA sought the release of records concerning agency policies and procedures relating to nonimmigrant temporary workers and particularly the adjudication of petitions for their lawful employment in the US.[SENTMARKER]The parties sought declaratory, injunctive, and other appropriate relief with respect to the unlawful withholding of these records by the DHS and the USCIS with oversight responsibility for immigration to the US, and the alleged applicability of FOIA exemptions to the records sought by AILA.[SENTMARKER]AILA appealed the withholding of the responsive record from disclosure by DHS and USCIS to the Court.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted AILA's motion for summary judgment, finding that the defendants had complied with their FOIA obligations and had not waived their ability to invoke FOIA exemptions, including 7(E) of the FOIA.[SENTMARKER]In a cross-motion for summary judgement, the defendants sought summary judgment as to the entirety of their searches and subsequent responses to plaintiff's FOIA requests.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' summary judgment motion, but denied the parties' motion for expedited processing.

gold_sents: Central American mothers and children detainees brought suit against the Department of Homeland Security and its various agencies for the government's unlawful expedited removal policies at the Artesia Family Residential Center.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the case in January 2015 after DHS remedied the violations of Plaintiffs' rights in their immigration proceedings and closed the Artesia facility.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 22, 2014, a mother and her two daughters from El Salvador and Honduras filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) seeking relief under the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the government's new expedited removal policies and procedures made it difficult for detained women and children with bona fide asylum claims to present and substantiate their claims to asylum or other forms of immigration relief, and to seek the assistance of counsel in doing so.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were detained at the Artesia Family Residential Center, a detention facility in New Mexico.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on January 30, 2015 without prejudice.

gold_sents: On June 20, 2018, three immigrant parents separated from their children filed a civil action against various federal agencies and officials in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia for immediate reunification with their children.The plaintiffs were detained after crossing the United States-Mexico border without inspection with young accompanying children, seeking asylum.[SENTMARKER]After plaintiffs were apprehended at the border, the children were separated under the “zero-tolerance” immigration policy announced April 6, 2018, which criminally prosecuted adult entrants crossing the border illegally and placed accompanying minors in custody of the government.[SENTMARKER]All three plaintiffs crossed the border prior to the Executive Order issued on June 20, 2018, which allowed immigrant parents and children apprehended at the border to remain together during the pendency of their proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged interference of family integrity in violation of Due Process, and sought preliminary and permanent injunctions to immediately reunite plaintiffs with their children.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs obtained preliminary relief and were (along with another parent who joined the case later to prevent separation from her daughter) ultimately re-united with their children.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 20, 2018, three immigrant parents who were separated from their young children filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and certain federal agencies and officials responsible for enforcing immigration laws and regulations.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction requiring the government to immediately reunify their children with their parents by July 10, 2018, and those age five and over by July 26, 2018.[SENTMARKER]On June 22, 2018, the plaintiffs filed an application for a temporary restraining order requiring defendants, inter alia, to provide reliable, daily information about the well-being of their children.[SENTMARKER]On July 9, 2018, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a TRO in abeyance and suggested that the parties meet and confer and provide a joint status report to the Court.[SENTMARKER]The court granted plaintiffs' TRO with respect to certain outstanding requests on July 16, 2018.[SENTMARKER]On July 6, 2018, the Court issued a class-wide preliminary injunction ordering the government not to separate children from their parents.[SENTMARKER]On June 26, 2018, the government agreed to comply with the court's order, but the court denied plaintiffs' request for a writ of habeas corpus.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This action, filed Jan.[SENTMARKER]31, 2017, challenges President Trump’s Jan.[SENTMARKER]27, 2017 Executive Order ban on admission to the U.S. of nationals of Iraq, Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleges that in preventing a Syrian national with a valid U.S. visa from returning to the U.S. pursuant to the EO, the defendants violated the First Amendment Establishment Clause, Fifth Amendment due process and equal protection rights, the Immigration and Nationality Act, the Administrative Procedure Act, and international law.[SENTMARKER]The case was filed in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff seeks declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, represented by private counsel and Bernard Harcourt of Columbia Law School, is a resident in the University of Illinois Chicago/Advocate Christ Hospital.[SENTMARKER]He returned to the United Arab Emirates to get married on Jan.[SENTMARKER]23, and upon returning to the U.S. to continue his residency, he was detained at Abu Dhabi International Airport on Jan 29.[SENTMARKER]Despite his valid visa, he was detained pursuant to the EO.[SENTMARKER]If the plaintiff cannot return to the U.S., he faces the risk of being deported to Syria, where he is a citizen but has never been a resident.[SENTMARKER]That same day, the plaintiff also filed a motion for a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case was assigned to Judge Elaine Bucklo.[SENTMARKER]At a status hearing on February 1, the parties told the judge they had reached a "settlement in principle."[SENTMARKER]On February 2, the plaintiff successfully entered the United States at Chicago O'Hare International Airport.[SENTMARKER]On February 8, the plaintiff filed a motion for voluntary dismissal and leave to reinstate on or before August 1, 2017.[SENTMARKER]Judge Bucklo granted this motion and terminated the case.[SENTMARKER]This case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 30, 2017, a Syrian-born doctor in the U.S. filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Departments of Justice (DOJ) and Customs and Border Protection (CBP) alleging violations of the First, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendments of the Constitution, the Administrative Procedure Act, and the Constitution's Due Process Clause.[SENTMARKER]On January 27, 2017, President Donald Trump signed an executive order temporarily suspending the entry of all non-citizens from Iraq, Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria, and Yemen.[SENTMARKER]According to the terms of the EO, the "entry into the United State" of those countries is "suspended" from 90 days from the date of the order.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff was detained at Abu Dhabi International Airport on January 29, 2017, and subsequently refused entry onto an Etihad Airways flight bound for Chicago, O'Hare International Airport.[SENTMARKER]On February 9, 2017, Judge Elaine E. Bucklo entered a final judgment enjoining the enforcement of the Executive Order, denying the defendants' motion to intervene, granting the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order, and granting them relief under the Declaratory Judgment Act. Judge Bucklo also granted a motion to dismiss the case without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On Aug.[SENTMARKER]14, 2013, 13 Indian guestworkers filed suit in S.D.[SENTMARKER]Miss.[SENTMARKER]for harm suffered as a result of an allegedly fraudulent and coercive employment recruitment scheme.[SENTMARKER]In Oct. 2013, the court transferred this case to E.D.La where it was consolidated with the Achari lead case.[SENTMARKER]The Achari case was dismissed due to settlement agreement but the court retained jurisdiction.
pegasus_output_sents: A group of Indian workers brought this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana against Signal International, LLC, a private limited liability company organized under the laws of India, and Global Resources, Inc. (a/k/a Medtech Consultants) alleging discrimination on the basis of race, ethnicity, religion, and alienage in violation of the Civil Rights Act of 1866.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were forced to live in the same overcrowded, unsanitary conditions as the other Indian workers at Signal's labor camp in Pascagoula, Mississippi.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that Signal threatened anyone who complained about these conditions with reduced pay, suspension, dismissal, or deportation.[SENTMARKER]The case was consolidated with Achari v. Signal International on October 15, 2013, and the parties agreed that the case should be dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.

gold_sents: In 2015, six refugees living in Utica, NY filed this class action in the Northern District of New York against the Utica School District Board of Education and the Utica City School District.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that that the defendants consistently denied Utica residents between the ages of 17 and 20 who were limited English proficient (LEP) and immigrants access to educational opportunity.[SENTMARKER]In 2016, the parties reached a settlement requiring the defendants to end their discriminatory practices and enact a detailed remedial plan.[SENTMARKER]Enforcement of the consent decree is ongoing as of November 2018.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 6, 2016, the Utica City School District Board of Education and its superintendent filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had a policy and practice of excluding limited English proficient (LEP) immigrant students aged 17-20 from Proctor High School, the only high school in Utica, and diverting them to either the Newcomer Program or the APPLE Program.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendants did not test LEP immigrant students to determine their level of English proficiency before placing them in the Newcomer program.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also excluded immigrants from the District’s GED program and have no regular contact with English-speaking students.[SENTMARKER]As required by the Equal Educational Opportunities Act (EEOA), the parties entered into a consent decree on June 6, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is effective immediately upon the signature of the Court.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed to implement corrective measures to address language barriers that impede equal participation by ELLs aged 16-20 in its instructional programs.[SENTMARKER]The decree also requires the defendants to provide the plaintiffs with the opportunity to earn a high school diploma.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment, and the case is closed.

gold_sents: In 2020, two immigration detainees in the Batavia Federal Detention Facility in Batavia, NY, filed this class action in the United States District Court for the Western District of New York.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed that they and others similarly situated had been improperly denied bond, that non-bond alternatives to detention had not been properly considered by their immigration judges, that such considerations were required by the Immigration and Nationality Act, and that the policy of placing the burden of proof on the Plaintiffs to show they posed no flight risk violated their Fifth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]The court granted relief for pre-hearing detainees, agreeing that they pled sufficient facts to state a Due Process Claim that the government is required to bear the burden of proof at bond hearings for individuals detained pursuant to 8 U.S.C. §1226(a).[SENTMARKER]It denied Plaintiffs' request to certify the putative post-hearing class.[SENTMARKER]Both parties appealed; the case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 11, 2020, a group of immigration detainees filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York against the Department of Justice (DOJ) and the Executive Office for Immigration Review (EOIR) alleging violations of the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) and its implementing regulations, the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought class certification, a declaratory judgment that the defendants' actions violate the INA, and a preliminary injunction that each class member is entitled to a custody hearing at which the government bears the burden to justify continued detention by proving by clear and convincing evidence that the detained individual is a danger to others or a flight risk.[SENTMARKER]The court granted in part and denied in part the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the United States Court of Appeals for the 2nd Circuit on July 22, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In May 2015, parents of children born in Texas sued the Texas Department of State Health Services.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs, all Mexican or Central American citizens, asked for the release of their U.S.-citizen children's birth certificates, which defendant would not issue after refusing to accept the parents' consular identity documents.[SENTMARKER]The parties privately settled in July 2016.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 23, 2015, a group of parents of children born in the United States to undocumented immigrants filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against the Texas Department of State Health Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' policy of denying birth certificates to the children of undocumented immigrants on the basis of their immigration status violated the Equal Protection clause and Due Process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' request for a Declaratory Judgment and ordered the defendants to provide the plaintiffs with certified copies of the birth certificates of their children.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the decision, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: This suit seeks to support Texas's law Senate Bill 4 (SB4), which requires local Texas law enforcement to cooperate with federal immigration officials and punishes them if they do not.[SENTMARKER]Unlike the suits that seek to challenge President Trump's "Sanctuary City" Executive Order, this suit aims to support the work of federal immigration officials.[SENTMARKER]There are, so far, four cases addressing SB4.[SENTMARKER]On May 7, 2017, Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton filed this suit seeking a declaratory judgment approving SB4.[SENTMARKER]Defendants are Travis County, City of Austin, and the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund (MALDEF).[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction on May 24, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the case without prejudice to refiling on August 9, 2017, finding that Texas lacked actual or imminent injury, which was required for Article III standing to seek declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]Texas appealed to the Fifth Circuit, who affirmed the district court's dismissal of the claim on December 12, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 7, 2017, the State of Texas filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against local governments, elected officials, and a non-profit advocacy group.[SENTMARKER]The State sought declaratory and injunctive relief for violations of Senate Bill 4 (SB 4), which prohibits local governments from refusing to cooperate with federal immigration authorities.[SENTMARKER]The District Court dismissed the suit for lack of jurisdiction, ruling that the City of El Paso engaged in a pattern and practice of prohibiting enforcement of federal immigration law.[SENTMARKER]On May 22, 2017, the Texas Organizing Project Education Fund ( TOPEF) filed a similar suit in the same court against the State.[SENTMARKER]On August 9, 2017, the District Court granted the State's motion to dismiss, finding that the State had not alleged an injury sufficient to confer standing and that the suit sought an impermissible advisory opinion.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the Supreme Court is considering whether to hear the case.

gold_sents: On May 3, 1993, the U.S. Department of Justice investigated the Harrison County, MI jail.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ found violations of inadequate staffing and medical care.[SENTMARKER]Apparently after negotiation, the Attorney General filed an action under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), 42 U.S.C. 1997 et seq., against the jail in 1995.[SENTMARKER]Six days later, Judge Walter J. Gex III approved a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree mandated doubling the number of officers, increased training, and hiring of medical professionals for the physical and mental health of the patients.[SENTMARKER]The decree was enforced sporadically throughout the next ten years.[SENTMARKER]On August 11, 2015, the parties filed a joint motion for dismissal, with the county agreeing to continue to use its best efforts to improve its mental health and medical care.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on August 12, 1995.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 3, 1993, the Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi against Harrison County, Mississippi.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the constitutional rights of inmates confined at the Harrison County Adult Detention Center (HCDC) by failing to provide adequate access to the courts, inadequate training to jail officers, inadequate mental health care services, inadequate medical staffing, and inadequate access to law books and legal research materials.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendants agreed to provide the DOJ with a law library, provide inmates with meaningful access to legal materials for research and writing, and discontinue the use of the facility's strip cell for disciplinary purposes.[SENTMARKER]The decree was entered on August 12, 2003, and the parties entered a final judgment on December 12, 2003.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment was entered by Chief District Judge Louis Guirola, Jr. on 8/12/15, pursuant to the terms of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice, each party to bear its own attorney fees and costs.

gold_sents: In 2003, prisoners filed this class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Erie County Sheriff's Department had an unconstitutional policy and practice of strip-searching prisoners when they entered the county facilities.[SENTMARKER]In 2012, the Supreme Court ruled that a similar strip search policy was constitutional in Florence v. Board of Chosen Freeholders.[SENTMARKER]Board of Chosen Freeholders.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs in this case argued that their case was distinguishable from Florence.[SENTMARKER]However, no further action occurred in the case after 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 26, 2005, a class of arrested persons filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York against the County of Erie, the Erie County Sheriff's Department, and certain of its officials alleging that they were subjected to unconstitutional strip searches in violation of their right against unreasonable searches under the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, and sought to interview other employees as witnesses to the alleged strip searches.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a writ of mandamus, and the district court's April 17, 2006 order was vacated.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then filed a motion to compel the release of e-mail communications to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit denied the defendants' request for a stay pending appeal.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Two detainees in Shelby County Jail in Tennessee filed this petition for a writ of habeas corpus.[SENTMARKER]They claimed that failure to take sufficient COVID-19 precautions violated the Fourteenth Amendment, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and they sought release.[SENTMARKER]The court appointed an "Independent Inspector" to assess conditions at the jail and, based on his report, denied preliminary relief.[SENTMARKER]The court also denied defendants' motion to dismiss, and a trial is scheduled for May 2021.[SENTMARKER]An Independent Inspector was tasked with inspecting the jail to evaluate the conditions.[SENTMARKER]While praising defendants' professionalism, he wrote that several adjustments needed to be made in order for the jail to be a safe place for detainees.[SENTMARKER]After attending mediation and filing a joint motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement, the court preliminarily granted the consent decree requiring monthly reports on the status of COVID-19 in the Jail and unannounced, periodic inspections by the Inspector.[SENTMARKER]A final approval hearing is scheduled for March 5, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 7, 2020, pre-trial detainees filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Tennessee against the Shelby County Sheriff's Office, alleging that their constitutional and statutory rights were being violated by the conditions in their jail due to the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]On June 10, 2020, the Court denied Defendants' motion and certified a class and subclass of medically vulnerable and disabled individuals detained pretrial at the Jail.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a proposed consent decree in which the Jail agreed to provide at least one mask to detainees and to implement a number of measures to protect people from COVID.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also required the Jail to provide the plaintiffs with free soap and that soap is not to be confiscated if the inmates have more than one bar.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the Jail was required to provide plaintiffs with access to the Skype for Business webpage for instructions on downloading the proper extensions for their computer.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for injunctive relief and dismissed their petition for dismissal.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In August 2014, detainees at the Franklin County Jail filed a lawsuit alleging that jail officials used excessive force against them and that the jail provided inhumane living conditions, in violation of the First, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]In March 28, 2016, the parties settled.[SENTMARKER]The defendant paid $400,557.66 in attorneys’ fees and was required to hire additional staff, renovate the prison, and adopt new mental health services policies.
pegasus_output_sents: In August 2014, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Washington on behalf of inmates at the Franklin County Corrections Center.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the jail's widespread unconstitutional practices, including the use of four point restraints against inmates, violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive and declaratory relief and sought a temporary restraining order barring the practices.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement on February 5, 2016 and the case was closed on July 31, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the plaintiffs were entitled to an award of their 19 reasonable attorneys' fees and costs pursuant to 42 U. S.C.  1988(b)(2).[SENTMARKER]The defendants have denied the allegations in the complaint and continue to deny liability for the allegations.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In early 2011, an electronic communication service provider that had received a National Security Letter (NSL) from the federal government filed a petition to set aside the NSL in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The recipient asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming that a nondisclosure provision of the NSL Statute, 18 U.S.C. § 2709, violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On March 14, 2013, U.S. District Judge Susan Illston granted the petition to set aside the NSL, declaring that § 2709 violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The government was therefore enjoined from issuing NSLs under § 2709 or from enforcing the nondisclosure provision in this or any other case.[SENTMARKER]The government appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit, but while the appeal was pending, Congress amended § 2709 and 18 U.S.C. § 3511 as part of the USA FREEDOM Act of 2015.[SENTMARKER]The district court and Ninth Circuit upheld the constitutionality of the revised § 2709 and § 3511.[SENTMARKER]But the district court held that the government failed to justify nondisclosure in one case involving the recipient, and the government found that nondisclosure was no longer required in another case involving the recipient.[SENTMARKER]As a result, the recipient could reveal itself as CREDO Mobile.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2011, a telecommunications and Internet service provider filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) alleging that the FBI's use of the National Security Letters (NSLs) in counterintelligence investigations violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The NSLs allow the FBI to issue national security letters to telecommunications companies to demand non-content information from service providers.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the government's improper practices included requests for information based on First Amendment protected activity.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the plaintiffs' complaint, but the case was remanded to the Second Circuit to address the first amendment issues presented in the 2006 Reauthorization Act of 2006.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit reversed the district court's decision in part and remanded the case to allow the government to enforce the NSL law.[SENTMARKER]The case is now pending before the Ninth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]In a parallel case, the plaintiffs appealed to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court declined to hear the case and the case is closed.

gold_sents: In 2014, an investigative reporter filed suit under the Freedom of Information Act against the National Security Agency and U.S. Department of Justice in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants were improperly withholding records concerning the NSA's surveillance of federal and state judges.[SENTMARKER]The Court ordered the defendant conduct an email search for draft memoranda or opinions concerning such surveillance program.[SENTMARKER]The search wielded no results.[SENTMARKER]A settlement agreement was reached paying plaintiff's attorney's fees on February 27, 2017.
pegasus_output_sents: In March 2014, Plaintiff Jason Leopold filed this Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the National Security Agency (NSA), the Department of Justice (DOJ), and the Office of Legal Counsel (OLC) seeking records related to the NSA's bulk collection and storage of telephone metadata.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated FOIA by failing to conduct an adequate search of the requested records.[SENTMARKER]In July 2015, the district court granted the defendants' first motion for summary judgment, finding that the search would impose an unreasonable burden on the agencies.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a second motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]On August 11, 2016, the court granted summary judgment to the defendants and denied the parties' motion for partial summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered the parties to reprocess the FOIA request by searching the records for responsive documents.[SENTMARKER]On October 6, 2016, the parties filed a motion for a declaratory judgment, which was denied by the court.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: On September 16, 2016, The Associated Press, Gannett Satellite Information Network LLC, and Vice Media, LLC, filed a lawsuit seeking information about the recently purchased tool allowing government access to the phone of one of the perpetrators of the mass killings in San Bernardino, California on December 2, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the defendant's summary judgment motion on September 30, 2017, finding information at issue was protected under FOIA exemptions 1, 3, and 7.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 29, 2016, the Washington, D.C. District Court for the District of Columbia granted summary judgment in favor of USA TODAY and two other news organizations in a FOIA case brought against the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA).[SENTMARKER]The News Organizations sought the release of documents related to the FBI's purchase of a tool to circumvent the need for a court order to access the locked iPhone of Syed Rizwan Farook, one of the perpetrators of the mass killings in San Bernardino, California last year.[SENTMARKER]The FBI initially denied each request on the basis of FOIA Exemption 7(A), which permits agencies to withhold records or information for law enforcement purposes to the extent that the production of such records could reasonably be expected to interfere with law enforcement proceedings.[SENTMARKER]On June 20, 2016, USA TODAY timely appealed the denial, arguing that the FBI had applied the exemption in violation of the law.[SENTMARKER]On April 21, 2016, AP reporter Eric Tucker filed a FOIA request with the FBI for records of the publicly-acknowledged business transaction that resulted in the purchase this March of the so-called iPhone access tool.[SENTMARKER]The Vice reporter filed the FOIA request on April 21, 2016.[SENTMARKER]On June 6, 2016, the FBI denied the Vice request.[SENTMARKER]On September 30, 2017, the court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the parties agreed that the records sought by the News Organizations were public records pursuant to 5 U.S. C.[SENTMARKER]552, and that they must be disclosed.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the parties' cross-motion for summary judgement for the costs of this proceeding, including reasonable attorney's fees, as authorized by FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On January 17, 2006, plaintiffs filed a lawsuit against the National Security Agency alleging that the Terrorist Surveillance Program was unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On August 17, 2006, the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan (Judge Taylor) agreed and enjoined the program.[SENTMARKER]On July 6, 2007, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 6th Circuit vacated the order and instructed to dismiss the case based on lack of standing.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 17, 2006, the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers and the Association of the Bar of the City of New York filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against the National Security Agency (NSA) alleging that the NSA's warrantless wiretapping program violated the separation of powers doctrine and the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a declaratory judgment and an injunction.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment on the basis of the state secrets evidentiary privilege and their lack of standing.[SENTMARKER]On September 4, 2007, the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals granted the government's motion to dismiss the case for lack of jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court declined to hear the appeal and the case was dismissed on September 4, 2007.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: The plaintiff, an individual citizen and lawful resident of the United States that was denied boarding a flight from the United Arab Emirates to the United States because of his alleged inclusion on the No Fly List of the federal government, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff specifically alleged that his inclusion on the No Fly List was to coerce him to be an FBI informant.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought declaratory, injunctive, and monetary relief for the federal government's various alleged constitutional violations and torture.[SENTMARKER]To date, the case remains pending.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 30, 2013, a man in the United Arab Emirates filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and the National Security Agency (NSA).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff alleged that he was detained by the secret police in the UAE and subjected to interrogation and torture for 106 days.[SENTMARKER]He also alleged that the defendants violated his Fourth Amendment rights by subjecting him to electronic surveillance and wiretaps without first demonstrating to a court the existence of probable cause that the person has committed a crime are unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed this claim with prejudice, and the Ninth Circuit affirmed the district court's dismissal of the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]On November 4, 2015, the court granted Defendants' Motion in part and denied it in part.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed Plaintiff's substantive and procedural due process claims as moot in light of the defendant's removal from the No-Fly List.[SENTMARKER]On February 12, 2015, after the parties stipulated DHS would reconsider the plaintiff's DHS TRIP application under the new procedures, the court issued an Opinion and Order in Latif v. Holder, 28 F. Supp.[SENTMARKER]Holder, 28 F. Supp.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff sought declaratory and injunctive relief, and for damages, based upon Defendants' violations of his constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The Court, however, concluded Tarhuni's claims were moot.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a temporary restraining order on February 12, 2015 and the case was dismissed on November 4, 2015.[SENTMARKER]On November 18, 2015, the Court dismissed Plaintiff’s Fourth Amendment claims with prejudice and dismissed the plaintiff’s procedural and substantive due-process claims.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit granted Defendants’ motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 8, 2009, the American Civil Liberties Union ("ACLU") of Washington filed this lawsuit in the District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]The ACLU sued the United States Department of Justice ("DOJ") under the Freedom of Information Act ("FOIA").[SENTMARKER]The ACLU asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief to compel the DOJ to disclose and release records it was improperly withholding from the ACLU regarding the National Crime Information Center Violent Gang and Terrorist Organization File ("CVGTOF"), which contains entries on suspected terrorist organizations and individuals.[SENTMARKER]Though the DOJ moved to dismiss the case, on March 10, 2011, U.S. District Court Judge Robert S. Lasnik only granted the motion to dismiss in part, and ordered the DOJ to edit any inappropriate redactions and provide the Court with more facts that would justify a claimed exemption.[SENTMARKER]After some back and forth regarding the confidentiality of the requested documents, the DOJ was required to release certain documents and on March 7, 2013 the parties came to an agreement whereby the United States was to pay the ACLU $50,000 within 60 days via wire transfer, as full settlement for attorneys' fees and costs incurred by the ACLU in this lawsuit.[SENTMARKER]This case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 19, 2008, the American Civil Liberties Union of Washington (ACLU) filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request under 5 U.S.C.  552, seeking records describing the operation and maintenance of the National Crime Information Center (NCIC) Violent Gang and Terrorist Organization File (VGTOF) maintained by the Federal Bureau of Investigation (DOJ) and the Transportation Security Administration (TSA).[SENTMARKER]On November 17, 2009, the DOJ denied plaintiff’s request for a fee waiver and 12 renewed its processing of the FOIA request.[SENTMARKER]On May 19, 2011, the Court granted the DOJ’s motion for summary judgment regarding the adequacy of its search and the production of reasonably segregable portions of the record is GRANTED.[SENTMARKER]On March 10, 2011, the court ordered the DOJ to produce specific categories of documents under the FOIA, including the TSA’s Integrated Automated Fingerprint Identification System (IAFIS) Integrated Surveillance System (ISS).[SENTMARKER]The court found that it has jurisdiction to evaluate the validity of the TSA's designation of information as sensitive security information.[SENTMARKER]The court also found that the public’s interest in understanding how the government exercises its extraordinary powers toward that goal is significant.[SENTMARKER]The case has been ongoing for over two years.

gold_sents: In 2017, the NAACP filed this lawsuit against the U.S. Dept.[SENTMARKER]of Commerce for failure to provide it with records under the FOIA concerning its preparations for the 2020 census.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged the Census Bureau was failing to adhere to deadlines, failing to confirm certain requests, and refusing to disclose documents in a timely manner in violation of 5 U.S.C. § 552 and 15 C.F.R § 4.6.[SENTMARKER]In 2019, the parties reached a settlement that required disclosure of the documents within several weeks and awarded attorneys' fees to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case likely closed in September 2019.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 5, 2017, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), NAACP Connecticut State Conference, and NAACP Boston Branch filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Connecticut.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the Department of Commerce (DOC) violated the FOIA by failing to respond to the FOIA request within the statutory deadline, in violation of 15 C.F.R.  4.6(f)(4).[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement on February 4, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to make reasonable efforts to resolve any disputes before making an application to the Court.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for summary judgment and ordered the DOC to pay the plaintiffs' fees and costs.

gold_sents: Jacqueline Jones filed this lawsuit challenging Florida's failure to provide her with sufficient home care services via the Traumatic Brain Injury/Spinal Cord Injury Medicaid waiver.[SENTMARKER]Although she sought to expand her case to represent a class of plaintiffs, the state began providing her with appropriate services after her lawsuit was filed and she agreed to a voluntary dismissal.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 2, 2009, a Florida resident who was paralyzed in a car accident filed a private lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida against the State of Florida, alleging violations of Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the state was using Medicaid's home and community based waiver services ("HCBS") to provide essential long term care to some residents with disabilities, but not to others.[SENTMARKER]The court certified the case as a class of individuals with traumatic brain or spinal cord injuries who the state has determined or will determine to be eligible to receive services from Florida's Medicaid Waiver Program for persons with TBI/SCI injuries and have not received such services.[SENTMARKER]On December 29, 2009, the court dismissed the case with prejudice pursuant to the settlement terms.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On November 28, 2005, the Florida Pediatric Society, the Florida Chapter of the American Academy of Pediatrics, the Florida Academy of Pediatric Dentistry, Inc., and certain named individual children who are eligible to receive medical and dental care through Medicaid filed this class action lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued several state defendants in their official capacities, claiming that these defendants violated Title XIX of the Social Security Act, 42 U.S.C. § 1396 et seq. (also known as the Medicaid Act), by failing to provide essential medical and dental services to eligible children in Florida.[SENTMARKER]After extensive discovery and a lengthy trial, the District Court (Judge Adalberto Jordan) held that the defendants were liable in several respects.[SENTMARKER]After several months of settlement discussions, the court approved a final settlement agreement on June 28, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The Court has jurisdiction over the litigation until September 30, 2022.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs $12,000,000 to cover attorneys' fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: The Florida Pediatric Society/The Florida Chapter of the American Academy of Pediatrics (FPS), the Florida Academy of Pediatric Dentistry, Inc.
