gold_sents: On December 28, 2011, two Hawaii-based religious organizations filed a lawsuit in United States District Court against the State of Hawaii.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit alleged that a California law set to take effect in 2012 was chilling plaintiffs' religious freedom and unconstitutional under the First, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The case was stayed, and the law changed in July of 2012.[SENTMARKER]On October 3, 2012, the case was dismissed for lack of standing.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 28, 2011, a group of same-sex couples filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Hawaii against the State of Hawaii, the Governor, and the Director of the State Department of Health.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Hawaii's Civil Unions Law violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution, and sought declaratory and prospective injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction on December 30, 2011.[SENTMARKER]On October 2, 2012, the court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss the case without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]On January 1, 2012, the plaintiffs filed an appeal to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court reversed the lower court's decision, and remanded the case for further proceedings.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs filed this class action against the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services in 1989 in the U.C.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the Northern District of Illinois claiming that the agency failed to provide services to assure family unification and instead removed children from parents and guardians who were unable to provide food or shelter.[SENTMARKER]The case resulted in a Consent Decree whereby the agency agreed to assist families in obtaining housing and food assistance.
pegasus_output_sents: In March 1991, a class action lawsuit was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services (DCFS).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DCFS violated the federal statutes and the federal Constitution by failing to provide adequate food and shelter to homeless children and families.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief, including the appointment of a monitor to monitor DCFS's compliance with the consent order.[SENTMARKER]The consent order was approved by the court on March 28, 1991, and the parties settled the case on March 29, 1991.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the monitor would report to the court and make recommendations concerning the implementation of the Consent Order for a period of four years from July 1, 1991.[SENTMARKER]The court granted in part and denied in part the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction on the basis that the defendant was not in compliance.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On Sept.[SENTMARKER]8, 2014, a same-sex couple filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Indiana under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against a county clerk and the Indiana Department of Health.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the state's ban on same-sex marriages violated the their 14th Amendment rights to due process and equal protection.[SENTMARKER]After the 7th Circuit struck down Indiana's marriage ban, the state agreed to recognize the plaintiffs' out-of-state marriage pending a final resolution to the case.

gold_sents: In 2013, three same-sex couples married under the laws of other states filed a lawsuit, individually and on behalf of their children, in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Kentucky against the Commonwealth of Kentucky, challenging the constitutionality of Kentucky's laws prohibiting same-sex couples from marrying and voiding within Kentucky marriages of same-sex couples validly entered into under the laws of other states and countries.[SENTMARKER]Judge John Heyburn found for the plaintiffs on July 1st, 2014, and issued the final order declaring Kentucky laws banning same-sex marriages to be unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]This order was stayed and then reversed by the Sixth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The case is pending before the U.S. Supreme Court.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 27, 2014, a group of same-sex couples filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Kentucky against the State of Kentucky, challenging the constitutionality of Kentucky’s laws excluding gays and lesbians from marriage and voiding within the State the marriages of gay couples entered in other states or countries.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs challenged the state’s ban on recognizing out-of-state gay marriages on the basis that it violated the due process and equal protection guarantees of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs relief in two of the cases, and the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals reversed the district court’s decision in the third case.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of Massachusetts held in 2003 that the State’s constitutional right to marry was guaranteed by the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The case was restyled on February 27, 2014 and the plaintiffs appealed to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]In the second case, the plaintiffs challenged Ohio’s refusal to recognize out- of-state marriages on their children’s birth certificates.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit held in favor of the plaintiffs in both cases, but the case was dismissed for lack of standing.[SENTMARKER]The Sixth Circuit held that the plaintiffs had standing to challenge the Ohio law.[SENTMARKER]The cases were restyled and the cases were dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the cases and the parties agreed not to appeal.

gold_sents: This class action was about whether the City of New York improperly denied federally sponsored cash assistance to qualified New York City residents under a program implemented by the city in the late 1990s.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs each claimed to be qualified welfare beneficiaries who had been improperly denied assistance by one of New York City’s new job centers in violation of the fourteenth amendment guarantee of due process, the city’s obligations under 7 U.S.C. §2020 (the Supplemental Nutritional Assistance Program—then referred to as Food Stamps) and 42 U.S.C. §1396 (Medicaid), in addition to violating state law; the plaintiffs sought class certification for all similarly situated New York City residents, as well as declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on December 16, 1998, with Judge William H. Pauley presiding.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a temporary restraining order on the same day directing the city to provide emergency food stamps and cash assistance to the named plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction in-part to the plaintiffs on January 21, 1999.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered the city to (1) allow applicants for public assistance to apply for benefits the first day they visit a job center, (2) cease conversion of income support centers to job centers without a formal hearing, (3) make eligibility requirements for food stamps and Medicaid separately from the eligibility determination from cash assistance, (4) send applicants timely notice of the city’s decision on whether they qualify for benefits, and (5) form a corrective plan for achieving its policy goals while also meeting the needs of public assistance applicants.[SENTMARKER]The city moved to vacate the preliminary injunction on December 10, 1999, after procuring more evidence surrounding the efficacy of the job centers in achieving their welfare obligations.[SENTMARKER]Meanwhile, the State of New York moved to dismiss the complaint against them for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]Judge Pauley denied both motions and granted the plaintiff’s motion for class certification on July 21, 2000.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a permanent injunction in favor of the plaintiffs on December 30, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The permanent injunction directed both the city and state to: (i) provide expedited food stamp service to eligible applications within 7 days; .[SENTMARKER](ii) separately process applications for food stamps when the applications for cash assistance are denied or withdrawn; .[SENTMARKER](iii) send notices to applicants confirming voluntary withdrawals for Medicaid in accord with 42 C.F.R. 435.913 and document such withdrawals pursuant to 7 C.F.R. 273.2(c)(6); and (iv) provide adequate and timely notice by correctly completing certain documentation.[SENTMARKER]The injunction also required the state to supervise the city and make sure it met the obligations of the injunction.[SENTMARKER]On January 13, 2005, the plaintiffs moved for reconsideration of the part of the December order in which the court concluded that 8 N.Y.C.R.R.[SENTMARKER]§ 387.8(a)(2)(i)(a) did not confer a privately enforceable right of action and that plaintiffs’ claim under New York Social Services Law § 133 was barred by the doctrine of sovereign immunity.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the motion on February 14, 2005.[SENTMARKER]Final judgement was entered on December 14, 2005; the court also granted the plaintiffs declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]Both the state and the city appealed the permanent injunction to the Second Circuit on January 12, 2006, but the city dropped its appeal.[SENTMARKER]On October 31, 2007, the Second Circuit reversed the district court, ruling that the state did not have a non-delegable duty to administer the decentralized Medicaid and Food Stamp programs, the state’s efforts in supervising the city since the permanent injunction was issued were adequate, and the district court exceeded its authority by issuing a permanent injunction in light of New York State’s affirmative supervisory steps it had taken to assure compliance.[SENTMARKER]In a series of stipulations and orders from January 31, 2007 to July 22, 2011, the City of New York agreed to pay a total of $2,920,675.94 to plaintiffs for attorney fees and costs sought; the state agreed to pay a further $639,918.98.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 16, 1998, the Welfare Law Center, the Legal Aid Society, and the New York Legal Assistance Group filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that New York City Human Resources Administration (HRA) and New York State Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance (OTDA) denied applicants food stamps and Medicaid benefits for failing to comply with PRWORA's work rules.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a preliminary injunction requiring the defendants to accept and process applications for food stamps, Medicaid and cash assistance, and to supervise the city's compliance with the injunction and to perform monitoring duties.[SENTMARKER]In April 2001, the district court held a bench trial and certified a plaintiff class ("Plaintiff Class"), which was represented by the L.A.[SENTMARKER]Law Center.[SENTMARKER]In September 2000, the district judge entered a final judgment for the plaintiffs, enjoining the defendants from violating the injunction, requiring them to provide applicants with written notice of the reasons for the denial of applications, and directing state officials to supervise compliance with injunction.[SENTMARKER]The state defendants appealed the final judgment, claiming that plaintiffs failed to allege facts on which relief could be granted.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed to meet and confer regarding reasonable attorneys' fees, costs and disbursements.

gold_sents: This case was brought by Disability Advocates, Inc. against the Governor of the State of New York seeking declaratory and injunctive relief to compel Defendant to provide services in the most integrated setting appropriate.[SENTMARKER]The District Court issued judgment in favor of Plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]After the Defendants appealed, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit vacated the judgment of the District Court and dismissed the action due to lack of standing.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ continued to pursue a settlement.[SENTMARKER]On July 23, 2013, the State and the DOJ filed a settlement to provide approximately 4000 qualifying adult home residents the option of living in community-supported private homes scattered throughout New York City.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was approved in March 2014.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was amended and changed several times from 2014 to 2018.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing and the court maintains jurisdiction.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 30, 2003, Disability Advocates, Inc. (DAAS) brought this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York on behalf of individuals with mental illness residing in New York City adult homes.[SENTMARKER]DAAS alleged that the adult homes violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by not ensuring that adulthome residents were receiving services in the most integrated setting appropriate to their needs.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted partial summary judgment to the plaintiffs, holding that the State's failure to place L.C.[SENTMARKER]residents in the community violated the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit affirmed the district court's holding that unnecessary institutionalization violates the ADA but remanded for a reassessment of the state's costbased defense.[SENTMARKER]On July 23, 2013, the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay up to $75,000 annually to DAAS for attorneys' fees and expenses through the term of the agreement.[SENTMARKER]On April 6, 2012, the parties dismissed the action for lack of jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs are lesbian couples who filed suit on November 3, 2004 in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma, against the United States and the State of Oklahoma, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief that the federal Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) and Article 2 § 35 of the Oklahoma Constitution (the "Oklahoma Amendment") violate the U.S. Constitution.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that DOMA and the Oklahoma Amendment violates the Due Process, Equal Protection, Full Faith and Credit, and Privileges and Immunities Clauses of the U.S. Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The court found for the plaintiffs, holding on Jan.[SENTMARKER]14, 2014 that the ban on same-sex marriage violated the Equal Protection Clause.[SENTMARKER]The Tenth Circuit found for the plaintiffs on July 18, 2014, and after the Supreme Court denied a petition for a writ of certiorari (on October 6, 2014), the Court lifted the stay on its original mandate and enjoined the Defendant from enforcing the Oklahoma Amendment and denying same-sex couples marriage licenses.[SENTMARKER]The Court awarded $309,485.27 in attorney's fees to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 3, 2004, two lesbian couples filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma challenging the federal Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) and Oklahoma's amendment to its Constitution (Oklahoma Amendment) prohibiting same-sex couples from being married in the State of Oklahoma and the recognition of out-of-state same sex marriages.[SENTMARKER]In response to the Plaintiffs' complaint, the Oklahoma officials moved to dismiss, claiming venue was improper and the plaintiffs lacked standing and the suit was barred by the Eleventh Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The District Court denied the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the case was stayed pending a ruling by the Tenth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]In November 2005, the Supreme Court of the United States (S.C.) struck down DOMA and the Oklahoma Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On March 1, 2006, the City of Ithaca, N.Y., announced that it would begin accepting applications for marriage licenses from gay and lesbian couples seeking to marry in the city.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed in part and denied in part, 447 F.Supp.2d 1239, but the district court allowed the plaintiffs to file an amended complaint naming as a defendant the Oklahoma Attorney General's Office and Tulsa County Court Clerk V. Intervenor, The Bipartisan Legal Advisory Group, The Tulsa County Attorney's office, the Tulsa County Clerk, the State Department of Health and the County Clerks of Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' request for declaratory and injunctive relief, enjoining enforcement of Section 2 of DOMA, Section 3 of Oklahoma Amendment, and Section 1 of the Oklahoma Constitution, and allowing the Plaintiffs to file a motion to withdraw as an intervening party.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit dismissed the case for lack of standing.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court remanded the case to the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The Tenth Circuit granted the parties' motion to dismiss and the parties filed an appeal, which was granted in part.

gold_sents: This case was brought by workers with limited English proficiency, whose jobs were lost or threatened by foreign competition against the U.S. Department of Labor, seeking injunctive relief, a declaratory judgment and costs for the DOL's failure to provide adequate training under the Trade Act of 1974.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled on December 30, 2005 and resulted in the establishment of a program for Limited English-Proficient workers in the El Paso area by the DOL as well as widespread policy changes as to the administration of the job training benefits.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 3, 2002, the Association of Border Workers (ATF) and several of its members filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against the Department of Labor (DOL) alleging that the Department violated the Trade Act of 1974 (Trade Act) by failing to provide training benefits to limited English proficient (LEP) workers in the El Paso area.[SENTMARKER]On December 17, 2003, the Court granted the Department's Motion to Stay the Original Texas Case.[SENTMARKER]On November 5, 2004, plaintiffs filed a Motion for Summary Judgment, which may include remedial training.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to fund and administer an LEP project for workers who lose their jobs due to foreign competition.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the parties agreed to dismiss all claims with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On September 13, 2013, an African American inmate in the Arizona State Prison Complex in Tucson filed this lawsuit against the State of Arizona and the Arizona Department of Correction in the District of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]He sued under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]The inmate alleged that the prison segregated him by race, in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement on December 22, 2015, under which the defendants would narrowly limit racial consideration in prison housing and employment opportunities, and pay $5,000 in monetary damages to plaintiff as well as $195,000 to plaintiff’s counsel in attorneys’ fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 13, 2013, a prisoner at the Arizona State Prison Complex-Tucson filed a pro se civil rights lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona against the Arizona Department of Corrections (ADC) alleging racial discrimination in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that he was assigned to and retained in segregation on the basis of his race, and that the ADC's policy of racial segregation violated the equal protection clause.[SENTMARKER]On June 9, 2014, the Plaintiff's counsel filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]On December 22, 2015, the parties filed their Stipulation for Payment of Monetary Damages (Doc.[SENTMARKER]C14-044-013), which was approved by the Court on December 22, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the defendants' motion for partial summary judgment and denied their motion for declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement agreement that required the defendants to develop and institute policies, procedures, and practices necessary to implement an integrated housing program.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to pay monetary damages to the Plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: In 2005, a group of California prisoners with mental illness filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California against the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation alleging that the prison system's policies regarding prisoners with mental disabilities violated the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled in 2015 and the court retained jurisdiction to enforce the terms of the settlement.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 1, 2005, inmates with severe mental disorders filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California against the California Department of Corrections and 24 Rehabilitation (CDCR) under Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (Rehabilitation Act) alleging violations of their civil rights under the ADA and Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, and reasonable attorneys' fees and costs, for defendants' violations of plaintiffs' rights.[SENTMARKER]On November 17, 2006, the defendants filed a Rule 12(b) and (f) motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case was stayed on March 15, 2007, and the parties engaged in settlement negotiations with the Coleman Special Master.[SENTMARKER]On May 3, 2011, the parties filed an appeal to the United States Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court affirmed the decision of the three judge court, and the case continues today.

gold_sents: In 2014, Disability Rights Florida filed this complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that certain inmates with mental illness at Dade Correctional Institution had been subject to torture, beatings, verbal harassment and food deprivation in violation of their Eighth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that these inmates had received insufficient care in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Federal Rehabilitation Act. (DRF) brought this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida on behalf of persons with mental illness confined by the State of Florida at Dade Correctional Institution (Dade CI).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act and Title II of the Federal Rehabilitation Act by terminating the counselor's employment.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a private settlement agreement in November 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case would be dismissed with prejudice on May 31, 2017 if no material breach of the agreement had occurred and the parties could not reach an agreement regarding reasonable attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The Court stayed the case for two years to allow for the implementation of the Private Settlement Agreement.[SENTMARKER]On May 31, 2017, the parties filed a joint motion for administrative closure of the case to allow time for the limited purpose of determining reasonable attorneys' fees and expenses in the event the parties were unable to resolve the issue through negotiation or mediation.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with Prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The Parties agreed to pay the Plaintiff reasonable attorneys’ fees and cost after the case is dismissed.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed to extend the date by which Plaintiff is required to dismiss or re-open the case with the Court by six months with all other terms of the Agreement remaining unchanged.

pegasus_output_sents: In September 2017, a blind inmate at Central State Prison filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Georgia against the Georgia Department of Corrections (GDOC) alleging that GDOC violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the Rehabilitation Act, and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act (RLUIPA) by failing to provide him with auxiliary aids and services at important meetings and events while under GDOC control and supervision.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that he was discriminated against on the basis of his disability and his native language was American Sign Language (ASL).[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to stay discovery pending consideration of their motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in September 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the court would analyze violations of the ADA, RLUIPA, and  2000cc-2 et seq., and that the parties would withdraw any claims not alleged in the proposed second amended complaint, including any claim under the RLuIPA.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2016, two Missouri Medicaid recipients filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Missouri after being denied medication to treat their Hepatitis C.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Missouri Department of Social Services and MO HealthNet denied medically necessary treatment to Medicaid beneficiaries with Hepatitis C, discriminated against similarly situated Medicaid beneficiaries, failed to provide "reasonably prompt" treatment, violated due process, and violated the American with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]In November 2017, MO HealthNet modified its policies and the case was dismissed as moot without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in November 2017.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 22, 2013, the U.S.[SENTMARKER]Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved a new direct acting antiviral (DAA) treatment for Hepatitis C virus (HCV), a serious and communicable disease that can cause severe liver scarring, liver damage, cancer, and death.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed this lawsuit under Title XIX of the Social Security Act against the Missouri Department of Social Services (DSS) in the United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri.[SENTMARKER]The DSS denied coverage for a single-pill treatment containing simeprevir sold by Janssen Pharmaceutical under the trade name Olysio® because it required negative drug and alcohol screens prior to submitting requests for DAA approval.[SENTMARKER]Because of the defendants' arbitrary and improper policies that restrict treatment for medically necessary treatment only to the sickest beneficiaries, the plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction prohibiting the DSS from requiring three months of negative drug screens and requiring the defendants to provide coverage for all Medicaid beneficiaries with HCV.[SENTMARKER]On February 14, 2016, the court granted the plaintiffs' request for a temporary restraining order and permanent injunction.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to comply with the terms of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: Four incarcerated women alleged that their First, Fourth, Fifth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights were violated by being housed in the same facilities as transgender women.[SENTMARKER]After years of litigation, the claims were eventually dismissed.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 12, 2018, three female prisoners filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas against the United States Bureau of Prisons, the Department of Justice, the Arizona Department of Education, and the Democratic National Committee.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' policy of transferring male prisoners to the general population of federal women's prisons violated their right to bodily privacy and endangers their physical and mental health.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the plaintiffs alleged violations of the Religious Freedom Restoration Act and the Equal Access to Justice Act.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment on May 31, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This case was filed by a trans woman incarcerated in a men's prison in Washington State on September 5, 2017 in the District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]She alleges that the blanket policy in the Washington Department of Correction denying prisoners access to gender affirming surgery amounts to a violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]She is represented by the ACLU, and is seeking injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties came to a preliminary settlement agreement on March 20, 2020, and proceedings were stayed for 180 days in an attempt to implement the agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 27, 2017, a transgender female inmate, CORR CRONIN LLP, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against the Washington State Department of Corrections (DOC) alleging that the DOC's policy banning gender reassignment surgery for all inmates violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff's counsel filed a motion for partial summary judgment, arguing that defendants' gender dysphoria policy is unconstitutional on its face 1 because it was a blanket ban on gender confirmation surgery, precluding surgery without any consideration for medical necessity.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement agreement, under which the plaintiff will receive the medical treatment she 2 seeks if a professional evaluator determines that she is ready for surgery and that it is medically 3 necessary.[SENTMARKER]On April 15, 2019, the parties filed a stipulated motion to dismiss the case with prejudice, and the parties agreed that the Court may retain jurisdiction over this matter solely 4 to enforce the terms of the settlement, and that once the terms have been 5 satisfied, they will file a stipulated motions to dismiss this action with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Three indigent persons charged with crimes filed a class action lawsuit in Skagit County Superior Court against the City of Mount Vernon and the City of Burlington alleging defendants failed to provide adequate assistance of counsel.[SENTMARKER]The Cities jointly contracted with two attorneys to handle all public defense assistance cases, and each attorney handled over 1,000 cases per year.[SENTMARKER]The Court found the plaintiffs established their rights were systematically deprived and the Cities were responsible for the deprivation.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted injunctive relief requiring the City of Mount Vernon and City of Burlington re-evaluate their contract for the provision of public defense services and hire one part-time public defense supervisor.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 15, 2010, the ACLU of Washington filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against the City of Mount Vernon and City of Burlington in the Skagit County Superior Court.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants were violating the constitutional rights of indigent persons charged with crimes in the municipal courts of the cities by systematically failing to provide assistance of counsel to the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to extend the duration of the contract by two years to 2 December 31, 2012 and to pay the plaintiffs for reasonable attorneys' fees from the other party.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Memorandum of Agreement in 2009 to reform the King County Correctional Facility.[SENTMARKER]In 2009, the United States entered a memorandum of agreement with King County, 6 Washington to reform King County's public defense system.[SENTMARKER]In 2011, the defendants removed the case to federal court in order to challenge the constitutional adequacy of the system provided by the city and the city's municipal courts.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled in 2012 when the parties entered a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the defendants to provide the plaintiffs with free legal representation for three years.[SENTMARKER]In the event of any litigation arising out of the settlement agreement, the prevailing party will be reimbursed for reasonable attorney's fees.

gold_sents: On November 13, 2018, CNN and CNN’s chief White House correspondent Jim Acosta sued President Trump and several senior members of his administration for violating his First and Fifth Amendment rights by revoking his White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]under The plaintiffs sued under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Declaratory Judgments Act, arguing that defendants violated the Constitution and APA when they revoked Acosta’s White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]On November 13, 2018, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction, requesting that the court require the defendants to restore Acosta’s White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]On November 16, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motion.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the case on November 19, 2018 after the Trump administration returned Acosta's White House press credentials to him.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 15, 2018, CNN and its chief White House correspondent, Jim Acosta, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against President Donald J. Trump, the White House, and the United States Secret Service.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the First Amendment and the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment by revoking Acosta's White House press credentials in violation of his First Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]On November 9, 2018, President Trump held a press conference to discuss the 2018 midterm elections.[SENTMARKER]During the press conference, President Trump accused Acosta of placing his hands on a White House staffer who attempted to take the microphone from him.[SENTMARKER]The White House had not told CNN or Acosta that his credentials were revoked in advance of the revocation.[SENTMARKER]The next day, CNN filed a motion for a preliminary injunction, which was granted by Judge Timothy J. Kelly on November 19, 2018.[SENTMARKER]On November 19, 2018, Judge Kelly granted a temporary restraining order and permanent injunction against the defendants.[SENTMARKER]Judge Kelly also granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: When mass protests against police violence were exempted from New York’s COVID-19 gathering restrictions, but congregational worship continued to be prohibited, two Catholic priests and three Orthodox Jews brought this lawsuit, alleging that New York officials were discriminating against people of faith.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction on June 26, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 10, 2020, a group of religious organizations filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York against New York Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, Attorney General Letitia James, and New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio.[SENTMARKER]Andrew M. Cuomo, Attorney General Letitia James, and New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their First and Fourteenth Amendment rights to freedom of exercise, speech, assembly, and expressive association by imposing a 10-person outdoor gathering limit and a 25-person indoor gathering limit on religious services.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a temporary restraining order (TRO) Dkt No. 7.[SENTMARKER]On June 26, 2020, the court held that the TRO did not violate the First Amendment right of freedom of speech and assembly.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit recently denied the plaintiffs' application for a TRO pending appeal.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: The NAACP and Detroit students and parents sued the Detroit school board and other state defendants in federal court, alleging unconstitutional segregation in Detroit's schools.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that Detroit's schools were illegally segregated, in part because of decisions made by the school board to create and maintain and segregated system.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that a Detroit-only remedy would be insufficient, and ordered a busing plan that would have affected students in city schools and 53 largely white suburban school districts, but the Supreme Court rejected this plan and a Detroit-only remedy was implemented.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 18, 1970, the Detroit Federation of Teachers (DFT) filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against the Detroit Board of Education, the Detroit Superintendent of Public Instruction, and various local and state officials alleging intentional racial segregation of the Detroit public schools.[SENTMARKER]The DFT alleged that the defendants had pursued a policy and practice of racial discrimination in the Detroit schools.[SENTMARKER]After a trial on the liability issue, the district court found that the Detroit School District was segregated on the basis of race.[SENTMARKER]The district court subsequently ordered the parties to submit plans to desegregate the Detroit Public Schools.[SENTMARKER]The Detroit Board submitted a plan that provided for transportation of approximately 51,000 students.[SENTMARKER]The District Court denied the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction and remanded the case for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]On June 12, 1973, the Court of Appeals, sitting en banc, affirmed in part, and remanded for trial.[SENTMARKER]On May 2, 1986, the Supreme Court granted certiorari and reversed the District Court's denial of fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
